HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Professional Judgment vs. Visual Imperatives in TV News

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Anyone who judges the newsworthiness of events by the pictures on the nightly news is likely to come away with a dim comprehension of recent goings-on in places like Lithuania, Nepal, the Natal province of South Africa, the Arab villages of the West Bank and other hot spots. It is a constant challenge to television journalists.
Why the lack of striking images of striking events? Well, Lithuania's Soviet masters have simply booted journalists out, and even when they were still there the nighttime takeovers by Soviet troops of important buildings and the roughing up of army deserters proceeded without benefit of cameras. The networks had to make do with routine shots of Soviet tanks rolling peaceably along the streets of Vilnius and after-the-fact interviews.
There is nothing unusual about governments keeping reporters and, more particularly, photographers at a distance from certain activities. It's a propensity that the leaders of democracies share with dictators when they can get away with it. Press and television were not permitted within reporting range of United States forces during the invasion of Panama. 
Some places, like the Himalayas, may just be too difficult to get to in time to photograph protesters being mowed down. News division resources being limited, slaughters of one sort or another often go unrecorded. Some killing grounds are remote; others are dangerous. There are regimes extant that do not make nice distinctions between television crews and uncredentialed victims. Baghdad does not encourage investigative reporting.
As for the recent spate of internecine killings in Natal and on the West Bank, they are harder to catch as they are happening, much harder, for example, than scenes of South African soldiers beating protesters with whips. (When Pretoria barred photographers, the networks accompanied reports of new disturbances with the old pictures, in most cases properly identified.) The difficulty for the television journalist is that there is no relationship between the significance of a story and the available film clips.
To be sure, all these events have been reported on network news, often intelligently, but in a less vivid manner than audiences have come to expect from the tube at its liveliest. The best-intentioned television journalists must constantly find their professional judgment colliding with the visual imperatives. Sometimes they and the news win. On Friday all the programs led with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's tough new threats against Lithuania. But the difficulty remains. The journalists are like missionaries competing with witch doctors from their own denomination to catch the attentions of impressionable locals.
The customary picture-directed coverage may have left many Americans with the conviction that the issue in Africa, for example, is exclusively one between white rulers and black subjects, or that the issue in the Middle East is exclusively between Israeli occupiers and uprooted Palestinians. Not outlandish notions, but at best incomplete.
It has been suggested that such black-white formulations are congenial to many journalists, but even those not so predisposed are to some extent at the mercy of the available photography. For the millions who watched the release of the estimable Nelson Mandela live on the networks, the glow of those dramatic moments is probably still obscuring his political plans and problems. Smitten correspondents will have to play catch-up as they are already doing in the case of the decreasingly glamorous President Gorbachev.
The pictures of the ravages that battling Christian militias have been inflicting on East Beirut - knocked-down buildings and burned-out cars - are identical to those resulting from Christian assaults on Muslim neighborhoods and Muslim assaults on Christian neighborhoods and Muslim assaults on Muslim neighborhoods. How unsatisfying compared with the clear-cut, often-repeated pictures of Israeli soldiers chasing Palestinian kids. (There they were again last week on ''World News Tonight,'' only you could not tell whether the pictures had been taken the other day or last year.) The rush of events in Eastern Europe presents a similar difficulty. From those exhilarating scenes a few months ago of people taking to the streets in defiance of their rulers, viewers can be pardoned for concluding that Eastern Europe is simply a field of confrontation between democracy and dictatorship. But that, alas, is not the end of the story, and the aftermath, the activities in the corridors of power, cannot match the activities on the streets for visual excitement. The ramifications of German unity, for a knotty example, is a far tougher story to report on television than the fall of the Berlin wall.
How many Americans can keep track of how Poland differs from Czechoslovakia or how both differ from Romania? Those, perhaps, who watched Ted Koppel's special early this month on the overthrow of Nicolae Ceausescu. Perhaps Peter Jennings's special on Cambodia scheduled for next week will do as much for that unhappy country. But specials are sporadic, and a few minutes on the nightly news are inadequate. The lead stories on ABC as the Hungarian election results came in were about the death of young Ryan White from AIDS and a follow-up on the sinking of a North Sea ferry, audience grabbers both. The pictures accompanying them were so much stronger than those of lines of Hungarians waiting to vote that a producer would have had to be unusually committed, not to say committable, to put Hungary up front.
Wherever one looks, the problem is apparent. It takes an event like violence in Trafalgar Square to give punch to so unvisual a subject as the economics of Thatcherite Britain. All the networks have reported on Corazon Aquino's troubles since winning the election in the Philippines, but how many viewers, impressed by the stunning pictures of the downfall of Ferdinand Marcos, have a clear sense of what has been happening since to the heroine of the week? And how many, though stirred by accounts so movingly photographed of starving children in Africa, grasp the extent of the little-photographed repression and tribal warfare throughout the continent? By the standard of pictorial excitement, nothing much is happening these days in such politically stressful places as China, Panama and Myanmar (formerly Burma). It will be interesting to see how Nicaragua is covered during its crucial post-election threshings.
How are television journalists to deal with this chronic predicament? They can't be everywhere at once; they can't compel governments to time their crackdowns conveniently and offer them as photo opportunities. And they certainly can't count on the fascination of their viewers with distant places. Producers know that Americans' patience for the details of bloodless foreign commotions is limited. Even at their most dramatic, the displays of people power in Eastern Europe did not win big ratings.
The main ingredients of the nightly news - headlines and pictures - are just not very useful for getting beyond the obvious; something there is that doesn't love a picture. For that you need more time and a willingness to settle for less drama. The television journalists, try though they may, are under pressure; competition seems to be pushing the three main news programs in the direction of features along the lines of ''The Person of the Week'' on ''World News Tonight,'' which are never short of good pictures. It may be the right direction for audience appeal but will do nothing to bring viewers into the picture on less photo-friendly subjects.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The cost of health insurance for the elderly is rising sharply, straining the budgets of millions of people who live on Social Security checks and fueling demands for tighter regulation of this insurance. The monthly cost of many types of ''medigap'' insurance, which helps the elderly and disabled to pay medical bills not covered by Medicare, rose at least 20 percent this year. Some medigap premiums increased more than 50 percent. [Page A1.] 
 
The Administration may extend antitrust laws to strike at American subsidiaries of foreign companies that are found to engage in price-fixing, the carving up of markets and other anti-competitive practices in their home markets. Under the plan, the Government could file antitrust lawsuits against the foreign-owned companies for damage their collusion might cause to American concerns operating abroad. [D1.]
 
The bond market has been ignoring the decline in oil prices. Analysts say the market's caution is justified, with prices unlikely to remain low over the long term. Consequently, any drop in inflation resulting from the weakness in oil is likely to be short-lived and is unlikely to have much effect on interest rates. [D1.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
The trade agreement between Canada and the United States, intended to eliminate virtually all tariffs and duties by 1999, is already having some unexpected grass-roots side effects, promoting a wide array of bilateral business and civic partnerships. Provincial and state governments are pursuing several new joint economic-development programs. [D1.]
 
Communism has experienced a success in rural Czechoslovakia. Over the last 20 years, the yield of Czechoslovak farms has doubled to reach Western levels. [D4.]
 
The war against apartheid is proving to be good business for manufacturers of the politically relevant T-shirt. [D4.]
 
COMPANIES
 
There were a number of factors behind H. J. Heinz's decision not to buy tuna trapped in nets that could kill dolphins. The company was extensively lobbied by environmental groups. In addition, there was an internal corporate debate that was ''almost theological in tone,'' the company's chairman said. [D1.]
 
THE MEDIA BUSINESS
 
The decision to cancel the publication of a book that addresses subjects of acute sensitivity to Time Warner has set off a bitter dispute about who killed the book and why. [D1.]
 
A French advertising conglomerate has made a striking move to establish itself as an international marketer. The BDDP Group of Paris is buying a 40 percent stake in Wells, Rich, Greene for an undisclosed sum. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D1.]
 
There is a newspaper explosion in Poland. More than 500 daily, weekly and monthly newspapers have been started since the Solidarity movement came to power last year. The papers are trying to defy the conventional wisdom that most new publications are unlikely to survive. [D8.]
 
The Deutsch ad agency has taken on the toughest client it has ever had - itself. Deutsch is beginning an unusual campaign to sell its brain power to prospective clients. Ad Scene. [D8.]
 
ABC has made a serious move toward prime-time leadership next fall with the unexpected success of ''Twin Peaks.'' [D8.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
Senator Joseph R. Biden is involved in a bitter confrontation with the nation's leading Federal judges over his plan to make the judiciary more accountable for keeping the court system efficient. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [D2.]
 
Why does UAL stock continue to trade around $160 a share, even though the company and its unions value their latest buyout agreement at $201 a share? Traders say ''too many people got burned'' when the previous deal for the airline company collapsed. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Antitrust Extension Is Weighed

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
The Administration is considering a significant extension of antitrust laws to strike at American subsidiaries of foreign companies that are found to engage in price-fixing, the carving up of markets and other anti-competitive practices in their home markets.
Under the plan, disclosed last week, the Government could file antitrust lawsuits against these foreign-owned companies for damage their collusion might cause to American concerns operating abroad. The action could ruffle relations with trading partners of the United States who might see it as an attack on their authority and an infringement on their laws.
The application of American antitrust law could be costly for the subsidiaries, since it subjects those that are found guilty to the payment of triple damages. 
 
Export Impairment Cited
''The Justice Department will not tolerate violations of the U.S. antitrust laws, where we have jurisdiction, which impair export opportunities for U.S. businesses,'' said James F. Rill, an Assistant Attorney General and head of the antitrust division.
He said at a news conference, and in a subsequent interview last week, that the division's foreign commerce section was actively reviewing the change and expected to complete its study by fall.
The division might then consider revising its international anti-monopoly guidelines. In the last revision, in 1988, the Reagan Administration stopped short of suggesting the extension now being considered.
Yet to be determined is whether new legislation would be needed, or whether the change could be effected by executive order.
 
Right to Challenge Practices
Throughout the postwar era, the United States has asserted that it has the right to challenge anti-competitive practices of foreign companies if those practices hurt American consumers. An example would be price-fixing that forces Americans to pay more for goods and services. Under the new plan, the United States could, for the first time, challenge foreign companies because of damage their collusion might cause American companies in export markets.
Thus, if Japanese auto makers were found to be part of anti-competitive arrangements that restrict markets for American cars or auto parts in Japan, the United States could strike at the American subsidiaries of those companies.
Although Mr. Rill, the antitrust chief, said the initiative was not aimed at any particular country, the review coincided with stepped-up American pressure on Japan to toughen its antitrust enforcement.
Stronger antitrust activity has been promised as one of the broad ''structural'' measures that Japan agreed to on April 5.
American antitrust experts generally welcomed the Justice Department review, but foreign governments, sensitive to any infringement of their sovereignty, expressed concern.
 
Japanese 'Not Surprised'
''We have to look at it; I can't comment right now,'' said Makoto Kurita, a spokesman on antitrust matters at the Japanese Embassy in Washington, He added that he was ''not surprised that the Justice Department is taking a stronger position on the issue.''
A British official, who asked not to be identified, warned that there could be trouble if the United States acted against a foreign company that complied with the laws of its home country.
Rather than strike out on its own, the United States should deal with such cases on a ''cooperative international basis,'' he said, establishing international guidelines through the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development or other such international consultative bodies.
 
No International Consensus
Although business increasingly moves across international borders, there is no international consensus, as yet, on ways to deal with anti-competitive practices in various countries.
''If a foreign cartel is deliberately cutting down American exports, you have not only an antitrust problem, but a foreign relations problem,'' said Robert H. Bork, the former United States Court of Appeals judge who is now at the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington-based research organization.
A constitutional as well as antitrust expert whose nomination to the United States Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate in 1987, Judge Bork said that while the extension of antitrust laws to cover a foreign cartel is a ''very complex'' issue, ''I think it's well worth studying.''
 
Significant Evolution Seen
Andrew F. Popper, deputy dean at the American University Law School, said the change would mark a significant step in the evolution of American antitrust policy. There has always been conflict, he noted, between ''our Horatio Alger view of competition engaging independently to provide the best service for consumers and the suspicion that nationalized foreign competitors will do violence to our fragile version of the market.''
''It's a natural development,'' commented Robert Pitofsky, former dean at the Georgetown University Law Center who is now at the Brookings Institution, a Washington policy research group. ''The world is growing smaller, with the result that American companies and American consumers can be injured by what foreign companies do abroad.''
The proposed broadening of antitrust enforcement would be the second Government move in recent months aimed at American subsidiaries of foreign companies. In February, Federal tax officials were reported to be investigating what they suspected to be underpayment of taxes by subsidiaries of companies from Japan and other countries.
 
Stretching of Doctrine
The antitrust proposal would stretch the ''effects doctrine'' established by a Federal appellate judge, Learned Hand, in a seminal 1945 decision. That decision, which the Supreme Court let stand, held that a foreign company engaging in behavior with anticompetitive consequences inside the United States was liable to punitive action.
Because of the growing importance of exports to the nation's welfare, the doctrine would be extended to embrace American marketing activities abroad. ''So long as the conspiring company does business in the United States, the fact that the conspiracy actually took place overseas wouldn't prevent us from exercising jurisdiction,'' Mr. Rill said.
The Justice Department has already moved in this direction. Last year, at the prodding of the department, the Japanese Fair Trade Commission, which is similar to the Federal Trade Commission, investigated allegations of bid-rigging by 140 companies at the Yokusuka Naval Base near Tokyo.
The practice was found to have hurt American construction companies, and the Japanese companies were assessed fines of $37 million.
''We know that Yokosuka is just the tip of the iceberg,'' said Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, who is considered an expert on Japanese construction industry practices.
 
Request by Pickens
Last week, T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman and investor, asked the Japanese trade agency to look at exclusive business arrangements between Japanese car makers and parts suppliers to see whether these violated antitrust laws. Mr. Pickens is the largest stockholder in the Koito Manufacturing Company, a maker of auto headlamps that has close ties to the Toyota Motor Corporation, Koito's largest customer and second-largest stockholder.
The complaint said that close relationships between auto makers and parts companies restricted competition and hindered the entry of outside companies into the market.
Timothy P. Andree, public relations manager for Toyota Motor Corporate Services of North America, said the company had no comment. ''This is a matter between Mr. Pickens and Koito, and so we don't feel any need to comment or reply to anything that he alleges,'' he added.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Canada Trade Border Blurs

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINNIPEG, Manitoba

 BODY:
The 16-month-old free-trade agreement between Canada and the United States, intended to eliminate virtually all tariffs and duties in that enormous trading relationship by 1999, is already having some unexpected grass-roots side effects, promoting a wide array of bilateral business and civic partnerships.
Provincial and state governments are pursuing several new joint economic development programs, from designing a snowmobile trail that wanders back and forth across the border to encouraging governments and businesses to disregard distant domestic suppliers if they can do business more cheaply nearby, even if it is in the other country. Minnesota and Manitoba are working to make government scholarships and academic credits mutually acceptable in their public university systems.
For the second year, Manitoba's tourism agency has negotiated a joint promotion with McDonald's restaurants in Minnesota. This year's grand prize: four families will journey by special railcar nearly 1,100 miles north to Hudson Bay to see the annual migration of beluga whales and their calves. 
 
Cross-Border Bank Effort
Canadian and American banks are working to program automatic teller machines so customers can gain access to their bank accounts on either side of the border. In February, New Flyer Industries, a Winnipeg bus manufacturer, opened an assembly plant in Grand Forks, N.D.
''These new developments are fascinating,'' said Jules Katz, a deputy United States trade representative. ''I doubt that anyone anticipated anything quite like it.''
In some sectors, the growing north-south links are forging closer ties between states and provinces than exist between Canadian provinces, which are still negotiating a domestic free-trade pact to eliminate discriminatory purchasing and trading practices.
''People realize they've got to go global to survive,'' said Jerry Nagel, executive director of the Northwest Regional Development Commission in Thief River Falls, Minn., in the northwest part of the state, 60 miles south of the Canadian border and 240 miles northwest of Minneapolis and St. Paul. ''The free-trade agreement made us realize who our natural economic allies were. And it's not the Twin Cities far away; it's Manitoba right next door.''
The trade pact, approved by the United States Congress and Canada's Parliament, was expected to stimulate economic growth on both sides of the border. More than $160 billion (United States) in trade flows across the border each year, giving the two nations by far the world's largest bilateral economic relationship. The United States trades more with Ontario, for instance, than with Japan.
Some of the stimulus is practical, like the elimination of tariffs. And some is psychological.
''Eliminating government trade barriers creates a spirit of cooperation that stimulates all kinds of activities, expected and unforeseen, that begin rolling like a snowball and yielding benefits for both sides far outside the legal framework of the agreement,'' said Judith Bello, who was general counsel for the United States trade representative during the negotiations for the free-trade agreement.
 
Strong Ties in the Prairie
The new cooperation seems strongest in the prairie regions of the mid-continent, but similar efforts are emerging elsewhere along the frontier. To help local businesses in both countries, economic development officials in Calais, Me., and St. Stephen, New Brunswick, for instance, are working together from an office on the American side to develop a scenic driving tour that meanders back and forth across the border.
''The free-trade agreement has focused folks' interest,'' said Jim Eldridge, the Manitoba official charged with intergovernmental relations. ''It's been an incredible catalyst.'' Indeed, northern Minnesota, Montana and the Dakotas have many things in common with Manitoba and Saskatchewan: heavy reliance on troubled agricultural sectors, faltering rural economies far from major markets, an exodus of young people unable to find steady work, pristine natural resources and distant federal governments that seem to place their regions' concerns low on the priority list.
 
Longtime Economic Ties
There have long been limited economic links between the northern prairie regions of the United States and their Canadian neighbors. About 30 percent of Manitoba's $800 million a year in tourism income is spent by Americans. Forty percent of all foreign visitors to the United States are Canadian, many of them weekend shoppers. Manitoba Hydro and the Northern States Power Company in Minnesota regularly sell each other electricity during their peak demand seasons, which is summer in the United States and winter in Canada.
The drive to cooperate is so strong now that an exploratory conference on the idea of mutual efforts, held last month in Grand Forks, was expected to attract 40 officials and business officers, but more than 210 attended. ''The idea was to get to know each other,'' said Joe Nathan, a conference organizer. ''Instead, we've had this explosion of joint ideas.''
Manitoba and Minnesota tourism officials have already met and agreed to distribute each other's literature and to program each other's computers to include their neighbor's offerings. They are planning several joint attractions, including an international fishing tournament, a canoe race from Winnipeg to Fargo, N.D., and construction of a snowmobile trail that would wind back and forth across the border.
 
Promotions in Europe
In recent weeks, the same tourism officials have traveled to Europe together to promote the region as a destination for European campers, hunters and history buffs. ''By itself, our parts might be a weak attraction,'' said Paul Robson, Manitoba's assistant deputy tourism minister. ''But together we form a critical mass and a viable destination.''
Regional bankers will meet next month to explore interlocking their automatic teller machines and making currency exchanges easier for travelers. Manufacturers on both sides are developing a regional directory so companies can buy from each other instead of from more distant national suppliers.
''We expect many more links like that going both ways,'' said Mr. Nagel, the executive director of the development commission in Minnesota, who is pressing his state bar association to make more training in international law available for local lawyers.
Manitoba, which is widening the main road between Winnipeg and the border, is also exchanging two provincial trade officials with the state of Kansas, about 600 miles south of the border. ''We'll learn how each other works,'' said Mr. Eldridge, Manitoba's government-affairs offical. ''Sure, sometimes we'll be competing. But other times we can throw business to each other.''
 
Coordinating Health Systems
Government and private health executives are drawing plans to coordinate the Minneapolis area's impressive health-care services with hospitals in Manitoba, where the Canadian Government is building a national disease center. The plan is to coordinate health-care equipment manufacturing, too. ''That way,'' Mr. Eldridge added, ''we can be more efficient, avoid costly duplication and together sell to the rest of the world.''
The political leaders of Saskatchewan, Manitoba, North Dakota and Minnesota have signed a compact to consider the environmental effect on their neighbors when examining broad economic development proposals.
Minnesota and Manitoba are making their college credits immediately transferable across the border and are working on the same for scholarships. Minnesota has sent experts to brief Manitoban educators on its satellite-television education program for rural areas. Winnipeg sends its Royal Ballet for regular appearances in the Twin Cities.
Mr. Eldridge is working on having the Timberwolves, the National Basketball Association team whose home is the Twin Cities, play some games in Winnipeg, where, thanks to cable television, the team is developing a following.
Last year, the Manitoba tourism office, which uses as its United States spokesman Bud Grant, the former coach of the Minnesota Vikings of the National Football League, flew in the winners of a contest sponsored by McDonald's in the Twin Cities to see some visiting panda bears. About 100,000 people entered the contest.
One measure of the dramatic changes will come in the next few days, Mr. Nagel said. His agency in Minnesota will submit a grant application to the United States Economic Development Administration that will rely in part on Canadian statistics. Northern Minnesota wants to attract new factory investment and jobs by improving the area around Warroad, Minn., a border community that relies heavily on binational business.
The figures will show the need for new jobs in Minnesota by including, among other things, unemployment data for the nearby Canadian side. ''Listen,'' Mr. Nagel said, ''we may be two countries. But we are one economy.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
A New Role for the Anti-Apartheid T-Shirt

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DURBAN, South Africa

 BODY:
The war against apartheid is proving to be good business for manufacturers of the politically relevant T-shirt.
The removal of the ban on the African National Congress and the release of Nelson Mandela have improved not only the prospects for black majority rule but also the appearance of its proponents.
Such garments were worn before as a symbol of defiance, but cautiously, because the police would confiscate them. Now, T-shirts legally endorse organizations that the white minority Government once decreed must be unseen and unheard. Even a Government official acknowledged that he bought his son a popular T-shirt welcoming home Nelson Mandela. 
But not every T-shirt will do. ''It's got to be a part of some struggle,'' said Don Joseph, a graphic artist. ''It's got to have a relevant message on it.'' Mr. Joseph has been designing T-shirts for Zenzeleni, a Durban cooperative that has become the leading purveyor of protest wear to apartheid's opponents.
 
Help From Labor Unions
Zenzeleni - the name means ''we do it ourselves'' in Zulu - was set up a year ago with labor union assistance for black workers left unemployed by the automation of South Africa's textile industry. The cooperative now has 320 employees, who, as a condition of employment, belong to the South African Clothing and Textile Workers Union.
Zenzeleni's few white employees include the cooperative's managing director, Glen Cormack, who took a two-thirds cut in salary and benefits from his former position as personnel director for Tiger Oats, a leading food corporation.
With a goal of employment over profit, Zenzeleni makes its T-shirts the old-fashioned way. The cotton cloth is cut and sewn by hand, and the messages are stenciled using a basic silk-screen technique.
''We elected to go the archaic method, which is certainly the least efficient, but maintains jobs,'' said Stephanie Miller, Zenzeleni's marketing director.
 
Logotypes of Liberation
Half of the ideas for new T-shirts come from the employees. When they proposed something for the newly unbanned South African Communist Party, Mr. Joseph designed a red T-shirt with a yellow star and a hammer and sickle imposed over a black fist. Other T-shirts hailing the African National Congress and Mr. Mandela feature the liberation movement's black, green and yellow colors.
Last year, Zenzeleni's garments upset both the South African Police and the United States Customs Service. While the security police here seized one batch of T-shirts as subversive, American customs officials declared another shipment illegal under the sanctions Congress legislated against South Africa.
''Ridiculous, absolutely ridiculous,'' Mrs. Miller said, referring to the American action. ''You would imagine that people would have a little more vision.''
The cotton material for each T-shirt costs 5 to 8 rand - about $2 to $3.20 - a meter, and the labor costs an additional 3.20 rand. The T-shirts sell for 15 rand - about $6 - which includes a 1 rand commission for the vendor, leaving Zenzeleni with a markup that Mr. Cormack said was half of what its competitors made.
 
Hoping to Break-Even Soon
Zenzeleni has yet to make money. South African banks refused to give loans, Mr. Cormack said, because of Zenzeleni's ties to the militantly anti-apartheid labor union movement. Indeed, two senior union stewards serve as directors of the corporation.
But Mr. Cormack hopes the cooperative will start breaking-even later this year. And any profits will be invested in the creation of more jobs for unemployed blacks.
Mr. Cormack said trendy T-shirts would not sustain Zenzeleni forever. So he has developed a line of work clothes, which will eventually account for most of its production.
Zenzeleni now has the capacity to manufacture 400,000 T-shirts a year for a domestic market that Mr. Cormack estimated can absorb at least two million.
The company could beat overseas sanctions and increase sales if it stenciled T-shirts imported from China, like some competitors, and distributed them through Swaziland or another country.

GRAPHIC: photo: With the removal of the ban on the African National Congress, political T-shirts have become popular. A leading seller is Zenzeleni, a Durban cooperative set up to create jobs for those put out of work by automation. Glen Cormack is managing director and Stephanie Miller is head of marketing. (The New York Times/Christopher S. Wren)

HEADLINE: Housing the Poor - Without Subsidies

BYLINE: By Howard Husock; Howard Husock is director of case studies at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
While social, political and judicial pressures to construct new low-income housing are growing, there is no obvious way to do so. Tight budgets at all levels of government have made the return of large-scale subsidized housing construction, whatever its merits, extremely unlikely.
Why not consider instead a ''back to the future'' solution: housing and neighborhoods that sheltered the poor and aspiring at the turn of the century but have withered in a world of zoning constraints and government subsidies?
It was not until Franklin Roosevelt's second term that public housing emerged as the leading response to the horrors and crowding of tenement life. Before that, with government acquiescence but not financial support, America produced a variety of housing that served both as shelter and as a means of upward mobility. Such housing became synonymous with the streetscape of our cities: row houses in Philadelphia, brownstones in Brooklyn, three-family houses (''three-deckers'') in Boston. 
This was construction on a grand scale, built at a level of density that almost no suburban area would permit today. But it did its job. The New England three-family house - 15,000 of which were built in Boston between 1890 and 1930 - is a particularly good case in point.
In addition to the obvious economic advantages of dividing the cost of construction three ways, small-scale, multifamily housing provided for social controls. Small landlords screened tenants carefully. Children were disciplined for disturbing rent payers. And, most important, low-income owners were brought into the social mainstream.
So it was that neighborhood and community were built, as well as housing provided, much of which has had a long, useful life. Even in relatively affluent streetcar suburbs (such as parts of Westchester County and northern New Jersey), districts of two-family houses, as well as small apartment buildings, coexisted happily with larger single-family homes.
The emergence of zoning laws in the 1920's began to change matters. By the time housing construction began in earnest again after World War II, multifamily housing was zoned out of newly developing suburbs. Long Island's Nassau County became a sea of single-family homes. One-acre and half-acre zoning became common in growth areas, insuring income stratification.
At the same time, government began the paternalistic practice of housing the poor in projects. Isolating the poor proved to have disastrous social results, both for residents and the surrounding communities. Just as important, the bad name acquired by projects persuaded suburban communities, such as Yonkers, to fight their hardest to keep them out.
Amidst these trends, the successful middle way represented by small-scale, owner-occupied multifamily housing, was forgotten. The time is ripe for its revival - and in some places it has already begun.
In Albany, for instance, new two-family row houses have been built with minimal public subsidies (to be later repaid). The houses should be affordable for people with an annual income of only $15,560. (Paying the mortgage was predicated on a tenant paying rent of $262 monthly.) In Boston, the city has begun an ambitious program to allow new homes to be built on some 747 vacant lots. It has eased zoning restrictions to allow the first new construction of three-family houses since the 1920's.
Such efforts should be a model for other cities with large vacant parcels and for suburban municipalities as well. Higher-density, owner-occupied housing with its own rental units represents a way for suburbs both to live up to their civic obligations to provide for those in need and to provide homes for local teachers, police and firefighters who cannot afford to buy single-family homes in many municipalities.
Such housing is likely to be far more politically palatable than projects for the poor. It has the further advantage of building its affordability on the Federal tax code - the mortgage interest deduction and deductions for rental unit maintenance - rather than on up-front subsidies.
Call it housing deregulation. Or upzoning. There is ample opportunity to apply it. The courts will need to do their part by accepting rezoning for higher-density construction, as opposed to construction of housing projects, as a good-faith effort to provide low-income housing. The result can be new housing and new neighborhoods for those in need.

HEADLINE: Lusaka Journal;
All About What's Going On in Zambia, Slyly Told

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia, April 15

 BODY:
For more than two decades, Kapelwa Musonda has been charming, amusing and occasionally provoking Zambians about the absurdities and frustrations of surviving amid the beleaguered economy and party politics of their African nation.
Every Tuesday, lines form around the newsboys on Cairo Road here for The Times of Zambia, one of the country's two daily newspapers, to catch how Musonda's characters, Aunt Agatha and Comrade Bonzo, view the world.
At a time when President Kenneth D. Kaunda has insisted that the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe have no application in his own backyard, Comrade Bonzo had some tough things to say recently.
Eastern Europe will have no effect, the character said rather tartly, because ''adequate and convincing lies have been invented to explain and justify our miseries and deprivations.'' 
 
A Risky Business
In a lighter mood, Comrade Bonzo, hired as protocol officer for Namibia's independence celebrations, bemoaned that he did not have the time to order up the ''luxury mansionettes'' deserving of the visiting heads of state.
The mere existence of Kapelwa Musonda and his characters is unusual in Africa, where challenging the wisdom of the ruling party, and particularly the President, is a risky business. A Ugandan journalist was locked up by the Ugandan authorities this year for daring to ask President Kaunda, during a visit to Uganda, whether after 26 years he had not been in power too long.
Columnists appear in some newspapers, but few have the dedicated following of Kapelwa Musonda or his skills at getting at the heart of the matter but still skirting trouble.
Indeed, one of the clues to the success of the column is that its creator is generally unknown, appearing in the columns only in the first person as an urban Zambian with a quizzical mind. An educated Zambian and follower of the column, asked the other day who she thought the pen name Kapelwa Musonda belonged to, said she thought he was a truck driver.
In fact, he is Wizas Phiri, an agronomist, who during the day works as the operations manager of Shell Chemical in Lusaka and, with an inspirational poster of Mark Twain in front of him and a library of books behind, writes at his electric typewriter at night. Three years ago, he was one of four Africans selected to attend the international writing course at the University of Iowa.
 
'Not Advancing Any Cause'
''I'm not advancing any cause and I'm not associated with any of the groupings - tribal groupings, trade unions, Zambian business,'' Mr. Phiri said, explaining his 23 years of durability as a columnist. ''If I was championing any cause I don't think I would have lasted.''
And he has a simple rule: ''You don't make a direct attack on any single individual.'' That, of course, especially applies to President Kaunda, his often talked-about wife and sons, and prominent politicians.
Mr. Phiri was hired by The Times of Zambia in 1967, some years before a Government takeover, as a way for the paper to maintain a thread of independence from the inward-looking discussion dominating post-colonial politics. Mr. Phiri said he determined not to be ''sycophantic'' but not to take a ''direct approach.''
His Aunt Agatha is an irrepressible, loyal member of the ruling party and the women's league's most ''eminent political theorist and prosperous marketeer.'' But lately, she has been down in the dumps, frustrated in her profession on the black market because of a new Government policy, mandated by the International Monetary Fund, that price controls be lifted.
''The cardinal duty of every black marketeer is to empty the shelves of any shop of all available essential commodities and have these displayed for resale at markets and roadside stands,'' Aunt Agatha said recently. But now, she lamented, ''our problem is we can't generate enough cash to enable us to empty the shelves.''
 
At the 'Rock of Authority'
Needless to say, Aunt Agatha was organizing a conference at Lusaka's major convention hall, the site of garrulous political gatherings and facetiously referred to in the column as the ''rock of authority,'' to get around the problem of lack of cash.
About to turn 50 - ''already past the average life expectancy of a Zambian,'' he said wryly - Mr. Phiri is soft-spoken and sociable, a sort of antithesis to the strident and striving party hack, Aunt Agatha. In a city where a chosen place for socializing implies a certain status, he avoids the obvious watering holes - the bar at the Inter-Continental, the gossip at the Flying Club - and sticks to the modest club for the employees of his company.
One of his biggest personal concerns is finding ways to get books from overseas, which because of the chronic economic crisis are nonexistent in Zambia.
''The worst thing we have done to ourselves is the state of education,'' he said. ''Walk around Lusaka and ask for a bookshop. You can't find one. And this is a capital city. In the whole nation, you can't find anything to read. You can't have a nation where the only thing you do is drink, and if you're thirsty for reading, you can't satisfy your thirst.''
 
Some Columns Are Censored
Two collections of his columns were published in the 1970's. There is now no functioning publishing house in Zambia and an effort he made to publish a new collection himself last year was stalled by interest rates of 35 percent.
Now and then his column does not appear, censored by the managing editor, who by tradition is appointed by the President. The last one to get the ax was due to appear the day before the opening of the annual convention of the ruling party last month.
The column expressed enthusiasm for a multiparty system in Zambia, a possibility that had actually been floated from the State House. But during the convention, President Kaunda denounced the motion of a multiparty state as ''Stone Age barbarism.'' Clearly, Mr. Phiri said, his editor knew more than he did.

HEADLINE: MALAYSIA ACCUSED ON BOAT PEOPLE

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 16

 BODY:
Despite continued protests from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Malaysia is turning away Vietnamese boat people with increasing frequency, diplomats and international relief workers say.
Since the end of May 1989, in violation of its agreement to provide first asylum to the Vietnamese, the Malaysians have sent back out to sea at least 5,401 people arriving in at least 109 boats.
In March alone, according to the High Commissioner, at least 1,050 Vietnamese in 22 boats were denied asylum in Malaysia and forced to return to sea.
On Feb. 19, the Malaysians towed out to sea in a new boat 159 Vietnamese who had been rescued on Feb. 8 by a commercial ship in Malaysian waters. 
 
Plight 'Speaks for Itself'
The captain of the vessel, upon receiving a letter from the Vietnamese, wrote an angry letter of his own to the refugee commissioner's office in Geneva, saying the Vietnamese letter ''speaks for itself and I would not know any other way to get attention to the fact that the Malaysian Government is knowingly putting refugees back on the high seas from which they have just been rescued.''
The Malaysians have even tried to push off boats landing on Bidong Island, where there is a refugee camp for Vietnamese boat people, in sight of officials of the United Nations refugee office. But after intervention by those officials, the Malaysians have been persuaded to accept the boats. The waters around Bidong Island are ''defended'' against Vietnamese boats by naval and police patrol boats and helicopters, diplomats and refugee officials say.
''In the beginning, the Malaysians were being very careful and selective, and seemed to be simply trying to make a point,'' a senior refugee worker said. ''But now they are pushing off more and more people in a more haphazard way. The noose seems to be tightening.''
As many as 50 to 60 percent of those Vietnamese boat people arriving in Malaysia are now being sent back out to sea, diplomats say.
The Malaysian Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, again denied last week that Vietnamese boat people are being towed away or otherwise denied asylum. He has said Malaysia is only ''preventing foreign vessels from entering our waters'' and protecting the rights of Malaysian fishermen.
 
Malaysian Is Indignant
But according to Eric E. Morris, representative of the High Commissioner in Malaysia and Brunei, virtually all the Vietnamese boats first came ashore in Malaysia. Often, the Vietnamese are regrouped and sent back out to sea by the Malaysians in different, refurbished boats, diplomats said.
Mr. Mahathir also said Malaysia has done a great deal for refugees since 1975, and diplomats say Malaysia treats those who are allowed to stay on Bidong Island with decency. Mr. Mahathir renewed his complaint that resettlement countries like the United States, Canada and Australia were ''picking and choosing'' the Vietnamese they want, leaving Malaysia with what he has variously called ''the residue'' and ''the scum.''
''Why should Malaysia be the repository of the unwanted of this world?'' he has asked.
But according to the High Commissioner's office and to Western diplomats, the Malaysian expulsions violate an agreement reached in June 1989 between first-asylum countries like Malaysia and resettlement countries. The agreement was reached at a conference in Geneva instigated by Malaysia.
The conference decided that all Vietnamese boat people arriving after a cutoff date - June 16, 1988, in Hong Kong and March 14, 1989, for other Southeast Asian nations - would no longer receive automatic status as refugees, but would be screened to decide who among them were real refugees with a ''well-founded fear of persecution'' and who were economic migrants.
 
Where U.S. Differs
The resettlement countries agreed to take all those who arrived before the cutoff dates and those judged to be refugees. But a disagreement persists over what to do with the economic migrants. Southeast Asian nations, the British, and officials in some other countries think these migrants should be returned to Vietnam, forcibly if necessary, as illegal immigrants. The United States and Vietnam object to forcible repatriation.
In the meantime, the numbers of those screened out are growing, which is a prime reason, diplomats say, that the Malaysians continue to push the new arrivals away - despite an agreement in June that first-asylum countries would in the meantime provide shelter for all who arrive.
The United Nations refugee officials interview Vietnamese who land further south on Galang Island, near Singapore, which belongs to Indonesia. There is no way of knowing how many Vietnamese are lost at sea after being denied asylum in Malaysia, the High Commissioner's office says, but a Western diplomat said that 3 to 10 percent of boat people do not find safe havens and perish in shipwrecks, from starvation or at the hands of pirates.
The Indonesians have sheltered all those pushed off from Malaysia, thus far without complaint, diplomats say. The Thais have also kept the June agreement, the diplomats say, but have been receiving about 1,000 boat people a month for the last three months and are unhappy about it.

HEADLINE: Blocked Funds Put U.S. Role In Seville World Fair in Doubt

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, April 16

 BODY:
As work advances on the new auditoriums, pavilions and stadiums for the Seville World's Fair, Expo '92, Spanish and American officials are concerned that construction may never begin on one of the main attractions: the United States pavilion.
Congress has approved only $2.9 million of the $15 million in seed money needed for the United States to officially guarantee its attendance.
The money has been budgeted for the fiscal year 1990 to contribute to the building of the United States pavilion, and it is hoped that a further $30 million will come from private sponsors. 
Former President Reagan, in a letter to King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain, committed the United States to participation in Expo '92, which is to draw 103 countries as well as at least 20 corporate exhibitors. President Bush endorsed Mr. Reagan's commitment.
 
Money Is Frozen
But the rest of the $15 million has been frozen by Representative Neil Smith, Democrat of Iowa, and Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who strongly oppose Federal financing of trade fairs. Mr. Smith and Mr. Hollings are the chairmen of the House and Senate Appropriations subcommittees, which allocate the money.
In 1992, Spain will be host not only to Expo '92 as part of celebrations of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage to the New World, but also to the Summer Olympics in Barcelona. The absence of the United States from the first of these events would dampen Spain's celebration of its new self-image as a mainstream European player.
Though several American corporations are planning to take part, Spanish officials are increasingly concerned that the United States Government may not occupy the 90,000-square-foot site allocated to it, the second largest after Spain's.
''We are worried because the United States is a star participant,'' said Emilio Casinello, president of the Expo '92 State Corporation. Referring to the fair's theme, ''The Age of Discovery,'' he added, ''How can the United States stay away from the age of discovery when they are the discoverers and innovators of modern times?''
 
U.S. Officials Anxious, Too
Mr. Casinello said the United States trade deficit could grow if it stayed away from Seville while all its major competitors were represented. American officials are also anxious. ''It would send the wrong signals not just to Europe on the eve of economic unification,'' Marvin Stone, commissioner general of the United States national section at Expo 92, said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Stone said that ''at this point it's a possibility'' that the United States might not attend.
But Spanish officials say they are confident that the United States will officially confirm its attendance.
''Every Western country, every member state of the O.E.C.D., every NATO member will be there,'' said Inocencio Arias, Under Secretary General of the Spanish Foreign Ministry. ''The United States cannot afford not to come.''
But he added that if the United States did not show up, ''it's not the end of the world.''

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Lack of Ads Kills 7 Days Magazine

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
Just two years after it was started with great fanfare, 7 Days magazine has ceased publishing.
In a tense meeting yesterday at the weekly's newly renovated offices in lower Manhattan, the publication's owner, Leonard N. Stern, told the staff that even though 7 Days covered New York City's social and political happenings in a ''stylish and provocative'' way, it could not generate the advertising support it needed to survive.
Some media analysts said the death of 7 Days might mark the beginning of a shakeout among magazines in the New York market aimed at young, trend-setting readers. ''These are the wine coolers of magazines,'' said John Meskil, executive vice president in charge of media at Warwick, Baker & Fiore, a New York advertising agency. ''They've had their moment and now they're becoming passe.'' 
Recently, for example, Spy magazine hired an investment banking firm to seek additional backing. Details, which once covered the trendy New York social scene, is being reintroduced as a men's fashion magazine, and Egg, a new Manhattan lifestyle magazine published by Forbes Inc., received a lukewarm reception.
Media analysts said that this category of magazines is suffering now because it is a marginal buy for advertisers. ''When the economy gets bad, advertisers only use the primary magazines,'' said John Power, a group vice president at Vitt Media International, a media buying and planning service.
Mr. Meskil said that ''young readers are hard to hold on to; they are too busy making a living and having social lives to spend much time reading.''
That is a lesson that Mr. Stern said cost him an estimated $10 million to learn. ''I'm terribly disappointed,'' he said in an interview. ''The costs to bring the magazine to the point of breaking even would have been enormous. It did not make sense on a business basis.''
Just two weeks ago Mr. Stern had begun looking for a buyer for the tabloid-size magazine. But none could be found. ''I didn't get any serious offers,'' said Mr. Stern, the sole owner of the Hartz Mountain Corporation and The Village Voice and a group of regional real estate publications.
''I believed that if we built a superior editorial product, the advertising would come in,'' Mr. Stern said.
But that was not the case. With a circulation of only 75,000, 7 Days was never able to attract large national advertisers, mainly because its readership was too small and because most of its subscriptions were given away, media analysts said. Only about one-third of the circulation for 7 Days went to paid subscribers.
At the same time, the magazine's original base of retail and real estate advertising sharply declined during the last six months.
To make a go of it, Mr. Stern said that 7 Days would have had to increase its readership to about 400,000, about the size of New York magazine. To do so, he added, the magazine would need a broader editorial approach, but a broader approach would include a segment of readers already dominated by New York magazine.
Other options were considered as a way of keeping the magazine alive, he said. At one point, there were discussions about turning 7 Days into a monthly. ''That wasn't viable,'' said David Schneiderman, the president of Stern Publications. ''We would have had to reinvent 7 Days, and that would have been too risky.''
A continually changing identity was one of the magazine's major problems, Mr. Stern said. ''We started out as an uptown Manhattan newspaper, then we evolved in a newspaper-magazine hybrid and finally changed into a magazine,'' he added.
The magazine had been praised for its sometimes wisely irreverent articles about New York's cultural and social scene. And although it came too late to make a difference, after the closing announcement the magazine's staff also learned that 7 Days had been chosen as a finalist for a National Magazine Award for general excellence in the small-magazine category.
''We were just hitting our stride,'' said Adam Moss, the magazine's editor. Readers were immediately captivated by the magazine's media, restaurant and other columns, he said.
The failure of 7 Days has not discouraged Mr. Stern, who plans to start another newspaper either in New York or some other major city. Sooner or later, he said, ''I'll find the key to success.''

HEADLINE: Careers;
Big Growth In Helping The Jobless

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
FEW businesses have grown as fast as outplacement in recent years, with much of that growth related to the rash of corporate mergers and work-force reductions around the country.
Outplacement firms receive a fee from corporations to handle job terminations as humanely as possible. Not to be confused with employment agencies, the firms help individuals who have lost jobs, usually middle- or upper-level managers. The firms provide counseling, office space, a telephone and secretarial help and aid in preparing and printing resumes. 
''January through March was the best quarter we've had,'' William J. Morin, said last week. He is chairman of Drake Beam Morin Inc., the nation's largest outplacement firm, with 47 offices in the United States and 40 internationally. The firm plans to open an office in East Germany in September and is considering opening offices in Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
''In 1974, our revenue was under $1 million,'' Mr. Morin said. ''Last year, it was $100 million around the world.''
For the industry as a whole, business is expected to grow another 15 percent this year, to more than $400 million in annual revenues from about $350 million in 1989, said Louis LeHane, president of the Association of Outplacement Consulting Firms.
So far this year, Mr. Morin said, there has been a ''steady flow'' of modest layoffs, in contrast to the large but sporadic layoffs in 1986-87. On average, the firm works with about 2,000 individual clients a year in New York and provides group counseling to about 15,000 others.
Mr. Morin, a man who thrives on statistics, said 20 percent of those dismissed decided to retire, especially those near the age at which they can collect pensions and Social Security benefits. Another 20 percent try to become entrepreneurs, with half of those actually going so far as to start their own businesses. But the bulk of those dismissed, 60 percent, seek jobs in the same field of work.
In Mr. Morin's view, finding a job usually is a numbers game, with success depending on how many resumes are mailed and interviews are held, and how much time is spent searching. He says about 60 percent of the firm's clients find jobs through ''networking'' among their acquaintances; another 20 percent find them through employment agencies and executive search firms, and the remaining 20 percent find them through advertisements, mass mailings of resumes and using the firm's computerized listing of jobs at more than 186 client companies.
Drake Beam was among the first to use such job lists, which now help ''4 or 5 percent of our clients find jobs, up from about 1 percent in 1987 shortly after the program began,'' Mr. Morin said. He added that he expects that figure to rise to 25 percent by 1995.
The best fields now for job searchers are marketing and sales, he said.
''Accounting is down or flat; human resources is flat,'' he said. ''Industrial and manufacturing jobs are coming back, and we see a revival in the Rust Belt: Cleveland, Pittsburgh and Detroit. Staff jobs are hard to find, but when found they pay higher salaries than previously.''
A crucial question is how long it will take to find a satisfactory job.
''Half of our people find jobs in 4.2 months, but the average runs around 5 months,'' he said. The time involved varies by region: 4.9 months in the Northeast and 5 in the New York metropolitan area; 4.8 in the Northwest; 5.4 in the Southwest, and 4.6 in the Southeast.
As for the Midwest, ''It is still tough out there,'' Mr. Morin said, estimating the job-hunting time at 5.1 months.
He urged managers to take charge of their careers and not count on staying a lifetime with one company. On average, people change jobs 4.7 times in a lifetime, although Mr. Morin said that several of these job changes came early in a career, while a person was trying to find a niche.
There is talk in the outplacement industry about the need for certification of counselors, and Mr. Morin thinks that should be done through the Association of Outplacement Consulting Firms. ''We favor more professionalism, and we're backing it,'' he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Alcoa's Income Fell 46.2% in First Quarter

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, reported a 46.2 percent decline in first-quarter earnings yesterday. The company cited an overall slower economy, lower prices and slightly higher costs.
Alcoa said its net income fell to $148.6 million, or $1.69 a share, from $276 million, or $3.12 a share, in the comparable period last year. Sales were up slightly for the quarter, to $2.63 billion, from $2.62 billion in the quarter a year earlier. 
Analysts said the results were generally in line with expectations. They mentioned that demand for many aluminum products had slowed in the first quarter because of slowdowns in the automotive, packaging and construction industries.
''Their costs are among the best in the industry,'' said Peter F. Marcus, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. ''We expect them to do well relative to the others in the industry, given what has occurred in the economy.''
On the New York Stock Exchange, Alcoa's shares rose 25 cents yesterday, closing at $64.875.
Paul H. O'Neill, Alcoa's chairman, said management was pleased with the results, given the softness of the economy. He added, ''The deterioration in the economy that began in the third quarter of last year seems to have stopped in the first two months of 1990.'' He said the company's order rates were higher than they had been in recent months.
 
Orders Pick Up
Mr. Marcus said that Alcoa's orders for can sheet aluminum had picked up in recent months, ''with no indication that the company was forced to cut price.''
The Pittsburgh-based company also attributed the lower earnings to lower prices for ingot and aluminum products from its operation in Brazil, Alcoa Aluminio, which accounted for 14 percent of the company's earnings last year. Alcoa, which owns a 65 percent stake in the Brazilian aluminum producer, said that earnings from that operation were at a break-even level; a year earlier it had income of $36 million.
''It is our expectation that earnings from Brazil will be negatively affected throughout the year,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''But we believe the strong measures that are being taken to curb rampant inflation in that country are in the long-term interest of Brazil and our company.''

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Verdict On Reagan

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
History is closing in fast on Ronald Reagan. Fifteen months ago he left office in a glow of public affection. Today he is increasingly identified with greed, corruption and conspiracy.
Conspiracy was one of the five felony counts on which a jury convicted his former national security adviser John Poindexter. The jury found that there had been a conspiracy in the Reagan White House to cover up the truth about arms sales to Iran and aid to the Nicaraguan contras. 
Mr. Reagan had denied that there was any such effort to deceive Congress and the public. The jury verdict meant either that his denial was false or that he didn't know what was going on: that he was a liar or a fool.
In a sense the jury verdict was a comment on the failings of the American political process. For it was the political system that should long ago have dealt with Mr. Reagan's performance in the Iran-contra affair.
Consider just one item: the shipment of American Hawk missiles from Israel to Iran in November 1985. The White House and various security agencies were involved in the deal. President Reagan knew about it. He later signed an intelligence finding that said the shipment was expected to lead to the release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon. (Mr. Poindexter, according to the prosecution, destroyed that document.) When the Iran-contra affair first began to emerge publicly, in November 1986, Mr. Reagan said: ''We have not - I repeat, did not - trade weapons or anything else for hostages, nor will we ever.'' He denied knowing about the 1985 Hawk shipment before it happened.
The political system dealt with those absurd misstatements by treating the President of the United States as ignorant. The Tower Commission used the euphemism of Mr. Reagan's ''management style.'' The Congressional investigating committees, focusing on the diversion of Iranian arms funds to the contras, assumed that the President had not been informed by Mr. Poindexter, Oliver North and others.
With all the polite evasions, it was plain enough that Mr. Reagan had not lived up to the minimum responsibilities of the Presidency. But his amiable style, his hold on the public's affection, made Congress shy away from the impeachment process or any serious political challenge.
The grin and the wave have faded now. The less pleasant realities of the Reagan years are becoming evident to more people.
Greed is one of those realities. In that regard the former President has done himself as much injury as anyone else.
Last fall Mr. Reagan went to Japan for a $2 million fee from a communications conglomerate. To many, including Republicans, it looked distastefully like payment for sympathetic policies in office.
Money rather than service has been the theme of this ex-President. In February he spent an hour at a Florida convention of hamburger franchise operators and collected $60,000.
Then there are the larger economic consequences of Reaganism. For one, the 1980's saw the boom in leveraged buyouts, financed by imposing huge debts on the acquired companies. Now some of those companies are having trouble meeting the debt obligations. And the junk bonds used for the deals are dangerous elements in portfolios. There is a risk of large-scale failure and economic distress.
The leveraged buyout craze was encouraged by Mr. Reagan's exaltation of the market as the final judge of what is good for society, and by his treatment of government as the enemy. His Administration did all it could to weaken Government regulation, by amending laws and appointing spineless regulators.
The most disastrous single result of weakened regulation was the savings and loan spree, which is going to cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars. Then there is the corruption at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, still unfolding.
The environment is another area hurt badly by Mr. Reagan's assault on Government regulation. A commission that investigated the Alaskan oil spill, for example, said that conditions for the spill were created by the collapse of the oil tanker regulatory system in the 1980's.
Of course there are a good many Americans who are still contented that Ronald Reagan was President. But Warren G. Harding was popular, too. My guess is that history will be not much kinder to Reagan than it has been to Harding. The process of deglamorization has begun.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

LENGTH: 1694 words

HEADLINE: Public Housing: For Workers or the Needy?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 16

 BODY:
The growing shortage of affordable shelter for millions of needy people is putting enormous pressure on the nation's already overburdened public housing system and giving a new edge to an old policy debate: who is it that public housing ought to serve?
While advocacy groups and Federal officials urge that the homeless, the disabled and the poorest of the poor be given priority for scarce public housing vacancies, officials of many large urban housing projects are arguing that they need a broader mix of incomes, including more low-income working families, to insure social stability in their developments.
The Chicago Housing Authority is the nation's second largest and one of the most troubled. To encourage working people to remain as residents, officials of the Chicago authority are pushing the Department of Housing and Urban Development for more flexibility in setting rents for those tenants with the highest incomes.
 
'Warehouses for the Poor'
''As it is now, our buildings have become little more than warehouses for the poor,'' said Vincent Lane, the chairman of the Chicago authority, noting that more than 80 percent of the city's 200,000 housing tenants are on welfare. ''More working people in the buildings would enhance diversity and community life, and insure stronger role models to compete with the gangs and drug dealers.'' 
The predicament facing some tenants was described by Pat Perry, a resident of a South Side public housing building, who said her family's rent rose from $65 a month to $742 when she and her husband got jobs and went off welfare. Federal housing rules require tenants to pay 30 percent of their income as rent.
''I like working, but you can see why a lot of people don't want to get jobs,'' said Mrs. Perry, who also serves as a resident manager in her building.
Mrs. Perry said she would stay in her apartment, in part because it is her longtime home and her family is comfortable there. But other working tenants are lured into the private market as their rents soar in the projects. And many tenants who are on welfare see little incentive to join the ranks of the working, because they know 30 percent of their pay will go for rent.
Delores Wilson, a resident of Cabrini-Green, a housing development on the city's North Side plagued with gang warfare and sniper attacks, told of a neighbor who recently moved out when her rent climbed to $900 a month. The rent rose after the woman and her husband both started working.
''It wasn't the shooting and the gangs that pushed them out; it was the rent,'' said Mrs. Wilson, a 61-year-old secretary for the city, who pays $539 a month in rent. Asked why she stayed, she said: ''It's my house. I love my neighbors and I love my building.''
New York, with the nation's largest system, is the exception: most of its public housing residents are families with at least one person working. Many of New York's poorest people are concentrated not in public housing projects but in older, rundown tenement buildings, many of which were taken over by the city after landlords defaulted on their property taxes.
Officials at H.U.D. and in Congress feel they have already addressed the problem of high rents for job-holding tenants by adopting regulations in March 1989 that enable public housing authorities to impose temporary rent ceilings for some tenants.
Under those regulations, rents may be lowered for as many as three years, so tenants would pay as little as the equivalent amount it costs the authority, on an average, to cover the overhead and any other operating costs necessary to maintain apartments of similar size.
Joseph G. Schiff, the special adviser to Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp for public and Indian housing, said about a dozen of the nation's 3,000 housing authorities have so far been granted permission to use the new formula in setting rents. At the same, he noted that Chicago and some other housing authorities had raised objections, arguing that the new rules did not bring rents down enough.
 
Permanent Rent Ceilings Urged
Mr. Lane said the rent ceilings ought to be permanent, rather than temporary. And he said they ought to be pegged to prevailing market rates in the neighborhoods surrounding public housing.
In addition, housing managers in Chicago, St. Paul and other cities complain that that new Federal policies are forcing them to accept former mental patients, including young single males, as tenants in buildings intended mostly for the elderly poor.
Mental hospitals across the country in recent decades released patients who do not need permanent care. But the small group homes that were envisioned for them rarely materialized -leaving them nowhere to go but public housing or the streets.
In Seattle, for example, more than 50 percent of the tenants in some high-rise elderly buildings are now younger people requiring special social services and whose life styles clash with those of older residents, said Harry Thomas, director of the Seattle authority.
''If you focus too much on housing the hard to house in existing public housing complexes, you run the risk of making the whole building, the whole community, fall apart,'' he said.
 
Federal Role Is Reduced
The debate has sharpened as the Federal Government has reduced its role in providing new housing and as the nation's stock of privately owned low-income housing has declined because of gentrification, the demolition of many single-room-occupancy hotels and the conversion of many apartments to condominiums. Meanwhile, the number of low-income households and homeless people has grown.
This has put more pressure on the nation's existing stock of 1.4 million public housing units as housing of last resort, as more and more people crowd waiting lists for the few vacancies that open each year.
Although the demand for public housing units varies greatly from city to city, a survey in 1986 counted 247,500 families on lists waiting for vacancies among 374,150 units in 64 cities. It also counted 32,555 elderly people on lists for 103,203 units for the elderly.
The trend toward giving preference to those least able to care for themselves has won the support of many advocacy groups for the mentally ill, people with disabilities and the infirm.
On the other side are public housing managers and many tenants' organizations that say they are sympathetic with the shelter needs of the very poor and infirm but believe it is unfair to force public housing communities, many of which are already under extreme pressure because of crime and poverty, to take in even more people least able to help themselves.
Their argument is that public housing's role today should be what it was when it was first created 50 years ago: an agent of social change that provides transitional housing for poor people, including the working poor.
Robert McKay, the executive director of the Council of Large Public Housing Authorities, says he finds it wrenching to be fighting with advocates for the mentally ill or patients with AIDS. ''But it is not right either that public housing is being asked to take in these populations because no place else will,'' he said.
In the middle are officials at H.U.D., where Secretary Kemp has pledged to give tenants a much greater role in managing their own buildings.
Mr. Schiff said he believes public housing is serving ''the appropriate population.'' But he said he also supports the idea of economic integration in public housing.
In fact, a Federal housing act passed by Congress in 1974 specifically authorized tenant selection criteria that would insure that buildings include families with a range of incomes. But recent Federal policy has run in the opposite direction.
A survey of large, urban public housing by the Citizens Housing and Planning Association in Boston found that 70 percent of the households are headed by women and that fewer than 36 percent of the heads of households are employed.
The major exception to this trend is New York City, where more than 72 percent of the city's public housing tenants are employed. Val Coleman, a spokesman for the New York Housing Authority, said the authority has delibrately sought to maintain a mix of different income levels in its buidlings.
''Without economic integration, public housing self-destructs,'' Mr. Coleman said. But he added that recent pressures have forced the authority to accept a greater proportion of the very poor, those with annual incomes of less than $8,000, whenever vacancies occur.
 
New York as a Role Model
Chicago has three times the proportion of welfare recipients as New York, and its aging high-rise buildings are plagued by crime, gangs and drug dealers. ''If we are going to make public housing work in Chicago, we have to begin to move closer to the New York model,'' said Mr. Lane, the Chicago authority's chairman.
George Sternlieb, a professor of urban affairs at Rutgers University, said the debate over housing policy reflected a clash of conflicting values.
''It's a very difficult dilemma,'' he said. ''If you want to preserve these public housing developments as stable communities, the managers need to be able to control the selection and eviction of their tenants. But we also have to find the room to address today's tragedies - the growing numbers of homeless and people without shelter.''
Gordon Cavanagh, a legal adviser to the Council of Large Public Housing Authorities, said public housing was being unfairly asked to absorb ''a whole set of problems that the rest of America refuses to accommodate.''
Part of the problem, he said, is that public housing ''is a stepchild within H.U.D., because its constituencies are poor and have virtually no politicall clout.''
In Congress, public housing is regarded as a drain on the Treasury.
The amount of money H.U.D. pays to subsidize the operating costs of local public housing authorities has increased to nearly $1.9 billion this year from $500 million in 1970. Those higher subsidies reflect in part the growing concentration of poor people in buildings who pay rents that do not cover the cost of building operations.
