HEADLINE: 2 Top Dinkins Advisers Form Unlikely Pairing

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
When Mayor David N. Dinkins discusses the New York City budget with his senior advisers, an unlikely pair of portly men is virtually always among them. After the Happy Land Social Club fire, they were at his side for hours. On weekends at Gracie Mansion, at sunset in City Hall, the two are there.
They are Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, and Bill Lynch, the Deputy Mayor for Intergovernmental Affairs, and 15 weeks into the Mayor's term they have emerged to almost no one's surprise as the two people Mr. Dinkins most depends on - Mr. Steisel for operations and Mr. Lynch for politics.
But in an evolution that was by no means as assured, other politicians said, the two potential rivals, steeped in different schools, have developed a steady relationship, comfortably sharing power and the Mayor's confidence. 
''We've occasionally had our differences, a few food fights,'' said Mr. Steisel, whose bravura and flexible face conjure up the curtness of a cabdriver and the comedy of Bert Lahr.
 
'A Lot of Similiarity'
''I think it's working out fine,'' said Mr. Lynch, a bearded owlish figure almost as disheveled as Mr. Dinkins is dapper. ''Although we might approach things differently, there is a lot of similiarity, and I think we read each other's body language well.''
There is no doubt that Mr. Lynch, a longtime aide who managed Mr. Dinkins's campaign, and Mr. Steisel, a former Sanitation Commissioner who had not known Mr. Dinkins well, are keeping long hours. It is harder to measure what they have done, because the new administration has been consumed with making appointments and coping with unexpected revenue shortfalls.
The budget troubles have helped put Mr. Steisel, who leads fiscal strategy, and Mr. Lynch, who is responsible for selling the plan's mix of tax proposals to Albany and the City Council, at the forefront of Mr. Dinkins's inner circle, although both are quick to insist they are part of a team.
The team has other players, including the other three deputy mayors, Barbara J. Fife for planning, Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero for economic development and Milton Mollen for public saftey, as well as Mr. Dinkins's senior special adviser, Ken Sunshine. The deputies meet together with Mr. Dinkins a few mornings a week and perhaps on the weekend. So far, their portfolios have not put them as much in the public eye.
 
No 'Calls From Rabbis'
On the other hand, Mr. Lynch is highly visible and accessible. He is likely to begin his day with a stream of calls from concerned constituents - black ministers or Hispanic community groups. And the stream virtually never stops. He ended a recent 12-hour day talking with a group of disabled people.
Mr. Steisel is more likely to focus on a problem in an agency or a snag in the budget. But he takes his share of calls from politicians and civic leaders. He said with a smile, however, ''I don't get calls from rabbis.''
Aides to both men said Mr. Steisel had played a central role in negotiating with the Council on a bill that would force the city to move homeless families out of barracks-style shelters by a fixed date. Mr. Steisel has negotiated because such a deadline would affect the operation of housing programs, and the administration is not sure it could comply.
Mr. Steisel said it was Mr. Lynch who made him realize that finding places to put the families was just the first question and that deciding how best to help them once they were housed was just as important and raised management challenges for Mr. Steisel's staff.
 
'Input on the Substantive Side'
''He convinced me that part of what we do has got to go beyond just moving people around,'' Mr. Steisel said.
Mr. Lynch said that if he was sometimes pegged as the ''people person'' in the administration, ''I have input on the substantive side,'' too.
''They each understand that the job of helping David Dinkins to run the City of New York is so huge,'' Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger said, ''that there's plenty of room for dividing up the responsibility and for using the other person to be helpful. They're both smart and they know how to play good cop, bad cop in different ways.''
Each man professes admiration for qualities in the other.
''He's more touchy-feely than I am, and he's better at it,'' said Mr. Steisel, a chemical engineer by training who as Sanitation Commissioner under Mayor Edward I. Koch built a reputation as a skilled and demanding manager. ''Sometimes I wish I were a little more like that.''
 
Frustrations and Stresses
Mr. Lynch, a former community organizer and employment training expert, said, ''I've learned a lot of things from Norman about city government.'' He said they have a ''similar sense of values'' and dedication to social justice. ''I think there is a side of Norman Steisel that people don't know about.''
Mr. Steisel, who grew up in Brooklyn and is the son of Polish immigrants, said he had more in common with Mr. Lynch than might be obvious. Mr. Lynch grew up on eastern Long Island, the son of a potato farmer and factory worker.
''We understand each other,'' Mr. Steisel said. ''He's a poor farmboy who made good, and I'm a poor baker's son who made good.''
Inevitably, there are some stresses. Aides to Mr. Steisel said he could sometimes be frustrated at how hard it is to reach Mr. Lynch, who talks to so many of the people who want to talk to him that he is perpetually behind in returning phone calls.
Mr. Lynch, in turn, bristles at any suggestion that he may be spread too thin. ''I like to believe that when you're in the people business, you've got to be in touch with people,'' he said. ''I don't think that every deputy mayor has to do that. But I think one of us should.''
Both men said nothing could have prepared them for the range and relentlessness of the decisions they face.
 
Reacting to Developments
''In the Borough President's office, you could almost pick and choose what you would react to,'' said Mr. Lynch, who was Mr. Dinkins's chief of staff in the Manhattan Borough President's office. ''Now it's the whole city, and all the time.''
Mr. Steisel cited a maxim of a predecessor, Nathan Levenathal, who allowed that short-term planning at the top of city government consisted of figuring out how to react to this afternoon's news and long-term planning in deciding how to respond to tomorrow morning's news.
Mr. Dinkins freely acknowledges that he can be a difficult boss, and his relationship with Mr. Lynch and Mr. Steisel is one among professionals, not pals. That in itself helps avert potential rivalries, other aides said.
 
'Businesslike Relationship'
When the Mayor swore in the first of his aides a few minutes after midnight on Jan. 1, he gave Mr. Steisel a warm handshake, not the bear hugs proferred to Mr. Lynch, Mrs. Fife and Ms. Hernandez-Pinero.
But despite Mr. Dinkins's years with Mr. Lynch, a senior aide said, the two have ''an extremely distant impersonal businesslike relationship.''
Explaining his decision to join Mr. Dinkins's team, Mr. Steisel said, ''I was interested in making the system work for the guy who sets the policy.''
Mr. Lynch said, ''I just want to be part of what we're going to do.''

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sony Is Said To Be in Deal For TV Plant

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
The Sony Corporation is expected to announce today that it will produce television picture tubes in a vacated Volkswagen factory near Pittsburgh.
Officials familiar with the deal said Sony plans at first to employ about 1,000 in the factory, in New Stanton, Pa., southeast of Pittsburgh. 
The Sony plant might also be used to produce high-definition television sets. But standards for such sets have not yet been agreed upon, and the market is still several years away from getting started in the United States. officials said. $300 Million Project Koh Shimizu, a spokesman for Sony, and David Stone, the director of communications for Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, said yesterday that the company and the state were in negotiations but were not ready to make an official announcement.
But a news conference to be attended by Governor Casey and Sony officials is planned for today in Pittsburgh.
Officials described Sony's effort to renovate the factory as a $300 million project that would be assisted by state loans and incentives valued at $23 million.
Volkswagen A.G. shut the plant, which made the Rabbit model, in July 1988, after its business had slumped. The plant employed 5,700 at its peak and 2,500 when it was shut.
Sony already makes television sets and picture tubes in San Diego and has several other big American manufacturing plants for other products. It is doing research on high-definition television in San Jose, Calif.
The prospect that Sony may make high-definition television sets in the United States cheered some analysts. Robert B. Reich, a professor of political economy at Harvard University, said that even if American companies do not make the sets, at least the technological expertise would be in the United States.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Rewriting A Budget (And Its Rules?)

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
The senators and representatives who will begin the thankless task of writing a new Federal budget this week have three basic choices.
They can produce a serious budget with real spending cuts and tax increases that would actually reduce the deficit in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 from more than $100 billion to $64 billion, the figure required by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law.
They can hoke up some phony numbers like unrealistically large reductions in military spending and an impossible-to-achieve revenue increase and hope that will lead them into serious talks with the White House.
Or they can change the budget-balancing law to make the deficit target this year easier to hit. 
At the moment, the odds favor the third alternative. ''When they can't deal with the deficit, they deal with the process,'' said Stanley E. Collender, a budget specialist at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm.
Writing a serious budget is just politically too difficult for the lawmakers. They are under no pressure from either constituents or the financial markets to raise taxes or make deep spending cuts. The November elections are on the horizon. And President Bush holds a veto card that can trump any play by Congress.
''If there is a serious agreement, it will have to be an immaculate conception,'' said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office. ''Neither party can afford to take responsibility for the parentage of something that imposes significant pain on the American people.''
A bill with phony numbers probably could not make it through the House and Senate intact. Nearly all the Republicans would vote against it. Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, would object to a budget crudely slashing the military, even if he knew it was just a bargaining chip. And the Democratic chairmen of the tax committees, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois and Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, would oppose a measure that puts the onus on them to raise taxes.
The annual deficit targets set by the budget-balancing law could be changed in the guise of improving budget-making procedures. The first step would be to remove Social Security from the deficit calculations, an action supported by many lawmakers in both parties. That would raise the official deficit figure by $75 billion more, making the current deficit figure impossible to meet. The next step would be to write new annual targets that would show a balanced budget by the late 1990's.
Changing the goals is exactly what Congress and the White House did three years ago, after the stock market collapse, when they could not meet the original targets.
''It's the easiest thing in the world,'' said Mr. Collender. ''You get to vote in favor of a balanced budget six or seven years from now. But you don't have to say right now whose programs will be cut or whose taxes will be increased.''
Whether the President will go along with this ploy is another matter. His budget director, Richard G. Darman, has been hinting for the last month that he would like to sit down with Congress and negotiate a real deficit-cutting budget. Two weeks ago he made a special trip to Capitol Hill to try to mend fences with Senate leaders. But the Democrats who control Congress still do not trust him.
The Democrats believe the budget Mr. Darman submitted last January relied on phony economic assumptions, a wrongheaded proposal to raise revenue by cutting the capital gains tax, and spending cuts that are unpalatable even to members of his own party.
Moreover, they suspect that Mr. Darman, for political reasons, will manipulate the way the savings and loan bailout is accounted for. For example, one way the Administration could reduce the official deficit for next year would be to spend money to take over failed savings institutions this year and collect money by selling them at a discount next year.
Whatever the case, nothing is likely to be decided quickly. Budget matters never are. Mr. Bush submitted his budget to Congress three weeks late. The lawmakers were supposed to have finished writing a budget resolution by April 15, and they are just starting to draft one this week. The last round of this shadowboxing may not end until after November.

HEADLINE: Rising Clamor by Airport Neighbors Brings Gains in Fight Against Noise

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
Neighbors of airports around the country, whose complaints were once often shunted aside by government officials and the airlines, are enjoying increasing success in their battle against aircraft noise.
In Seattle, communities near the airport earlier this month reached an agreement with airlines, pilots and the Federal Aviation Administration to cut noise in half by 2001; it is thought to be the first time that airport neighbors participated in drafting such a plan from the outset.
In northern New Jersey, where more than 1,000 flights a day pass over neighborhoods that hardly saw a plane four years ago, residents from 208 communities have banded together in what may be the largest display of opposition to aircraft noise. They have persuaded the F.A.A. to alter some flight paths over the region and have joined with their members of Congress to fight for more changes on Capitol Hill.
In Dallas, opposition to two new runways has been so potent that officials at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport are considering buying from homeowners the rights to fly over their neighborhoods. 
 
Gains in Noise Controls
In other areas, communities have won stricter flight curfews and bans on takeoffs and landings of noisier jets. They have also stalled airport expansions and discouraged construction of new airports. More than 300 airports now have some type of curfew or other noise control, compared with only a few dozen two decades ago.
But the victories are coming at a time when flight delays are on the rise and Federal officials agree with frustrated travelers that more runways and additional flight paths are desperately needed to ease congestion. Industry experts say the biggest obstacle to expanding the nation's air transportation system is not the cost but the opposition to aircraft noise, as well as to other environmental concerns like increased vehicle traffic.
Further, pilots say some of the noise controls compromise safety. At some airports, pilots are required to reduce engine power after takeoff.
The airlines complain that the growing number of curfews and other restrictions across the country also create a scheduling nightmare. They are calling for national noise standards that would override those limits.
In a draft version of his national transportation policy, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner had included a provision for such national noise standards. But under pressure from communities and the Office of Management and Budget, which was concerned about the lawsuits on noise that the Government might face, Mr. Skinner retreated and simply acknowledged that the issue was a serious one.
 
Community Pressure on Rules
The communities insist on setting their own standards, contending that they must live with the noise. ''We go 17 or 18 hours at a stretch with airplanes overhead,'' said Shirley Gazsi, a resident of Cranford, N.J., who is a spokeswoman for the Coalition Against Aircraft Noise, a group objecting to a re-routing of planes over the area. ''My windows rattle terribly; I can't hear the stereo or watch TV. Even speaking on the phone is difficult.''
The community groups have been successful in part because they are now displaying some of the political influence of other environmental groups. They are hiring Washington law firms and commissioning sophisticated lobbying campaigns.
The fury comes at a time when the airlines are phasing in quieter planes, and according to the F.A.A. fewer than half as many people are exposed to significant aircraft noise as in the 1970's.
''It's part of the whole environmental movement,'' said John Wesler, a noise expert with Wyle Laboratories, a consulting firm. ''People's expectations have changed.''
But many groups, as well as the Environmental Protection Agency, say the F.A.A. drastically underestimates the problem because of the way it calculates noise levels. It averages noise over 24 hours, with noise at night weighed more heavily.
Critics say such averages mean little. ''Four hours of jet noise and 20 hours of quiet is still four hours of jet noise,'' said Patrick Russell, a lawyer representing the residents in northern New Jersey.
 
Impact on the Pilots
Under pressure from neighbors, some airports have agreed to require pilots to use lower power after takeoff and to steer planes over more sparsely populated areas. At John Wayne Airport in Orange County, Calif., which has the toughest noise restrictions in the country, most airlines require that pilots be trained to carry out the special maneuvers needed.
''It's getting downright dangerous'' at John Wayne Airport, said Richard Deeds, chairman of the Air Line Pilots Association's Noise Abatement Committee.
Other airports, including ones at Washington, Boston and Long Beach, Calif., have imposed nighttime curfews on all but the quietest jets, which include new models like the Boeing 757 and 767 and the McDonnell Douglas MD-80. John Wayne Airport and the airport at Burbank, Calif., have even banned noisier planes.
Groups of airport operators are urging a nationwide ban of noisier jets, which include older versions of the Boeing 727 and 747, by the end of the decade.
But the airlines argue that with order backlogs for new planes reaching four or five years, they cannot get the new planes quickly enough. About 55 percent of the jets flying in this country are still the louder planes.
The agreement reached in Seattle, which must still be approved by the city's Port Commission, establishes a steadily shrinking ''noise budget'' for the airlines. Under the plan, an airline must meet a cap on total noise - deciding between fewer flights using noisy planes and more using quieter planes.
 
Protests at Rerouting
Residents of northern New Jersey have been battling the Government since 1987, when the aviation agency rerouted planes flying into the New York area to reduce flight delays. The residents, who also complain that the residue from jet fuel stains their homes, want the aviation agency to roll back the plan.
The group complains that the Government had no environmental assessment before carrying out the plan. The F.A.A. said such a study was not required because the rerouting involved planes flying miles from an airport and at altitudes above 3,000 feet. ''We never anticipated the change would have this effect,'' said Kathleen Bergen, a spokeswoman for the agency. Indeed, some of the people complaining about the noise live as far as 40 miles from Newark International, the nearest major airport.
The agency has since changed some of the flight paths to Newark International but rejected the group's request that it reroute planes over the ocean, saying such a move would be unsafe and too costly.
''The economic side of this far outweighs the inconvenience of someone out in the rolling hills who hears a distant roar,'' said one F.A.A. official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. ''It's not like we're pumping toxic waste into a stream.''
Airport officials in Dallas, who are trying to build two new runways, are considering unusual means of overcoming opposition, including not only paying nearby residents for the right to fly over their homes but also guaranteeing the property value of people affected by the new runways, said Dana Ryan, senior planner for the airport.
Given such battles, ''airports are reluctant to roll out plans for expansion because they know about this kind of opposition,'' said E. Tazewell Ellett, a Washington lawyer and former chief counsel for the aviation agency.
Only one major airport - in Denver - is to be built this decade. Local officials were able to overcome environmental objections to that airport, which will be the world's largest when it is completed in 1993, by buying land for a buffer zone around it.
Eliot Cutler, a Washington lawyer who represents communities in such cases and whose firm has grown to 20 lawyers from four a few years ago, said better land planning was a good solution. ''This obsession with new runways is wrongheaded,'' he said. ''The solution is to build new airports where we can accommodate them.''

HEADLINE: Meditators and Money Find Home in Heartland

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Iowa, April 16

 BODY:
In the quiet of the early morning, the trek to the golden dome begins. One by one the business executives and owners arrive, ready to start their day - by sitting in silence.
All are successful entrepreneurs. And all are meditators. Thousands of people have flocked to this small city in southeastern Iowa, home of Maharishi International University, to study, share a style of living and build their own businesses. And they have brought with them prosperity and growth. 
''It is a remarkable community,'' said Daniel Dittemore, head of the Iowa Product Development Corporation, a state-sponsored seed capital investment program. ''They have an uncommon appetite and knack for entrepreneurship.''
 
A Variety of Businesses
In the last several years, scores of transcendental meditators have moved their companies to Fairfield or begun new ones here. There is an ice cream maker who sells to stores in New York, Chicago and other cities, a chimney sweep supplier with thousands of customers, and a studio owner who photographs many of the country's major marathons. Others are engineers, lawyers, insurance agents or computer experts.
''There's a remarkable population of technologically oriented companies out of all proportion of what you'd expect to find in a community that size,'' Mr. Dittemore said.
Gov. Terry E. Branstad has called Fairfield, a city of 11,000 people, one of Iowa's economic ''superstars.''
The local Chamber of Commerce does not track the number of companies run or owned by meditators, but some in the community say that such companies employ about 1,000 people. More than 50 do business nationally or overseas.
 
'A Lot of Job Opportunities'
''We've put a lot of energy into this town, a lot of money, a lot of talent and a lot of job opportunities,'' said John Narducci, president of Chappell Studio-Marathon Foto, which photographs marathons.
But Mike Brouwer, executive vice president of the Chamber of Commerce, said that even though meditators contribute to Fairfield's successs they are not the prime movers.
''I'm not willing to slight 22 major manufacturers in this community,'' he said. ''Some have been here over 100 years.''
Still, Mr. Brouwer credits the meditators with creating innovative ways to support themselves.
Some come because of the university, which was founded by the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the Indian guru who once dazzled the Beatles and other celebrities. Others come because ''the benefits seem to grow when you're meditating with other people,'' said Patty Schneider, the university's public affairs chief.
 
The Maharishi Effect
Transcendental meditators believe if they gather in large numbers, they create the Maharishi Effect, a positive influence on events ranging from global conflicts to traffic deaths.
Each morning and afternoon the meditators, segregated by sex to avoid distractions, practice their technique in the Golden Domes of Pure Knowledge. Estimates of meditators range from 2,000 to 3,000; many attend or work at the university, which moved from California in 1974 into the campus of defunct Parsons College and has a full-time enrollment of 799. Meditators also run their own elementary and high schools.
Meditators work side-by-side with nonmeditators in businesses and the City Council. But ''there's still the dividing line between those people and some people in the community,'' said Royse Huff, president of the Fairfield Economic Development Association.
There are, for example, jokes about yogic flying competitions, which prompted one enterprising company years ago to sell cushions to soften levitation landings.
 
'A Stronger Acceptance' Now
But Mayor Bob Rasmussen said attitudes have changed since the early days, when some townspeople wondered if the meditators were a cult. ''There's certainly a stronger acceptance, less divisiveness,'' he said. ''They've integrated much better. We respect each other and get along.''
Some problems remain. Mr. Huff, for example, said there had been a ''tremendous turnover'' of businesses owned by meditators.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Value of a USX Spinoff Is Disputed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARY, Ind.

 BODY:
The USX Corporation's sprawling plant along the shore of Lake Michigan here is the foundation of what many consider to be among the most efficient steel operations in the United States.
Yet some analysts say the nation's largest steel producer would have difficulty continuing to outperform the industry as an independent company, spun off from USX as proposed by Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder. They also doubt that a spinoff would make each existing USX share worth $48 - 40 percent more than the current price - as Mr. Icahn stated in proxy material sent to shareholders early in April.
''If the value of the company were $48 with a spinoff of steel, the stock price would reflect a value closer to that,'' said Jeffrey Miller, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago.
 
Shareholder Vote Set
Shareholders will vote at the company's annual meeting on May 7 whether to spin off at least 80 percent of the steel business into a separate company called the U.S. Steel Corporation, the name used by USX for 85 years until 1986. Under Mr. Icahn's plan, each existing USX share would be replaced with two types of shares - one representing the steel company and the other an energy company composed of USX's large oil and gas holdings. Management would be under no obligation to carry out the plan if it was approved. 
Mr. Icahn, who urged management to put his proposal to a vote in lieu of his waging a proxy fight, is eager to rid USX of the steel business, which accounts for one-third of the company's sales and earnings. During a down cycle, he argues, the lagging steel unit could weaken the earnings of the energy subsidiary.
He believes the market would value a pure energy and a pure steel stock higher than it now does a hybrid USX, which he contends is trading at less than its fair value because few analysts understand the intricacies of both businesses.
Mr. Icahn has valued a separate steel company at $9 a share and the energy company at $39 a share. [Shares of USX closed on the New York Stock Exchange Monday at $34.50 each, up 37.5 cents.] But some analysts believe the stock is already overvalued, run up by the presence of Mr. Icahn, who owns 13.3 percent of USX. And most say the value and virtue of spinning off the steel group depend on how certain issues regarding taxes and retiree benefits are resolved.
Other analysts agree that steel should be sold, but question the timing of a sale. They say the unit would bring a higher price if the steel market were healthier. Some believe that Charles A. Corry, chairman and chief executive of Pittsburgh-based USX, opposes Mr. Icahn's proposal because he would rather sell steel when the market improves.
While shareholders are expected to defeat the spinoff proposal by voting with management, as they usually do in these situations, Mr. Icahn could get support from some institutional investors. Like Mr. Icahn, some of these investors are irritated that USX's stock has risen only 8.4 percent in the last 15 years, lagging behind the 308 percent increase in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index during the same period.
They contend that a restructuring undertaken by USX in 1987, after Mr. Icahn proposed taking over the company, was not radical enough, and welcome his latest threat as a much-needed catalyst for change. Under the restructuring, which management promised would raise the value of the stock, the company repurchased shares and placed its faltering Texas Oil and Gas unit up for sale. That unit is still unsold.
 
Earnings Improve
But management argues that the company is healthier than it has been in years. It earned $965 million last year on sales of $18.7 billion, up from net income of $756 million on sales of $16.8 billion in 1988.
Also, since Mr. Icahn began to invest in USX three years ago, the company's stock price has increased 66 percent, compared with the 37 percent rise in the Standard & Poor's 500 during that period.
And the oil and gas business, entered into in 1982 with the purchase of the Marathon Oil Company to protect against the cyclicality of the steel sector, now accounts for nearly two-thirds of USX's sales and earnings, up from 58 percent in 1988.
Operating earnings of Marathon, the centerpiece of USX's energy holdings, have climbed significantly since 1987, to $862 million last year. They should continue to grow with the anticipated improvement in oil production and demand, analysts said.
''Marathon is a valuable energy company with significant growth potential,'' said Rolf Wagner, an analyst at Scott & Stringfellow in Richmond. ''If the steel business were separated, none of that would change.''
The steel business has also staged a turnaround. After losing more than $2 billion during the four-year industry slump that began in 1983, the company became profitable in 1987 -helped by widespread layoffs, new equipment, improved demand and Federal restrictions on imported steel. It earned $432 million in 1989.
 
Evidence of Revival
Here in Gary, it now takes only 3.5 hours of labor to produce a ton of steel, down from 10 hours 10 years ago and significantly less than the domestic industry average of 6.6 hours. USX has pruned its work force to about 20,000 people, from 75,000 a decade ago. And by next year, Gary's output will be produced entirely by continuous casters, the equipment that casts steel far more efficiently than the old method, in which ingots were used. Now, more than 60 percent is continuously casted.
But management calculates that operating the steel group as a stand-alone company could cost an additional $100 million to $200 million a year. Without the energy assets, analysts said, the steel company would have more difficulty raising the equity and debt capital it needs to keep pace in technology and modernization. It likely would also be saddled with more than $1.5 billion in debt at a time when steel earnings are expected to fall.
Management is also concerned about losing $900 million in tax-loss carry-forwards. In the proxy materials, Mr. Icahn said USX's tax carry-forwards could be used up by the end of this year, before the spinoff.
 
Question of Pensions
But Mr. Icahn did not address several other concerns, such as how the steel company could cover its enormous retiree and medical benefits. Last year alone, the company paid $972 million in pension benefits.
''It may be necessary for USX to create a trust fund, or to make a commitment to fund retiree benefits beyond the time of a steel spinoff,'' said John C. Tumazos, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''That would have some impact on the results for the energy segment's performance.''
What is more, while issuing stock in the entity would invite an acquisition, top management and analysts say the steel business might be worth more in the second half of this year, or in 1991, when auto demand is expected to pick up and the steel market, which began to soften in the last quarter, bounces back.
Based on their longstanding interest in the United States steel industry, Japanese steel companies are among the most likely acquirers, according to analysts. Japanese steel companies have ownership stakes or joint ventures with all of the large, integrated steel producers in the United States, including USX.
USX officials say that Japanese companies have expressed interest in acquiring the company's huge plant here. But Mr. Corry has opposed a piecemeal divestiture.
 
Interest From Europe
Company officials say there is also growing interest from steel companies in Europe. That was underscored last month when the LTV Corporation, the nation's third-largest steel producer, said it was talking about a possible sale of part of its steel unit to Groupe Usinor-Sacilor, the giant French steel company.
Hans Mueller, an industry consultant and professor of economics at Middle Tennessee State University, in Murfreesboro, Tenn., said candidates for a purchase or joint venture include Thyssen Stahl A.G., the large West German steel company, and British Steel P.L.C.
However, several European steel officials say that the smaller, specialty steel companies in the United States are more likely targets than companies like USX, because their margins are higher. ''It seems that an investment in a large, integrated steel producer in the United States is not the best way to make money,'' said Heinz Kriwet, chairman of Thyssen.
Still, some foreign steel companies say that USX's mill here would be a significant foothold in the United States market. ''The Gary facility,'' said a senior official at another West German steel company, ''is now something to look at seriously, considering the activity of Carl Icahn.''

SECTION: Section D; Page 8, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 821 words

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Talkative Policy Is Aiding P.&G.

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
THE stock price of the Procter & Gamble Company, which has taken a beating in recent months, has made a strong recovery in the last few weeks.
Shares of the consumer-products giant rose 50 cents yesterday, to $71.25 a share, a new 52-week high and up from about $67 in late March.
P.&G., known for consumer products like Ivory soap and Pampers diapers, has long been derided by many people on Wall Street for being slow, parochial and secretive. Among some analysts, P.&G.'s nickname is the Kremlin. 
But now Procter & Gamble may at last be getting respect from investors.
In part, that is because P.&G. has a consistent record of turning in earnings that are better than analysts expected. That has been the case in at least six of the last eight quarters, by the count of Jay H. Freedman, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody.
Still, the stock action, on the face of it, is somewhat puzzling. P.&G., which has more than 80 brand names and annual revenue exceeding $21 billion, reported no developments that would account for the recent increase. Company spokesmen in Cincinnati routinely decline to comment on stock fluctuations.
P.&G. is not the only stock in its sector showing gains. Institutional investors in a cautious mood often seek the shelter of ''recession-proof'' packaged-goods companies in the belief that consumers will always shave with Gillette razors, guzzle Coca-Cola and munch Sara Lee cakes.
But P.&G. is different because of its Kremlin reputation. ''There have been a lot of people who just did not believe in P.&G.,'' said William K. Newbury, an analyst at College Retirement Equities Fund, an $80 billion pension fund that is one of P.&G.'s largest holders. In the mid-1980's, sales were strong but earnings were spotty. ''P.&G. had been a disappointment to investors,'' he said.
The company's reluctance to talk to analysts made matters worse. ''Imagine, one of the premier marketing companies in America couldn't market itself,'' said Lynne R. Hyman, an analyst with First Boston.
But, just as with the one in Moscow, the Kremlin at P.&G. has been undergoing revolutionary change. P.&G. has strengthened its international business through acquisitions. Overseas business provided about a third of revenue and profits last year, but by 1995 it is expected to account for more than half of revenue and more than 40 percent of earnings, Mr. Freedman said. Much of that business is in Europe, and P.&G. should benefit from the opening up of Eastern Europe.
The international operations have a friend in Edwin L. Artzt, who became the company's chairman in January. He once headed foreign operations and was responsible for much of the company's international growth.
Mr. Artzt has also been showing unexpected vigor in cutting costs, something P.&G. has been slow to do in the past, analysts say. As a result, several analysts have upgraded the stock from ''moderately attractive'' to ''buy.''
Most revolutionary of all, at least to analysts, P.&G. is slightly less secretive than before. It has just sent out invitations to analysts for a May 21 meeting with management, the first such gathering in eight years. That last meeting occurred when Mr. Artzt's predecessor, John Smale, became chairman.
''That is really the last time we heard from Smale,'' Ms. Hyman said. ''He was afraid that he'd say something at a meeting and the stock would go down.''
But the hopes aroused by such changes and P.&G.'s habit of outperforming expectations may have set the stock up for the tumble it took early this year.
Anticipating a good second-quarter report in late January, analysts reviewed their earnings projections. ''Even the dumbest of us started taking notice and jacking up our estimates,'' Ms. Hyman said. ''I jacked up mine from $1.18 a share to $1.25. Nobody wanted to be caught short again.'' P.&G., in the new spirit of openness, answered analysts' inquiries, confirmed that business was encouraging, but cautioned them that nothing had really changed to support revised forecasts.
Many analysts were projecting quarterly operating profit of $1.20 to $1.25 a share, an increase of 31 percent to 36 percent. But some were projecting numbers as high as $1.30 or more and saying so to big institutional investors. The stock price rose in the weeks before the earnings report.
The upshot: On Jan. 25, when P.&G. reported $1.22 a share, an increase of 33 percent, Wall Street was ''disappointed.'' Share prices tumbled $3.50 that day on volume of more than 1.6 million shares.
Will P.&G. tumble again when it reports third-quarter earnings on April 25? Some analysts say no, because earnings projections are more conservative now, with most putting operating earnings at $1.05 a share, an increase of 20 percent or so.
Others are not so sure. ''P.&G. seems to be falling into this pattern,'' Mr. Newbury said. ''And there is that old saying, 'Buy on the rumor and sell on the news.' ''

HEADLINE: Ancient Find, But How Ancient?

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: SAO RAIMUNDO NONATO, Brazil

 BODY:
STANDING in the hollow of a 135-foot high rock shelter, Fabio Parenti painted a mental picture of hunters at the same spot thousands of years ago, surveying the valley floor below for game.
Near a spring, the Italian archeologist used his machete to draw aside bushes covering sandstone paintings that depicted an ancient menu: antelope, deer and armadillo.
Where Mr. Parenti usually sparks controversy is with his next contention: that ancient man hunted animals, built cookfires and bedded down in this rock shelter 47,000 years ago, at the time Neanderthal man inhabited Europe.
That claim has rocked the prevailing wisdom, which holds that the first Americans inhabited the Western Hemisphere 12,000 years ago. Although many archeologists are coming to believe that the date of the first human habitation may be earlier than that, Mr. Parenti's proposed date is so astonishingly early that it has been greeted with skepticism by mainstream American archeologists. Many doubt, in particular, that Mr. Parenti and his colleague, Niede Guidon, have accurately dated the geologic layers as they dug into dirt at the foot of this cliff wall, producing a series of increasingly older sites they say show signs of being inhabited. 
Criticisms of their findings by other archeologists were systematically rebutted by Mr. Parenti one recent morning as the calls of birds echoed against the soaring rockface, formally called Pedra Furada. Mr. Parenti, who is a doctoral student at an Italian university, removed his straw hat, wiped his brow from the 100-degree heat and recounted what a decade of research had found.
Between two 16-foot-deep trenches, a block of undisturbed soil illustrated descending layers of sedimentation from the present era to 55,000 years ago.
Judging from paint drops found on loose rocks, the archeologists estimate that the wall paintings were made as long ago as 10,000 B.C.
''These are deer, here is a jaguar, these men are probably hunters,'' the bearded archeologist said, studying a series of stick figures scrawled on stone.
 
Stones Arranged for Hearths
As far down as the 12,000-year level, Dr. Guidon found stones arranged in semi-circular hearths filled with charcoal and surrounded by flint artifacts.
The nearest source of flint is almost a mile away, indicating that the inhabitants quarried the flint to make knives, scrapers and choppers.
American archeology generally accepts the earliest dating of human habitation in the Americas to be provided by 11,500-year-old stone projectile points found in the 1920's near the town of Clovis, N.M., and later identified in sites throughout North America.
Here, digging below the 12,000-year level, the team continued to find charcoal and burned rocks arranged in hearths. Using two dating methods, radiocarbon or thermoluminescence, researchers dated 21 samples from 14,300 years ago to 47,000 years ago. In an unbroken sequence, the deeper the samples were found, the older the dates became.
 
Critics Point to Forest Fires
Academic skeptics have speculated that the charcoal samples were produced by ancient forest fires.
''Forest fires, sure - but do forest fires place rocks in circles?'' responded Mr. Parenti.
Skeptics have also speculated that rain, water runoff from the cliff or flooding from the valley disturbed sediments, mixing ancient charcoal with modern charcoal.
Mr. Parenti replied that the cliff's concave face protects the excavated area from direct rainfall, that runoff flows through two water chutes flanking the site and that nearby sample trenches show no evidence of floods in the area in the last 50,000 years.
Critics also charge that the 1,000 quartzite rocks believed to be crude tools from before 10,000 B.C. are actually rocks that fell from the top of the cliff.
 
Throwing Stones From Cliff
In response, Mr. Parenti said that he studied quartzite rocks, dropping hundreds off the cliff to study the natural fracturing processes.
''In nature, it is highly improbable that a rock will be repeatedly chipped on one end to form a blade,'' he said. ''I am certain that 200 to 300 are real artifacts.''
The Italian said that American archeologists were used to looking for defined arrow heads. European archeologists, he said, have more experience recognizing the primitive tools customarily found at prehistoric sites in Europe.
Foreseeing another criticism, Mr. Parenti said that the acidity of the sandstone soil has precluded finding human or animal bones older than 10,000 years. This year, excavation is to start in a limestone cave where soil conditions are suitable for preserving bone fragments.
The center of this growing debate over the first Americans is a remote and rugged range of cliffs and canyons reminiscent of the American West. Lying five hundred miles from the sea and a five-hour drive from the nearest airport, Sao Raimundo Nonato is lost in the dry northeastern backlands of Piaui state, an area often described in Brazilian novels as ''the end of the world.''
 
Threat From Quarries Averted
Here a trove of ancient rock paintings and engravings lay forgotten until the early 1960's when Dr. Guidon first ventured into this wilderness on a donkey.
In 1970, Dr. Guidon started a systematic survey of the ancient rock art. She has catalogued 310 prehistoric sites containing hundreds of engravings and about 10,000 rock paintings of red ochre.
But, at the same time as archeologists became interested in the rock art, economic development reached the area, leading to quarrying of limestone, which now threatens prehistoric sites here and in the Brazilian states of Goias and Rio Grande do Norte.
''Some paintings have been transformed into lime,'' Mr. Parenti said of this area.
Racing against the spreading quarries, Dr. Guidon managed to have 170 of the sites protected in a new, 320,000-acre national park, Serra da Capivara. In a rare arrangement for Brazil, the federal government delegated the administration of the park to Dr. Guidon's new Museum of the American Man Foundation.
With the most important sites safe, the archeologists returned to their digging.
In rural Brazil, laborers can be hired for $2 a day. With a cheap, skilled work force, Mr. Parenti said that he and Dr. Guidon were able to perform the kind of large, exhaustive excavation that is prohibitively expensive in Europe and the United States.
 
'This Is Hot Stuff'
Until the dig was suspended last year, a 15-man team dug for a decade, sifting through 3,300 cubic meters of soil at the base of the cliff here. About 7,000 rocks, many of them artifacts, were catalogued.
The Brazilian findings have set off sharp debate among archeologists. ''This is hot stuff - this will change our understanding of the peopling of the Americas,'' Robson Bonnichsen, the director of the Center for the Study of the First Americans at the University of Maine, said in a telephone interview.
''The Brazilian work is at the top of our list for studying the peopling of the Americas,'' added Mr. Bonnichsen, who is virtually the only American archeologist to have visited this isolated site.
But from a different quarter, Tom D. Dillehay, an archeologist at the University of Kentucky, who is digging at an ancient site in Chile, said in a telephone interview, ''Everybody has pretty much deep-sixed Guidon's work.''
Archeologsts on both sides of the argument agree that much of the dispute stems from a lack of communication.
Dr. Guidon, an archeologist at the Institute of Advanced Social Science Studies in Paris, has reported most of her findings in French. News reports from this desolate spot have been rare and written in French or Portuguese.
''Most of the arguments have been made by people who have never visited the site,'' said Dr. Bonnichsen. ''We are trying to arrange to get some eminent American scholars down there to study the methods and the results.''
Next year Mr. Bonnichsen plans to lead the first American excavation here. With at least 150 sites available for excavation, the American archeologist said he believed that further work will either prove or disprove the theory that man walked these canyons nearly 500 centuries ago.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
'New Harvest, Old Shame,' About Farm Workers

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
In the 30 years since Edward R. Murrow's powerful report ''Harvest of Shame,'' the safety and welfare of America's migrant workers have been improved by Federal legislation and union bargaining. Nevertheless, as tonight's strong documentary, ''New Harvest, Old Shame,'' shows, for the 800,000 farm workers who follow the crops north each spring, it's still mighty hard traveling. The latest offering from ''Frontline'' can be seen at 10 on Channel 13.
Dave Marash, tonight's correspondent, joins a family in Indiana as it prepares for the September trip back to Florida. Pedro Silva, 40 years old and the family head, was already working in the fields when the Murrow documentary appeared. It has been a tough year for his 15-member family, ages 9 to 62. The tomato crop suffered from too much rain, and at 35 cents a bucket, the Silvas are ending their six-week picking season with only $1,400. 
By the time they arrive at what serves as their home in the Everglades Migrant Camp, truck breakdowns and illness along the way have put them in debt. Their plans to stop off for some picking in South Carolina were destroyed by Hurricane Hugo, and the crops in Florida have been killed by a freeze.
In interviews with union organizers, farmers, officials and community workers, Mr. Marash finds that big growers are still enjoying an oversupply of labor. In Florida, he notes, there are three farm workers for every available job, and Americans like the Silvas are losing out to people from poor countries who are willing to work for less. A woman who has been hiring migrants for generations tells how the black Americans who did the picking 30 years ago were replaced first by Mexicans and Salvadorans and more recently by Guatemalans and Haitians, many of them illegal aliens.
In a particularly painful passage, Mr. Silva directs his anger not at the growers or at the authorities who set the minimum picking wage, but at the newcomers. ''It's killing us,'' he says. ''They're running us out of there. Those Guatemalans, they say, 'If you pay him $3.35 an hour, you can pay me $3 an hour.' '' Marshall Barry, a professor at Florida International University who has made a study of the state's agricultural economy, directs responsibility elsewhere: ''Employers will lower the wages and then if you refuse to accept those wages, they'll hire a man who's hungry or someone who desperately needs work.''
The farmers, lobbyists and officials interviewed seem bland and evasive compared with the workers and union organizers. That may be a tribute to the editing skills of the program's producers, but the evidence appears to support the case that despite the recent reform of the immigration law, illegal aliens continue to pour into the United States, where, with the cooperation of growers, they depress wages. Mr. Marash draws attention to the power of big farm interests in states like Florida as well as in Washington, D.C., to create loopholes in the law and discourage strict enforcement. As a rural organizer observes, ''Farm workers are not anyone's constituency in Congress.''
The income of Florida's farm workers, Professor Barry reports, buys less than half the goods it did in 1967. Moreover, the great majority of workers have no health insurance, no sick days, no paid vacations, no pensions. Their children, constantly on the move, are unlikely to complete the schooling that might break the migrant cycle. ''This ain't no life really,'' says Pedro Silva.
 
A LIFE OF INDIGNITIES - NEW HARVEST, OLD SHAME, a ''Frontline'' report, written by Hector Galan and Dave Marash; produced by Mr. Galan for PBS; David Fanning, executive producer; Mr. Marash, correspondent; Judy Woodruff, anchor. Tonight at 10 P.M. on Channel 13.

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
A Benefit Performance by and for Students

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
The Emergency Fund for Student Dancers, which presented its first benefit program on Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, was devised by administrators from five leading New York City dance schools in response to the slaying last year of a dance student in Manhattan. Four or five benefits a year are to be presented, to build a fund that will lend money to students from other countries and other parts of the United States to meet financial crises.
The participating schools - the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center, Laban-Bartenieff Institute of Movement Studies, Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance, Merce Cunningham Studios and Nikolais and Louis Dance Lab - could not have put together a better opening program. There was not a dull, unsophisticated or unimaginative spot in the dances choreographed, staged and performed by students from 13 countries, representing 4 of the studios. This unself-conscious, professional format could become one of the city's best showcases for new dance talent. 
Ben Geboe, an American Indian studying at the Graham school, opened the program with ''Tokahe's Medicine Song,'' set to music by Mr. Geboe and George Zaks. Based on a Sioux legend, the solo was a provocative and eloquent blend of Indian dance and Graham technique. ''Path Winding Through Tall Grass,'' choreographed by Wendy S. Turner, an American Graham student, was a dance for six women, set to Debussy, that succeeded completely on its own lyrical, simple terms. ''Untitled,'' a solo choreographed and performed in silence by Sioned Huws, a Welsh student at Cunningham, served as a quietly powerful display for Ms. Huws's fiercely uncompromising, mysterious presence.
''Sol,'' a dance set to music by Strafe fur Rebellion and choreographed by Gabriela Simon and Tanja Meding - Cunningham students from Argentina and West Germany, respectively - looked like lithe and nuzzling play for animals. It was performed by Ms. Simon, Ms. Meding and Bruce Jones, all dressed in tights and T-shirts with stylish patterns drawn on them. Bruno Sajous, a French student at the Nikolais and Louis Lab, choreographed and danced an expressionistic solo called ''Moment Donne,'' set to Schubert, that was a powerfully weighted and capricious dance for a show-stopping performer.
''Poem for Brenda,'' choreographed by Camille Brown, an American Graham dancer, was a simple, potent journey for Brenda Baden-Semper, a performer of iridescent intensity from Trinidad and Tobago. The piece was danced to music by Nakai with a text written and spoken by Ms. Brown.
Mr. Sajous returned in ''Polar Synthesis,'' a starkly dramatic duet set to music by Peter Gabriel and created and performed with Andrea Didisheim, an American student at Nikolais and Louis who moves with a dragonfly's lightness. ''The Memorial,'' a solo set to music by Minoru Miko and choreographed and performed by Reiko Uemura, a Japanese student at Graham, offered a look at a performer of special delicacy and dramatic intensity.
A solo from Murray Louis's ''Deja Vu'' was the evening's only dance by a well-known professional. Jim Xing, a young Chinese dancer from Nikolais and Louis, made the solo his own, dancing it with an extraordinary deftness, modulation and dramatic shading. His profoundly moving performance was a highlight of the evening.
The program closed with ''Tinig Ng Lupa,'' a charged ritual for 14 dancers from the Ailey School and the Ailey second company, led by Takeshi Yazaki, Cynthia Prim and the electric Guillermo Asca. Choreographed by Max Luna 3d, an Ailey teacher from the Philippines, to music by Ryan Kayabyab and Rick Mascarinas, the dance would have been even more powerful with a little editing.

HEADLINE: Farm Policies Called Wasteful

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PARIS, April 16

 BODY:
Farm subsidies and import barriers cost the world's richest nations $72 billion a year in lost income, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reports.
Agricultural policies waste resources by overstimulating output in farming and food processing and pushing up land and consumer food prices, the study by the research group said. It concludes that eliminating all farm supports in the 17 large nations reviewed in the study would increase income in O.E.C.D. households by almost 1 percent.
The study focuses on agricultural policies in Australia, Canada, the European Community, Japan, New Zealand and the United States, the dominant nations in the 24-member O.E.C.D.
Although eliminating farm supports would hurt farming in North America, Japan and the European Community, the study said, it would reduce food prices by 1.6 percent and knock down land prices by 40 percent.

HEADLINE: Companies' Anti-Union Tack In Strikes Is Blocked by Court

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today strengthened labor unions' hand in strikes marked by the hiring of replacement workers.
By a 5-to-4 vote, the Court upheld a National Labor Relations Board policy against automatically presuming that the replacements are anti-union for purposes of deciding whether the union any longer commands majority support.
The effect of the ruling was to make it more difficult for struck employers that hire replacements to free themselves of dealing with the striking union.
The decision today, N.L.R.B. v. Curtin Matheson, No. 88-1685, cut across the Court's usual ideological divisions. Justice Thurgood Marshall wrote the majority opinion, joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices William J. Brennan, Byron R. White and John Paul Stevens. 
Justices Harry A. Blackmun, Antonin Scalia, Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy dissented.
The decision upheld a much-disputed policy of the labor board that a number of lower Federal courts have refused to enforce.
The board supervises elections for union affiliation and certifies unions chosen by a majority of the workers. For years, it took the view that replacement workers hired during a strike were presumably anti-union, and could be counted as such by an employer seeking to show that a union had lost its majority.
Three years ago, however, the board adopted a new policy of refusing to presume anything about the union sentiments of replacement workers. Instead, the board said it would evaluate each situation case by case.
The issue is significant because under Federal labor law, an employer is justified in refusing to bargain with a union when there is a ''good faith'' doubt that it still enjoys majority support. The labor board's former policy of presuming that replacement workers were hostile to the union supplied the requisite doubt, permitting employers who had replaced a majority of striking workers to stop dealing with the union.
The labor board said today that it kept no records that would show how many employers had asserted such doubt in the past. But employers are increasingly using replacement workers to keep operating during strikes, offering the new workers permanent positions.
Greyhound Lines, which has been operating with replacement bus drivers during a drivers' strike that began six weeks ago, is only one current example. Other companies that have made extensive use of replacement workers are Eastern and Continental Airlines, the International Paper Company, the Boise Cascade Corporation and the Phelps Dodge Corporation.
The case before the Court today concerned a small Texas company, Curtin Matheson Scientific, which was struck by 22 out of 27 members of a bargaining unit represented by the teamsters' union. The company, which buys and sells laboratory supplies, hired 29 replacement workers. It then refused to bargain further with the union, asserting that with replacement workers now in the majority, it was legally entitled to doubt the majority status of the union.
 
Appeals Court Backs Company
The union charged the company with an unfair labor practice for its refusal to bargain. The board ruled for the union in 1987, citing its new policy against presuming the new workers' views and concluding that the company had not demonstrated that the teamsters had become ineligible to represent the workers. The board ordered the company to bargain over a new contract.
But the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, refused to enforce the order. It ruled that the board should have permitted the company to presume that the replacement workers no longer supported the union. The labor board appealed to the Supreme Court.
The dispute between the majority and the dissent was not so much over the intricacies of Federal labor law, including the National Labor Relations Act, as over the degree of deference owed by Federal judges to policies adopted by specialized administrative agencies.
''We will uphold a board rule as long as it is rational and consistent with the Act,'' Justice Marshall said, ''even if we would have formulated a different rule had we sat on the board.''
 
Wanting It Both Ways
Justice Marshall said the board's decision to presume nothing about replacement workers' union sentiments was ''rational as an empirical matter.'' He said replacement workers might have felt driven by economic necessity to cross the picket lines, but might still want the protection of union representation once on the job.
''Because the circumstances of each strike and the leverage of each union will vary greatly,'' he said, ''it was not irrational for the board to reject the anti-union presumption and adopt a case-by-case approach in determining replacements' union sentiments.''
In a concurring opinion, Chief Justice Rehnquist said, ''The board's no-presumption rule seems to me to press to the limit the deference to which the board is entitled in assessing industrial reality.'' But he added, ''I agree that limit is not exceeded.''
In dissenting opinions, Justices Blackmun and Scalia said the labor board had not adequately supported its position. Justice Scalia said: ''Since the principal employment-related interest of strike replacements (to retain their jobs) is almost invariably opposed to the principal interest of the striking union (to replace them with its striking members), it seems to me impossible to conclude on this record that the employer did not have a reasonable, good-faith doubt regarding the union's majority status.''
 
Ruling on Civil Rights
In another decision today, the Court ruled unanimously that suits brought under an important Federal civil rights law may be filed in state court as well as in Federal court.
The statute, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, prohibits employment discrimination on the basis of race or sex. Lower courts have disagreed over whether the Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over cases brought under the law.
The decision today, Yellow Freight System v. Donnelly, No. 89-431, upheld a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, that state as well as Federal courts can hear these cases. Justice Stevens wrote the opinion.

HEADLINE: Bush Warns Moscow of U.S. Move Over Cut in Fuel for Lithuanians

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
President Bush warned Moscow today that he would retaliate for a cut in fuel shipments to Lithuania, and officials said possible responses ranged from canceling official meetings and educational exchanges to stalling talks on a variety of trade issues.
That could affect negotiations on civil aviation, trade, investment and tax treaties and maritime transportation that grew out of the Malta summit meeting and that the Soviet Union is anxious to conclude, officials said. But they said the White House was not prepared to cancel the summit meeting between Mr. Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, planned for May 30 to June 3.
Mr. Bush summoned his top advisers, including Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, to the White House this evening to discuss reports from Moscow that the Lithuanian government had been told that its natural gas shipments would be reduced. 
 
Watching 'Very Closely'
Before the meeting, Mr. Bush called the move ''contrary to the approach that we have urged and that others have urged upon the Soviet Union.''
''Obviously, we are watching this situation very, very closely,'' Mr. Bush said. ''We are considering appropriate responses if these threats are implemented.''
But the President refused to elaborate on his comments and concluded by repeating his plea for ''dialogue, discussion and a peaceful resolution of this great difficulty'' in Lithuania. The republic's declaration of independence from the Soviet Union prompted a test of wills that has strained Soviet-American relations just as they seemed to be steadily improving.
 
Meeting With Honduran
The President raised the issue of Lithuania today at a brief photography session in the Oval Office before a meeting with President Rafael Callejas of Honduras. This departure from his usual practice in such meetings signaled that the White House was anxious not to appear to be inactive when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was increasing the pressure on the Lithuanians.
Mr. Bush refused to say what particular options he was considering and other Administration officials also were careful to avoid making specific threats toward the Soviet Union, in part because they are concerned about inflaming already high tensions in the Soviet Union and in part because the Administration believes that in the final analysis, there is little it could do.
Some officials also have argued that taking any action, even the most innocuous, could increase public expectations that Mr. Bush would respond more harshly if the Soviet Union cracked down further on Lithuania and thus propel the Administration toward actions it might not want to take.
 
Under Pressure in Congress
Mr. Bush has come under pressure from some members of Congress to take more forceful action. But after a White House meeting today, Senator George Mitchell, the Democratic leader, signaled that he was satisfied so far with the President's approach and declined to say how he thought Mr. Bush should respond to Moscow's latest move.
Speaking in an interview with Cable News Network, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania also declined to say what he thought Mr. Bush should do. He said only that the United States should make clear that the ''Soviet Union has no right in Lithuania, no constitutional or lawful rights.''
Administration officials said the list of possible responses if Moscow carried out its threat of economic sanctions against Lithuania were reviewed at an interagency meeting here today.
The mildest measures would involve canceling such things as official visits or programs like educational and cultural exchanges. Officials acknowledged that such action is unlikely to hurt Mr. Gorbachev or the Soviet leadership much and that it might be considered inadequate by those who have been pressing Mr. Bush to act more strongly.
 
Economic Area Responses
If Mr. Bush decided on a tougher response, officials said he had the option of suspending or canceling a range of discussions that are planned in the near future on trade and economic initiatives that Mr. Bush offered to Mr. Gorbachev in Malta last December.
''In all reality, the most likely response would be in the economic area, since that's the most logical and has the least widespread potential damage,'' one official said.
In the next several weeks, the Soviet Union and the United States are scheduled to begin a third round of talks on a trade agreement and to open negotiations on expanded civil aviation, maritime transportation and proposed treaties covering investment and tax arrangements.
At Malta, Mr. Bush also pledged to help the Soviet Union gain the status of observer in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade starting in 1991, to work for the lifting of export-import credits and to pursue expanded cooperation in finance, agriculture and other areas. The Soviet-American grain agreement also is on the Lithuanian contingency list, officials said.
 
'Good, the Bad and the Ugly'
In considering its options, an official said, ''The Administration is focusing on this aspect of the relationship first.''
There is strong resistance within the Administration to allowing Lithuania to interfere with the summit, officials said.
''A lot of people want to go through with that summit,'' an official said. ''Any relationship is a mixed thing. There's the good, the bad and the ugly, and you don't sacrifice everything because you have tensions in one area.''
Administration officials argued that the summit should proceed as scheduled since, as one put it, ''it serves a certain function in itself by putting things on the agenda, keeping on the pressure and allowing the relationship to go forward.''

HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICES CLIMBED IN MARCH BY A SHARP 0.5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Consumer prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in March to make the annual inflation rate 8.5 percent for the first three months of 1990, the most rapid increase in a quarter in nearly eight years, the Labor Department reported today.
Higher prices for housing and apparel accounted for more than two-thirds of last month's increase, which was considerably more than most analysts expected and which sent bond prices tumbling.
The widespread assumption among economists today was that the Federal Reserve has lost, at least for the foreseeable future, any leeway it might have had to reduce interest rates and might eventually have to raise them. Recent economic signals, including data today showing strength in industrial output but weakness in housing starts, have left unclear whether the economy is rebounding from slight growth in the final quarter of 1989 or is still in danger of tipping into a recession. 
 
Economic Vigor Suggested
By itself, today's inflation report tends to suggest economic vigor, but if the Federal Reserve was to decide to combat inflation more strenuously, it could raise interest rates and possibly induce a recession.
Most analysts, however, believe the economy is strong enough not to require lower rates and that inflation is not high enough to prompt higher rates. The Federal Reserve is further inhibited from raising rates by the strength of the dollar in currency markets, which is making it difficult for world leaders to coordinate economic policy.
In today's inflation report, some analysts were particularly disconcerted by the fact that the so-called core rate of inflation - the Consumer Price Index excluding food and energy - rose even faster than the index as a whole, by seven-tenths of 1 percent. This meant that the increase could not be easily dismissed, as frequently occurs, by pointing to aberrations such as harsh weather pushing up the price of fuel oil or fresh vegetables.
''You take away the special stuff and you still have a reading on inflation that is not very favorable,'' said Edward F. McKelvey, a senior vice president at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''Inflation is worse than we thought.'' But while economists generally agreed that there was little consolation to be found in today's figures, several suggested that future reports would reflect considerably diminished price pressures.
 
Moderation Cited
Patrick C. Jackman, senior economist in the Labor Department branch that prepares the price index, called the first quarter ''very bad'' but observed that prices of much food and energy had now moderated or turned lower and that the price of apparel - which rose 1.6 percent in March after climbing more than twice that in February on the introduction of higher-priced spring and summer clothing - would almost certainly fall in April.
Mr. Jackman also said a 1 percent rise in homeowners' costs last month, which contributed to a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in the housing category, did not reflect any identifiable factor that would continue to push prices higher.
 
Housing Is 42 Percent
Housing accounts for 42 percent of the price index, with food and transportation almost equally splitting another 35 percent. Apparel and its upkeep represent 6 percent. The other categories are medical, clothing, entertainment and ''other'' goods and services.
Consumer prices are nonetheless rising faster than those at the producer level. The Labor Department last week reported a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods in March.
A big part of the difference, according to some economists, is that 55 percent of the consumer index consists of services, which rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month. That is a 6.3 percent rate of increase for the six months through March.
The producer index, a tabulation of prices received by domestic producers for their goods, contains no directly measured services.
Service jobs have been expanding smartly and, with the nation's unemployment rate of 5.2 percent hovering just above 16-year lows, it appears that a tight labor market is generating cost pressures.
Some of the tightest labor markets are in metropolitan areas where bidding for certain kinds of workers has raised rates of pay substantially and put pressure on prices. Of the five major metropolitan areas for which price data are collected monthly, Philadelphia and New York had by far the biggest increases in March -1.1 percent and 1 percent, respectively. Los Angeles rose seven-tenths of 1 percent; San Francisco, six-tenths, and Chicago, two-tenths.
These wage pressures are likely to be given additional impetus by the April 1 rise in the minimum wage to $3.80, from $3.35 an hour.
Among those stressing the effect of wage pressure on inflation is Kathryn L. Kobe, a vice president of Joel Popkin & Company, a firm named for a former senior Labor Department official who specializes in analyzing inflation. Ms. Kobe predicts the core inflation rate will rise to 5 percent this year, from 4.4 percent in 1989.
 
All Categories Show Rises
All seven of the main Consumer Price Index categories showed price acceleration during the first quarter, making the total the fastest inflation in a quarter since the 10.1 percent posted in the second quarter of 1982. For 1989, the rate was 4.6 percent.
Food and beverage prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March as declines for fruits and vegetables and for dairy products largely offset increases for poultry, pork and eggs.
Transportation, which showed an overall decline of one-tenth of 1 percent, benefited from a 1.4 percent drop in the price of gasoline after an 8.5 percent January-February increase.
