HEADLINE: New Delhi Journal;
A Call to the Downtrodden: Break Down the Door

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, April 17

 BODY:
A brown washcloth in hand to mop his brow under the fiery Indian sun, Kanshi Ram stepped up to the microphones to start a revolution.
Tens of thousands of India's most disadvantaged people - the poor, the powerless, the untouchables - sat along the capital's stately Rajpath boulevard to listen to the message that he asked them to carry to millions more ''in all the corners of India.''
Daring to attack half a century of official self-satisfaction that ''the weaker sections'' were being looked after by those better born, and rejecting the label ''harijan,'' or ''children of God,'' that Mohandas K. Gandhi bestowed on the millions of outcastes who remain victims of Hindu prejudice, Mr. Ram, a 56-year-old former Government scientist, said simply:
''For too long we have been knocking at the doors of the system, asking for justice and getting nothing. It is time to break down those doors. No sacrifice will be too great.'' 
 
'The Party of the Majority'
His message was addressed, he said, to what is potentially the most powerful political force the country has ever known, the 650 million of India's 840 million people who exist outside Hinduism top three caste groupings: Brahmin, Kshatriya and Vaisya. Mr. Ram calls his new political organization the Bahujan Samaj, the Party of the Majority.
Saturday was the beginning of a yearlong commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Bhim Rao Ambedkar, India's first Law Minister and one of the framers of the national Constitution. Mr. Ambedkar was born in untouchability in 1891; his teacher would not handle his books or papers as he sat isolated on a burlap bag at a far corner of the classroom. He died in 1956 still despairing of Hinduism. One of his last acts was to become a Buddhist, along with several hundred thousand followers.
Mr. Ram, saying he is picking up the struggle for social equality where Mr. Ambedkar left off, has given his followers a year - until April 14, 1991, his mentor's birthday - to travel by bicycle all over India spreading the exhortation ''to develop ourselves'' and ''be worthy sons of our father.''
In the next general election, which could occur any time between now and 1994, Mr. Ram, whose followers call him ''the second savior,'' says he will field hundreds of candidates, ''the majority of them Ph.D.'s.''
Mr. Ambedkar, helped by the Maharajah of Baroda, who recognized his brilliance, eventually graduated from Columbia University in 1915 and then from the London School of Economics. He also became a barrister at law at Gray's Inn.
 
An Opponent of Gandhi
His experiences in the United States, where he developed a belief far ahead of his time in the efficacy of social change through law, caused him to oppose Gandhi, a higher-caste Bania, who thought Hindus could be persuaded to change their ways by example.
Gandhi and his Congress Party prevailed. Only now has India, under a non-Congress Government, honored Mr. Ambedkar posthumously with its highest award, the Bharat Ratna.
Mr. Ram, also born an outcaste but educated as a scientist in India, left his Defense Department job in 1965 after becoming involved in another employee's discrimination problems.
''His life changed forever after he read Ambedkar's Caste Annihilation,'' an associate, Arun Choudhury, said. ''He wrote to his mother. It was a 24-page letter that said: I am not coming home. I am not going to marry. I am going to give my life to this cause.''
Mr. Ram, who began his campaign by organizing self-help projects among the educated lower castes in government jobs, was a newcomer to Indian politics when his party came from nowhere to capture three seats in the Indian Parliament in November 1989 and to cut substantially into votes cast for many other candidates.
Within five years, he said in an interview, his Bahujan Samaj could take power through the ballot.
 
Obstacles to Overcome
There are obstacles to overcome. The new party, formed less than a decade ago, is still limited in strength geographically, with most of its support in the populous Hindi-speaking north and New Delhi. Other, often competing, parties draw on the vote of the poor in other parts of India. There are also subcaste antagonisms and personal rivalries to face.
Mr. Ram is in favor of continued affirmative action programs in education and jobs that have given many of the lowest caste and outcaste people better lives. He encourages young people to make the most of these opportunities.
But he is solidly opposed to what are known as ''political reservations'' - the setting aside of certain parliamentary or state-level seats for people who fall into categories called Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. These designations also include members of minority religions, all of whom would be technically outcastes since they are not part of the Hindu universe.
 
Fundamental Changes Sought
Mr. Ram said the political reservation system had created token seats for ''stooges'' of the major parties, all of them controlled by Brahmins or other high-caste people.
The Bahujan Samaj is not ideological. In fact, it has begun to lure young people away from leftist groups because the Communist parties are also dominated by higher castes.
''Our main targets are social transformation and economic emancipation,'' he said. ''But basically, our problem is the unique social system of India.''
''Where Brahminism is a success, no other 'ism' can succeed,'' he said. ''We need fundamental, structural social changes.''

HEADLINE: ALLIES STILL LAG ON ARMS, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
The United States, which spent a larger share of its national income for the military budget in 1988 than virtually all its NATO allies and Japan together, criticized its friends today for not doing enough to close the military spending gap in recent years.
In an annual study of military ''burden sharing,'' the Pentagon cited two of the largest and wealthiest allies, Japan and Canada, for what it called below-par contributions to Western defenses.
But the Pentagon acknowleged that Canada has increased its rate of arms spending in recent years. It also said Japan has significantly increased its military spending and purchases of American military goods since the report was compiled. 
Congress has required the Pentagon to report each year since 1985 on allied contributions to Western arms expenditures. This year's report has added significance, however, because the Pentagon is under new pressure to sharply reduce its commitments under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in light of the reduced Soviet military threat to Europe and the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact.
 
Some U.S. Cutbacks in Process
The United States has already proposed to reduce its Army and Air Force troops in Europe from 305,000 to 225,000, as part of an East-West agreement reducing conventional forces in Europe. Some members of Congress have called for European nations to assume a greater share of NATO military spending to simplify the process of making sharp cuts in Pentagon spending later this decade.
The Pentagon report uses several gauges to measure military spending by the United States and 15 allied nations, and finds ''substantial differences among the burden-sharing and force improvement efforts'' of individual countries.
The United States spent $293.1 billion on defense in 1988, or 60 percent of all military spending by the nations surveyed, according to the report. By comparison, Japan spent $28.9 billion, or 5.9 percent; West Germany spent $35.1 billion, or 7.1 percent; France spent 36.1 billion, or 7.4 percent, and Canada spent $10 billion, or 2 percent.
But when military spending is measured as a percentage of gross domestic product - the sum of all goods and services sold in a nation - the United States, with 6.1 percent devoted to defense, ranks second to Greece, with 6.4 percent.
Britain, Turkey and France also devote relatively large shares of their gross domestic products to military spending, the report said.
 
Pentagon's Heroes and Laggards
The Pentagon report praised Turkey, Greece, Britain and France for contributing relatively more than their share to the common defense, and called Luxembourg, Denmark and Canada as laggards in military spending.
Japan, the only non-European nation included in the survey, is ''substantially below par'' in military spending as measured by the usual indicators, such as percentage of gross domestic product, the report says. But because it is so wealthy, the total amount of money spent by Japan on defense in 1988 - $28.9 billion - is larger than all but a handful of nations.
Japan also purchases more American-made products under the Foreign Military Sales program than any other nation, and more than Italy, Britain, France and West Germany combined, the report stated.
A spokesman for the Canadian Embassy in Washington said today that the Pentagon report contains ''some truth'' in its assessment of the country's arms spending. But the spokesman pointed out that Canada has a relatively small population, and said that its spending appears far more robust when it is measured on a dollars-per-person basis. The report also ignores Canadian contributions of military aid to Turkey, Greece and other poorer NATO members, he said.

HEADLINE: Use of Drugs in Religious Rituals Can Be Prosecuted, Justices Rule

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled today that governments may prosecute those who use illegal drugs as part of religious rituals. It said such prosecutions were not a violation of the constitutional guarantee of religious freedom.
By a vote of 6 to 3, the Court refused to grant two men who are members of an American Indian church a religious exemption from an Oregon law that makes it a crime to possess or use peyote.
The decision, written by Justice Antonin Scalia, has broader implications for the Court's approach to resolving the conflicts that occur with some frequency between individual religious practice and generally applicable government policies. 
The ruling overturned a decision by the Oregon Supreme Court that the First Amendment's protection for the ''free exercise'' of religion required an exemption in state law for the sacramental use of peyote.
 
A 'Desirable' Exemption
Oregon had not sought to prosecute the two men, who used peyote in the rituals of the Native American Church. Rather, the state's employment division refused to pay the men unemployment benefits after they were dismissed from their jobs for using peyote. The state agency said the criminal status of peyote use rendered the men ineligible for the benefits.
Peyote, a cactus that contains the hallucinogenic substance mescaline, has been used for centuries in Indian religious ceremonies. Federal law and the laws of 23 states, including many with substantial Indian populations, exempt the sacramental use of peyote from criminal penalties.
Justice Scalia said such an exemption was permissible, even ''desirable,'' as a choice for legislators to make. But, he added, ''the First Amendment's protection of religious liberty does not require this.''
He noted that the Court ruled more than a century ago that Mormons could be prosecuted for polygamy even though their religion incorporated it. ''We have never held that an individual's religious beliefs excuse him from compliance with an otherwise valid law prohibiting conduct that the State is free to regulate,'' he said.
''It may fairly be said that leaving accommodation to the political process will place at a relative disadvantage those religious practices that are not widely engaged in,'' Justice Scalia said, ''but that unavoidable consequence of democratic government must be preferred to a system in which each conscience is a law unto itself.''
A generally applicable law or regulation that places an incidental burden on religious practice is constitutional, Justice Scalia said, unless it is ''specifically directed'' at a religious act. As an example, he said, a law prohibiting ''bowing down before a golden calf'' would ''doubtless be unconstitutional.''
The majority's analysis drew strong dissents, not only from the three Justices who said the Constitution required an exemption for sacramental peyote use, but also from Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who agreed with the outcome of the case but differed sharply with Justice Scalia's approach.
The three Justices who disagreed with the outcome as well as the approach were Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and William J. Brennan Jr. In her opinion concurring only in the result of the case, Justice O'Connor called the majority opinion ''incompatible with our nation's fundamental commitment to individual religious liberty.''
 
'Vitality' of First Amendment
She added: ''If the First Amendment is to have any vitality, it ought not be construed to cover only the extreme and hypothetical situation in which a state directly targets a religious practice,'' she said.
''The essence of a free exercise claim,'' she said, ''is relief from a burden imposed by government on religious practices or beliefs, whether the burden is imposed directly through laws that prohibit or compel specific religious practices, or indirectly through laws that, in effect, make abandonment of one's own religious or conformity to the religious beliefs of others the price of an equal place in the civil community.
''The history of our free-exercise doctrine amply demonstrates the harsh impact majoritarian rule has had on unpopular or emerging religious groups such as the Jehovah's Witnesses and the Amish.''
In addition to filing their own dissenting opinion, Justices Blackmun, Marshall and Brennan signed much of Justice O'Connor's opinion. All four agreed that the Government must be required to justify a burden on religious practice by demonstrating that it served a ''compelling state interest.''
Justice O'Connor concluded that Oregon could have met that test in this case because of the state's compelling interest in curbing drug use. The three others concluded that the state's interest was not sufficiently compelling.
Justice Scalia's majority opinion rejected the ''compelling state interest'' test, saying it would ''open the prospect of constitutionally required religious exemptions from civic obligations of almost every conceivable kind.''
He said: ''We cannot afford the luxury of deeming presumptively invalid, as applied to a religious objector, every regulation of conduct that does not protect an interest of the highest order.''
The majority opinion, Employment Division v. Smith, No. 88-1213, was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, John Paul Stevens and Anthony M. Kennedy.

HEADLINE: Baby Orphaned but Enriched By Quake Is Going to Cousins

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, April 17

 BODY:
A 10-month-old baby orphaned in the earthquake last Oct. 17 will be raised by second cousins who own a hog farm in the Central Valley town of Chowchilla, a judge announced today, six months to the day since the parents were crushed to death beneath the Nimitz Freeway.
In announcing the custody for Jimmy Brown, after months of hearings and genealogical research, Judge Roderic Duncan of Alameda County Superior Court rejected the claims of two grandparents. Each had charged that the other was unfit to raise the child and collect compensation from the State of California to the baby that could reach a quarter of a million dollars. 
Just hours before the hearing today, the grandparents met with a mediator and accepted the judge's custody decision. They also set up a visitation schedule that will bring Jimmy to the Bay Area for a few days every other month.
The baby has been in Chowchilla with the second cousins, Arthur and Tonia Lewis, since the end of March, when Judge Duncan awarded them temporary custody.
 
Praise for the Family
''Everybody has pulled back and recognized that their own personal wishes are not the most important thing,'' said Judge Duncan, who congratulated the relatives for sparing Jimmy continued conflict.
Jimmy was born to unmarried, unemployed teen-agers in a family in which generations of women have had children out of wedlock and generations of men have served time in jail. The case was closely watched here because of the poignancy of Jimmy's circumstances and the judge's insistence that he hoped to reverse the course of the child's life even if it meant making an unconventional custody choice.
Jimmy has already been awarded $100,000 from the state in compensation for the death of his parents. At a previous hearing, the judge placed that money under the control of the Alameda County's public guardian. Potentially the baby could be awarded hundreds of thousands of dollars more as the state processes other claims from the earthquake.
 
Down the Family Tree
The Chowchilla couple were found by officials of Alameda County Family Court. The officials investigated the grandparents, then looked further into the family tree for a suitable home for Jimmy. The Lewises, who have a 5-year-old daughter, run a 50-acre hog farm halfway between Modesto and Fresno, in the rich farm belt that runs through central California.
Arthur Lewis, 30 years old, is a cousin of Jimmy's late mother, Michelle Marie Richard, although apparently Mr. Lewis has had little contact with other members of the family. He was in the courtroom today, but declined comment except to say that the baby was ''doing wonderful.''
The main petitioners for custody had been Anita Williams, Jimmy's 35-year-old maternal grandmother, and James Brown 2d, the baby's 37-year-old paternal grandfather. Ms. Williams is raising her own children on welfare and during court proceedings was accused of consorting with drug-abusing men. Mr. Brown, who runs a landscaping and hauling business, is on parole after a prison term for grand theft.
Also seeking custody of the infant were Vickie Reed, Mr. Brown's former wife, who is Jimmy's paternal grandmother, and Gerald Brown, an Army major who is Jimmy's uncle.

HEADLINE: Black Militancy

 BODY:
In Milwaukee, a black alderman has called for a black militia to wage ''urban guerrilla warfare'' - actual violence - unless ''racial parity'' is achieved in the city by 1995. In Teaneck, N.J., black youths angered by the killing of a black teen-ager by police erupted in violence after a prayer vigil.
In Harlem, the pastor of a famous black church is campaigning to paint over billboards carrying cigarette and liquor ads because, he feels, blacks are disproportionately victimized by both tobacco and alcohol. And in Brooklyn, a black neighborhood is boycotting a Korean grocer for allegedly abusing his black customers. 
In American cities and some suburbs as well, a new militancy is evident among African-Americans. It takes different forms, not always laudable. But each instance is a reminder of an old agenda overshadowed by the thawing of the cold war and forgotten by all except those whose circumstances won't let them forget.
Milwaukee is a case in point. Alderman Michael McGee's call for a black militia was actually a dramatic attempt to call the city's attention to the desperate situation of African-Americans there. The first item on his list of three demands was a $100 million emergency jobs program. That's jobs, not welfare - or certainly no more welfare than is involved in the jobs of featherbedding union members or business executives on golden parachutes. The emergency is clear. While the overall unemployment in Milwaukee is about 5 percent, it's 25 percent among blacks. And 40 percent of Milwaukee's blacks live in poverty.
What justifies his militancy, says Mr. McGee, is not just desperation but Milwaukee's ability to act decisively when it wants to. He points to the city's exertions on behalf of its sports teams, including a baseball stadium that could cost $100 million.
The same sort of densely compacted, highly distilled poverty and disadvantage exist in virtually every American city. And as the recent events in Teaneck indicate, the problems for blacks, including poor relations with police, don't end with affluence and a move to suburbia.
Talk of armed militias understandably frightens many people. But those who listen will hear a cry of anguish over unyielding poverty, joblessness, bad education and health care; a demand for compassion leading to practical help, and a determination not to settle for a degrading status quo.

HEADLINE: Believe It, the Deficit Affects Interest Rates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Rostenkowski Plan: A G.O.P. Triumph'' (Op-Ed, March 15), Paul Craig Roberts again rejects sound economic science with his denial that budget deficits affect interest rates -specifically, in denying that balancing the United States budget would reduce interest rates.
In rebuttal to this virtually self-evident thesis, he asks: ''Why do West Germany, with its trade surplus, and Britain, with its budget surplus,'' have higher interest rates than the United States? 
The simple answer is that interest-rate determinants are complex. Real inflation in Britain and feared inflation in inflation-phobic West Germany explain their higher interest rates. Since each national economy carries its own economic configurations, the scientific question is this: What happens, other factors assumed equal, to Britain's, or Germany's or America's, interest rates when budget deficits rise?
Economic logic decrees that, in strict accordance with the law of supply and demand, interest rates rise when budget deficits rise. This virtually axiomatic truth can be demonstrated by linear regression analyses of United States interest rates. Such analyses show definite correlations between mortgage rates, corporate bond rates, Treasury bond rates and Federal budget deficits.
Mr. Roberts tacitly recognizes the critical role of the law of supply and demand when he warns that ''raising taxes could put the economy in the tank.'' Why? Because the consequently reduced income could reduce demand for goods and services.
The same law operates in the money markets. When borrowers compete for a budget-reduced pool of lendable dollars, the price of money - i.e., the interest rate - tends to rise. Significantly, this basic economic truth is rejected only by the Reagan Administration's supply-side ideologues.
 
C. W. GRIFFIN
Phoenix, April 2, 1990

HEADLINE: A New Service Begins at Stewart Airport

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y., April 17

 BODY:
American Airlines Flight 793, seven minutes late but its 118 seats filled, roared out of Stewart International Airport for Chicago today, the first regularly scheduled passenger service in the history of this former Air Force base 60 miles north of New York City.
Amid champagne, speeches and drumrolls, state and local officials gave the maiden flight a festive send-off. Officials hope the service will help relieve congestion at the metropolitan region's three major airports and help the economy of the Hudson Valley.
''If you look at the greater New York region, the only place left for expansion is the Hudson Valley,'' said Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development. 
This first step toward Stewart's development as a commercial airport is small: American is offering three daily flights to Chicago and three to Raleigh, N.C. But it comes in the face of continued opposition from a coalition of environmental organizations, including the Sierra Club and Scenic Hudson.
The coalition has sued New York State, demanding a comprehensive environmental review of the new air service and the proposed development of some 1,500 acres of state-owned land around the airport.
A State Supreme Court justice has ruled in favor of the coalition, but the state has appealed the decision.
 
'Intelligent Decisions' Asked
Carol Sondheimer, associate director of Scenic Hudson of Poughkeepsie, said the public had a right ''to have the full ramifications of the largest development project in the Hudson Valley clearly and completely laid out, so we can make intelligent decisions about our future.''
Today, however, there was an air of possibility as officials reviewed the credentials of the state-owned airport, which has been used only by cargo carriers, the Air and Marine National Guards and private jet owners, including Donald J. Trump and Bill Cosby. In area, the 10,000-acre airport, just west of Newburgh, is the second largest in the nation, behind Dallas-Fort Worth.
Stewart's 11,818-foot main runway -2,518 feet longer than Newark International Airport's top runway, but 2,754 feet shorter than Kennedy International's - can handle the largest jetliners. And the state has proposed transforming as many as 1,500 acres into a series of light industrial and office parks.
In addition the airport is near two highways: the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and Interstate 84. Land has been set aside for a second major terminal. The airport also has foreign trade zone status, meaning that goods coming through are not subject to Federal customs duties.
A spokesman for American Airlines, Ed Stewart, said flights for the next month were ''more than 80 percent booked, which is much higher than any of us projected.''
 
Airline Wins Concessions
After months of negotiations with the state, American announced last October that it would begin flying out of Stewart. The state won over the airline by offering six extra gates at Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark and by waiving the state sales tax on materials bought in New York for the addition to the passenger terminal.
Initially American Airlines will offer three round trips a day on Boeing 727's to Chicago and Raleigh-Durham.
While Mr. Tese played down Stewart's potential as a multi-carrier hub -''If another airline comes in here, that's fine,'' he said, ''but we're not thinking long-range'' - other state officials were more blunt. ''We're talking to all of the airlines all of the time,'' said Russell B. Vachon, the Director of Aviation with the State Department of Transportation.
 
Easier Driving Reported
The assumption is that many people who live in the half-dozen counties of the Hudson Valley region, as well as some in northern New Jersey, are tired of fighting traffic to reach La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark. A sampling of the passengers boarding the 12:50 P.M. flight today seemed to bear that out.
''The key is not the distance, but the driving time,'' said Bob Scherreik of Bloomingdale, N.J., the general manager of McBride Corporate Real Estate in Harriman, N.Y.
''It takes me an hour and a half to drive 30 miles from my home in Bergen County to Newark during rush hour. It takes only 45 to 50 minutes to get to Stewart, and there really aren't any rush hours here.''
Michael J. DiTullo, president of the Orange County Partnership, a quasi-public corporation that coordinates economic development for the county, said passenger service was essential to attract businesses.
But it is the airport's potential service as a catalyst for growth, not only around the airport but throughout the Hudson Valley, that troubles many residents and environmental groups.
Only 2,000 acres are now used for aviation purposes, and an 8,000-acre buffer zone is valued as open space for hikers and hunters. The state has targeted a maximum of 1,500 acres in the buffer zone for possible development over the next 20 years.
Six proposals, ranging from no development to development of the full 1,500 acres, are now the subject of an environmental review, overseen by the Department of Transportation and the Federal Aviation Administration.
''We're seeking a balance between preservation and controlled growth,'' said Stephen M. Finkle, the director of economic development for Stewart International Airport at the state's Urban Development Corporation.
 
Rubber-Stamping Charged
But environmentalists, who charge that the state ''rubber-stamped'' the passenger-service expansion a year ago, argue that any development must be reviewed in light of the increased flights.
''The development in the buffer zone and the expansion of the airport ought to be studied together in one comprehensive document,'' said Michael S. Elder, a partner in the law firm of Elder & Long in Kingston, who represents the Stewart Park and Reserve Coalition, one of the plaintiffs.
''This is the state's effort to take an unproductive piece of property from a financial point of view and turn it into a money-making operation,'' Mr. Elder said. ''It's sad that money is the primary objective here and that the environmental review is secondary.''

HEADLINE: METRO DATELINES;
The News Is Accused Of Unfair Practices

DATELINE: MANHATTAN

 BODY:
The largest union at The Daily News struck back at the paper's management yesterday, accusing it of 10 separate instances of unfair labor practices in violation of Federal law.
The accusations, filed with the National Labor Relations Board by the Newspaper Guild of New York, came a day after The News said it had halted its practice of deducting union dues from employees' paychecks. 
Barry F. Lipton, president of the Guild, which represents nearly 800 news, advertising and clerical workers at the paper, asserted that the management was refusing to bargain in good faith or to honor its contractual obligations, including the dues checkoff. A spokesman for the paper, John T. Sloan, said there would be no immediate comment by The News.
The News, which terminated its contracts with all 10 unions at the paper last week, has said that apart from wages and benefits, it was no longer legally bound to observe most provisions of the previous agreements, which expired March 30. Management has tied the paper's economic survival to the need for sweeping work-rule concessions by the unions and has vowed to continue publishing in the event of a strike.
Mr. Lipton and other union leaders said they had arranged for alternative methods of collecting dues from the paper's 2,466 unionized workers, including having the employees' credit union deduct the money from paychecks. There will also be various forms of direct billing, they said.

HEADLINE: Witness Calls Commissions Routine in Marcos Dealings

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
A Philippine shipping executive, testifying at the racketeering trial of Imelda Marcos, said yesterday that he paid more than $25 million in commissions as a routine part of doing business with the Philippine Government.
The executive said he was instructed to deliver the money, not to the Government, but to a man who has been described by prosecutors as ''the Marcoses' personal Swiss banker.''
The executive, Jose M. Reyes, said he paid the money over a 10-year period while Ferdinand Marcos was the Philippine President, and that as soon as Mr. Marcos was forced from power in February 1986, most of those payments were no longer required.
Mr. Reyes did not say the commissions went directly to an account owned by Mrs. Marcos or her husband, nor did he suggest that the money was spent improperly, but his testimony seemed to enhance one of the prosecution's chief contentions: The Marcoses amassed a huge fortune by covertly sending money to foreign banks. 
 
The Economy Was in Crisis
Mrs. Marcos is charged with stealing more than $222 million from the Philippines and through a variety of channels around the world, investing most of the money in four Manhattan buildings.
Gerry Spence, Mrs. Marcos's lawyer, noted that the payments made by Mr. Reyes were made in the late 1970's and early 80's while the Philippine economy was in crisis. The money, he said, was deposited in Swiss accounts to help the Phillipine Government secure Swiss loans.
Mr. Spence also said that the Aquino Government had dropped the commissions in exchange for his testimony.
It was another uneven, difficult day for Mrs. Marcos and Mr. Spence, who has tangled several times with Judge John F. Keenan of Federal District Court in Manhattan.
 
'Go Away From the Bench'
In a lengthy session yesterday morning, Mr. Spence questioned Dr. Angelita Reyes, Mr. Reyes's wife, who testified about documents belonging to the Marcoses that she had reviewed for the Aquino Government. When Mr. Spence asked her to identify a document that he held up from about 20 feet away, Judge Keenan interrupted, saying, ''How in the world is she going to be able to identify that?''
Mr. Spence, citing the laughter that erupted in the courtroom, asked the judge to refrain from chastising him.
Strangely, it was in Mr. Spence's cross-examination of Mr. Reyes yesterday that the shipping executive said the payments he made totaled $25 million. He said he paid the money while doing business with the Philippine National Oil Corporation, which is owned by the Government.
 
Accounts in Switzerland
Mr. Reyes said that he paid from $100,000 to $200,000 for each trip and that with few exceptions, those payments have stopped.
The commissions, he said, were paid to accounts in the name of Stephane Cattaui, who worked for Banque Paribas in Switzerland. An assistant United States Attorney, Debra A. Livingston, had said in her opening statment that Mr. Cattaui had arranged the Marcoses purchase of the Crown Building at 730 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street.
Mr. Reyes said that as of Feb. 26, 1986, when the Marcoses left Manila, he stopped making the payments, except for shipping he does for the Philippine International Trading Corporation.
In unrelated testimony, Mr. Reyes's wife, Angelita, said that two days after the Marcoses left Manila, she went to the Malacanang Palace, the president's residence, to pick up documents.
One of the documents, she said, was a contract between Mrs. Marcos and the Swiss Credit Bank. The name Jane Ryan appeared on the first page of the documents, with the notation pseudonym. Underneath was the name, Imelda Romualdez Marcos, followed by the notation true name.

HEADLINE: European Officials Dispute Bush Over Global Warming

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
President Bush called today for more research into the scientific and economic ramifications of global warming linked to pollution, but several European officials attending a conference here argued for more concrete and prompt action as well.
The differences over how quickly to proceed highlighted the opening session of a two-day conference called by the White House to discuss research into the scientific and economic uncertainties surrounding the issue of the warming of the earth.
In his speech, Mr. Bush urged environmental ministers and other delegates from 18 nations to consider the economic consequences while drawing up policies to deal with the problem.
The delegates, Mr. Bush said, should ''sort out the science on this complex issue'' as well as explore ''the links between our environmental well-being and our economic welfare.'' 
 
'An Excuse' for Inaction
But West Germany's Minister for the Environment, Klaus Topfer, said in a statement today, ''Worldwide action against the climatic threat is urgently required, even if the complicated scientific interrelationships of climatic change have not all been fully understood.'' He added, ''Gaps in knowledge must not be used as an excuse for worldwide inaction.''
The disagreement comes at a potentially embarrassing time for the Administration as several nations, including the United States, focus on pollution and environmental issues in advance of Earth Day next Sunday.
In the last year, there has been considerable debate within the Bush Administration over how quickly to respond to potential global warming. William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, at first urged a specific commitment to reduce carbon dioxide, which is produced by the burning of fossil fuels and is thought to contribute to global warming.
But the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and other officials opposed such a move. At this point the entire Administration, including Mr. Reilly, appears to have closed ranks behind Mr. Sununu's more cautious approach.
Many scientists now predict that climate shifts will occur in the next century as the gases in the atmosphere retain radiation from the sun that would otherwise be reflected back into space. But in his speech to the conference, Mr. Bush made it plain that more research was necessary and that actions to deal with the situation should be weighed against economic consequences.
''Environmental policies that ignore the economic factor, the human factor, are bound to fail,'' Mr. Bush declared.
Several officials of major European nations attending the White House Conference on Science and Economics Research Related to Global Change, said it was time for action to reduce the pollution, mainly from carbon dioxide, that is expected to cause the earth to warm in the next century.
West Germany, the Netherlands and France, disclosed their own plans for unilateral action to reduce their emissions of carbon dioxide.
Bert Bolin, the Swede who is chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said in an interview, ''This conference avoided bringing up certain issues such as how do you get an effective decision-making process without too much delay.'' He said that while there was a need for research, ''it must be in parallel with action.''
In his remarks, Mr. Bush said the conference was intended to help speed the efforts of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a panel of experts organized by the United Nations Environmental Program and the World Meteorological Organization. The panel has been given the task of assessing the state of science with regard to global warming and to recommend possible international responses.
Other Administration officials who addressed the plenary sessions held today, sounded similar themes. They included Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; D. Allan Bromley, Assistant to the President for Science and Technology; Michael R. Deland, chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality, and Mr. Reilly, the E.P.A. administrator.
Several noted that the United States had committed $1 billion to research into global warming and that Mr. Bush had agreed to act as host to a meeting to plan a framework treaty for international cooperation to deal with the problem.
Dr. Topfer of West Germany said he had prepared a proposal for his Government's cabinet that would reduce his country's emissions of carbon dioxid, by at least 25 percent by the year 2005. He said the cabinet would take up the issue before its summer recess.
Per Villinga, who is in charge of global warming issues in the Netherlands environmental ministry, said his country was planning to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions by 5 percent by the end of the decade.
Mr. Villinga told reporters on Monday that his country believed this conference should discuss policy as well as research and said that the economic problems may be exaggerated.
Brice Lalond, the French Environmental Minister, said his country had set a goal of reducing per capita emissions of carbon dioxide, now 2.3 tons a year per person, to 1.7 tons. He did not say when France hoped to achieve that goal.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Modest University in Florida Is Blazing a Trail For Blacks to Careers in the World of Business

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.

 BODY:
A bespectacled young man, beaming in a double-breasted suit, thrust out his hand at a reception here. ''Matthew Bowman,'' he said. ''I'm a business administration major at FAM U., and I'm from Fayetteville, N.C.'' Without pause, he produced a business card with his school address, his home address and his telephone numbers. ''What brings you here?'' he asked. At the School of Business and Industry at Florida A&M University, Mr. Bowman's attire and his welcoming speech are routine; only the card is optional. These and bigger things -like annual three-month internships at major companies and training in persuasion, adapting to change and jockeying for power - are a part of an unusual approach to teaching business at this predominantly black university, and one that some major American companies say the top business schools would do well to emulate.
While many companies are paring management and curbing hiring because of the soft economy, recruiters from Eastman Kodak, Hewlett-Packard, Champion International, Pepsico, Merck, General Motors, Procter & Gamble and Amoco are pouring through Florida A&M's business school handing out job offers.
Recruiters say the school's blend of a business curriculum with grooming in the methods and manners of business is at least as appealing as the fact that the students are skimmed from the top ranks of 40 states' high schools, or the fact that almost all of the 1,150 students are black. 
In addition to about 250 bachelor's degrees in business, the School of Business and Industry expects to award 80 to 90 M.B.A.'s this year, up from 30 last year and 14 the year before. The school's dean and creator, Sybil C. Mobley, is trying to steer Florida A&M into the ranks of the business school elite.
This seems a quixotic ambition for an institution of otherwise modest dimensions. The university is not even accredited by the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business. It cannot meet some standards for accreditation because of its limited resources: it has a tiny endowment of less than $10 million, is short of faculty, and does not offer some basic business courses, like marketing.
For its undergraduates, the concentration on business behavior means it cannot provide as big a dose of liberal arts courses as most undergraduate business schools do. A freshman complained that Florida A&M does not offer courses in the language of the nation's No. 1 economic rival, Japan. And rather than stay here for a fifth year to get an M.B.A., some students move on to schools like Wharton or Northwestern because they believe those M.B.A. degrees carry more weight. 'Ready to Go Right to the Job' But in the judgment of many of those who hire business school students, Florida A&M's training in business behavior more than compensates for its shortcomings.
''The difference among these students is that they are ready to go right to the job,'' said Barbara Recchia, a recruiter who was here recently for Hewlett-Packard, which hired six graduates for career jobs last year and nine more as interns.
''We've identified this as one of our key business schools for students of finance,'' Ms. Recchia said. ''FAM U. is in the top five.''
B. Lawrence Branch, who led a team here from Merck, the pharmaceuticals company, said: ''We are looking for certain skills at Wharton, Columbia, Carnegie-Mellon and FAM U. FAM U. is providing the same caliber of student the others are.''
Among this year's objects of recruiters' blandishments is Seralyn Pink, a 23-year-old master's degree candidate. Ms. Pink said she was juggling four offers at salaries ranging from $40,000 to $60,000 - right in line with offers to Harvard and Stanford M.B.A.'s - and she said two included job-signing bonuses of $2,500 and $4,000. ''Money is secondary,'' she said. ''I'm interested in the job and upward mobility.''
Darryl Jordan, 23, a candidate for a bachelor's degree, said he had had offers of $25,000 to $30,000 from Dow Chemical, Barnett Banks of Florida, the Bank of Boston, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing before accepting one from Atlantic Richfield. ''When I came here I was a jock,'' he said. ''I couldn't speak to people.''
That the students are black matters to companies, the recruiters say, but not so much because of moral considerations or affirmative action programs. The companies say they are driven by hard-core business reasons; they are suffering a post-baby-boom shortage of talented managers, they like Florida A&M's training in business behavior, and they want culturally diverse executive staffs to master an increasingly diverse marketplace.
Barbara J. Laski, vice president and treasurer of Capital Holding, a big financial services concern in Louisville, said: ''The days of affirmative action and equal employment opportunity left a bad taste among some companies. That has evolved into thinking that as an organization, you have to value diversity.''
In teaching methods of maneuvering in management, like vying for top management's ear, competing for slices of the corporate budget, winning others over in developing a new product, she said, ''there is not anything that comes close to FAM U.'' Reading and Dress With Eye on Career Business Week or The Wall Street Journal are required reading for freshmen, after which the students are presumably hooked. A visitor saw only six earrings on men (and three were on one ear). Men and women, who are in a majority at the school, wear conservative suits one or two days a week when they listen to speeches given by the chief executives of leading companies and join them in seminars. At such times, the suits are mandatory, but there is no formal dress code. The business dress is part of a culture that the faculty and the upperclass students inspire.
The woman who devised this novel approach to business education is Dean Mobley, whom business leaders call an extraordinary promoter and scholar. The 64-year-old dean spends part of every week on the road, visiting chief executives and cajoling them to come speak at the school -with the expectation that once they see it, they will send money and recruiting teams, and advise her on curriculum changes to keep the school abreast of their needs.
Dean Mobley, who has an M.B.A. from Wharton and a doctorate in accounting from the University of Illinois, worked as a clerk-typist at Florida A&M, after getting her degrees, became an accounting teacher, then head of the business department, and then dean when the department became an autonomous school 16 years ago.
Early on, she said, she found that her graduates were struggling in their jobs, so she went to see their bosses and asked, ''What is the instrument by which you decide who makes it and who doesn't?'' It turned out to be the evaluation form. ''So we sent out for evaluation forms from 100 companies,'' she said, ''and they were all consistent.''
The forms, she said, asked supervisors to assess subordinates' technical knowledge and ability to apply it, their written and oral communication, their teamwork skills and their social graces. She said business schools, including her own, were sending out graduates who were trained in only one category, technical knowledge.
''So,'' she continued, ''we went to other business schools and said, 'How do you prepare your students for this and for that?' They said, 'We don't.' So we said, 'How could we in good conscience neglect these things, when we are the only people in control of four or five years of the students' lives?' ''
In the years since, Dean Mobley has constructed a two-track curriculum, one devoted to conventional business courses, the other devoted to personal development.
In one class, for example, George R. Auzenne, the assistant dean, requires that freshmen write him a one-page letter the first day, a two-page letter the second, a three-page letter the third. Thus starts a long process in business communication.
Freshmen are also instructed to buy a blank book and collect autographs from students and faculty. No one signs until the student introduces himself as Mr. Bowman did at the reception.
''Now what are we doing there?'' said Amos Bradford, a professor of organizational behavior. ''We're trying to teach one of the first steps in interpersonal competence. Dress is important. How you persuade is important. How you impact with your peers is important.'' Mock Corporations: A Flavor of Reality To give students a flavor of business organization, the school has established seven mock corporations, with seniors serving as chief executives and presidents and lower classmen filling lower management ranks where they vie for promotion. One company prepares and manages visitors' itineraries; another drills students in writing, public speaking and personal appearance; a third handles public relations and publications; a fourth manages a small shopping center the school owns.
''You feel you're in the corporate world,'' said LaDeidra Ellis, 22, a senior from Ocala, Fla. ''It's the way you begin to think.''
A vital part of the program is the internship. Students go off to three-month paying jobs three or four times in their years at the school, rarely to the same company or the same part of the country. During the internships, management sizes up the students for permanent jobs, and the students size up management.
Irene Jones, 22, a senior who has taken a job at the Deloitte & Touche accounting firm, spent one internship at another company. ''I noticed that my supervisor had been in the same job for 17 years,'' she said, a sign that she could be stymied there, too. Determination To Accept Challenge Students say they have no qualms about joining a business establishment that blacks have often reviled for discrimination and exploitation.
''Some people might see this as selling out,'' said Alisa Mosley, 20, a sophomore who ranked first in her class at Dunbar High School in Fort Worth. ''Others see it as getting the tools you need to deal with the world.''
LaTonia Davis, 21, a senior undergraduate, added: ''I know who I am, If you know who you are, you don't have to run around in a dashiki. There's a time to do that and a time to wear a suit.''
It is too soon to tell how Dean Mobley's progeny will do in the upper ranks of management, since her first graduates are under 40 years of age, generally the threshold for promotion to senior jobs. But some seem well on their way.
Ronald E. DeNard graduated seven years ago and went to Alcoa, where he is now cash manager for the company's subsidiaries. He has been moved three times, from Cleveland to Chicago to Pittsburgh, and been promoted four times. Dean Mobley's business school served him well, he said: ''I wouldn't change a thing.''

HEADLINE: Star Chefs Find Themselves On the Outside Looking In

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
BY the early 1980's, as restaurant mania began to build, chefs became celebrities. And like star baseball players, if a kitchen home-run king left one restaurant team, there was always a more lucrative contract waiting.
But in the last year or two the business has slowed and established restaurants have started fighting for customers who seem less willing to spend large sums dining out. Fewer expensive restaurants are being built as monuments to chefs' and owners' egos, especially in New York. Now when talented young chefs leave jobs, they have no guarantee of finding better positions.
Recently many head chefs left well-known New York restaurants not knowing where their next kitchens would be. Geoffrey Zakarian of 44 in the Hotel Royalton, Thomas Keller of Rakel, Michel Attali of Petrossian and Ali Barker of 150 Wooster Street have spent weeks, even months, sitting on the bench. 
Others had plans that did not quite work out. Brendan Walsh, highly acclaimed for his Southwestern cooking at Arizona 206 when he left there in January 1989, had a deal to open a restaurant in SoHo. When that fell through last August, he had no prospect for another project in Manhattan. He is making his debut Friday as chef at the new Coyote Grill in Island Park, L.I.
Another talented chef, Bob Pritsker did not reopen his restaurant, Brive, after its usual summer vacation last year. He had been unable to attract enough customers for his very personal interpretation of haute cuisine. He said that he was unsure of his next move but that he is likely to cook again, although he is also a lawyer and has a graduate business degree.
''I don't remember a situation like this, with five or six lionized chefs out of work,'' said Alan Reyburn, a restaurant consultant and recruiter. ''Each is hopeful of reassignment exploring possibilities but there aren't enough new restaurants to snap them up.''
Other prominent chefs no longer cooking in New York include Alain Sailhac, formerly of the Plaza, who is now in France, and Jonathan Waxman of Jams who is now working in Aspen, Colo.
Not all chefs are having these problems. Seppi Renggli, the former executive chef at the Four Seasons, said he has received several offers since becoming a consultant there three weeks ago.
Experts say the New York scenario has not played out in other cities. Market Watch, a monthly trade publication for the wine, spirits and beer industry, recently suggested that the restaurant industry in Los Angeles had become saturated and is slowing. But as yet there are no star chefs without kitchens.
''New York became a restaurant mecca almost overnight in the 1980's,'' said Marc Sarrazin, owner of De Bragga & Spitler, a wholesale butcher, who often helps chefs obtain jobs. ''There was a glut. Now it has become time to re-evaluate. There are fewer investors.''
Mr. Sarrazin said once-typical salary offers in the $75,000-to-$90,000 range are extremely scarce now and he is seeing offers of around $45,000 for chefs.
The chefs without portfolio tend to agree about the reasons for their situation. ''People are less eager to commit the kind of capital it takes, the millions needed to establish a place and keep it going on a sound basis for a couple of years,'' Mr. Zakarian said.
He had planned to leave 44 in May to open his own restaurant but quit in early March in what he characterized as a dispute with management over the quality of the service. Nancy Robinson, the manager of 44, said, ''We were all frustrated about the service, but Geoffrey did not give us a chance to work it out.''
Mr. Zakarian took his sous-chef, Patrick Robertson, and the pastry chef, Melissa De Mayo, with him for his yet-undetermined venture.
Mr. Attali said he left Petrossian in September because word was out that he was planning to open his own place. He said that he was still optimistic that the project, an elaborate caviar restaurant and shop in midtown Manhattan, will materialize, but that finding investors to put up the $5 million needed has been a struggle. ''Some people say it's nuts, but we think there's a market for it,'' Mr. Attali said.
If investors are more cautious these days, so are the chefs. ''The past three months have been like a crash course in real estate, investments and law,'' Mr. Zakarian said. ''There's so much fine print in this business.''
Other chefs, among them Mr. Walsh, Mr. Keller and Mr. Barker, have also learned that talent at the stove is not enough. Mr. Walsh said he walked away from the Hudson Street deal because the financing did not seem sound.
''I didn't want to wind up in a situation where the suppliers won't deliver the food because the bills aren't paid,'' he said. ''And I didn't want to be personally liable for someone else's financial nightmare.''
Mr. Barker left 150 Wooster Street at the end of November after disagreements with Brian McNally, the owner. Both say that there were problems and that Mr. Barker would have left sooner or later. He is now executive chef for the restaurant that is opening in late May in the new Macklowe Hotel on West 44th Street.
Lydia Shire, former executive chef of the Four Seasons Hotel in Beverly Hills, devoted more than a year to setting up her Boston restaurant, Biba. She said the experience amounted to a business education. ''When you're working for someone else you don't get involved in these kinds of details,'' she said.
Even Mr. Renggli of the Four Seasons is carefully considering the proposals before him.
Steve Zagor, manager of restaurant consulting for Laventhol & Horwatch, an accounting and consulting firm, said: ''Chefs have to be more cautious than in the past because there are no guarantees that the up-side will be there these days. They have to look closely at the capitalization and management side.''
Mr. Keller left Rakel, where he was the chef and an owner, in November in a dispute with his partner, Serge Raoul, over the restaurant's direction. But he said he is still liable for about $250,000 in financing.
''People say I was unwilling to compromise on my food,'' he said. ''But I'm not convinced that merely downscaling the food and prices could solve the restaurant's problems.''
The fiduciary conservativism of investors and chefs has been generated to a great extent by the public mood. ''Customers have more choices and they have become more selective about where they want to spend their money,'' Mr. Reyburn said.
Many owners have lowered prices and recast restaurants as bistros, a notion that infuriates some chefs and consultants, who regard it as a faddish makeshift solution. Mr. Zagor said the public was looking for more value, not just a smaller check. ''There are expensive places that deliver value and there'll always be an audience for that kind of experience,'' he said. ''These days we can probably count on good food, but the quality of service will make the difference between success and failure.''
But he added that sometimes chefs concentrated too much on the kitchen and not enough on service. ''They all have egos,'' Mr. Reyburn said. ''But perhaps it's time for them to be a little less impatient.''
Mr. Keller, for one, said he was redefining his focus and might put some goals on hold. Meanwhile, he misses the kitchen. ''I really need to be in a public arena,'' he said.
Mr. Reyburn also suggested that these chefs might find it increasingly difficult to reintroduce themselves into the New York restaurant world as time went on. Some chefs worry about that, too.
''I may lose something by being away for a period of time, but I'm here for the long term and I'll be back,'' Mr. Walsh said. ''I love the power of running a big kitchen and seeing it click.''
A number of experts suggested that because a number of established locations were on the market at lowered rents, this is a sensible time to think about starting a restaurant in New York. ''You can also pick up equipment for less,'' Mr. Zagor added, ''and your start-up costs are lower. Now there's a chance for rebirth.''
Mr. Walsh plans to open a restaurant in New York in the future with his new backer, John Vitale, the owner of Coyote Grill and an adjacent restaurant, Paddy McGee's.
Other chefs, notably Mr. Zakarian and Mr. Keller, have explored opportunities outside New York but see New York as the place to be.
''Everyone still dreams of opening an economically viable 125-seat restaurant in midtown,'' Mr. Walsh said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Consumer prices climbed by 0.5 percent in March to make the annual inflation rate 8.5 percent for the first three months of 1990, the most rapid quarterly increase in nearly eight years, the Labor Department reported. [Page A1.]
 
Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell by 11.3 percent in early April. [D2.] 
 
Industrial production rose by 0.7 percent in March, the Fed reported, in a second consecutive strong showing that led analysts to suggest that the manufacturing recession may have ended. [D4.]
 
Housing starts continued to fall in March from their January peak, the Commerce Department reported. [D4.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Citicorp earnings fell 56.3 percent because of bad loans. Earnings were up at Wells Fargo and NCNB. [D1.]
 
Eastern's creditors and management presented sharply different views of a trustee running the airline. [D3.]
 
McDonald's will buy recycled materials worth up to $100 million for building and remodeling its restaurants. [D14.]
 
Four of the nation's 10 largest local telephone companies reported modest increases in sales and profits. [D3.] United Telecom will become the Sprint Corporation. [D3.]
 
Great American Bank sharply increased its estimate of losses from soured loans, making it a likely candidate for seizure. [D15.]
 
The abrupt replacement of National Geographic's editor appears likely to alter the magazine's course. [D17.]
 
Paine Webber reported a 17.4 percent profit rise, but the gains came against a weak quarter a year earlier on Wall Street. [D19.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Deutsche Bank announced a joint venture to give it control over roughly a third of the banking network in East Germany. [D1.]
 
The Justice Department froze hundreds of U.S. bank accounts suspected of having been used to hide nearly $400 million in Colombian drug profits. [D1.]
 
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY
 
Most Americans will not see new less-polluting gasolines at local pumps for at least three years because of a shortage of a crucial additive. [D1.]
 
Digital Equipment has developed a system for cleaning electrical equipment that will help the ozone layer. [D5.]
 
MARKETS
 
A former stock speculator was sentenced to four months in prison and fined $1 million for insider trading, closing the Government's most difficult Wall Street corruption case. [D1.]
 
The S.E.C. censured Donaldson, Lufkin and suspended one of its managing directors for 45 days for the alleged, systematic misuse of securities belonging to customers for the firm's own profit. [D1.]
 
The Dow, after dropping 21 points, fought back steadily for a gain of 2.71, to 2,765.77. [D6.]
 
The bond market was rocked by the consumer price report, and prices of Treasury securities tumbled in heavy trading. [D12.]
 
Two influential OPEC ministers reportedly agreed to reduce production to try to restore oil prices to their benchmark level of $18 a barrel. [D13.] The dollar ended lower. [D13.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
In the U.S.-Japanese trade drama, narrowing the gap between savings and investment might make a difference. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
Buyout fever is about to sweep Europe - that, at least, is the hope of a number of new funds. Market Place. [D6.]
 
The 1990's may turn out to be the age of ''melding,'' one advertising analyst says. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D17.]

HEADLINE: Citicorp Earnings Drop 56.3%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that problems with real estate loans and loans for corporate takeovers caused its earnings to fall 56.3 percent in the first quarter, to $231 million, from $529 million a year ago.
Other regional banking companies announced strong gains in earnings. The NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., grew rapidly enough to raise earnings despite more real estate problems. Earnings also rose at Wells Fargo & Company, San Francisco, which is a heavy lender for real estate and corporate takeovers, but has managed to avoid making loans that turn sour. 
 
Problems Expected
As the nation's largest lender for real estate, Citicorp has not avoided lending to projects in regions where a glut of new buildings has caused prices to fall and made some developers unable to repay their loans. Problems with real estate loans began increasing more than a year ago, and Citicorp executives have warned investors that they expected problems to grow this year.
''The key question for Citicorp is whether they will have another round of loan difficulties after the examiners come in June,'' said Thomas Hanley, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers.
Citicorp earned 60 cents a share, slightly less than most analysts had expected, and well below the $1.52 it earned in the first quarter last year.
Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, said last month that examiners would be focusing on real estate loans. In the earnings report released yesterday the bank said that becuase of unsettled conditions in the real estate market, a ''relatively high level of real estate charge-offs may continue.''
The real estate loans causing problems are for commercial properties like apartments, shopping centers and offices. Mortgages for single-family houses have not been a problem at major banks recently.
In the first quarter, the company charged off $135 million of commercial loans in developed countries, including $56 million of real estate loans, mostly in North America. About 40 million of loans to finance corporate takeovers or other heavily indebted borrowers were charged off. A year ago, charge-offs in those countries totaled only $36 million.
Citicorp said that problems with loans to highly indebted companies involved in corporate takeovers or other refinancings accounted for about half the $548 million increase since the end of the year in loans that are troubled and not paying interest. Analysts noted that Citibank was one of the leading lenders to the Campeau Corporation, whose American retail operations filed for bankruptcy earlier this year.
Another sign of real estate problems was the $570 million allocated to the reserve for loan losses, up $212 million from a year earlier. About $56 million of the increase was to cover commercial real estate loans. American real estate loans that are not paying interest rose $119 million, to $1.3 billion.
The strongest aspect of Citicorp's business continues to be consumer banking, which reported record profits of $270 million, up from $214 million a year ago. The credit card business, where Citicorp's various banks are the most active in the country, and the consumer banking business in the New York City market were especially strong,the company said.
Despite the decline, Citicorp said its long-term prospects were favorable enough to increase its quarterly stock dividend nearly 10 percent, to 44.5 cents a share from 40.5 cents. Citicorp stock rose 25 cents, closing on the New York Stock Exchange at $24.50 a share.
 
NCNB
The NCNB Corporation, the seventh-largest banking company, announced first-quarter earnings of $140.1 million, or $1.33 a share, up 84.5 percent from $75.8 million, or 82 cents a share, a year earlier. Much of the growth reflects the acquisiton last year of a 100 pwercent ownership of the Republicbank Corporation of Texas, now known as NCNB Texas.
As it warned analysts in March, NCNB said the weakening economy in the Southeastern part of the country caused some increase in problem loans, particularly for real estate. The banking company added $88.7 million to its reserve for loan losses in the first quarter compared with a $57.2 million addition a year ago. Troubled loans not paying interest, or facing other difficulties were $599.1 million, up from 446.1 million at the end of 1989.
NCNB is benefiting from cost savings as it develops its operations in Texas. Non-interest expnses in the first quarter fell 2 percent from the fourth quarter of 1989. NCNB's shares gained 37.5 cents yesterday, to $37.375.
 
Wells Fargo
Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's 12th-largest banking company, which relied heavily on lending to real estate and corporate takeovers to become one of the country's most profitable banks in the 1980's yesterday reported a 12.9 percent gain in earnings, to $159.8 million from $141.5 million.
The strong gain in earnings confused many banking analysts, who have expected that Wells Fargo's concentration in real estate and corporate takeover lending would eventually result in losses.
''They continue to defy Wall Street,'' said Mr. Hanley of Salomon Brothers, ''and the quality of their loans remains squarely intact.''
In the first quarter, Wells Fargo added only $75 million to its reserve for loan losses, down from $100 million a year earlier. Troubled loans that are not paying interest or have been restructured rose to $752.1 million, from $625.1 million a year earlier. Wells Fargo stock rose 50 cents, to $71.50.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Trade Wars Postponed

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
HAUNTED by visions of Toshibas and Toyotas being shoved off the pier in Seattle, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is making a big push to appease America's Japan-bashers. The Bush Administration, which has been playing good cop to Congress's bad cop in the unfolding trade drama, emerged from the latest round of negotiations with a sheaf of commitments that should make it far easier for American consumer goods to break into the Japanese market.
But as John B. Taylor, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, told the Senate last month, greasing the wheels of commerce will not reduce Japan's trade surplus or America's trade deficit by more than a few billion dollars. What might make a big difference are a variety of freshly negotiated measures aimed at narrowing the gap between savings and investment in each of the two countries. 
This breakthrough in the ''structural impediments initiative'' is not, however, guaranteed to take the wind out of the Japan-bashers' sails. The White House seems unwilling to put real muscle behind its part of the deal, commitments to cut the budget deficit and change tax policy to stimulate private savings.
Tokyo's promises to beef up investment in public works and open land for housing can be taken more seriously, if only because Japan's long-suffering urban majority is growing impatient with Government policies geared solely to the interests of exporters and farmers. In the best of circumstances, though, it would take years for these measures to reabsorb Japan's savings surplus. And in any case, the impulse of Congress to bash seems to have taken on a life of its own - one that has more to do with an ill-defined sense of American economic decline than evidence of dirty tricks by Japan.
Trade barriers do, of course, make a difference. The latest Japanese concessions should make it easier for American brands to navigate the labyrinth of Japanese distribution from portside to retailer's shelf. But the promised changes, which range from fast-track licensing of discount malls to overnight clearance of imports through Japanese customs, cannot possibly accomplish what Congressional trade hawks seem to have in mind.
Neither, for that matter, would the declaration of Japan as the 51st state. Forget economic theory: The laws of accounting alone guarantee that Japan will run a surplus on its external financial accounts as long as Japanese savings exceeds Japanese domestic investment. Thus, to narrow the trade surplus, Japan must consume more or invest more.
It would be a pity, Mr. Taylor says, for the Japanese to adjust by imitating America's profligate ways. Far better, he suggests, for Japan to make long-overdue investments in infrastructure. For example, just 50 percent of the dwellings in that nation of cities are connected to sewer systems. Bringing such public services in Japan up to the standards of other rich nations would cost hundreds of billions of dollars - hundreds of billions' worth of productive resources, most of which would probably be diverted from exports.
By the same token, promised changes in zoning and tax laws that now discourage investment in housing could make an enormous difference. And along with easing trade frictions, they would defuse the smoldering resentment of overworked Japanese ''salarymen,'' who have yet to share in the bounty from Japan's economic miracle.
How Japanese promises of long-run structural change will play on short-run American politics is unclear. Until recently, it was widely believed that behind every unfocused Congressional denunciation of Japanese economic perfidy lay a highly focused complaint by some special interest. By that cynical logic, the way to quiet the protectionists was to pay off their corporate and union sponsors.
But a decade of appeasement in which the domestic steel, auto and computer chip industries gained protection at the expense of consumers does not seem to have made much difference on Capitol Hill. Nor has the Japanese decision to build plants in the United States that employ tens of thousands of workers.
Indeed, the vague equation of Japanese economic success with American failure seems to have taken deeper root in the political culture. And the ubiquitous presence of high-quality Japanese products seems to evoke resentment from people who can no longer imagine life without them.
Buoyed by the agreement, free traders in the White House and the State Department will probably be able to resist pressure for anti-Japanese protectionism a while longer. Just what will happen, though, if Tokyo grows weary of the appeasement game or the American economy slips into recession is anyone's guess.

HEADLINE: Sales of Vehicles Down By 11.3% in Early April

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 17

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell by 11.3 percent in early April, compared with relatively strong sales a year ago, despite aggressive cash rebates and other discounts.
The nine auto companies that report their domestic sales every 10 days combined to sell 163,507 cars in early April, down 13.3 percent from 188,608 cars sold a year ago.
On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 6.6 million during the first 10 days of April, slightly below the 6.7 million pace for the last 30 days, and lagging behind the annual rate of 7 million cars set during the first quarter. The seasonally adjusted annual rate a year ago was 7.5 million cars. There were eight selling days in both periods. 
Auto makers sold 98,864 light trucks and mini-vans during the 10 days, a decline of 7.7 percent from 107,127 a year earlier.
The Big Three - the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation - which offer the most extensive rebates, also showed the biggest declines in the first 10 days of April, while the Japanese auto companies with plants in the United States continued to increase their sales.
The G.M., Ford and Chrysler rebates average $1,200 a vehicle, some analysts estimate.
Soft sales provoked a gloomy prediction from an economist at the National Automobile Dealers Association, Tom Webb, who said, ''Unless there is a major change in the economy, such as reduced interest rates, domestic new-car sales appear destined to remain in their current doldrums.''
Other analysts, however, were still hopeful that auto sales would pick up this spring. ''Consumer demand can turn on a dime,'' said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst at Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco. Mr. Glantz attributed the sluggish auto sales to ''slow income growth and falling real estate prices, which have made people more cautious, especially in areas of the country like New England and California,'' where property values have tumbled.
Chrysler registered the biggest drop in the 10-day period, posting a 29.2 percent decline in car sales, to 18,007 units. Sales of the No. 3 auto maker's light trucks and mini-vans fell by 24.9 percent, to 17,974 units.
G.M.'s car sales fell by 13.6 percent, to 74,400 units, while its sales of light trucks rose by 2.2 percent, to 43,298 units.
Ford sold 50,116 cars in early April, down 20.7 percent from a year ago, and 34,861 light trucks, a decline of 9.3 percent.
The foreign makers in the United States continued to add sales despite the overall decline in the American car market, extending a trend that began last July.
The Honda Motor Company sold 9,455 cars in early April, a gain of 17 percent. The Toyota Motor Corporation doubled sales, to 5,379 cars, while the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation tripled its car sales, to 1,485 units. The Mazda Motor Corporation sold 3,139 cars in the period, a gain of 221 percent.
The Nissan Motor Company once again lagged behind as the only Japanese producer in the United States to report a decline, with sales of Nissan cars off by 6 percent. However, Nissan's sales of light trucks rose by 14.2 percent in the period.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Up by 0.7% in March

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
The nation's industrial production rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Federal Reserve reported today, in a second consecutive strong showing that led analysts to suggest that the manufacturing recession may have ended.
''We may have been through the worst of the slowdown,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an industrial analyst with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ''You'll hear less talk of recession from the pessimists for a while.'' 
March's increase followed an even stronger rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier. Both increases reflected rises in the output of automobiles, the Fed said.
 
Rise in Utility Output
''The other major contributor to the overall production increase in March was utility output, which increased markedly as temperatures were more normal after an unseasonably warm January and February,'' the Fed added. ''Elsewhere, production was little changed, on balance.''
That report was the first to combine the previously separate output and capacity utilization reports.
The Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities - which usually move in tandem with industrial production - rose by four-tenths of 1 percent, to 83.3 percent, last month. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels.
Production had plummeted by 1.3 percent in January because of the effect of the weather on utility output and of layoffs in the auto industry as car makers trimmed bloated inventories.
 
Questions on Sector's Strength
''The suggestion is that the bottom has been reached in the industrial-sector weakness, and the issue raised is whether, in light of such high inflation, the industrial sector now may be too strong,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company.
Evelina Tainer, senior economist for the First National Bank of Chicago, said she believed the slowdown in manufacturing reached bottom in the fourth quarter of 1989, but added that the industrial sector was still ''not showing particular strength.''
Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in March on top of a 1.1 percent increase a month earlier.
Manufacturing of durables was up by nine-tenths of 1 percent after jumping 1.7 percent in February. Manufacturing of nondurables was down four-tenths in March after inching up by two-tenths a month earlier.
Output at mines rose by six-tenths of 1 percent last month after dropping by 1.6 percent in February. Reflecting the return to relatively normal weather, utility output jumped by 6.1 percent in March after falling by 1.2 percent in February.
 
First Report With 1987 Base
The Fed said its industrial production index in March stood at 108.8 percent of its 1987 base, up from 108.1 percent in February. It was the first report using a revised production index with 1987 as its reference period. Previous indexes were pegged to 1977.
The manufacturing operating rate rose by one-tenth of 1 percent, to 82.7 percent. The rate at factories producing durable goods increased by five-tenths, to 81.6 percent, while the rate at plants producing nondurable goods dropped by six-tenths, to 84.1 percent.
The operating rate at mines moved ahead by six-tenths of 1 percent, to 87.8 percent, while it jumped at utilities from 81.5 percent in February to 86.4 percent.
