HEADLINE: Market Place;
Europe's Buyouts Draw More Firms

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
THE flurry of corporate buyouts that has swept across Europe in recent years appears to be on the verge of new growth. At least, that is the hope of some on Wall Street and in the international financial community.
In recent months, a number of funds have been established by European firms, as well as American investment houses, to try to tap into this buyout binge, which is in large part a response to the European Community's plans to drop trade barriers by the end of 1992. These funds would provide a layer of financing that is essential in many large takeovers. 
Yesterday, Wasserstein, Perella Group Inc., the mergers and acquisitions firm, jumped into the business of providing such financing for European deals. The New York firm, formed in 1988, announced that it had created the largest such fund in an agreement with a number of European financial institutions.
The fund holds the equivalent of about $366 million, and is being managed in coordination with Banque Paribas, the French financial institution. Other managers of the fund will include Commerzbank, the third largest bank in Germany, and Amsterdam-Rotterdam, or Amro, Bank, the largest bank in the Netherlands.
A number of other investors are also negotiating to invest in the fund, including financial institutions from Italy, Spain, the United States and Japan. Any deal with those parties should be announced within 8 to 10 weeks, and would increase the fund's capital to about $427 million to $488 million.
The fund will hold 300 million European currency units, which are baskets of 12 European Community currencies. At current exchange rates, each unit is worth approximately $1.20.
Under the agreement announced yesterday, the capital will be used to provide so-called mezzanine financing for friendly merchant banking deals and corporate reorganizations in Europe. Mezzanine financing generally involves subordinated debt and equity securities, like warrants, and is used as one piece of a total financing package for deals.
Wasserstein and the other firms join a number of financial institutions that have already put together similar funds. The largest of those is a $326 million fund established two years ago by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street investment house that collapsed in February. A spokesman for Drexel said yesterday that the fund was run by a third party and was still operating.
Stephen A. Oxman, the deputy chairman of Wasserstein, Perella International, said the firm was forming the fund because of the opportunites being created by the economic upheaval throughout Western Europe. ''We see attractive opportunities for mezzanine finance in Europe that are the result of a number of factors, including the approach of 1992, the globalization of business and the restructuring that is occurring in a number of industries,'' Mr. Oxman said.
While some people had feared that the upheaval that has swept across Eastern Europe in recent months would possibly delay the implementation of the plans for 1992, a number of international investment bankers said yesterday that they had seen no evidence of a slowdown in the European Community's interest in strategic buyouts.
Mr. Oxman said the additional investors would not change the types of financing by the fund and he emphasized that no unfriendly deals would be undertaken.
Rather, both Wasserstein and Paribas would use the capital in transactions in which the firms could invest as participants, either together or separate, in the equity portion of the deal. Both firms have equity funds that are used to commit their capital in such investments.
''The transactions that the mezzanine fund may invest in may well be the ones that are controlled by either of us at the pure equity level,'' Mr. Oxman said.
Although Wasserstein had originally hoped to establish the mezzanine fund by itself, it chose to enter into the agreement with the foreign firms so that it would be better able to understand local attitudes toward financing techniques.
''We concluded from our point of view that it would be better to have a leading institution as a local partner so as to increase our sensitivity to local markets,'' Mr. Oxman said. ''It is always useful to have someone with local eyes and ears.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, Up Modestly Abroad, Ends Trading Day Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower yesterday against major foreign currencies after rising modestly overseas. Currency dealers attributed the dollar's slide to Government reports that consumer prices surged an unexpectedly sharp five-tenths of 1 percent last month and that industrial production rose seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Traders said the market thought the rise in inflation was too steep and could cause future economic problems. 
Dealers said trading was relatively quiet, however, before the release of the February trade data today. The market has been expecting the trade gap to narrow to around $7.5 billion, dealers said, from January's $9.25 billion shortfall.
 
Dollar Up in Tokyo
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 159.83 Japanese yen, from 159.42 yen Monday. It stood at 159.85 yen in London, and 159.69 yen in New York, up from Monday's close of 159.30.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.6340 in London, down from $1.6425 late Thursday, and $1.6383 in New York, up from $1.6304 late Monday.
The European markets were closed on Friday and Monday for the Easter holiday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday quotes, included: 1.6765 West German marks, down from 1.6768; 1.4895 Swiss francs, down from 1.4900; 5.6360 French francs, down from 5.6365; 1,231.75 Italian lire, down from 1,232.50, and 1.16485 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16885.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, were: 1.6770 marks, up from 1.6730; 1.4900 Swiss francs, up from 1.4835; 5.6370 French francs, up from 5.6213; 1.8885 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8840; 1,232.00 Italian lire, up from 1,231.50, and 1.1680 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1633.
Gold prices were mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $375.20 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $375 an ounce, up 40 cents.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $374.05 an ounce, from $375.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to $374 an ounce from $375.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 81 cents to close at $375.39 an ounce.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: LITHUANIANS SAY MOSCOW HAS CUT MAIN OIL PIPELINE;
Growing Pressure

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 18

 BODY:
After a confusing day of threats and denials, Lithuania reported tonight that the Soviet authorities had cut off the principal supply of oil to the republic as part of the Kremlin's campaign to force Lithuania to retreat from its declaration of independence.
The Lithuanian information office said the pipeline supply of crude oil to the Mazeikiai refinery in the northwest of the republic was cut off at 9:30 P.M. Vilnius time, five minutes after notice was telephoned to the plant in the name of Kremlin officials. On Tuesday, Lithuania said it had been warned that the supply would be halted today in keeping with an ultimatum issued by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last Friday.
 
Search for a Solution
Even as the announcement came, it was clear that attempts to find a solution to the crisis were continuing. During the day in Vilnius, the Lithuanian Parliament offered a conciliatory gesture to the Kremlin by voting to refrain from enacting new laws for two weeks if Moscow agreed to begin preliminary consultations on the independence campaign. 
But the Parliament also said that it ''confirms its loyalty to the acts of March 11,'' when the Parliament declared independence and suspended the Soviet Constitution. [Text of the Parliament's resolution and letter to Mr. Gorbachev, page A10.] There was no confirmation in Moscow tonight that the ultimatum threatening an oil cutoff had, in fact, been carried out.
 
Signs of Pressure
Its enactment would signal a far higher level of pressure from Mr. Gorbachev than has previously been seen in the five-week-long sovereignty crisis and would also increase the calls in other nations for retaliatory economic measures against the Soviet Union. [In Washington, the Bush Administration said that until it could confirm reports of the cutoff it would not have any response. The reports came only a few hours after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told a Congressional committee that the United States would consider severing certain commercial arrangements with the Soviet Union if Mr. Gorbachev continued tightening a economic noose around Lithuania. Page A10.] Soviet officials denied earlier today that orders for a cutoff had yet gone out. But managers at Mazeikiai, the sole refinery in Lithuania, said tonight that the pipeline supply from the city of Polotsk in the republic of Byelorussia in the western Soviet Union was finally stopped tonight.
 
Resolve Called Deeper
''The Soviet Union, being unable to find a humane solution, is resorting to economic coercion against a neighboring country,'' the Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, said after receiving the news and vowing that the pressure would only deepen the republic's commitment to independence.
There was no immediate indication of how long the reported cutoff might continue. The struggle between the Kremlin and the republic has been marked by steady psychological pressure and changing Kremlin tactics, with alternate waxing and waning of the sense of crisis.
The reported cutoff of oil itself would presumably mean no immediate industrial hardship or shortage of refined oil in the republic, because Lithuanian officials estimated earlier this week that there was a stockpile of up to four months of crude oil with which to continue operations in the event of a cutoff.
Plant officials confirmed tonight that work was continuing after the pipeline inflow fully stopped, about an hour after a decrease was first evident.
Lithuanian officials quoted plant officials on the night shift as reporting that the authorizatiofofor the toppage was gngned by uhe Soviet Primeininister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, under a resolution of the Council of Ministers.
 
A 48-Hour Ultimatum
On Friday, just before the long Easter weekend, President Gorbachev issued a 48-hour ultimatum to the Landsbergis government to repeal a series of independence laws or face reductions in supplies from the rest of the Soviet Union. On Monday, the Lithuanians had responded to the ultimatum with an offer of talks on central issues mentioned in the ultimatum.
Before the cutoff, a Soviet deputy oil and gas industry minister, Aklim Mukhamedzyanov, said in a telephone interview that ''allegations that these supplies have been terminated are completely groundless.
''We have received no instructions from the Council of Ministers to implement such measures,'' he said.
 
Republic Dependent for Energy
With no fuel resources of its own, Lithuania is completely dependent on the crude oil, natural gas and petroleum shipped in from the Soviet Union, and panicked citizens have been lining up daily at gas stations around the republic to fill up their cars and trucks. There was no sign today of a cutoff of natural gas, which had also been threatened.
The Mazeikiai refinery processed almost 13 million tons of oil last year. About 7 million tons of that was used in Lithuania, while the remainder was sent to the other Baltic republics and elsewhere. Small amounts also are sold into northwestern Europe through Hamburg, West Germany.
Lithuania imports 97 percent of the fuel it consumes, with nearly half of the total supplied by oil produced in other Soviet republics that is used to heat and power Lithuanian factories. Factories and other industrial activities also run on coal. Homes are heated mainly by natural gas. Lithuania does produce some energy at a nuclear power station at Ignalina and in some small hydroelectric stations.
Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Ryzhkov threatened Lithuania on friday with a cut-off of critical supplies if the Parliament there did not revoke within 48 hours recently passed legislation, including a call to boycott the Soviet spring military call-up and the introduction of mandatory citizen identity cards.
The ultimatum from Moscow did not include a demand that the republic revoke its declaration of independence, made March 11, a move the republic has repeatedly rejected.
 
A Gesture to Moscow
Lithuania's Parliament, in a conciliatory gesture to the Kremlin, voted unanimously today to refrain from passing new laws for two weeks if Moscow agrees to begin preliminary consultations about the republic's drive for independence. The Parliament's resolution did not specifically mention the status of laws passed since the independence declaration, except to say the Parliament supports a statement made Monday by the Lithuanian Prime Minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene.
In that statement, the first sign that the republic was willing to compromise with Moscow, Mrs. Prunskiene sent a telegram to the Soviet leadership saying that Lithuania would not stand in the way of Lithuanian men willing to serve in the army and would not take action against Soviet citizens choosing to stay in the republic while maintaining their soviet citizenship. Then, Tuesday, as the specter of a fuel blockade loomed, Lithuanian legislators began urging that serious concessions be offered to Moscow in the hopes of encouraging the Kremlin to agree to negotiations.
In addition to the proposal on temporarily suspending the passage of any new laws, the Lithuanian resolution urges Moscow ''to refrain from using force, including economic pressure, against Lithuania and it citizens.''
It further calls on Lithuanian citizens and economic organizations ''to prepare for a period of austerity and spiritual endurance.''
 
Letter to Soviet Leaders
The Parliament also unanimously adopted a letter to Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Ryzhkov, outlining its latest position and supporting the points raised by Mrs. Prunskiene in her telegram to the Soviet President earlier this week.
The parliamentary letter says that a Lithuanian delegation will soon be going to Moscow and will be ready to meet with Kremlin representatives to begin the proposed ''preliminary consultations.'' The delegation is to be led by Bronius Kuzmickas, deputy chairman of the Lithuanian Parliament.
In the one critical note raised in the letter, the Parliament says it ''regrets the position and methods chosen by the U.S.S.R.'' during the current crisis.
Mr. Gorbachev issued his ultimatum to Lithuania after a month of steadily increasing threats and warnings that Lithuania must rescind its declaration and all subsequent legislation. Moscow has maintained that Lithuania and all other Soviet republics are free to secede from the Soviet Union provided they follow guidelines recently adopted by the national Parliament in Moscow, which include a referendum requiring a two-thirds vote to approve secession, a transition period running a minimum of five years and approval by the Congress of People's Deputies, the full Soviet Parliament.
Lithuanian officials insist that they are seeking not to secede, but rather to re-establish the independence that was lost in 1940, when Lithuania and the neighboring Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia were forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union by Stalin.
As the Parliament worked today on a political solution to the stalemate with Moscow, Mrs. Prunskiene and the Lithuanian Foreign Minister, Algirdas Saudargas, left for a trip to Norway, trying to find practical help for the fledgling republic through foreign investors and economic aid.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: LITHUANIANS SAY MOSCOW HAS CUT MAIN OIL PIPELINE;
Soviets Hold All the Cards

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Lithuania is ill equipped to withstand an economic siege by Moscow, Eastern European analysts agree. The New Hampshire-sized republic is utterly dependent on energy purchased from the Soviet Government at bargain rates, Nor is there reason to believe that a retaliatory cutoff of Lithuanian exports would do much damage to the Soviet economy. While farms and factories do supply the other Soviet republics with a handful of critical products, Moscow could easily find alternative sources in European markets.
Looking down the road, however, the risks to each side appear more balanced. An independent Lithuania, suggests Lawrence Summers, a Harvard economist who has been advising the republic's rebellious government, could serve Soviet interests as well as its own. By failing to make a deal on mutually acceptable terms, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is passing by a vital opportunity to transform the dependent Baltic economies into Hong Kong-style windows to the West. 
Lithuania and the other Baltic republics are relatively prosperous. According to PlanEcon, a Washington consulting firm, output per person was more than double that of the impoverished Tadzhik Republic, and exceeded the overall Soviet average by one-fourth.
 
Highly Vulnerable
But with a population under four million, Lithuania is much too small to be self-sufficient. As a matter of practical economics and longstanding Soviet political policy, it is tightly bound to the greater Soviet economy. Most of the manufactures and raw materials used in Lithuania come from other republics still within the Soviet fold. And while Lithuanians might be able to survive for months or years without the bulk of the these imports, they are highly vulnerable to the embargo on energy.
According to a Lithuanian government report published last month, 97 percent of the fuel used to heat Lithuanian homes and run its factories is imported. A nuclear plant, which has been the focus of protest by Lithuanian nationalists, would be able to supply electricity for some time. But stockpiles of oil are reportedly only sufficient to carry the economy for about six weeks. Supplies of natural gas, used in four out of five Lithuanian homes, are yet smaller.
Lithuania has little or no hard currency to pay for Western imports to replace the losses. It is not clear, in any case, that the Soviet Navy would permit foreign oil tankers to dock.
Nor would Lithuania have much hope in the short run of earning desperately needed foreign exchange through sales to the West. Just 20 percent of Lithuanian exports, Mr. Summers estimates, are of sufficient quality to compete in world markets. Even exports of Lithuanian foodstuffs, tainted by pesticides banned in Europe, are problematic.
 
Major TV Parts Supplier
For the Soviet side, a trade embargo would mean losses for its enterprises and consumers who now depend on exports, however inferior, from Lithuania. The little economy produces, for example, some 75 percent of the components for Soviet television sets and 30 percent of vital tractor parts.
But in the view of Thomas Telma, an economist at PlanEcon, the creaky Soviet economy could bumble along for many months without feeling the loss. And within that time, it could easily open the economic bottlenecks with substitutes from the West.
In fact, there is reason to believe that the Soviets would gain in the short run by severing economic ties with Lithuania. The prices Lithuanian enterprises have been paying for oil and gas and other raw materials, analysts agree, are far below those the Soviets could fetch in the West. And while this implicit annual subsidy to the Lithuanian economy may be much smaller than the $5.9 billion claimed by Moscow, there is little doubt that the immediate impact of a cutoff would be a windfall for the Soviets.
But other considerations, Mr. Summers argues, ought to temper President Gorbachev's taste for a fight. A Lithuania subdued by Soviet power is likely to remain a focus of economically costly ethnic conflict and a bottomless pit for Soviet subsidies. By contrast, an independent Lithuania, one with close ties to the Soviet Union based solely on mutual interest, could serve as a conduit for the Western technology and organizational skills so desperately needed by Moscow.
 
High-Quality Labor
In Mr. Summers's view an independent Lithuania (or Estonia, or Latvia for that matter) would be able to attract capital - and modern factories -from nearby Scandinavia. ''Where else,'' he asks, can you hire high-quality labor for one-eighth the wage of a South Korean?''
Lithuanians would, of course, benefit most directly from newly forged ties with the West. But Moscow would benefit, too, as capital and technology followed the path of greatest expected profit.
The battle over Lithuania might only delay the day when the Baltics might become Moscow's Hong Kong. But with the Soviet political system in ferment and the Soviet economy in free fall, delay is a luxury that Mr. Gorbachev call ill afford.

HEADLINE: MILITANTS PROMISE TO FREE AMERICAN

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 18

 BODY:
A pro-Iranian group believed to be holding three American hostages in Beirut said today that it would release one of them within 48 hours.
The group, the Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, said it was acting in response to ''urgent appeals by officials of the Islamic Republic of Iran for a good-will initiative in order to close the hostage file.''
News agencies in Beirut said the group's handwritten statement was delivered to the Beirut newspaper An Nahar and to a Western news agency. [Text of statement, page A8.] Baker Reacts Cautiously The statement was acompanied by a photograph of Jesse Turner, 42 years old, who was a professor at Beirut University College when he was taken hostage in January 1987. Islamic Holy War has also said it is holding Alan Steen, 50, and Robert Polhill, 54, both of whom were professors at the University College. Experts on Iranian affairs speculated that the hostage to be released was Mr. Turner. 
In its statement, Islamic Holy War said that it would like John H. Kelly, the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, to be on hand in Damascus, Syria, to ''coordinate final measures necessary for the success of the release within 48 hours.''
In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d reacted cautiously to the reports and said there were no plans to send Mr. Kelly, who is in Bonn, to Damascus.
Iranian affairs experts said the formal linking of Iran's name to the pro-Iranian groups said to be holding hostages, and the positive reference to resolving the matter, was a notable change. Iran has previously denied all formal ties to the pro-Iranian groups, who are believed to be holding 18 Western hostages, including 8 Americans.
 
Syrian Efforts Noted
Senior Arab Government officials said the move also underlined Syria's wish to improve its ties to the West and its role in the release of hostages held by pro-Iranian militias.
In its statement, Islamic Holy War emphasized ''the permanent Syrian efforts in this line,'' and a senior Palestinian official said tonight that ''the whole thing has been cooked up by the Syrians.''
Irfan Parviz, the editor of The Teheran Times, the first Iranian publication to call for the release of foreign hostages, also said Syria had helped bring about the development.
''I am really happy,'' Mr. Parviz said in a telephone interview from his home in the Iranian capital. ''I can say it is the beginning and there will be more good news in the pipeline.'' The Teheran Times is known for its close ties to the Iranian Foreign Ministry and President Hashemi Rafsanjani.
The move by Islamic Holy War gives support to the view that the so-called pragmatic faction of the Iranian Government led by President Rafsanjani may have settled a long-running power struggle in Teheran to its advantage.
''I think it does in fact mean that Rafsanjani and company are winning,'' said Gary Sick, an Iranian affairs expert formerly on the United States National Security Council who handled the first hostage crisis when American diplomats were taken prisoner in Teheran in 1979.
 
'A Humanitarian Gesture'
Mr. Parviz said the expected release of American hostages was because of Mr. Rafsanjani's efforts. He dismissed all notions of opposition to the Iranian President's decision to end the hostage question as a ''fiction'' of the Western press.
''Everything has always been under his control,'' Mr. Parviz said, adding, ''It is a humanitarian gesture to which America can respond by ending its hostile attitude towards Iran.''
Mr. Rafsanjani and his supporters in the Iranian Government have long advocated a resolution of the hostage issue to allow Iran to pursue the normalization of relations with Western countries, a process that began with France in 1988 when all French hostages held by pro-Iranian militias were released.
On March 21, Iran began a five-year development program for which it says it needs $27 billion in foreign credits and in hard currency.
Mr. Sick said the Bush Administration should respond to the potential release of an American hostage with ''a gesture, but only a small one,'' adding that the Iranians have begun a long process of negotiations.
''The bottom line is that Rafsanjani wants to see the hostage business ended, not for humanitarian reasons, but so as to get on with his economic programs and to get access to United States technology, particularly in the area of improving Iran's oilfields,'' Mr. Sick said in a telephone interview tonight.
Arab diplomats noted that the good-will gesture toward the West comes when Iraq, an enemy of Iran and Syria, finds its relations with the West deteriorating after a long period of improvement that started when the Iraq-Iran war began in 1980.
Virtually all Iranian affairs experts consulted said the offer to release an American hostage and the way it was announced strongly suggested that Iran expects countersteps by the United States.
The United States has repeatedly vowed not to bargain over the release of hostages. For its part, Iran has often asked for the return of Iranian Government funds frozen in the United States.
The statement by the terrorist organization strongly suggested that the move came after negotiations it described as assuring ''a fruitful solution for all parties.'' It said that ''all those who should be consulted were unanimous that fruitful and convincing formulas should be sought.''
 
'An Implicit Bargain'
The group also said it was moving to liberate an American hostage ''on the basis of reciprocal positive action from the other party to speed the issue toward a happy ending,'' suggesting that some bargaining over Iranian demands had taken place or was expected.
Mr. Sick and a number of other Iranian affairs experts said they felt some kind of talks between the Bush Administration and the Iranian Government must have taken place. ''I don't really know, but I feel there is here an implicit bargain,'' Mr. Sick said.
Although little is known about Islamic Holy War, it is generally acknowledged that all the pro-Iranian groups holding hostages fall under the umbrella of a Shiite Muslim Lebanese organization known as the Party of God. The group is financed by Iran, but also has ties with Syria, which controls some of Iran's access to Lebanon.
Islamic Holy War said today that it had proposed a way for the United States to respond to its offer in ''a verbal message which will be carried to President Bush.''
The statement added, ''We wish the humanitarian aspect of this move to be balanced from both sides as a condition for it to move forward, otherwise there is no point in advancing from one side.''
On March 15, Islamic Holy War threatened in a statement in Beirut to kill all three hostages unless the United States met its demands. It also threatened to blow up planes carrying Jewish Russian immigrants to Israel.
The group previously offered to trade the three professors for 400 Arabs held in Israeli jails. Israel rejected the proposal.

HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT FELL IN FEBRUARY TO A SIX-YEAR LOW

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit took an unexpectedly sharp fall in February, the Commerce Department said today. At $6.49 billion, it is the smallest gap between imports and exports in more than six years.
Administration officials hailed the report, which showed the smallest monthly trade imbalance for the United States since the $5.68 billion in December 1983 and reflected impressive gains with many trading partners.
''The overall situation in U.S. trade has been improving for some time, and we are pleased with these numbers,'' said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. 
 
'Elements of a Fluke'
But private economists were more skeptical. ''There were the elements of a fluke,'' said Cynthia Latta, senior financial economist for DRI/McGraw Hill. And some analysts, in studying parts of the report, saw signs of a softer economy.
On Wall Street today, stock prices tumbled, but traders said the main factor was rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 32.89 points, to 2,732.88. [Page D12.] In currency trading, the dollar fell despite expectations that a strong trade report would provide support.
The trade deficit fell 30 percent from a revised $9.32 billion in January. But the improvement reflected declining imports; exports actually fell slightly. Oil accounted for nearly two-fifths of the overall $3.14 billion decline in imports from January to $38.12 billion in February. The price of imported oil, which had surged in January, declined as unseasonably warm weather curbed energy demand in February and oil exporting countries maintained high production levels.
Most analysts expect that over the longer term both oil import volumes and prices will rise. Ms. Latta of DRI/McGraw Hill said, ''The energy import bill is going to have to have an upward trend to it.''
Acknowledging the volatility of trade numbers, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher still noted that exports over the first two months of the year rose ''an encouraging'' 11.6 percent over the corresponding months last year with more than half the increase in advanced technology products.
The Bush Administration is counting on export growth to lift the fortunes of American manufacturers and to add overall strength to the economy.
But there were declines in the capital goods and industrial product sectors as well, suggesting a softer economy to some analysts, including Joel L. Prakken, vice president of Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, and William T. Archey, vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
''The economy has been in a temporary lull,'' said Mr. Prakken, whose St. Louis firm forecasts economic growth. ''Once the economy rebounds later this year, imports will pick up.'' He expects that economic growth for the first quarter, to be announced by the Commerce Department next week, will be at an annual rate of 1.5 percent, compared with 3 percent for all of 1989.
The trade report showed that exports at $31.63 billion were off 1 percent from the record $31.93 billion, but would have been off more had it not been for the strength of aircraft orders, reflecting a backlog at Boeing whose assembly operations were hit by a strike late last year.
The most striking improvement was with the European Community. The United States converted a $48.9 million deficit with the community in January into a $1.15 billion surplus.
The gap with Japan widened, after shrinking in January, but the average for the first two months was still 27 percent narrower than the corresponding months of 1989. Exports to Japan increased by 24 percent, while imports fell 5 percent.
 
Discussion With Tokyo
The improvement in the trade deficit with Japan over the first two months comes as the Bush Administration, under heavy Congressional pressure, has been urging Tokyo to open its market to more foreign products.
Although recent trade pacts with Japan have been hailed by the Administration, Congress remains skeptical and many lawmakers are demanding that Japan be cited again for its trade practices and be subjected to negotiations as a so-called priority country under tough provisions of 1988 trade legislation. The Administration is deeply divided on the issue, and today's report was seen as bolstering the position of those who are against citing Japan again.
As for the overall deficit, imports of manufactured goods at $28.8 billion were $1.6 billion less than the $30.4 billion of January. Among sectors showing steep declines were clothing and footwear, specialized industrial machinery, iron and steel mill products, airplanes, organic and inorganic chemicals, telecommunications equipment, textile yarns and fabrics, metalworking machinery and electrical machinery. But an increase was shown in imports of passenger cars.
 
More Aircraft Exports
Exports of manufactured goods at $23.3 billion were $600 million more than the $22.7 billion of January. Exports of aircraft, up $1.2 billion, more than accounted for the increase. Other increases were shown in vehicle parts, new passenger cars, trucks, and spacecraft and parts.
Decreases were shown in the categories for power generating machinery, organic and inorganic chemicals, chemicals-plastics, office machines and scientific instruments.
Oil imports at $4.7 billion in February were $1.2 billion less than the $5.9 billion of January. Imports totaled 243 million barrels, down 48 million from January. The February average price of $19.39 for a barrel was 74 cents below January.

HEADLINE: State Acquires Most of Times Square Project Site

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
After a six-year legal battle, New York State acquired most of the Times Square development area yesterday, and officials said demolition to clear the way for the $2.5 billion project could begin as early as the fall.
Under a condemnation order signed by Justice Stanley Parness of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, the State Urban Development Corporation took title to about two-thirds of the 13-acre site, including parcels at Seventh Avenue, Broadway and 42d Street on which four huge office towers are planned. The order also includes eight of the nine theaters that are to be renovated as part of the project.
Vincent Tese, chairman of the development corporation, said of the significance of yesterday's action: ''We own it. It's ours.'' State officials characterized the action as a decisive step forward for the largest public commercial urban-renewal project ever planned in the state. 
 
More Than 40 Lawsuits
Before the condemnation order was signed, the project's developers, Park Tower Realty and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, increased their letter of credit from $155 million to $241 million, in compliance with an earlier ruling by Justice Parness that took into account increasing real-estate values. The letter of credit will cover the cost of acquiring the property.
The project, a decade in the making, has been delayed by more than 40 lawsuits, two of which are pending. But Mr. Tese, who is also the State Commissioner of Economic Development, said the two lawsuits were not ''deal breakers.''
The developers withdrew their declaration that there was significant litigation affecting the project, signifying their belief that the pending lawsuits would not materially affect the project.
Mr. Tese said companies and individuals occupying offices in the buildings to be demolished would be moved in the next three to four months. The agency will also conduct a final appraisal of the 34 properties the state acquired to determine purchase prices.
A revised plan for the area, unveiled last summer, calls for four skyscrapers varying in height from 32 to 57 stories and comprising 4.1 million square feet. The buildings were redesigned to reflect the honky-tonk atmosphere of the area, with setbacks, cutouts, asymmetrical grids, angled roofs, reflective surfaces in blue and green glass and built-in multicolored neon signs.
 
Hotel and Mart Proposed
The 42d Street-Seventh Avenue subway station would be reconstructed, and one official said work on the subway station would help determine the sequence of construction on the project.
The plan also calls for a hotel and a wholesale merchandise mart on Eighth Avenue at the western end of the project. But the agency does not yet have a deal with a developer for those projects, and yesterday's condemnation order does not include those sites.
''Now that the east has been resolved, I think the west will pretty quickly fall into line,'' said Carl Weisbrod, former head of the 42d Street Redevelopment Project, a state agency set up to manage the huge undertaking. As head of New York City Public Development Corporation, Mr. Weisbrod is now the city's lead representative to the project.
The fate of the former Times Tower is uncertain, but Mr. Weisbrod said it was unlikely that the building on an island between Seventh Avenue and Broadway would be torn down.
Although the condemnation order does not include the ninth theater planned for renovation, the New Amsterdam, the Urban Development Corporation is already working with its owners.
 
Tens of Thousands of Jobs
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called yesterday's action ''a milestone for the economy of New York.'' Mayor David N. Dinkins said the project would create 16,000 construction jobs and 20,000 permanent jobs, making it ''one of the most productive public projects of the decade.'' It is certainly among the most controversial.
Supporters contended that it would clean up an area marred by seediness and afflicted with crime. Opponents condemned the skyscrapers as too large and the tax abatements granted to the developers as too generous.
Many new office towers have already risen in the Times Square area, and in a soft real-estate market there are fears that a project once intended to stimulate development could now flood the city with unneeded office space. And because of tax abatements, the project's developers might have an edge in luring tenants.
''This will not save Times Square,'' said State Senator Franz S. Leichter, Democrat of Manhattan and a longtime critic of the project. ''It will destroy Times Square.''
But Veronica W. Hackett, a senior vice president of Park Tower, said that despite all the development in the area, the 42d Street project was necessary because 42d Street was still ''a terrible disgrace to this city.''
As the legal wrangling over the project dragged on, Chemical Bank, which was expected to be a prime tenant, withdrew, concluding that the new buildings might not be ready by the time the lease on its current Park Avenue headquarters expired in 1994.
But even without such a tenant, and despite the weak real-estate market, both developers expressed confidence that the project would be a success.
''Even though the short-term picture isn't rosy, we feel that by the time the office buildings are constructed, there will be a new cycle and it will be a great opportunity,'' said Tom R. Jago, a spokesman for Prudential.
 
'No Grounds That We Can See'
Valerie Caproni, senior vice president and general counsel for the Urban Development Corporation, said that Justice Parness's condemnation order could be appealed, but that her agency had no indication it would be.
In any event, she asserted, there were ''no grounds that we can see that will result in a reversal.'' She also said a property owner could contest the value of an appraisal.
Gary M. Rosenberg, a lawyer for the Durst Organization, a real-estate concern that has a lease on property that includes seven of the theaters on West 42d Street and has been one of the project's most determined foes, said he had yet to read the judge's order and could not comment on it.
But, he acknowledged, ''I would say that from U.D.C.'s point of view, yes, this is a big step.''

HEADLINE: Nepal's Tense Days: Foreign Aid Reported at Risk

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 18

 BODY:
The World Bank and several nations that give aid to Nepal warned aides to King Birendra last month that financial help for this impoverished kingdom could be jeopardized if the King failed to respond to the democracy movement that has since started to take power, officials here say.
The movement, led by the Nepalese Congress Party and a Communist coalition, included a surge of popular unrest and street marches that reached a peak 12 days ago, and won an end to Nepal's 30-year ban on political activity. A member of the Nepalese Congress Party, Krishna Prasad Bhattarai, was named Prime Minister, and he announced the names of the 11 members of his Cabinet today. 
An international aid official said today that the World Bank's concern about the future of Nepal was made known to officials in the palace and the Finance Ministry late in March as the movement grew in strength.
The bank financed $65 million in projects last year and plans to finance a series of projects worth about $120 million per year for the next five years.
The former Foreign Minister, Shailendra Upadyaya, who was in the Government at the time, said he knew about threats of aid disruption from France, Britain, the United States, West Germany and Switzerland.
Fresh commitments of $466 million in aid to Nepal in fiscal year 1988-89 were made by the Aid Nepal group, a consortium including West Germany, Japan, Britain, Switzerland and Canada, that is led by the World Bank.
''If the Government had come to the Aid Nepal meeting in Paris in May'' without making major political and economic changes ''it would have got a rocket,'' said the international aid official. The warnings, he said, ''did have some effect.'' He did not elaborate. He and others here said West Germany and Switzerland had virtually decided on April 8 to pull back on existing projects and delay future assistance. Then, King Birendra bowed to the movement and ended the ban on political activity. The democracy movement took another week to force the resignation of the King's Prime Minister, Lokendra Bahadur Chand, and the dissolution of Parliament, paving the way for an opposition government and new elections.
The new 11-member government led by Mr. Bhattarai, which is to be installed Thursday, gives important economic posts like Industry, Commerce, Agriculture, Tourism and Land Reform to leftists. The Finance post went to Dhirendra Raj Pande, a prominent human-rights organizer and independent economist Mr. Bhattarai kept for himself the portfolios of Foreign Affairs, Defense and Palace Affairs. The last post involves coordination with the 44-year-old King, who has ruled with nearly absolute power since 1972. Aides in the Nepalese Congress Party were given Ministries of Home Affairs, which involves control of law enforcement and the intelligence network, and Water Resources.
The international aid specialist said that donor nations, while impressed by Nepal's prudent management of its foreign-exchange reserves, credit restraints and budget management, were irked by its use of large amounts of money on projects. He estimated that more than $1 billion in aid has not been disbursed over several years because of poor handling of projects and administrative inefficiency.

HEADLINE: Census Chief Believes in Numbers and Optimism

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Long before she came to Washington, Barbara Everitt Bryant had established herself as an information-age alchemist, using survey research to transform the public's needs and habits into the numbers necessary to manage hospitals, television stations and schools.
Now, just four months after President Bush appointed her to be Director of the Federal Census Bureau, Dr. Bryant's skills are being put to a daunting test: She is being asked to rally an apathetic public and transform the problem-plagued census.
On Thursday, Dr. Bryant will appear before the Census and Population Subcommittee of the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee to try to explain an unexpectedly poor return rate of census forms - as of today, only 62 percent had been mailed back - and to say what she plans to do. Many in the bureau and Congress think the appearance will give Dr. Bryant, the 64-year-old executive of a Michigan survey-research firm, a chance to answer the one big question about her ability: whether she has the mettle to handle the political rough-and-tumble.
 
Going After Money
At the hearing, Dr. Bryant will be seeking at least $130 million to complete the census. She will also get barbed questions on what is going wrong, and why. 
''I knew I'd be jumping immediately into the tidal wave,'' she said. Although she worried ahead of time about taking control of a machine she had not designed, she has said nothing publicly about the stress of the past two weeks, since her people in the field let her know how far behind the mail-response rate was from the 70 percent rate originally projected.
Her response to these and other problems is dogged optimism. ''I think we at the Census Bureau always shoot for extremely high goals,'' she said. ''We'll count everybody, even if we do it door to door.''
Since the revelation of the low return rate, Dr. Bryant has run daily afternoon staff meetings, trying to pinpoint the cause. Much of the rest of her time has been spent trying to generate publicity for the census and logging mileage on the Suitland Parkway as she shuttles from her own meetings in Maryland to almost daily ones at the Commerce Department, 10 miles away.
 
Criticism Called Inevitable
''There's no way you're going to have that job right now and not have a lot of criticism,'' said Robert Teeter, once a campaign poll taker for George Bush. Mr. Teeter is a former colleague of Dr. Bryant at Market Opinion Research and the man who, as head of the President's transition team, suggested her for the job she considers ''the mountaintop of the field.''
Dr. Bryant was finally appointed by President Bush during Congress's Christmas break. The timing of the recess appointment, which filled a job that had been vacant for nearly a year, meant that she not only had to take over responsibility for a census on the eve of the massive operation, but that she would do so without Senate confirmation. Also, during the interregnum, a lot of management of the bureau had been picked up by the Department of Commerce's Division of Economic Affairs.
She had not been the White House's first choice. She won the appointment after White House officials, bruised by the rejection of John G. Tower's nomination as Defense Secretary, realized they would be courting another fight with Congressional Democrats if they persisted in their intention to nominate Alan Heslop, a Republican redistricting specialist from California. He provoked strong opposition from that state's Democratic Congressional delegation, who considered him far too partisan.
Dr. Bryant's stength, at a time when partisan nerves were raw, was her reputation for both technical competence and fairness. Her background in communications, Commerce Department officials said, was also a plus, since the 1990 head count would need a public relations effort.
''She's a very public person,'' said Mark Plant, a deputy Under Secretary at the Commerce Department. ''She is a very intelligent, bright woman walking into the biggest government operation outside of a war.'' Cheerleader or Quarterback? As for the census, Mr. Plant said: ''If anything was certain, it was that unforeseen circunmstances would come up. That's where the director of the census comes in. She calls herself a cheerleader. Cheerleader is too modest. She's the quarterback.''
Compared wtih some earlier census directors, he said, ''she's a much gentler person.'' Her approach, Mr. Plant said, ''plays well at the bureau.'' He added, ''It plays well upstairs.''
To the public Dr. Bryant's cheery manner and neatly coiffed white hair may seem oddly dissonant with her mission. ''The nature of the dissonance is that this is a high school math teacher; this is my grandmother, running a huge statistical agency,'' Mr. Plant said. ''It doesn't compute.''
For Census Bureau officials, she does compute. Several of her colleagues, preferring professional anonymity, refused to repeat for the record the complimentary things they say about her. Privately, they respect her as someone who talks their language and shares their values about how data should be produced, analyzed and distributed.
 
Biggest Place of All
At a time when many census bureau veterans are doubling or tripling their government salaries with jobs in the booming information industry, and when the political and legal pressures on the bureau are intense, Dr. Bryant wanted to move in the opposite direction. ''After a career in survey and market research, this is the biggest place of them all for doing the total census and the largest surveys,'' she said in an interview.
A generation ahead of the demographic curve, she started on her new career in 1961, after the youngest of her three children entered first grade. Oakland, a small university in Michigan, offered her a part-time job doing public relations and teaching science in the continuing-education program. Her neighbors disapproved, saying her decision to work would deprive her children.
She persisted. In 1965, she began graduate studies in communications, first at Oakland and later at the University of Michigan.
She had taken her undergraduate degree from Cornell University in physics, though her father had accused her of spending more time on the student newspaper, The Cornell Daily Sun, than in the lab.
 
Father Taught Engineering
But numbers fascinated her. At the age of 10, she was using a slide rule. ''Dad thought that anyone with his genes had to be good at math,'' she said. Her father, who taught engineering at the University of Ohio, became dean of the school of engineering at the University of Illinois.
When she was 8, her father asked her and her younger brother to solve a puzzle. The needles had fallen off the Christmas tree. He gave them a thimble, a cup, and a bucket and asked them to calculate how many needles the tree had shed. ''We figured out how many needles fit in a thimble, how many thimbles in a cup, how many cups in a bucket, and so on,'' she said. ''We figured out the number. I've forgotten it now.''
She met her husband, John H. Bryant, an engineer, at a party her father threw for students. Before their children were born, she worked as a science writer. When his work took him to the Detroit area, she continued her graduate studies in communications at the University of Michigan. Her work on her doctorate caught the eye of Mr. Teeter, who asked her to join his public opinion-research firm in 1970. There, while doing polling and survey research for health care agencies and transportation planners, she paid closer and closer attention to census data.
 
Changes in a Decade
By the mid-1980's, she had become head of a census advisory committee of the American Marketing Association and had gotten to know Vincent Barabba. A former census director now General Motors' executive director for market research and planning, he became legendary at Census Bureau headquarters in Suitland, Md., for his ability to rescue the troubled 1980 census and to maneuver within the Commerce Department and on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Barabba was one of the people she consulted before deciding to take the job, as was Mr. Teeter. Both encouraged her, but both pointed out the way the job had changed since 1980.
For one thing, since Mr. Barabba declined to make statistical adjustments in the 1980 count to compensate for the acknowledged undercount of minorities, more than 50 lawsuits had been filed seeking to force adjustment. In 1987, the Commerce Department took control of the adjustment issue - the biggest statistical policy question facing the bureau - as Under Secretary Robert Ortner announced the Commerce Department's opposition to statistical adjustment.
Last summer, in settling a lawsuit brought by New York City, the department agreed to consider adjusting the 1990 count.
In the decade between Mr. Barabba's departure and Dr. Bryant's arrival, the adjustment issue had been the cause not only of external lawsuits but bitter internal disputes, culminating with the 1988 departure of Barbara Bailor, the respected head of the bureau's Statistical Methods Division, after she switched to the pro-adjustment camp.
Her job, which had symbolized both statistical creativity and independence for the bureau, had been vacant since 1988, amid rumors, never confirmed, that all candidates had to convince the Commerce Department that they were anti-adjustment.
 
Professor Is Recruited
One of Dr. Bryant's first moves, since arriving last January, has been to appoint Robert M. Groves, a respected sociology professor from the University of Michigan, to fill the statistical-methods job.
The problems of the census have left Dr. Bryant scrambling to divide her time between managing the census and the bureau's budget planning for fiscal 1992. She is also trying to work on the two tasks closest to her heart: figuring out how to get more and better data out to the bureau's clients in government and business and industry, and how to find a way to make the census a smoother operation in the year 2000.
''I saw that coming in late I couldn't drastically change plans for this year,'' she said. ''But I could exercise some real leadership for the future.''

PUB-DATE: April 19, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 597 words

HEADLINE: Kansas City Rights Leaders Praise Supreme Court Ruling

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 18

 BODY:
Civil rights leaders here voiced satisfaction today over a Supreme Court ruling upholding the right of Federal judges to make local officials raise taxes to remedy problems left by a history of Kansas City school segregation.
But William Webster, the Missouri Attorney General, who had appealed lower-court decisions requiring costly actions by both the state and the Kansas City School District, found some consolation in the Court's ruling. He noted that the Court found that although a judge can order a local governing body to raise taxes, the court cannot directly impose the tax increase itself. 
''It's a victory for civil rights litigants,'' said Arthur A. Benson 2d, a lawyer for a group of plaintiffs in the city's long-running battle over desegregation. ''It affirms the principle that constitutional violations can and must be remedied, even if the remedy requires the constitutional violators to raise taxes, and whether or not their constituents are in favor of new taxes.''
 
Board President 'Delighted'
At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Webster said requiring tax increases to be imposed by the school board was ''a positive step,'' because ''these school board members are elected and therefore accountable to those whom they represent.''
The school board has consistently sided with the plaintiffs in this case. ''I'm delighted,'' the board president, Julia Hill, said of today's ruling.
The legal battle began in 1977 when Mr. Benson, representing a group of schoolchildren and their parents, filed suit seeking to reverse the effects of local school segregation. Over the years, many whites had fled the school district, putting their children in mostly white private or suburban schools. Voters in the city, meanwhile, had rejected a series of proposed tax increases to pay for school improvements.
After a series of complicated interim rulings, Federal District Judge Russell G. Clark in 1986 ordered the state and the Kansas City School District to share the cost of a plan for city school improvements. When voters rejected tax increases to pay for them, Judge Clark in 1987 issued an order increasing the school district's property tax and imposing an income tax surcharge.
 
Many Paid Under Protest
The state appealed, with the Landmark Legal Foundation, a private group, joining the appeal on behalf of district taxpayers. At the Landmark Legal Foundation's urging, many residents paid the increased taxes under protest. That money was put into escrow.
In 1988, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis, overturned the surcharge. It upheld the property tax increase, but it made a key modification. It required that the school board impose the increase, rather than Judge Clark.
The Supreme Court ruling today upheld that modification.
Since Judge Clark's original order, $36 million in tax increases have been paid under protest and held in escrow, according to Jerry Hill, president of Landmark.
About $10 million of the protested taxes were paid in 1987, the year of the direct imposition ordered by Judge Clark. Both Mr. Webster and Mr. Hill said today that they thought the money in escrow would be refunded to taxpayers, and Mr. Hill argued that all the increased taxes paid that year ($17 million was paid without protest) should be subject to refunds because they were unconstitutionally imposed by Judge Clark.
Questions about the taxes paid in protest since 1987, a total of $26 million, were settled by the Supreme Court today when it said they were properly imposed and collected.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: MISSOURI, USA (95%); 

CITY: KANSAS CITY, MO, USA (95%); SAINT LOUIS, MO, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: KANSAS CITY SCHOOL DISTRICT (73%); LANDMARK LEGAL FOUNDATION (67%);

LENGTH: 553 words

HEADLINE: Zeal Won't Free Lithuania

 BODY:
There's no shortage of absolutism in the Soviet Union, Lithuania or the United States on the question of Lithuanian independence:
Soviet hard-liners believe that Mikhail Gorbachev, facing widespread unrest, must tolerate absolutely no impudence from the Lithuanians. Lithuanian patriots, rightly excited at the prospect of reclaiming their destiny, insist on driving to independence immediately. American true believers affirm that, as he loves freedom, President Bush must absolutely support that drive. 
On all sides, they act as though the only choice is to be purist or pusillanimous. But that's harsh, hasty and false. Despite Moscow's cutoff of oil supplies yesterday, there's still an honorable way to resolve the crisis. For all their reciprocal threats and bluster, Lithuania's leaders and President Gorbachev are groping for ways to work out their differences. And with measured skill, President Bush continues to encourage them to find a political solution to a political problem.
Mr. Bush rightly resists pressures to retaliate against Moscow over Lithuania. He warned Tuesday of ''appropriate responses'' if Moscow carried out its economic blockade. But he was careful not to draw lines in the sand.
His critics think they detect a pattern in his reactions to the violent crackdown in Tiananmen Square and the intimidation of Lithuania - indifference to human rights. But that misses a key distinction. Unlike those struggling for rights to be freer in China, Lithuanians seek to secede from the Soviet Union. Mr. Gorbachev says he accepts their right to choose independence, if not their procedures. Having acknowledged the guarantee of self-determination in the Soviet Constitution, Mr. Gorbachev had a statute drafted to give it effect. But Lithuania's leaders did not wait. No lengthy due process slowed their annexation by the Soviets in 1940. Why go slow now in undoing it?
Even before the secession law was enacted, they declared independence. They also passed laws to form a militia, suspend the draft of Lithuanians, issue new national identity cards and take over buildings and factories that are, under Soviet law, Moscow's property.
Mr. Gorbachev then turned tough. He refused to talk to the Lithuanians until they backed down from these acts of self-determination. He reportedly came under pressure to take control of the republic, by force if necessary. Instead he has begun an economic blockade that he says will last until the Lithuanians repeal their new laws - though not necessarily their declaration of independence. In effect, he's floating a concession on a tide of threats.
Some Lithuanian leaders have sensed an opening and tried to enlarge it. On Tuesday, Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said she took ''Moscow's newer, softer position as a sign of their willingness to negotiate.'' Yesterday she persuaded the Lithuanian Parliament to halt new laws asserting independence. She has also hinted at suspending implementation of other new laws. Those conciliatory gestures may not satisfy Mr. Gorbachev but they betoken political realism in Vilnius.
Compromise would be unwarranted if Moscow were still trying to deny self-rule. But it's not. It's contesting the pace of secession and the interim rules. Those are matters for political dialogue, not zealous purism.

LENGTH: 337 words

HEADLINE: Miracle on 42d Street

 BODY:
Finally, it looks like a go. The redevelopment of shabby West 42d Street, an ambitious idea born two decades ago and then delayed by esthetic objections, lawsuits and economic pressures, has taken a giant stride toward reality.
It won't be easy, given the troubled real estate market. But by signing a condemnation order yesterday allowing the state's Urban Development Corporation to take title to most of the site, State Supreme Court Justice Stanley Parness opened the way. That, and a $241 million letter of credit from the developers, mean the transformation of 13 deteriorated, dangerous acres in midtown could actually begin in the fall. 
The saga of 42d Street means something even more profound: It proves that New York has learned from its costly mistakes how to Build Big. Westway, the proposed highway on Manhattan's Hudson River shoreline, died five years ago, a victim of litigation and naive, ill-coordinated political leadership. By contrast, every official involved in the 42d Street project, led by Gov. Mario Cuomo and former Mayor Edward Koch, worked to common purpose.
The result: 43 lawsuits won, only two minor cases still pending, and the prospect of reclaiming what should be a dazzling stretch of urban life. To get to this point, city and state officials have managed to deal with a collection of remarkably diverse interests. For instance, producers and preservationists are concerned about grace and taste for Broadway; community activists are intent on retaining 42d Street's honky-tonk environment, and neighborhood residents are worried about their homes.
The project involves rebuilding eight treasured but dilapidated theaters, constructing four office towers, renovating the Times Square subway station, creating 16,000 construction jobs and 20,000 permanent jobs and, eventually, building a hotel and merchandise mart.
The Great White Way, people used to call the area. They may call it that again, for New York officials are now free to show they can build as big as they think.

HEADLINE: Legislators Tangle Over Trenton Budget

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 18

 BODY:
Republican legislators tangled repeatedly today with their Democratic colleagues and members of the Florio administration as hearings opened on an austere budget everyone agrees will cost taxpayers more and give them less.
Republicans accused the Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, of stifling debate, gagging department heads and pulling the strings of Democratic leaders to ram through a $12.1 billion budget that promises substantially higher taxes and sharply reduced services across the board.
Assemblyman Rodney Frelinghuysen, the ranking Republican on the Joint Appropriations Committee, warned of a ''rush to higher taxes'' that ''may very well be leading our state on the road to economic disaster.''
He also accused the administration of trying to ''railroad'' the budget through the Legislature and vowed, ''I won't be gagged.'' 
 
'A Puppet Show'
Another Republican, State Senator John H. Ewing of Somerset County, charged that ''Governor Florio has turned the budget process into a puppet show in which he controls the strings.''
''The puppeteer has arranged things in such a way as to make informed decisions impossible,'' he said.
There was considerable difference on who should be blamed, but all sides agreed that the state was in the midst of a fiscal crisis.
Democrats blamed former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who in eight years in office presided over a state budget that doubled from $6 billion to $12 billion, with a deficit that, without drastic cuts and new taxes, threatens to go well over $1 billion next year.
The Republicans did not address that criticism head on, but instead maintained that Mr. Kean's successor, Governor Florio, and the Democrats were exaggerating the fiscal crunch in a bid to wrest total control of the purse strings from the Legislature and into the Governor's office and to lay on excessive new taxes.
They suggested even sharper budget cuts and little or no new taxes.
Although the Office of Legislative Services projected revenues about $175 million higher than the administration's estimates over the current and next year's budgets, it agreed revenues remain ''far short'' of supporting the recommended spending without new revenues.
 
Pessimistic Estimates
State Senator Laurence Weiss, the Middlesex Democrat who is chairman of the Joint Appropriations Committee and Governor Florio's legislative point-man on the budget, called it ''New Jersey's worst budget crisis in history.'' He based his assessment on the administration's more pessimistic estimates.
Confronted with a $590 million shortfall in the budget for the fiscal year ending June 30 and $1.4 billion over two years, the budget calls both for new revenues and reduced spending to balance the budget. Neither is likely to be popular in a state that already has a high tax burden but benefited in recent years from a strong economy that made the burden bearable and state service expenditures ample.
Beyond the treacherous political situation that creates for the Governor - who is clearly trying to get the crisis behind him early in his new four-year term - the tightly controlled method he is using to contain it is raising criticisms of its own.
Rather than calling all or most of the state's 19 department heads to answer questions about the new budget, which includes such politically sensitive items as an increase in the state sales tax to 7 percent from 6 percent and elimination of $305 million in homeowner property-tax rebates, the Democratic leadership opted to call only Treasurer Douglas Berman to answer legislators' questions about the budget.
Republican legislators charged that the order to do so came directly from Mr. Florio. Senator Weiss repeatedly denied this, saying the departure from tradition was entirely his idea, although a Democratic colleague conceded that changing the mode of debate was ''admininistration prerogative.''
 
Tactics Could Backfire
While Republicans complained loudly in public over the change, even some Democrats conceded privately that the Governor's close-to-the-chest tactics could backfire.
Besides the decision not to call department heads to testify, ostensibly by the Democratic leadership, Governor Florio has himself mandated that all news releases in the executive branch, not only on the budget but on all other matters as well, go through his office.
This has made not only the Republicans but also reporters restive. A news article Monday in The Trentonian, with the headline ''King Florio and palace guard keep tight hold on power,'' got wide circulation and set off wide discussion in Statehouse corridors.
Mr. Berman also reminded the committee that it was Governor Kean who as late as last October was predicting a $300 million surplus by the end of the fiscal year in June, while it actually is turning out to be a $590 million deficit.
 
Broad Range of New Taxes
It is the shortfall, the admnistratin says, that will require a broad range of new taxes, as well as elimination of about 1,480 state jobs and spending reductions at state colleges and universities that could cut an additional 1,400 jobs.
The proposed budget also cuts state aid to public schools to the lowest level since 1977, recommends no funds for capital construction and a static subsidy for mass transit that will mean a fare rise of 15 percent along with service reductions.
The budget also recommends a wide range of other cuts, including $3 million from the $8 million allocated for community drug programs, $1.2 million from the $17.8 million for AIDS-related programs, and about half of the $18 million for the State Council on the Arts.

Senator Laurance Weiss, left, Democrat and chairman of the Joint Appropriations Committee, talked to reporters as two Republican Senators, Henry McNamara and John H. Ewing, right, conferred. (The New York Times/William E. Sauro)

HEADLINE: Bush Denies Putting Off Action On Averting Global Climate Shift

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
President Bush, responding to criticism that the United States had delayed taking concrete steps to address the threat of global warming linked to pollution, said today, ''We have never considered research a substitute for action.''
Closing a two-day White House conference on the issue, Mr. Bush said: ''To those who suggest we're only trying to balance economic growth and environmental protection, I say they miss the point. We are calling for an entirely new way of thinking, to achieve both while compromising neither, by applying the power of the marketplace in the service of the environment.''
Mr. Bush also proposed a series of steps for integrating international responses to the issue of global climate change. They included an international ''charter'' for cooperation in science and economics related to global change, a statement of principles to guide such research, the creation of international research institutes and a communications network to monitor global changes. 
 
Criticism From Europeans
Although Administration officials said the drafting of the speech had begun some time ago, Mr. Bush's remarks clearly addressed concerns voiced Tuesday by European delegates to the 18-nation conference who complained that the United States only wanted to discuss the scientific and economic uncertainties surrounding the issue rather than specific remedial action.
White House officials warned on Tuesday of the potentially huge cost of reducing the pollution that many scientists believe will raise the temperature of the earth's surface in the next century. They said more research was needed into the economic and scientific uncertainties.
At today's session, a document was inadvertently released, revealing specific proposals made by Mr. Bush later in the day. The document was written in the form of a resolution, seemingly for the approval of the conference.
Many of the delegates protested vigorously when they were given the document, saying they could not approve such sweeping proposals with only a short time to study them. Several commented that the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change convened by the United Nations was doing a good job and that there was no need to create more institutions to address the problem.
Within an hour, the United States re-issued the paper with a cover sheet saying that it had been released in error and was not meant to be acted on by this conference.
White House officials were uneasy over the unauthorized release to reporters of a document containing ''talking points'' for use by American delegates to the conference. Among the points listed under ''debates to avoid'' was the statement that it was ''not beneficial to discuss whether there is or is not'' global warming or how much or how little warming. ''In the eyes of the public,'' it went on, ''we will lose this debate. A better approach is to raise the many uncertainties that need to be better understood on this issue.''
 
Suspicions of Environmentalists
A spokesman for the President's science adviser, D. Allan Bromley, a co-chairman of the conference, said the talking points had been prepared by the conference staff to assist the American delegation.
Environmentalists who provided the document to reporters said it confirmed their suspicions that the conference was called by the White House to plead scientific uncertainty as an excuse for delaying action to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other industrial gases in the atmosphere. Such gases, many scientists contend, will cause a substantial warming of the globe because they retain infrared radiation from the sun that would otherwise be reflected back into space.
Several European officials praised Mr. Bush's speech today, saying it was an improvement over his remarks on Tuesday, which stressed the need for more research. Bert Bolin of Sweden, the chairman of the intergovernmental panel, said, ''I take the President's speech to be a clear signal to proceed very vigorously with what we are trying to do with the I.P.C.C.''

HEADLINE: Dinkins Names Executive Panel On Volunteers

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
To encourage businesses and foundations to adopt programs that need money and manpower, Mayor David N. Dinkins named a committee of business executives yesterday to coordinate volunteer efforts in New York City.
Mr. Dinkins said the committee, which will be known as the Mayor's Committee for Public-Private Partnerships, would expand existing volunteer eforts and develop new ones. The panel will work with a newly created unit at City Hall, the Office of Partnership Programs, he said. 
The Mayor named Carl Spielvogel, the chairman and chief executive officer of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide Inc., to head the committee. Larry Bortoluzzi, who headed economic development efforts in the Manhattan Borough President's office when Mr. Dinkins had that job, has been chosen director of the partnership programs office. Mr. Bortoluzzi will report to First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel.
 
Examples Offered
Mr. Dinkins cited several examples of joint efforts between public and private groups, saying he hoped that the committee and the partnership programs office would find ways to copy them. These were among the ventures he mentioned:
* A program - agreed to by the City Bar Association and the city's Human Rights Commissioner, Dennis deLeon - to recruit and train lawyers to handle discrimination cases on a pro bono basis.
* A plan for the city and Mr. Spielvogel's ad agency to adopt We Can, an organization that redeems empty bottles and cans collected by homeless people. We Can collection boxes will be placed in city-owned office buildings and in Backer Spielvogel Bates offices in the Chrysler Building.
* A pilot program run by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and the Village Nursing Home to bring corporate sponsors together with groups that work with people who have AIDS.
* Adopt-a-Park programs involving Samuel LeFrak, the builder, who will redevelop the landscaping around Willow Lake in Flushing Meadow Park; the Combat roach-control unit of Shulton Inc., which has adopted the Cedar Sedgewick park in the Bronx and will subsidize a summer program for children there, and Grenadier Realty, which has promised to pay for a full-time recreation specialist at the Breukelen Houses Playground, in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
City officials said the leaders of the programs mentioned by the Mayor had agreed to urge other businesses and individuals to join in volunteering. These are the vice chairmen of the committee:
 
Donald Platten, chairman emeritus of Chemical Bank.
Margaret Mahoney, president, Commonwealth Fund.
Horace Morris, executive vice president, the United Way.
Lewis Rudin, president, Rudin Management Company.
Lawrence Tisch, president and chief executive officer, CBS Inc.
J. Richard Munro, co-chairman and co-chief executive officer, Time Warner Inc.
James Robinson, chairman, president and chief executive officer, American Express Company.
Fred Wilpon, chairman, Sterling Equities.
