HEADLINE: Takeovers Face New Obstacles

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
In Harrisburg, Pennsylvania's capital, a long-running battle is being watched in corporate board rooms across the country because it raises issues that will affect how American companies are managed in the 1990's.
Within days, Pennsylvania is expected to enact the most far-reaching anti-takeover law in the nation. To be sure, the corporate buying spree of the last decade has slowed strikingly with the economy sluggish, the junk bond market in a shambles and other takeover financing getting tighter.
But the Pennsylvania law would make it more difficult not only for hostile predators to buy a company with headquarters in the state but also for dissatisfied shareholders to change management through tactics like proxy fights.
 
Statutes in Other States
The Pennsylvania measure is the most sweeping, but other states, including Indiana, Ohio and Delaware, have enacted anti-takeover statutes in recent years. And Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts signed a bill yesterday to increase the protections for its companies. State and Federal courts have also made a series of rulings making it harder to force changes in corporate control. 
Behind the debate in Pennsylvania is a power struggle between the shareholders who own corporations and the directors and managers who run them. In this case, Pennsylvania business groups supporting the bill are aligned with unions seeking to protect the jobs of their members and local politicians worried about the impact of corporate takeovers on communities.
The bill's supporters point to a wave of populist revulsion with the takeover boom of the 1980's and say the statute is just what corporate America needs. It will free companies, they insist, from living in constant fear of being taken over and will allow them to invest to become more competitive rather than worry about increasing quarterly profits to ward off raiders.
 
S.E.C. Chief Among Critics
But critics, including economists and the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, say that moves like the Pennsylvania bill, however well intentioned, will only make American industry less competitive by protecting incompetent managers from being ousted. The law may also be challenged on constitutional grounds of hindering interstate trade and conflicting with Federal securities laws.
The Pennsylvania bill has already overwhelmingly passed both chambers of the Legislature, and the Governor has pledged to sign it.
Its ground-breaking provision requires any person or investment institution owning more than 20 percent of a company's shares for less than two years to forfeit - or ''disgorge'' - any profit on shares sold within 18 months after a failed buyout or proxy fight. The disgorgement provision increases the potential losses to raiders, should they fail.
A ''control share'' provision in the bill would prohibit a shareholder with more than 20 percent of the company from voting his or her own shares to change corporate control, without the approval of the remaining shareholders. And another provision places others - employees, suppliers, or any other identifiable group - on the same footing with shareholders in giving them a say in board decisions.
 
Blunt Criticisms
Harvey J. Goldschmid, a professor in securities law at the Columbia University Law School, said the disgorgement provision was ''clearly one of the most significant and least wise provisions passed by any state legislature.'' It is an unwarranted deterrant to hostile takeovers, and proxy fights, he said, that makes management less accountable to shareholders.
Other critics were even more blunt. Too many corporate managements, said Senator Vincent Fumo, the ranking Democrat on the Pennsylvania Senate Appropriations Committee, are merely ''hacks trying to protect their fat-cat jobs.'' He added, ''I see this bill as a catastrophe and I'm offended as someone who believes in capitalism.''
But in the Pennsylvania Legislature, Mr. Fumo is an exception. The bill passed the state Senate by 45 to 4 last December, and the House this month by 182 to 10.
 
Proponents Equally Passionate
Proponents of the measure are equally passionate, viewing it as a way to protect companies and workers' jobs from becoming the playthings of big investment funds, which often profit from takeovers. ''Pension funds want to see companies in play,'' said Clifford L. Jones, president of the Pennsylvania Chamber of Business and Industry.
Advocates of the bill contend it is intended to let Pennsylvania corporations - like H. J. Heinz, Scott Paper, Westinghouse Electric and Conrail -operate for the long term, unimpaired by raiders.
''We've seen our country go from a major world power to the now-nowism of a short-term orientation,'' said Steven H. Wallman, a lawyer at the Washington firm of Covington & Burling, who drafted the bill. ''The Pennsylvania vote shows we want to go back to that long-term view.''
 
Effect of Local Politics
The overwhelming support for the bill is explained less by philosophy than by local politics. Politicians, business executives and organized labor view it as a means of protecting local jobs and communities.
''Once a company is in play, from what we see, that starts the death dance on the corporation,'' said William M. George, a steelworker and secretary-treasurer of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. The bill includes a provision requiring anyone acquiring a Pennsylvania company to honor all existing labor contracts.
The bill's opponents also lobbied hard. These critics were a diverse group, including the Belzberg family of Canada, which is engaged in a proxy fight to take over Armstrong World Industries in Lancaster, Pa., as well as large institutional investors and public officials like Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C.
Even some leading Pennsylvania companies had qualms. Westinghouse, for instance, reluctantly supported the bill only after a provision was added allowing it and other companies to ''opt out'' of the measure.
But local politics prevailed. ''If you are a representative or a senator, are you more interested in the Belzbergs or in seeing your community prosper?'' Mr. Jones, the State Chamber of Commerce president, asked.
 
Slower Pace of Takeovers
Even without laws like the one in Pennsylvania, the pace of corporate takeovers has slowed considerably. Potential buyers have found the financing for big takeovers in short supply, and courts have increasingly ruled in favor of measures that deter acquisitions.
In 1987, the United States Supreme Court upheld an Indiana statute that limited takeover activity in that state by requiring certain hostile bidders to obtain approval of ''disinterested'' shareholders in order to vote their own shares. Other states followed suit by enacting similar measures.
Last February a three-judge panel of the Delaware Supreme Court ruled that corporations had the right to decide their own future rather than having to sell to the highest bidder. The suit was a reaffirmation of a decision in a case brought by Paramount Communications Inc., which had tried to block the offer by Time Inc. to buy Warner Communications Inc.
Still, a constitutional challenge to the Pennsylvania law seems likely, Professor Goldschmid of Columbia said. And Mr. Breeden has said that the S.E.C. may try to use Federal laws to invalidate portions of the Pennsylvania bill.
Large institutional investors, who now own nearly 50 percent of the equity in American corporations, have been most irked by the Pennsylvania law's provisions that discourage proxy contests. The fund managers do not want to acquire companies, but they increasingly want a say in the management and policies of companies in which they invest heavily. Proxy fights, with shareholders voting for or against changes, provide the means for big investors to exercise their influence.
With proxy contests becoming more frequent as a way to change corporate policies or to take over a company, pension funds and institutional investors are becoming more powerful. They have been sought after in a variety of recent proxy battles designed to change corporate control - but with mixed success.
Coniston Partners, for example, is using a proxy fight to try to unseat the board at the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines. And BTR P.L.C. is engaged in a similar proxy battle at the Norton Company, a Massachusetts-based maker of abrasives, as part of a $1.6 billion bid.
This month, the Torchmark Corporation began a proxy battle to change the board at the American General Corporation, as a prelude to a $6.4 billion takeover of the insurance company. Pension funds were successful in gaining representation on the board of the Lockheed Corporation after backing the corporate raider Harold C. Simmons in a proxy fight in a losing effort to take over the aerospace company. It was the Belzberg proxy assault on Armstrong that spawned the Pennsylvania bill.
The biggest investment institutions, like the $60 billion California Public Employees' Retirement System, have grown so large that the number of companies they can invest in is increasingly limited. They face a predicament in that they often cannot sell shares in a particular corporation without losing large amounts of money themselves.
Investment fund managers say their activism should be a force for improving competitiveness.
This position, however, has not stopped some institutions - among them, public pension funds in California, New York, Massachusetts and Florida - from threatening to reassess their Pennsylvania holdings.
''Who would want to put their money in Pennsylvania corporations if their profits could be jeopardized?'' Elizabeth Holtzman, Comptroller of the City of New York, asked. ''This legislation could well backfire.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Fall Sharply; Rates Soar

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates rose yesterday to their highest levels since last May, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell for the fourth straight day.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 96 1/2, down more than 1 1/4 points, or more than $12.50 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.83 percent. Late Tuesday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.70 percent.
Bond traders looked past the best monthly merchandise trade report in more than six years. The trade deficit shrank to $6.49 billion in February, with both imports and exports lower. 
 
Ignored by the Markets
''I thought the trade report was very good,'' said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh. ''But it seems as if the credit markets are ignoring some of the near-term positives and are beginning to focus instead on some longer-term anxieties.''
An array of investors were reported to be selling securities. Traders at several investment firms said domestic investors were big sellers of intermediate-term note issues. And rumors persisted that Japanese accounts continued to unload bonds.
''I have heard rumors that $6 billion worth of bonds were sold in the last week or so,'' said one bond trader at a large Japanese investment bank. ''We have seen some Japanese selling, but nothing of a size that would lead to that sort of a number.''
 
Rising Inflation
Remarks by Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, helped fuel the downturn. In an interview in Los Angeles with Reuters, Mr. Parry noted that so far this year inflation was running at a higher rate than in 1989 and said that the Federal Reserve needed to take steps to deal with the problem.
''In my way of thinking, inflation is worse,'' Mr. Parry told the news service. ''The Fed must set an objective to get it down and do it.''
James A. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities, said: ''The market was trying to recover when that story was printed. It had a noticeable negative effect.''
Even with the big rise in market interest rates over the last two days, Mr. Capra said, conditions are still unfavorable.
''Most portfolio investors are already heavily invested and don't have a lot of new cash to commit,'' he said. ''And liquidity on the Street is pretty limited.''
Specifically, worries about the upcoming Treasury refunding auctions are increasing, market participants said. Those concerns have been accentuated by the rumors of widespread sales of bonds by big Japanese institutions.
Prices of Treasury securities fell across the board yesterday, with bonds dropping the most.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 14/32 in late trading, down 15/32, to yield 8.73 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 23/32, down 5/32, to yield 8.65 percent.
The Treasury announced late yesterday that it would sell $10.5 billion of new two-year notes on April 25.
 
Bill Rates Rise
Treasury bill rates rose again. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent, up 5 basis points. Six-month bill rates rose by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.77 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.76 percent, up 8 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The big rise in interest rates did not dissuade one corporate borrower, Ontario Hydro, from pricing a $600 million offering of five-year notes.
The 9 1/4 percent notes, which mature May 1, 1995, were priced at 100, 50 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the transaction, which is rated triple A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Demand for the issue was so strong that it was increased from $500 million.
New issues in the tax-exempt municipal bond market were highlighted by the negotiated sale of $172.72 million of triple tax-exempt bonds from the Puerto Rico Housing Finance Corporation.
The bulk of the issue consists of serial bonds from 1990 to 2007. Coupons on the bonds range from 6 percent in 1990 to 7.40 percent in 2007.
Citicorp Investment Bank acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated AA by Standard & Poor's but is not rated by Moody's.
 
Secondary Market Falls
The selloff in Treasury securities continued to hurt prices in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds.
Dealers said prices of most long-term bonds fell by about 3/4 point. Intermediate-term issues slipped by about 1/2 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most actively traded issues fell by about 1/4 point, market participants said.

HEADLINE: Some Smog in Pledges To Help Environment

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
On the bottom of the paperboard container that McDonald's uses for its hash-brown potatoes is the three-arrow symbol that generally denotes a product made of recycled material, and the words ''Recyclable Paper.'' But McDonald's officials concede that the package is not made of recycled paper, is not being recycled and may not even be capable of being recycled because of a promotional label glued to the back.
''It's a little embarrassing,'' said Shelby Yastrow, McDonald's senior vice president for environmental affairs. ''We're going to take the recycling logo off everything except what we are actually recycling.''
 
Meaningless, False Claims
Such labeling typifies what many environmentalists view as a flood of meaningless, irrelevant or false claims being made by corporations trying to look environmentally sensitive, or green. With the 20th anniversary of Earth Day approaching, and major environmental legislation like the clean air measure nearing passage, the number of such claims has been increasing. 
To be sure, many American companies have made sincere efforts in recent months to improve their environmental record. McDonald's, for example, said this week that it would spend $100 million on recycled construction materials used in building and remodeling its restaurants. Last week, the Star-Kist subsidiary of H. J. Heinz said it would stop buying tuna caught by methods that injure dolphins, and most of the industry quickly followed.
But spokesmen for environmental organizations say other moves have been merely window dressing.
''The nature of American business has not changed,'' said Alan Hershkowitz, a senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council. ''Right now the environment is a marketing trend they have to respond to. Three years from now, they will be doing something else as socioeconomic issues change.''
Examples of claims that are not what they seem to be abound. Some marketers of cosmetics labeled ''cruelty free'' may not have actually tested the ingredients in them on animals for toxicity. But the ingredients are often purchased from companies that did such testing, said Jacquelyn Ottman, a marketing consultant in New York.
Claims that a particular brand of toilet paper is made from recycled paper may be similarly confusing, said researchers at Arthur D. Little Inc., a consulting firm. ''What the consumer may not realize is that almost all toilet paper on the market today is made from recycled fibers,'' the consulting company said in a recent report.
 
An 'Ozone Friendly' Spray
Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, the Attorney General of Minnesota, recently cited the case of a hair-care product, White Rain Styling Mousse, that was labeled ''ozone friendly,'' apparently because it had eliminated ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons as a propellant. For one thing, such CFC's are banned by Federal regulation from all but a few aerosol products. Worse, he added that the substitute, with volatile organic solvents like butane and propane, was an important contributor to smog closer to earth.
Another product cited by Mr. Humphrey as making misleading claims is Arrid Extra Dry deodorant, for which some cans proclaim, ''Safe for the Ozone Layer.''
Mr. Humphrey and seven other state law enforcement officers, including New York's, recently formed a group to challenge deceptive or misleading environmental claims for products.
Under pressure from the group and the Federal Trade Commission, the Mobil Corporation recently said it would remove the term ''degradable'' from boxes of its Hefty plastic trash bags. The bags contain a chemical agent that promotes degradation in the presence of sunlight, but because the vast majority end up buried in landfills, the claim was misleading, the officials said. First Brands, which makes Glad Bags, took similar action.
Mr. Humphrey said at a recent conference on packaging that unless false or meaningless environmental claims are curbed, ''consumers will grow as disillusioned about the environment as they are about cholesterol.''
''Wrapping a product in a green package is not enough,'' he added.
 
Caution on Claims
The drive to appear green is being fueled by the rising environmental consciousness of American consumers. ''Just as the 80's saw a proliferation of 'light' products designed to meet growing health awareness, the 90's will be the decade of 'green' products,'' said Dorothy MacKenize, head of product development for the Michael Peters Group, a package design firm.
But environmental advocates say claims that products are labeled ''environmentally friendly'' and ''good for the environment'' should be treated with the skepticism reserved for foods said to be ''organic'' or ''cholesterol free.''
''Many of these claims are dubious at best and outright wrong at worst,'' said Jonathan Schorsch, a researcher with the Council on Economic Priorities, a consumer-oriented group.
''Caveat emptor still holds,'' Mr. Schorsch said. ''Just because a polystyrene container is labeled recyclable, it does not mean much if the nearest recycling plant is hundreds of miles away.''
Indeed, when Heinz announced recently that it would introduce a new type of plastic ketchup bottle that will be labeled ''recyclable,'' officials of the National Resources Defense Council said they would challenge the assertion in places where no recycling programs for such plastics are in existence.
David Ruder, Heinz vice president for consumer products, said the company would use the year before the new bottle is introduced to help start recycling programs. And he said the label would help educate customers about how to recycle plastics.
 
Labels Criticized
Many other packaged-products companies are doing things like putting the three-arrows symbol on products and labeling them ''recyclable.'' But environmentalists point out that virtually everything is recyclable with enough time and effort. They say adding labels like ''recyclable'' and ''degradable'' is a cheap way of looking green without getting involved in the hard work of reducing solid waste.
In the case of the McDonald's hash-brown container, Mr. Yastrow said he was unaware until recently that the recycling symbol was on the package. He said that in years past, environmental groups had urged the company to use the symbol to educate customers that paper products could be recycled.
Even companies that do not do business directly with the public are stressing their concern for the environment. For example, the Chemical Manufacturers Association recently began what it calls its ''responsible care'' program. It includes assurances that the industry will pay more attention to health, safety and the environment.
But even Chemical Week magazine, a trade publication that is hardly hostile to the industry, said that the program might have little practical effect because it ''imposes no timetable or quantitative standards to achieve its goals.''
The conflict between image building and actual practice was highlighted at a recent exhibit in Washington called ''Earth Tech.'' At the exhibit, companies like Du Pont and USX emphasized efforts like the use of bacteria to clean up contaminated waste sites and materials conservation through recycling.
 
Diversion Seen
But some environmentalists said the exhibit was an attempt to divert attention from the pollutants these big industrial companies emit in the course of their operations each year. Peter Bahouth, director of Greenpeace U.S.A., denounced it as ''a slick opportunity for some companies to greenwash their dirt.''
John McAllister, an environmental affairs official for Du Pont, agreed that the company wants to improve its image. ''We want to show technology that now and in the immediate future will contribute to sustainable development.''
Some of the ''green'' assertions being made demonstrate considerable imagination. Speaking for the paper industry, John A. Luke, the chairman of the Westvaco Corporation, acknowledged that the industry pumps 250 million tons of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, into the atmosphere each year. But, he said, trees on company-owned land absorb one billion tons of the substance each year, which he described as ''a very favorable 4-to-1 ratio.''
In addition, he said, the trees emit 750 million tons of oxygen a year. These activities, Mr. Luke said, ''are superb environmental contributions which no other industry can claim.''
A Westvaco spokesman had no immediate response to the observation that the trees would have absorbed the carbon dioxide and emitted the oxygen even if not owned by paper companies.
 
Credit Sought
Alan Lucier, a forestry specialist with the paper industry, said the companies deserved some environmental credit for growing trees on worn out farmland and managing them for faster growth.
For consumer products companies, so-called green consumerism is becoming increasingly important as surveys indicate that customers will choose items that appear to be environmentally friendly over those that do not. One, by the Michael Peters Group, found that 78 percent of consumers said they would pay more for a product made of recycled or biodegradable materials and that 53 percent had declined to buy a product because of environmental concerns.
Patrick A. Carson, a vice president of Loblaw's, Canada's largest food store chain, said, ''We are in the early stages of a green revolution'' in which buyers ''will vote at the cash register on ethical, moral and environmental issues.''
He said when the company offered toilet tissue made of recycled paper, it was the chain's ''best launch in history.''

HEADLINE: Seamen's Bank Seized; Chase Buys Its Deposits

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Seamen's Bank for Savings, which was formed in 1839 to encourage thrift among seamen, was put under the control of Federal regulators at the close of business yesterday. All of its deposits were bought by the Chase Manhattan Bank, which will begin operating Seamen's 13 branches today.
The Seamen's Bank fell on hard times in the early 1980's when sharply higher interest rates paid on deposits caused losses at many savings banks. The losses from high interest rates were compounded in 1987 and 1988 when Seamen's invested heavily in new kinds of mortgage-backed securities. The securities failed to protect the company from fluctuating interest rates and, instead, resulted in large losses. In the first nine months of 1989, Seamen's lost $166.8 million. 
The Federal takeover of Seamen's is expected to cost the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation $350 million to $400 million, according to Alan Whitney, a spokesman for the F.D.I.C. The Government insurance fund, with assets of about $14 billion, will sell Seamen's assets, including loans and securities, and use the proceeds to repay creditors other than depositors. The F.D.I.C insurance fund is separate from the reorganized insurance fund created by Congress last year to rescue the savings and loan industry. $5 Million Price Chase, which will rename the branches, plans to combine Seamen's $2.1 billion of deposits and 13 branches with the $13.7 billion of consumer deposits and 185 Chase branches in New York City, Long Island and Westchester County. For the right to buy the deposits, Chase paid $5 million, beating the price offered by another, unidentified bidder. Chase said it planned to honor the interest rates on all Seamen's deposits until they mature.
Chase has set up a phone line at 800-862-4273 for customers with questions about their deposits. Seamen's customers with questions about loans from the bank may call the F.D.I.C. in New York City at 212-428-4560.
''Chase is getting a pretty good franchise,'' said Henry S. Peltz, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm. Like other savings banks in the New York market, Seamen's branches operated with much higher levels of deposits than normal at commercial banks.
Besides the benefits of a larger deposit base, Chase expects to benefit by offering Seamen's customers various other services like credit cards and personal loans.
The collapse of Seamen's comes at a time when a consolidation of savings banks in New York is moving ahead on several fronts.
Mr. Peltz said that even strong savings banks would consider partners because they ''recognize that size and economies of scale are critical to profitability and meeting capital guidelines.''
Among financially strong savings banks, the Manhattan Savings Bank agreed in recent months to be acquired by the Republic New York Corporation, which will merge it with the Williamsburgh Savings Bank. Apple Savings Bank has rejected a $38-a-share bid from Stanley Stahl, a New York developer, for stock he does not already own.
Home Savings Bank, Brooklyn, is discussing a merger with the Bowery Savings Bank, a unit of H. F. Ahmanson & Company. And Crossland Savings of Brooklyn, the largest savings bank on the East Coast, is working on plans to raise new capital after the breakdown of negotiations to obtain a $150 million capital injection from the Coast-to-Coast Financial Corporation of Chicago.

HEADLINE: G.M. to Begin Production Of a Battery-Powered Car

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 18

 BODY:
Responding to concerns about poor air quality, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it would proceed with commercial production of a battery-powered electric car for personal use.
Despite the announcement, the project seemed to remain somewhat speculative. G.M. acknowledged that a number of technical, regulatory and market uncertainties had not been cleared up. Indeed, G.M. cited competitive reasons for declining to answer the most critical questions about when or where it would begin production of the car and what technology would be used. 
G.M. had displayed a battery-powered car called the Impact in January and said it would decide on the commercial feasibility of the vehicle within a few months. The Impact would be the basis for the car that G.M. said it would produce.
 
Timely Announcement
The announcement that the company planned to begin production was made by Roger B. Smith, the chairman of G.M., at the National Press Club in Washington. The announcement came less than a week before Earth Day and at a time when Congress is considering broad clean-air legislation that could force auto makers to put new pollution controls on their vehicles.
A spokesman said later that the company had not established a definite date and place for the start of production.
Mr. Smith said G.M.'s goal was to be ''the first automobile company since the early days of the auto industry to mass-produce an electric car'' that is safe, performs well and that consumers find appealing.
''What that means is that the Impact is suitable for most urban drivers' daily activities,'' he added.
G.M. has said the car will accelerate from standstill to 60 miles an hour in eight seconds and run for 125 miles before its battery needs recharging. The Big Three and some foreign auto makers have also been testing battery-powered vans.
 
Support for Zero Emissions
Mr. Smith said that public and governmental reaction to the Impact has been positive since G.M. began displaying a prototype at auto shows in Los Angeles, Chicago and Geneva. ''People are concerned about the range of the car, but they're also very much impressed by the fact that Impact produces zero emissions,'' he said.
In the late 1970's, at the height of the energy crisis, G.M. said it would be building 100,000 battery-powered cars a year by 1984, a plan that was abandoned for lack of interest by the public, a company spokesman said.
Mr. Smith said the technology had improved, ''so it's possible to do this with a fresh design.''
G.M. is seeking changes in Federal regulations to make production of the car more feasible, Mr. Smith said. Although he was not specific, he said that current safety standards were meant for the size and weight of internal combustion cars.
G.M. will also lobby the Government for electric cars to be counted in the calculation of corporate average fuel economy, he said.
 
The Battery Problem
But the biggest question is about the vehicle's power source, its battery. Scientists who worked on the Impact prototype noted that it used conventional lead-acid batteries, which emit relatively little power and must be replaced each year at considerable expense.
Noting that the battery ''is such an essential piece of the final picture,'' Mr. Smith said developing one for commercial production might require ''a broad-based development effort, one that involves not only the entire domestic auto industry and the Government, but the electric utility industry as well.''

HEADLINE: Media General Has 77.3% Fall

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RICHMOND, April 18

 BODY:
Media General Inc. today reported a 77.3 percent decline in its first-quarter profit from the period a year earlier as newspaper earnings contracted because of a downturn in advertising.
The company said income in the first quarter of 1989 had been helped by a one-time gain. 
Excluding that, earnings this year were down 56.3 percent. Total revenue slipped slightly. ''Although 1990 revenue growth is expected, the uncertainty of the economy currently is clouding the earnings outlook,'' said James S. Evans, the company's president and chief executive.
Net income fell to $2.7 million, or 10 cents a share, from $11.9 million, or 46 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1989. Last year's earnings included an after-tax gain of $5.7 million, or 22 cents a share, from the sale of a California newsprint recycling mill.
Revenue declined to $148 million, from $149.3 million in last year's quarter.
Media General is the parent of The Richmond Times-Dispatch, The Richmond News Leader and other daily newspapers as well as several broadcast operations. Broadcast profits rose by 2.5 percent in the period.

HEADLINE: U.S. Assailed Over Trade

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, April 18

 BODY:
The European Community today accused the United States of undermining world trading rules through what it said was an array of unfair trade practices.
In its annual report, the European Community's Executive Commission criticized unilateral action by Washington against trade partners to force them to change. 
''The practices identified in this report raise doubts whether the United States is sufficiently committed to the multilateral system which provides the main reference point for resolving disputes,'' the report said.
The report is published by the commission each year as a response to Washington's report on trading partners.
A senior commission trade official said the European report ''illustrates that although the United States is in general terms a comparatively open economy, it nevertheless maintains numerous unfair or discriminatory practices and legislative provisions which impede and distort trade and which undermine the multilateral trade regime itself.''
The report, which the commission said was by no means exhaustive, identified nearly 50 tariff and nontariff trade barriers in the United States.
These included discriminatory policies covering public-sector contracts, unreasonable requirements for standards, testing and labeling, excessive customs fees, export subsidies and tax barriers.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Behind the Selloff Of 3 Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
THE publicly traded shares of three major mutual fund companies have been tumbling in recent weeks, as investors reacted to the fear that credit problems in the commercial paper market could affect the companies' immensely popular money market mutual funds.
T. Rowe Price, whose shares traded around $30 each at the end of March, closed yesterday at $24.375. Similarly, Alliance Capital ended yesterday at $15.625, off from roughly $17 three weeks ago. And Dreyfus, which traded at $36 at the end of March, closed at $32.125 yesterday. 
Behind the selloff is the bankruptcy on April 12 of Mortgage and Realty Trust, affecting $150 million in outstanding commercial paper. Half of that paper was owned by a number of money market funds, including those sponsored by T. Rowe Price and Alliance. In each case, the parent companies of the affected funds bought back the defaulted paper. That made the funds whole and prevented any losses to money market investors.
While the default is not large within the vast $540 billion commercial paper market, it has hit a nerve in the mutual fund industry because it underscores what had previously been largely ignored by investors: that money market funds, while considered very safe, are not totally risk-free.
''There is an age-old view,'' said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytic Services, ''that risk and reward are correlated. The reason that these funds pay you a return that is higher than the bank rate is that you're taking some risk.''
Federal regulators, too, have emphasized that investors need to be aware that money market investments are not guaranteed and risk-free. In the aftermath of a default last fall by Integrated Resources, the Securities and Exchange Commission began talking with mutual fund industry executives about the need to diversify their holdings and keep the average maturity of their funds short.
One indication of the level of the mutual fund industry's concern is that the sponsors of every fund affected by recent commercial paper defaults have stepped in to protect investors. While such response cannot be guaranteed in the future, Robert Pozen, general counsel and managing director of Fidelity Investments in Boston, echoed a common industry response when he said that Fidelity ''would make every possible effort'' to insure that its money fund investors were protected from any default losses.
The industry's protective response is even more remarkable given most analysts' worst-case estimate: that the losses the affected money funds were facing would have reduced yields to investors by only about 1 percentage point, shaving perhaps a penny off the traditional $1-a-share asset value.
''People have always viewed these funds as riskless,'' an industry analyst said, ''and the fund managers now are willing to take on the credit exposure that their money market funds have incurred so they can continue to keep that perception around.'' Is the perception valid? Obviously, money market funds are not insulated from any market risk, Mr. Lipper said. ''We spent a decade leveraging the society, and as we un-leverage, there will be accidents,'' he said. ''I don't think they will be too great, and I think the industry can handle it. But if people are concerned, they should diversify into a number of different money market funds, or focus on funds that invest only in U.S. Government securities.''
So far, investors do not seem to be manifesting any serious concern, although tax-paying season typically produces a flow of cash out of money market funds. A survey of big fund sponsors and various money market monitors yesterday showed little sign that investors are shifting funds out of taxable money market funds.
But in contrast to mutual fund investors, stock market players are reacting - some analysts say ''overreacting'' - to the possibility that the money management firms' willingness to bail out their money market funds may hurt shareholder profits in the future. As evidence of panic, one analyst noted that Dreyfus's shares have been battered even though none of its money market funds were affected by the recent default.
''I think it's overdone,'' Mr. Machmany said. ''Given the earnings power these companies have, the actual amount of defaults that could occur just won't be that substantial. These stocks have gone down many times what the actual earnings impact could be.''

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Slide as Dow Tumbles 32.89

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices tumbled yesterday in the wake of weak corporate earnings, rumors of rising interest rates in Japan and signs that the American economy is much stronger than many people believed. The latest indication of that strength was the improvement in the nation's trade deficit announced yesterday.
As sentiment spread that a decline in interest rates seemed out of the question for now, bond prices fell and interest rates rose and investors scrambled for higher rates. By the end of the day, as the market continued down, the Dow Jones industrial average had sunk 32.89 points, to 2,732.88 - the biggest decline in almost two months. 
The Dow utilities slid 1.76, to 211.96 - the lowest since July 6, when it stood at 210.32.
Volume continued weak at 147.1 million shares, with 1,056 stocks down and 477 ahead. The day before only 128 million shares changed hands.
William M. LeFevre, market strategist for Advest Inc., said, ''The new low in utilities suggests investors think interest rates are headed higher.''
Richard G. Unruh Jr., chief investment officer for Delaware Investment Advisers, with $16 billion of pension funds under management, said, ''We've been surprised the market has held up as well as it has in view of the increase in interest rates.''
''The decline in earnings momentum,'' he added, ''is far greater than normal and because rates are going up with the economy slowing, we've been in a cautious mode, not bearish but cautious.'' To meet that situation, he said Delaware Investment had ''tried to increase the yield on our portfolio.''
First-quarter earnings reports are beginning to pour in and with some exceptions, investors seemed to be taking their profits.
Despite a strong earnings advance, Philip Morris topped the New York Stock Exchange's active list, falling 3/8, to 42 5/8, on 2.35 million shares, after trading as high as 43 1/2.
Tandem, the third most active, rose 1 1/8, to 24 1/8, on 1.98 million shares, because of strong earnings. I.B.M., which advanced 4 earlier in the week on good earnings, fell 1 1/4 in profit taking, to 109 7/8.
A.T. & T., which reported a 12.5 percent rise in profits, fell 1, to 41. MCI, which said profits rose 20.7 percent, fell 1 5/8, to 35 1/8. Continental Bank fell 1 1/8, to 14 5/8 after it said that nonperforming loans for highly leveraged deals rose sharply.
Coca-Cola, which reported a 9.1 percent rise in profits, fell 1, to 79 1/4. Merrill Lynch, whose profits rose 11 percent, fell 3/4, to 23 1/8, and General Electric, which reported an 11.9 percent rise on Tuesday, fell 3/8, to 66 1/2.
After reporting a 5.9 percent drop in profits, BellSouth fell 1 1/4, to 54 3/4. AMR fell 7/8, to 64 1/2, after reporting a $19.3 million loss.
Merck, whose profits rose 18.6 percent, rose 5/8, to 74 3/8.
The S.& P. 500 fell 3.96, to 340.72; the Nasdaq composite 3.90, to 431.52, and the Amex market-value index 1.50, to 353.22.

HEADLINE: Timber Industry Outlook

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
United States timber harvests will increase 55 percent in the next 50 years, but industry employment will drop because of modernization, the Government said on Tuesday. The South will feel the biggest effect, losing about 36 percent of its timber jobs, the General Accounting Office told the House Ways and Means Committee. It said timber employment would probably fall 26 percent in the Rocky Mountain region, 23 percent in the North and 13 percent on the West Coast.

HEADLINE: Catholic Bishops' Big P.R. Blunder

BYLINE: By Eugene Kennedy; Eugene Kennedy, a former Roman Catholic priest, is professor of psychology at Loyola University.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
America's Roman Catholic bishops have committed a blunder as big as the Ritz in hiring public relations and polling organizations to design campaigns against abortion.
Seeking to bolster their moral authority, the bishops chose a strategy that is manipulative at best and numbingly amoral at worst. Sadly, this leaches away the bishops' spiritual authority, even among Catholics who strongly support them and their pro-life position.
In behaving like corporate C.E.O.'s, the bishops are subverting their admirable pastoral strengths and risking the reputation for integrity they have elevated in the last decade. That new respect has been built upon biblically based pastoral letters - public meditations on the morality of nuclear arms and the ethical foundations of economic policy. 
The bishops apparently don't see the incongruity of placing the pro-life issue - which they define as their deepest present moral concern - in the hands of Hill & Knowlton, which also represents Playboy Enterprises. (The $3 million to $5 million that the bishops will spend, even if privately raised, surely can be put to sounder church uses.) Hill & Knowlton, America's largest public relations firm, numbers among its clients the Warner-Lambert Company, which makes oral contraceptives and condoms, and Baxter International, which makes intrauterine devices. It has shaped the images of defense industries, whose contracts do not read like the Gospels.
Public relations agencies and pollsters have prepared the center ring for the ethical circuses of our age. These include Watergate - the tiny car from which moral clowns still tumble - and the Reagan Presidency's masterly illusions, which still deceive us.
The bishops' failure to anticipate that making friends with Mammon would strike great numbers of Catholics as unseemly suggests they are not as in touch with the world and their own people as they once were.
You call in public relations operatives when the truth won't do. That's why p.r. - the very letters evoke subtle maneuvers and manipulation of opinion - has become, in business as in politics, the substitute for a genuine moral and ethical sense.
The p.r. boys made the contras into freedom fighters just as they have tried to make Exxon's monumental oil spill in Alaska into an ecological triumph. No strategy could be more antithetical to the spiritual and moral tradition that the bishops are required to interpret.
Humans cannot be manipulated into moral convictions. Such convictions have no meaning unless they are freely embraced, without external pressure, no matter how deftly applied. Morality depends on a demanding search through the rubble, the noise, of life for facts and principles from which we may forge wise, enduring judgments.
The bishops have always taught this, just as they have taught that no end, no matter its worthiness, justifies ignoble means. No strategy that so obviously affronts the living can advance the interests of the unborn.
Defending themselves, the bishops argue that large-scale public relations campaigns have been successfully used by foes of their pro-life position. They're right. The masterly shift from being ''pro-abortion'' to being ''pro-choice'' has proved enormously beneficial to critics of the church's stand.
But in the long run, neither Hill & Knowlton nor the politically connected Wirthlin Group, the hired pollsters, can help settle the abortion debate. The implications of this issue are too deep to be handled, like Coke-Pepsi wars, by the glibness and window-dressing techniques that form p.r. agencies' bottom-line morality.
Why aren't the bishops demonstrating enough confidence in what they are really best at - being pastors to all people?
We are genuinely moved when John Cardinal O'Connor of New York brings his priestly consolations to the bedside of the burned, sick and dying.
We are stirred when Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago preaches steadily not only about abortion but also about the seamless web of all moral issues - like capital punishment, tax policy, proper nutrition -that affect life.
We are touched by the sincerity of Archbishop Rembert Weakland of Milwaukee, who sympathetically listens to the women of his archdiocese speak about abortion.
In such vignettes, we see the bishops as priests responding to the spiritual longings of their people.
It isn't too late for the bishops' Committee for Pro-Life Activities to cancel the public relations and polling contracts. The recovery of their spiritual authority, the success of their pro-life moral crusade, may well depend on doing just that.
Good shepherds do not invite wolves to help them tend flocks.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 27, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An April 19 article by Eugene Kennedy on Roman Catholic bishops' use of Hill & Knowlton to design their anti-abortion campaign said Baxter International, a onetime client of the public relations firm, makes intrauterine devices. According to a company spokesman, Baxter has never made them.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
First Fisherman Casts An Environmental Line

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
When President-elect Bush visited Islamorada in the Florida Keys after his election, he was just ''goin' fishin'.'' When he returns to Islamorada this weekend, he will be ''enjoying the splendors of our great outdoor heritage.''
Sunday is the 20th anniversary of Earth Day, and the White House is eager to court voters concerned about the environment. So the trip had to have a loftier purpose than sportsmanly pursuit of the wily bonefish and tarpon in the land of Key lime pie and Kon Tiki bars. 
In fact, this whole week is chockablock with what are supposed to be environmentally conscious events, culminating on Sunday in the Everglades, where Mr. Bush will cast his line and discuss conservation with Curt Gowdy for an ''American Sportsman'' television special.
''Fishing on Earth Day,'' sniffed Ruth Caplan, executive director of Environmental Action. ''That's a real commitment.''
President Bush ordinarily shies away from events designed so baldly for image polishing. But for the environment, one of the few areas where his popularity is slipping, he is making an exception. So, the Administration heads for the Great Outdoors.
On Monday, children streamed out of the White House Easter egg roll carrying Virginia pine seedlings grown from genetically improved seeds and a booklet called ''Fifty Simple Things Kids Can Do to Save the Earth,'' like taking shorter showers and refusing plastic foam cups at fast-food restaurants.
On Tuesday and Wednesday, Mr. Bush was the host of an 18-nation conference on global warming from pollution. In Florida on Earth Day, he is expected to approve a Coast Guard plan for new shipping lanes to protect the Florida Keys.
But that is not the ''big announcement'' Florida environmentalists want to hear. They have been waiting for a new oil drilling ban long promised by the White House, and are waiting to pounce.
Meanwhile, even the daily ''points of light'' citations honoring volunteers are devoted to spaceship Earth. In his four-day trip in the South, which started today, Mr. Bush will honor Daniel Keith Odell, a marine biologist from Florida's Sea World Stranded Animals Research Facility.
In Islamorada he will honor Reef Relief, a group that takes boys out to view the coral without dropping anchors that could damage the reefs.
Mr. Bush defends his environmental record with his support for a tougher Clean Air Act, for elevating the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet rank and for increased Federal money for climate research.
Environmentalists find him less menacing than his predecessor. This week's global warming conference was supposed to prove he cares.But it turned out to be less than a perfect photo opportunity; Europeans demanded action, not talk.
Michael J. Boskin, the White House economist, parried, saying the Administration had achieved a ''bold and aggressive and financially and intellectually forceful upgrading of the debate.'' Environmentalists like Dan Becker, lobbyist for the Sierra Club, countered that the emphasis on possible economic disruptions from conservation produced a disturbing clash of Greens and green eyeshades.
The local chapter of the Sierra Club did more than talk; it announced it would sue the White House for not following the District of Columbia's office wastepaper recycling laws. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, had trouble keeping a straight face as he invoked national security concerns to explain the lack of compliance.
The week's events, conducted at the President's usual fast pace, have left even Mr. Bush a bit confused and chagrined.
''Look, I'm down there to have fun,'' Mr. Bush said of his fishing trip. ''If we can help by pointing out the sensitivity of the environment there, the ecological balance in the Everglades, I want to do that.''
But he said, ''I want some understanding and sympathy when I'm out fishing, because I work like hell around here.''

HEADLINE: Excerpts From High Court Decision That Judges May Order Tax Increase

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision on Wednesday that Federal judges may order local governments to increase taxes to remedy constitutional violations like school segregation. Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy the dissenting opinion.
 
FROM THE OPINION
By Justice White
It is accepted by all the parties, as it was by the courts below, that the imposition of a tax increase by a Federal court was an extraordinary event. In assuming for itself the fundamental and delicate power of taxation, the District Court not only intruded on local authority but circumvented it altogether. Before taking such a drastic step, the District Court was obliged to assure itself that no permissible alternative would have accomplished the required task. 
We have emphasized that although the ''remedial powers of an equity court must be adequate to the task . . . they are not unlimited''. . . and one of the most important considerations governing the exercise of equitable power is a proper respect for the integrity and function of local government institutions. Especially is this true where, as here, those institutions are ready, willing, and - but for the operation of state law curtailing their powers - able to remedy the deprivation of constitutional rights themselves.
The District Court believed that it had no alternative to imposing a tax increase. But there was an alternative, the very one outlined by the Court of Appeals: it could have authorized or required Kansas City, Missouri, School District to levy property taxes at a rate adequate to fund the desegregation remedy, and could have enjoined the operation of state laws that would have prevented K.C.M.S.D. from exercising this power.
The difference between the two approaches is far from than a matter of form. Authorizing and directing local government institutions to devise and implement remedies not only protects the function of those institutions but, to the extent possible, also places the responsibility for solutions to the problems of segregation upon those who have themselves created the problems.
 
Financing Public Schools
As Brown v. Board of Education . . . observed, local authorities have the ''primary responsibility for elucidating, assessing, and solving'' the problems of desegregation. . . . This is true as well of the problems of financing desegregation, for no matter has been more consistently placed upon the shoulders of local government than that of financing public schools.
The District Court therefore abused its discretion in imposing the tax itself. The Court of Appeals should not have allowed the tax increase to stand and should have reversed the District Court in this respect. . . . ...
The Court of Appeals held that the District Court in the future should authorize K.C.M.S.D. to submit a levy to the state tax collection authorities adequate to fund its budget, and should enjoin the operation of state laws that would limit or reduce the levy below that amount.
The State argues that the funding ordered by the District Court violates principles of equity and comity because the remedial order itself was excessive. . . . We think this argument aims at the scope of the remedy rather than the manner in which the remedy is to be funded. . . . We accept, without approving or disapproving, the Court of Appeals' conclusion that the District Court's remedy was proper.
We turn to the constitutional issues. The modifications ordered by the Court of Appeals cannot be assailed as invalid under the 10th Amendment. ''The 10th Amendment's reservation of nodelegated powers to the states is not implicated by a Federal court judgment enforcing the express prohibitions of unlawful state conduct enacted by the 14th Amendment.'' Id., at 291. ''The 14th Amendment . . . was avowedly directed against the power of the states,'' Pennsylvania v. Union Gas Co., . . . and so permits a Federal court to disestablish local government institutions that interfere with its commands. . . .
 
Judicial Power Defined
Finally, the State argues that an order to increase taxes cannot be sustained under the judicial power of Article III. Whatever the merits of this argument when applied to the District Court's own order increasing taxes, a point we have not reached . . . a court order directing a local government body to levy its own taxes is plainly a judicial act within the power of a Federal court.
We held as much in Griffin v. Prince Edward County School Bd., 377 U.S., at 233, where we stated that a district court, faced with a county's attempt to avoid desegregation of the public schools by refusing to operate those schools, could ''require the [county] supervisors to exercise the power that is theirs to levy taxes to raise funds adequate to reopen, operate and maintain without racial discrimination a public school system.''
A local government with taxing authority may be ordered to levy taxes in excess of the limit set by state statute where there is reason based in the Constitution for not observing the statutory limitation. In Von Hoffman, the limitation was disregarded because of the contract clause. Here the K.C.M.S.D. may be ordered to levy taxes despite the statutory limitations on its authority in order to compel the discharge of an obligation imposed on K.C.M.S.D. by the 14th Amendment.
To hold otherwise would fail to take account of the obligations of local governments, under the supremacy clause, to fulfill the requirements that the Constitution imposes on them.
However wide the discretion of local authorities in fashioning desegregation remedies may be, ''if a state-imposed limitation on a school authority's discretion operates to inhibit or obstruct the operation of a unitary school system or impede the disestablishing of a dual school system, it must fall; state policy must give way when it operates to hinder vindication of Federal constitutional guarantees.'' North Carolina State Bd. of Education v. Swann. . . . Even though a particular remedy may not be required in every case to vindicate constitutional guarantees, where (as here) it has been found that a particular remedy is required, the State cannot hinder the process by preventing a local government from implementing that remedy.
 
FROM THE DISSENT
By Justice Kennedy
Today's casual embrace of taxation imposed by the unelected, life-tenured Federal judiciary disregards fundamental precepts for the democratic control of public institutions. I cannot acquiesce in the majority's statements on this point, and should there arise an actual dispute over the collection of taxes as here contemplated in a case that is not, like this one, premature, we should not confirm the outcome of premises adopted with so little constitutional justification. The Court's statements, in my view, cannot be seen as necessary for its judgment, or as precedent for the future. . . .
The premise of the Court's analysis, I submit, is infirm. Any purported distinction between direct imposition of a tax by the Federal court and an order commanding the school district to impose the tax is but a convenient formalism where the court's action is predicated on elimination of state law limitations on the school district's taxing authority. As the Court describes it, the local K.C.M.S.D. possesses plenary taxing powers, which allow it to impose any tax it chooses if not ''hinder[ed]'' by the Missouri Constitution and state statutes. Ante, at 21.
This puts the conclusion before the premise. Local government bodies in Missouri, as elsewhere, must derive their power from a sovereign, and that sovereign is the State of Missouri. . . . The Missouri Constitution states that ''[p]roperty taxes and other local taxes may not be increased above the limitations specified herein without direct voter approval as provided by this Constitution.''
For this reason, I reject the artificial suggestion that the District Court may by ''prevent[ing] . . . officials from applying state law that would interfere with the willing levy of property taxes by K.C.M.S.D.''State laws, including taxation provisions legitimate and constitutional in themselves, define the power of the K.C.M.S.D.
Taxation by a legislature raises no due process concerns, for the citizens' ''rights are protected in the only way that they can be in a complex society, by their power, immediate or remote, over those who make the rule.'' Bi-Metallic Co. v. Colorado State Bd. of Equalization. . .The citizens who are taxed are given notice and a hearing through their representatives, whose power is a direct manifestation of the citizens' consent.
A true exercise of judicial power provides due process of another sort. Where money is extracted from parties by a court's judgment, the adjudication itself provides the notice and opportunity to be heard that due process demands before a citizen may be deprived of property.
The order here provides neither of these protections. Where a tax is imposed by a governmental body other than the legislature, even an administrative agency to which the legislature has delegated taxing authority, due process requires notice to the citizens to be taxed and some opportunity to be heard. . . .
The citizens whose tax bills would have been doubled under the District Court's direct tax order would not have had these protections. The taxes were imposed by a District Court that was not ''representative'' in any sense, and the individual citizens of the K.C.M.S.D. whose property (they later learned) was at stake were neither served with process nor heard in court.
The method of taxation endorsed by today's dicta suffers the same flaw, for a district court order that overrides the citizens' state law protection against taxation without referendum approval can in no sense provide representational due process. No one suggests the K.C.M.S.D. taxpayers are parties. ...
The confinement of taxation to the legislative branches, both in our Federal and state governments, was not random. It reflected our ideal that the power of taxation must be under the control of those who are taxed. This truth animated all our colonial and revolutionary history. ...
Our Federal judiciary, by design, is not representative or responsible to the people in a political sense; it is independent. Federal judges do not depend on the popular will for their office. They may not even share the burden of taxes they attempt to impose, for they may live outside the jurisdiction their orders affect. And Federal judges have no fear that the competition for scarce public resources could result in a diminution of their salaries.
It is not surprising that imposition of taxes by an authority so insulated from public communication or control can lead to deep feelings of frustration, powerlessness and anger on the part of taxpaying citizens.
The operation of tax systems is among the most difficult aspects of public administration. It is not a function the judiciary as an institution is designed to exercise. Unlike legislative bodies, which may hold hearings on how best to raise revenue, all subject to the views of constituents to whom the legislature is accountable, the judiciary must grope ahead with only the assistance of the parties, or perhaps random amici curiae.
Those hearings would be without principled direction, for there exists no body of juridical axioms by which to guide or review them. On this questionable basis, the Court today would give authority for decisions that affect the life plans of local citizens, the revenue available for competing public needs and the health of the local economy. ...
This case is a stark illustration of the ever-present question whether ends justify means. Few ends are more important that enforcing the guarantee of equal educational opportunity for our nation's children. . . . But courage and skill must be exercised with due regard for the proper and historic role of the courts.
I do not acknowledge the troubling departures in today's majority opinion as either necessary or appropriate to insure full compliance with the equal protection clause and its mandate to eliminate the cause and effects of racial discrimination in the schools. Indeed, while this case happens to arise in the compelling context of school desegregation, the principles involved are not limited to that context.
There is no obvious limit to today's discussion that would prevent judicial taxation in cases involving prisons, hospitals or other public institutions, or indeed to pay a large damages award levied against a municipality. . . . This assertion of judicial power in one of the most sensitive of policy areas, that involving taxation, begins a process that over time could threaten fundamental alteration of the form of government our Constitution embodies.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Justice Byron R. White; ''A court order directing a local government body to levy its own taxes is plainly a judicial act within the power of a Federal court.'' (The New York Times); Justice Anthony M. Kennedy; ''Today's casual embrace of taxation imposed by the unelected, life-tenured Federal judiciary disregards fundamental precepts for the democratic control of public institutions.'' (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Oakland: Winning by Losing

 BODY:
The city of Oakland, Calif., is a city of sorrow, burdened with high unemployment, inadequate housing and bankrupt schools. Yet it was prepared to shell out $428 million to lure the Los Angeles Raiders professional football team back to the city where the Raiders played until nine years ago, when they moved south. 
This week, however, Oakland's City Council voted unanimously to withdraw the offer. The vote followed a hostile petition drive that gathered 33,189 signatures.
The decision was as rare as it was sensible. It came at a time when cities are falling all over themselves to attract sports franchises or pamper the teams they already have. Most of Oakland's $428 million guarantee would have underwritten season ticket sales, but a big chunk would have been used to build ''luxury boxes,'' those glassed-in suites that rent for thousands of dollars.
Oakland's message is that luxury boxes built at public expense are obscene amid poverty. To Al Davis, the Raiders' owner, luxury boxes are very important. Oakland will lose the team if Mr. Davis decides to take his wandering franchise elsewhere. But the city will have gained something more important - a sense of priorities, and pride.

HEADLINE: Raising New York Housing Allowance Won't Cut Homelessness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Despite New York's pressing need to increase welfare benefits, your support of the Court of Appeals ruling requiring the state to set adequate housing allowances for welfare recipients (''The Court Rules for the Homeless,'' editorial, April 6) doesn't take into account hard facts documented by research. There is no evidence that this response to the inadequacies of the low-income housing market will have any impact. Quite the opposite is true. 
A recent New York University study shows that homeless families are no more likely to have paid higher rents than families who do not become homeless. Furthermore, increases in the shelter allowance in 1984 and 1988 did nothing to alleviate homelessness. After several months, public assistance rent levels caught up with shelter allowance maximums. Increasing the shelter allowance merely increased the money in landlords' pockets without affecting the availability of low-income housing.
Further, the number of families living doubled up or in otherwise substandard conditions has not improved. And this is because there is not enough housing at the low end of the market, with vacancy rates running at practically zero.
The cost of raising the shelter allowance to ''adequate'' levels will be about $300 million to $400 million for the city and $400 million to $500 million for the state, but will not be sufficient to encourage creation of new housing for the poor. At the same time, welfare benefits, which have declined in the last decade about 40 percent in real dollars, will increase about 20 percent, but will be quickly absorbed by higher rents and do nothing to decrease dependency.
The first solution is a straightforward policy to create more housing at the low end of the market, primarily for small, young families, where the bulk of the problem is. The second answer is to reform New York's welfare system by doing away with the categories of welfare (basic grant, utility allowance, shelter allowance) and creating a flat grant system tied to poverty levels, with indexing triggers tied to inflation and incentives for those who make real efforts to get off welfare by education, training and employment. This will reduce welfare rolls, encourage family responsibility and provide families on welfare flexibility to adjust their needs to the realities of the marketplace.
If the court's decision thus provides an opportunity to achieve these ends it will be of lasting significance. Otherwise it will be another costly example of judicial activism with little positive impact on the problem it attempts to solve.
 
WILLIAM J. GRINKER
New York, April 12, 1990
 The writer is former commissioner-administrator of New York City's Human Resources Administration.

HEADLINE: Scrap Immigration Act's Backfiring Sanctions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
If the employer sanctions of the 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act were simply a failed effort to combat job discrimination, more education and streamlined paperwork might counter employment discrimination (''Hasty Hysteria on Aliens,'' editorial, April 3). However, the sanctions provisions were designed to conscript all employers as border enforcers; antidiscrimination measures were included only because critics knew the law's consequences could be disastrous for United States minority and eligible foreign workers. The General Accounting Office report, like the New York State study before it, confirms that the antidiscrimination measures aren't working. 
When a Government program is causing discrimination, more than patience and fine tuning is called for. The program leading to new discrimination should be ended.
That the sanctions program isn't delivering on its promise is all the more reason to call it off. The G.A.O. argues in the most tentative terms that the law is reducing the number of immigrants coming to this country. The law, however, was also intended to drive home those undocumented immigrants who didn't qualify for the amnesty program by making it impossible for them to work. The G.A.O. didn't even examine this matter, but all the evidence is that the vast majority of the three million immigrants and refugees who remain undocumented have stayed. They find the prospects of return to warfare, political upheaval and dire poverty that they fled a poorer option than the exploitative underground economy to which they have been driven in the United States.
Finally, Congress promised organized labor that sanctions would ''save American jobs.'' The G.A.O. report ignores this promise. No evidence has demonstrated that the presence of one undocumented worker results in the loss of one native worker's job or that one immigrant turned back saves one job. Indeed, by strengthening the underground economy, employer sanctions have weakened the status of organized labor and undermined conditions for all workers.
If Congress adopts your recommendations of more educational efforts to instruct employers in the law and simplification of paperwork, Government-caused discrimination will continue. Meanwhile the flaws in the sanctions policy will remain untouched. Employer sanctions do not respond to the overwhelming push to immigration in Central America, the Caribbean and Mexico, nor do they affect the demand for cheap labor in the United States that continues to pull immigrants.
An end to war and repression in Central America and imaginative efforts to ease the impact of debt burdens in Mexico, coupled with rigorous implementation of tough labor protection laws at home, offer better and more humane strategies for reducing the numbers of immigrants to the United States.
 
BONNY BUTLER
Philadelphia, April 9, 1990
 The writer is with the immigration policy issues working group, American Friends Service Committee.

BYLINE: By Andrew L. Yarrow

 BODY:

FRIDAY
 
FILMS FROM HUNGARY
A cinematic look at Communist and pre-Communist Hungary will be offered in a film series opening tonight at the Hungarian House, 213 East 82d Street. It will begin with ''Sinbad'' (1970), Zoltan Huszaruk's portrait of love and life in turn-of-the-century Budapest, and continue on April 27 with ''My Way Home'' (1964), Miklos Jancso's film about a schoolboy captured shortly after the Soviets occupied the country in 1945. The last two films will be ''Confidence'' (1979), Istvan Szabo's tale of assumed identity, love and mistrust during World War I, on May 4, and Peter Gothar's ''Time Stands Still'' (1982), a story of two boys who idealize America in post-1956 Budapest, on May 11. Screenings are at 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $6; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 861-7362 or 879-8893. 
 
RHYTHMIC VARIETY
During a half-century of tap dancing, James (Buster) Brown has played the vaudeville circuit, appeared on stage and screen, and performed with the likes of Cab Calloway, Duke Ellington, Count Basie and Dizzy Gillespie. Now a member of the Copasetics, Mr. Brown will join the Peggy Spina Tap Company, a nine-year-old ensemble noted for its rhythmic variety, for three performances this weekend at the Dance S. Studio, 115 Prince Street in SoHo. The program, ''Foot Fetishes II,'' will include four solos by Mr. Brown. Ms. Spina's company will present eight other works, including three premieres that she described as a ''duet for African Talking Drum and dancer'' choreographed by Theresa McCleary, and two compositions by Joel Forrester, a ''Baroque jazz fantasy'' and a ''funk groove piece.'' Performances are tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 7 P.M. Tickets are $10. Reservations: 674-8885.
 
THE FACES OF POVERTY
The faces and circumstances of poverty in the United States are all too many and varied; one in seven Americans and one in four children live below the officially defined poverty line. This vast swath of America -including urban youths, homeless veterans, Midwestern farmers, unemployed Appala-chian coal miners and Mexican-Americans living in Texas border towns - is the subject of a photographic exhibition that opened yesterday at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street. The show, ''Below the Line: Living Poor in America,'' includes about 60 black-and-white images by Eugene Richards, a photographer who was commissioned in 1986 by Consumers Union to capture the experiences of the country's poorest citizens for a book. The exhibition will be on view Tuesdays through Sundays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., through June 29. Admission is $3; $2 for the elderly, and $1 for children. Information: 873-3400.
 
SATURDAY
 
RUNNING IN TANDEM
For couples who run together, the Trevira Twosome in Central Park is the ideal event. The 10-mile race for male-female partners will begin at 10:30 A.M. at Tavern on the Green, near West 67th Street, and the front-runners are expected to reach the finish line - also at the restaurant - between 11:15 and 11:30 A.M. The event, which is expected to attract 4,000 runners, was the first couples' race when it was started in 1979. A Trevira two-mile race will begin at 10:32 A.M. Registration is closed, but spectators may watch the race at locations throughout the park. Information: 860-4455.
 
SUNDAY
 
SONTAG ON CULTURE
''Culture watching'' is what the Neuberger Museum at the State University College at Purchase is calling its three-part lecture series that begins on Sunday with the writer and critic Susan Sontag. Ms. Sontag's talk, ''Traditions of the New,'' examines ''modern'' ways of looking at the world. The series of Yaseen Lectures on Culture Watching, now in its eighth year, will continue on April 29 with the painter Eric Fischl and on May 6 with the novelist and poet Maya Angelou. Each talk will be at 4 P.M. in the university's Performing Arts Center and will be followed by a reception at the museum. Tickets are $14, or $36 for the series. The university is near Exit 28 (Lincoln Avenue) of the Hutchinson River Parkway. Information: (914) 251-6200.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A NEW ERA AT EASTERN
 
A Federal bankruptcy judge accomplished what organized labor had sought for years. He took control of Eastern Airlines from Frank Lorenzo and appointed an outsider to run the troubled carrier, which had become a symbol of labor strife in the 1980's. The judge's goal is to keep the airline flying at least until it becomes palatable to a buyer. [Page D1.] 
 
Passengers and travel agents were cautiously optimistic, but others are concerned that the naming of a trustee may signal the beginning of liquidation for the airline. [D5.]
 
Martin R. Shugrue's appointment as trustee puts Eastern's operations in experienced hands, but analysts doubt whether he will be able to attract the needed passengers. [D5.]
 
MARKETS
 
The S.E.C. authorized the creation of a new market for stocks and bonds in a move that could increase the dominance of large investment firms in the U.S. financial markets. In the new market, securities can be issued and traded actively, but can be bought only by large institutional investors. [A1.]
 
Stock prices continued to weaken amid computerized selling brought on by inflation fears. The Dow sank 20.94, to 2,711.94. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities dipped for the fifth straight session in light trading. [D15.]
 
Oil prices rebounded after sinking to a 19-month low on Wednesday. Traders cited technical factors more than a planned OPEC meeting. [D14.] The dollar was mixed, losing ground against a revived yen but rising against other currencies. [D14.]
 
COMPANIES
