HEADLINE: Marshall Field Deal By Dayton

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 19

 BODY:
In a deal announced today, Marshall Field & Company of Chicago, one of the oldest and grandest names in American retailing, is to be sold for $1.04 billion to another venerable retailer, the Dayton Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis.
At a news conference here, Dayton Hudson said it would pay cash to acquire Marshall Field from Batus Inc., the American arm of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. The British conglomerate said last September that it would sell the 135-year-old Chicago-based chain of 24 stores as part of a move to thwart a possible takeover. B.A.T. also has Saks Fifth Avenue up for sale.
Dayton Hudson's department store division has 37 stores, divided mostly between the Minneapolis and Detroit areas.
 
Price Called Fair
Analysts said the price agreed upon for Marshall Field was fair. In fact, some retailing experts expressed concerns that Dayton Hudson might be overpaying and could find itself in trouble down the road if consumer buying slackened significantly. 
Officials of Dayton Hudson said they were confident about coming up with the money now for the purchase and in the future to pay down its debts. Both chains have been doing well financially, meaning that Dayton Hudson will not have to spend time whipping Marshall Field into shape.
In a grueling auction, Dayton Hudson prevailed over two other prominent retailers, the May Department Stores Company and Dillard Department Stores Inc. It said it planned no big changes in Marshall Field's operations. The stores, which are in Illinois, Ohio, Wisconsin and Texas, will all remain open, keep the Marshall Field name and will continue to carry the great majority of their existing merchandise.
 
Consolidation Expected
Still retailing experts said they expected a significant behind-the-scenes consolidation of the two chains, as Dayton Hudson sought to reap savings by eliminating overlapping functions like purchasing and advertising.
''There is no question that now that Dayton Hudson has started on the road to becoming a multi-market player there will be a lot of people who will lose their jobs at the management, administrative and merchandising levels,'' said George Rosenbaum, a Chicago-based retailing consultant. ''You don't need one plus one to run this organization.''
If, as expected, the deal receives antitrust clearance, the combination of Dayton Hudson and Marshall Field will create one of the nation's largest retailers, with annual department store sales of nearly $3 billion and operating profits of nearly $270 million. If revenues of Dayton Hudson's other two principal subsidiaries, the Target discount stores and the Mervyn's chain of moderately priced department stores, were added, the new entity would have total sales of $14.4 billion and operating profits of $1.07 billion.
 
Advantage Over May Foreseen
Beyond sheer size, however, a takeover of Marshall Field would give Dayton Hudson a leg up over May, with which it has been vying for leadership in retailing in the Middle West and the Great Plains. The acquisition would add 24 stores and Dayton Hudson has planned to open three more by the end of 1992, raising its total number of stores after the acquisition to 64. Together, these stores would make up the core of a retailing empire that would operate from Ohio west to the Dakotas.
''Dayton Hudson is now in a very good position to dominate the Middle West,'' said Catherine Cooper, a retailing analyst for Kemper Financial Services Inc., the big investment concern based here. ''As a result, it will face a lot less markdown pressure. If you own the market, you pretty much control the pricing.''
Indeed, while Dayton Hudson's share price at first fell on the news -finishing today at $69.125, down $1.625 - the initial reaction among Wall Street analysts was largely positive. Most agreed with Ms. Cooper that the merger would increase Dayton Hudson's market share, permitting the chain to accelerate growth of its sales and earnings.
 
Chains' Similarities
Analysts were also heartened by the similarities of the two chains, similarities they said would allow Dayton Hudson to focus on savings in its operating costs. For example, both chains dominate their home markets - Marshall Field in Chicago, where it operates 13 stores and Dayton Hudson in Minneapolis and Detroit, where it operates 17 Dayton's and 20 Hudson's stores, respectively.
Similarly, both chains sell the higher-priced, higher-quality clothing and other items that cater to well-heeled, fashion-conscious shoppers. Both pride themselves on offering shoppers a high level of service.
''Of all the retail properties out there, this is one of the jewels up for sale,'' said L. Wayne Hood, the retailing analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''This is a strong retailer in markets they understand.''
 
Some Perils Remain
But the acquisition of Marshall Field is not without its perils for Dayton Hudson.
For example, it remained unclear today whether Philip B. Miller, Marshall Field's chairman and chief executive, would stay on. Mr. Miller, whose management team also submitted a bid for Marshall Field, is the one most credited with reviving the chain's fortunes in recent years.
There are also some financial risks. At the news conference, Kenneth A. Macke, Dayton Hudson's chairman and chief executive, said he expected Dayton Hudson's ratio of long-term obligations to total shareholders' equity to rise to 69 percent, from 62 percent, meaning that Dayton Hudson plans to sell bonds to raise at least $400 million of the money needed for the purchase.
''So Dayton Hudson comes out a more highly leveraged company which, in a softer economy, could spell a problem,'' said Monroe H. Greenstein, the retailing analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.
 
Confidence in Financing Deal
But Dayton Hudson officials seemed unfazed by this prospect. Asked whether he was confident he could obtain money for the deal given the uncertain outlook for department store business, Mr. Macke said, ''We will have absolutely no problem financing this.''
Asked about the suggestions that Dayton Hudson might be paying too much, Mr. Macke said, ''We think we got a value that meets our hurdle rates.''
Most important, perhaps, Marshall Field and Dayton Hudson are both fixtures in their selling areas, which some analysts said should give them an edge over rivals if sales weaken overall.
 
Landmark Chicago Store
With its soaring atrium selling floor that is crowned by a 6,000-square-foot Tiffany dome, with its ornate exterior clock towers and its sweeping, Chicago-style windows, Marshall Field's downtown State Street store is a landmark. The store's darkly paneled Walnut Room restaurant is still a favorite among diners in search of a quiet lunch with gracious service. And Marshall Field's mint-flavored chocolates known as Frango Mints are a popular souvenir for visitors.
The 109-year-old Dayton Hudson chain is equally steeped in tradition. Each Christmas, thousands of children make the pilgrimage to the auditorium of Dayton's downtown Minneapolis store to see the Christmas show. In spring, the auditorium is used for a vast display of tulips and artificial butterflies that shoppers line up for hours to see.
Hudson's downtown Detroit store was shuttered several years ago, replaced by stores in suburban malls.

HEADLINE: Group of 7 Asks Money-Laundering Curbs

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
Representatives of the Group of Seven industrial countries proposed a broad set of regulatory and banking reforms today to combat the growing problem of concealing illegal narcotics profits in banks and other financial institutions.
A study panel set up by the group was joined by eight other nations, including Switzerland, Austria and Luxembourg, which are known for bank secrecy. The participation of these three nations was taken as a sign that they would support important modifications of their laws and banking practices, although Bush Administration officials said they did not know if any changes would be imminent.
The proposal calls for the elimination of anonymous bank accounts and accounts held in fictitious names. It also asks for greater international coordination among law enforcement and regulatory authorities. 
Numbered and anonymous accounts have long frustrated investigative efforts to track down drug money and have kept even bankers from knowing the source of funds. In attempting to peel away the layers of anonymity in some European banks and to put pressure on the bankers to change their rules, the recommendations represent a significant step in drug law enforcement.
''It is the single most comprehensive, significant and forceful international declaration on money laundering to date,'' said John E. Robson, Deputy Treasury Secretary, who headed the American delegation. ''It is a clear recognition of the global nature of the problem and acknowledges the need for rapid and tough actions.''
The group also proposed an easing of bank secrecy laws to permit bankers to report suspicious deposits to authorities and called on prosecutors to develop cases against corporations - not just their employees - which engage in money laundering. The committee said bankers should be forbidden to tell customers when they are under investigation.
The report is to be on the agenda at the meeting in Houston in July of the leaders of the Group of Seven - Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, the United States and West Germany. Several of the eight other nations that participated in the study have long been identified as havens for illegal profits. In addition to Switzerland, Austria and Luxembourg, the group includes Australia, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain and Sweden.
Although declarations by the Group of Seven are more often statements of desire and determination than commitments to change, they often lead to, or reinforce, changes in domestic economic policies.
If adopted by the European countries, the proposals could encourage banking by drug traffickers in laundering havens in Latin America and the Caribbean that did not participate in the report.
 
Set Up Last Year
The study panel was set up last July at the annual meeting of the Group of Seven, even though all of the industrial nations have not yet ratified the Vienna Convention of 1988. That convention set out principles for multinational narcotics investigations and provided for treating money laundering as a crime and for extraditing money launderers in nations that signed the convention.
Under the laws of seven of the nations in the study group, including the United States, money laundering is already treated as a crime. Four other nations are considering such legislation. Among the Group of Seven, only West Germany and Japan do not outlaw it.
Congress is expected to strengthen the Federal law this year. The House is scheduled to vote next week on a bill that would set up a procedure for considering the revocation of the license or charter of a bank if it or an employee was convicted of money laundering. The measure is expected to be adopted; a similar proposal has been introduced in the Senate. $85 Billion Laundered Annually The report estimated that each year as much as $85 billion was laundered and reinvested from illegal profits from cocaine, heroin and marijuana.
In recent years, a number of large international prosecutions have illustrated the use by drug traffickers of major banks and other financial institutions to conceal large amounts of illegal money and to repatriate profits abroad. Earlier this week, the Justice Department announced that it had ordered 173 banks in 23 states to produce the records of more than 750 accounts in a case involving the laundering of $1.2 billion through more than a half-dozen foreign countries. The banks were not accused of wrongdoing.
There is also concern among some prosecutors and law enforcement officials that the integration of Europe's markets in 1992 will make it easier to launder money as national regulatory barriers are dropped and trading activity increases.
 
Some Differences Expressed
Several regulatory issues failed to gain unanimous support. For example, the report noted a division over whether banks should be required to report suspicious transactions.
Nor did the report address other important areas, like regulating electronic transfers of money, in the effort to prevent the use of banks to hide narcotics proceeds. With increasing frequency, narcotics traffickers use these transfers to move their profits swiftly between accounts in different countries. Mr. Robson said the Treasury Department expected to complete by summer regulations announced last fall that could require greater record-keeping by banks and clearinghouses of electronic transfers.
The study did not call for member nations to adopt the reporting requirements of American banks; currency reports must be filed for transactions of more than $10,000. That regulation has stirred considerable debate in a number of nations, most recently in Canada where the opposition has criticized the Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney for failing to adopt a proposal similar to American law.
Rather, the report called upon member nations to ''consider the feasibility and utility'' of a system of reporting large currency transactions to a national central agency.

HEADLINE: Oil Issue: How Much for Reserve?

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The oil reserve established by the Government 15 years ago as an insurance policy against supply disruptions is coming under new scrutiny as imports rise and the budget-conscious Bush Administration looks for ways to cut costs.
The chairmen of important committees in the House and Senate have introduced bills calling for the reserve, now at 580 million barrels stored in salt domes on the Gulf Coast, to reach a billion barrels eventually. Supporters say a bigger reserve is needed because American imports are growing - they are now just shy of half of domestic demand, a record.
They point out that the reserve currently represents 81 days of imports, down from 118 days at its peak and below the 90-day level that the United States and other members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development each agreed to maintain after the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo. What is more, experts note, world oil supplies are becoming tight, leading to fears that a war or natural disaster could cause a shortage and a jump in price. 
 
A Novel Approach
But the Bush Administration, citing the cost of filling the reserve and arguing that so much oil is already on hand that additional reserves would probably not be useful, has proposed capping it at 750 million barrels, and filling it at a slow rate, 59,000 barrels a day. At that rate it would take almost eight years to reach that goal.
And to reduce expenses without limiting the reserve even more, the Administration has recommended that Congress authorize a novel way to fill the reserve: Rather than buy oil outright, the United States would lease it from countries like Saudi Arabia. It would be bought only when actually needed. The oil would still be stored in this country, under the control of the Government.
The five-year legislation under which oil is bought for the reserve expired on April 1, but Congress has not decided what long-term action to take and has extended the current law until Aug. 15. The budget for the reserve, known as the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, is $600 million for the current fiscal year; including that sum, the United States has spent $19.4 billion on the reserve since its inception. The reserve was set up in the Ford Administration after the Arab embargo quadrupled the price of oil and left drivers fuming and cars sputtering.
 
Domestic Output Is Down
The importance of the reserve has increased, proponents say, because of a 17 percent decline in domestic oil production in the last five years.
In the Senate, J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, the chairman of the Energy Committee, has introduced legislation calling for a billion-barrel reserve. He said that by the time the reserve reached the current goal of 750 million barrels, that amount would most likely not equal 90 days of imports; in fact, under some Government forecasts, even one billion barrels may be less than 90 days' worth by 2000.
In the House, Philip R. Sharp, Democrat of Indiana, the chairman of the subcommittee with jurisdiction over the reserve, has also introduced legislation calling for a billion-barrel reserve, assuming that a system can be found for ''suitable financing,'' presumably leasing.
 
Oil Products Sought, Too
His bill would also establish reserves of oil products like gasoline and heating oil as well as a reserve for crude, and make it easier to release crude oil supplies so the reserve could be used ''in circumstances that are less than an energy apocalypse,'' Representative Sharp said. In testimony before the Senate Energy Committee last month, Robert H. Gentile, Assistant Secretary of Energy for fossil fuel, acknowledged the benefits of the reserve. But he added, ''The question is whether expanding the S.P.R. beyond 750 million barrels is necessary or justified.''
The reserve is already ''one of the largest direct investments by the Federal Government in the energy sector,'' he said. The Administration believes that an oil supply interruption in which more than 750 million barrels would be useful is sufficiently unlikely that the added security would not be worth the expense.
 
New View at OPEC
Experts cite some trends that endorse this idea. Since the 1970's, they say, oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have repeatedly asserted that they see stability of supply and price as being in the interests of sellers as well as buyers. The sudden price increase of 1979 led to development of oil wells in consuming countries that reduced dependence on OPEC. It also led to lower demand, and oil prices plummeted.
But Philip K. Verleger, a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics, testified that an interagency study on which the Bush Administration based its position had vastly underestimated the potential for price rises.
The reserve is intended to deliver oil at a rate of 3.5 million barrels a day, which is about 40 percent of the level of imports lately, and the plan is to increase the capability to 4.5 million barrels a day. Experts expect that not all imported oil would be cut off and that therefore the reserve would last far longer than the 81 days if it made up for all imports.
 
Two Major Shortfalls
According to the Department of Energy, the oil shock of 1973-74 was caused by a supply shortfall of 1.6 million barrels a day, or 2.75 percent of worldwide consumption, and the shock of 1979, set off by the fall of the Shah of Iran, was caused by a shortfall of 3.7 million barrels a day, or 5.68 percent of consumption.
While the reserve would seem to make up for a shortage, Mr. Verleger said that the market would react sharply in hours or even minutes, while pumping oil out of the reserve would not begin for weeks. To be effective in stabilizing prices and preventing panic, he said, the reserve's oil should be sold to refiners immediately, even while still in the salt domes. Much oil already changes hands this way, he pointed out, in contracts for future delivery.
In fact, the most valuable part of the reserve may be the realization by dealers that its oil could quench demand in the market, proponents say. Representative Bill Green, Republican of Manhattan, described its value as like that of a nuclear missile, with a ''deterrent effect.''
But a new study by Cambridge Energy Research Associates commissioned by the Council on Foreign Relations, a nonprofit study group, suggested another possibility. ''During a real or perceived supply interruption, inventories might be husbanded because of rising price expectations,'' the study said. ''So S.P.R. oil might just go from salt domes into steel tanks.''
 
The Leasing Proposal
Among the alternatives explored by the Cambridge study was leasing oil for the stockpile, rather than buying it. The Energy Secretary, James D. Watkins, has recommended that Congress authorize such leasing, although the details have not been worked out. One possibility is that the Government would pay an annual fee equal to 5 percent of the oil's value, or about $1 a barrel. The oil would be stored on the Gulf Coast and the Government would decide when it would be sold to refiners.
The Saudi oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer, said at a news conference in New York last month that his country was interested in providing the oil on that basis. The theory behind leasing is that it would mean added revenue for an OPEC member without violating production quotas. The oil would not come under the quota until it was sold, American oil experts say.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
It's 'Slugflation,' Not 'Stagflation'

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the United States economy on the verge of stagflation, that baleful mixture of stagnation and inflation from which it suffered in the late 1970's and early 1980's?
The report this week that the Consumer Price Index had jumped by one-half of 1 percent in March, pushing the first-quarter annual rate of increase in retail prices to 8.5 percent, heightened inflationary worries. Bond prices tumbled, the dollar fell and interest rates climbed. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bonds shot up to 8.83 percent on Wednesday, with the Japanese said to be big sellers of long-term United States bonds. 
At the same time, some reports pointed toward economic stagnation. Sales of domestically built cars, vans and light trucks fell by 11.2 percent from a year ago in the first 10 days of April. Housing starts dropped by 9.3 percent in March, to an annual rate of 1.32 million units, down from 1.57 million units in January. The real estate market looked sick and corporate profits are off.
But analysts should look at all the evidence before deciding that either inflation or stagnation is the order of the day. For instance, business plans for spending on new plant and equipment this year are up by more than 8 percent.
The report on the rise in consumer prices in March was preceded, a week earlier, by a report that producer prices fell in March by two-tenths of 1 percent. Since wholesale prices feed into retail prices, the April report on consumer prices, when it arrives, will probably show a decline from the high first-quarter rate.
And oil prices have been edging down, as OPEC struggles to get its act together; that is in sharp contrast with the oil-price explosion of the 1970's that kicked off the last stagflation. The American economy is still rising, if at a slow rate. Real gross national product rose in the fourth quarter of 1989 at an annual rate of just nine-tenths of 1 percent, but it seems to have picked up to a rate of 2 percent or more in the first quarter of this year. There are no signs that the American economy is about to fall into a recession. Indeed, demand has been strong enough to permit retailers to take a chance on raising prices, in an effort to improve profit margins.
The relative strength of demand also emboldened Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and a majority of the members and the Open Market Committee to resist earlier pressures to bring down interest rates. The pressures came from the White House and Treasury, many manufacturers and home builders, and even from some members of the Fed. Those pushing for an easier monetary policy feared that the buildup of private and public debt in the last decade had been so great that the nation simply could not afford to risk a recession, lest it result in a financial breakdown. The collapse of savings and loans, with an ultimate cost to taxpayers now estimated at $325 billion to $500 billion by the General Accounting Office, even without a recession, dramatized the risks of the enormous debt overhang.
Now the concerns about inflation have caused even those Fed governors who had been pushing for easier money to back off. But there is still enough concern about the economy's sluggishness to stop the anti-inflation hawks from tightening further. The hawks can afford to wait and let the market take on the unpopular job of raising rates.
The retreat of foreign investors from the United States bond market is also bringing down the dollar. This may help to shrink the trade deficit this year, easing protectionist pressures in Congress, although few economists expect that the drop in the trade deficit, to $6.49 billion in February, will continue at so low a rate.
So, in the midst of these conflicting pressures, monetary policy is now on hold, as the Fed waits to see whether the real economy will break out, by next autumn, on the high or low side, and whether the inflation rate holds within the 4 to 4.5 percent rate that nowadays is considered ''normal.'' If consumer prices are really moving up, not to the 8-plus rate reached in the first quarter, which looks highly improbable, but even above 5 percent, the Fed would be bound to tighten, unless the economy was plunging.
Instead, continued slow growth and moderate to slightly higher inflation appear to be in the cards. The majority of private economists polled by Blue Chip Indicators are continuing to predict no recession this year, with the real growth rate moving up from 1.9 percent in 1990 to 2.3 percent in 1991. And the consensus calls for a rise in consumer prices of 4.6 percent this year and 4.2 percent next year.
Some other term than stagflation is needed to describe this state of the American economy combining sluggish growth with sluggishly rising prices. ''Slugflation'' might do it. Or Prof. Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology may come even closer with the title of his new book: ''The Age of Diminished Expectations.''

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Pact Brings Skepticism in Congress

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
In the first public exchange between the Bush Administration and Congress over a new trade agreement with Japan, lawmakers voiced skepticism today about Tokyo's commitments and the extent to which the accord would help American exports.
''My impression is that other agreements with Japan with very specific goals have not worked and have been ignored, and this agreement is kind of soft and fuzzy, which makes it even more difficult to put in effect,'' said Sam Gejdenson, a Connecticut Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade.
But Administration officials defended the pact as ''historic and unique'' in its focus on fundamental barriers to market forces, and said that while results might not be felt overnight, it should help insure a healthy and balanced economic relationship between the countries. 
 
Going on Record
''This is the first time the Japanese Government has gone on record as admitting that there are structural impediments in Japan,'' said S. Linn Williams, the deputy United States trade representative. ''This is the first time there is something approaching a comprehensive undertaking to address them.''
In an interim accord announced on April 5 in Washington and Tokyo, the Japanese Government promised to stiffen penalties for antitrust violations, shorten the time needed to open large retail stores, spend more money on public works, alter tax laws to expand land use for residential construction and make other ''structural'' reforms.
Administration officials from five agencies, appearing at a joint hearing before two subcommittees of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, tried to show how these and other measures would eventually improve the American trade accounts. The agreement is expected to become final in July.
 
Few Specifics
Lawmakers said today that the accord seemed to lack specifics, had few time frames or deadlines and that even if it succeeded in knocking down some barriers provided little assurance that the United States would get the business, rather than the European Community, Australia or other competitors.
Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, citing a comment of The Economist, the British weekly magazine, asked whether the accord was ''fishy.''
Stephen J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat who is the chairman of the Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs, tried to get the Bush officials to predict how much the agreement would actually lift American exports.
The Administration witnesses said that the United States, which accounts for about 23 percent of Japan's total imports, should at least maintain that proportion as Japanese imports increase, but they declined to make specific forecasts.
Charles H. Dallara, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, said the relationship between the Structural Impediments Initiative, as the effort to deal with broad obstacles to trade is called, and the exernal accounts was ''so complex that I don't think any model-based figures are going to be worth the time and effort.''
''What we are essentially trying to do is to create a level playing field,'' said Dr. John B. Taylor, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
But at another hearing before the Senate Banking Committee, David C. Mulford, the Under Secretary of the Treasury, citing the recent depreciation of the yen and Japan's closed markets, warned that the American trade deficit might worsen this year.
Congressional criticism of Japan, sometimes known as Japan-bashing, has been a primary force behind Administration initiatives to try to get the Japanese to open their markets. The Congressional criticism is a response to complaints from business constituents about the difficulties of selling in Japan.

HEADLINE: 3 Bell Units Post Gains In Profits

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Three of the seven regional Bell operating companies announced moderate growth in first-quarter earnings and sales yesterday, while a fourth, the Pacific Telesis Group, said its sales rose slightly while earnings fell.
The improvements came despite a national trend of state regulators' agreeing to loosen rules in return for lower local rates. Pactel's earnings fell 17.4 percent, which the company attributed to a rate reduction in California. 
Profit growth at the Bell regionals has been limited because many state regulators are demanding reductions in local rates in exchange for issuing new rules that allow companies to keep more of the gains from cost-cutting measures, said Edward M. Greenberg, an analyst at Morgan Stanley.
In the last two years, 11 states have introduced regulations that give incentives for cost reductions, said Ward H. White, the vice president for government affairs of the United States Telephone Association, a trade group in Washington.
Another common thread in the first-quarter reports has been rapid growth in the number of cellular phones, said Charles W. Shelkey, an analyst at Smith Barney.
 
Nynex
The Nynex Corporation reported that net income rose 2.8 percent, to $291.4 million, or $1.46 a share, from $283.6 million, or $1.44 a share, for the quarter a year ago. Revenues at the parent of New York Telephone and New England Telephone grew 2.2 percent, to $3.3 billion, from $3.23 billion.
William C. Ferguson, chairman and chief executive, attributed his company's slow growth in earnings to weakness in the Northeast's economy. Allowing for that, ''I'm not too unhappy with that 2.8 percent, because we got it by controlling our costs,'' he said in a telephone interview.
Jennifer L. Stonestreet, manager of the Fidelity Select Telecommunications Fund, said Nynex's results matched predictions because of cost-cutting, especially efforts to trim the work force to levels prevailing at other Bell regionals. ''Their expense control was excellent,'' she said. Nynex shares lost $1.50 yesterday, closing at $81.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Pacific Telesis
Pactel's earnings fell to $262 million, or 65 cents a share, from $317 million, or 76 cents a share. Revenues crept up 1.3 percent, to $2.37 billion from $2.34 billion.
California introduced new rules on Jan. 1 that increased Pactel's flexibility in price and spending decisions. But the new regulations were tied to an annual rate reduction of $391 million, which cut earnings and revenues at Pactel's main subsidiary, Pacific Bell. The announcement came after the close of trading.
 
Bell Atlantic
The Bell Atlantic Corporation announced a 7.4 percent increase in earnings, to $355.3 million, or 90 cents a share, from $330.8 million, or 84 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues increased 9 percent, to $3.02 billion from $2.77 billion.
The nation's largest provider of local telephone service attributed the revenue rise to strong demand for its network services products. These include Caller ID, which had attracted 65,000 customers by the end of the quarter, Bell Atlantic said.
 
U S West
Earnings at U S West Inc. rose 7.4 percent, to $271.9 million, or 73 cents a share, from $249.6 million, or 68 cents a share, for the period last year. Revenues climbed 1.4 percent, to $2.43 billion from $2.39 billion.
The number of subscriber lines served by U S West grew by 3 percent over the last 12 months, to 12.3 million. But reduced rates associated with regulatory change and lower interstate access charges meant that overall telephone revenue was little changed, Jack MacAllister, chairman and chief executive, said in an interview. U S West shares fell 25 cents, to $72.50 on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Trustee Has Experience, And Plenty of Problems

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The appointment of Martin R. Shugrue as the special trustee of Eastern Airlines puts the troubled company in the hands of an experienced airline executive, but analysts doubt that he will be able to attract the thousands of additional passengers that Eastern must have to emerge from bankruptcy as an independent airline.
Former associates at Pan American World Airways described the former Navy pilot, who is 49 years old, as a hard-charging, accessible executive who immerses himself in the details of daily flight schedules and other operations, while leaving broader planning and financial issues to others.
''Marty is a hands-on type of guy,'' said Tom Lambert, president of the Pan American chapter of the Flight Engineers International Association. ''He's got a lot of moxie. He can move in and take care of a problem. He doesn't delegate it.'' 
 
Rose Through the Ranks
The son of a policeman in Providence, R.I., Mr. Shugrue received a bachelor's degree in economics from Providence College in 1962. He rose through the ranks at the Pan Am Corporation, which he had joined in 1968 as a pilot known as a cockpit navigator, to become vice chairman in 1984.
A year later, he added the title of chief of operations. He had previously held senior marketing and personnel posts at the airline. By most accounts, Mr. Shugrue enjoyed favorable relations with Pan American's unions.
Some people in the industry said Mr. Shugrue burdened the company with heavier costs than other large airlines by committing Pan American to large wage and benefit packages for its employees. ''He has a little trouble saying no to somebody he likes,'' Mr. Lambert said.
Pan Am's directors eventually forced Mr. Shugrue and Edward C. Acker, the company's chairman and chief executive, to resign after the two executives sparred over plans to rescue the faltering airline in 1987 while losses mounted.
 
President of Continental
Within months, Frank Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, parent of both Eastern and Continental Airlines, hired Mr. Shugrue to direct daily operations at Continental as its president.
But Mr. Shugrue quit that post in less than a year after he clashed with D. Joseph Corr, a strong-willed executive whom Mr. Lorenzo had recruited to preside over Continental -and over Mr. Shugrue - as its chairman and chief executive.
''Marty is a capable guy,'' Mr. Lorenzo said yesterday in an interview. He said Texas Air's directors had hired Mr. Corr to work with Mr. Shugrue in changing Continental's strategy and operations to appeal more to business travelers. ''Marty and Joe just didn't hit it off,'' Mr. Lorenzo said.
Industry analysts said Mr. Shugrue's goal at Eastern would be to increase the number of passengers and keep its operations intact through the summer as creditors attempt to find a buyer for the airline.
That could raise more cash for Eastern and enable it to step up payments on its debt, which totals nearly $1 billion. Creditors would be more likely to limit their losses on Eastern if the company were sold.
 
A Grim Alternative
The grimmer outcome for creditors would be a complete shutdown of operations, followed by an auctioning of Eastern's aircraft and gate slots at several airports, including the line's hub at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta.
Raymond E. Neidl, an analyst at Dillon, Read & Company, and Mr. Lambert of the flight engineers' union each said that Mr. Shugrue faced an almost impossible task and that Eastern was not likely to survive the year as an independent carrier.
If Eastern's passenger count and ticket revenues are not stronger through the summer, which is the busiest season for air travel, creditors at Eastern will probably press either for an immediate sale or dismemberment of the airline's opeations, Mr. Neidl said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Yen As It Closes Mostly Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday in domestic currency exchange trading, losing ground against a revived Japanese yen but rising against most other leading currencies.
Analysts said rumors in the markets that the Japanese were about to raise interest rates - placing the yen in a better position against the American currency - put pressure on the dollar.
Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc., said the dollar had not performed as well as might have been expected in recent days, given a surprisingly large improvement in the American trade deficit this week, and an increase in market interest rates in the United States. 
 
Rates May Be Stabilized
Mr. Barbanel said exchange rates might be stabilizing, or foreign currencies may be enjoying a technical ''bounce'' after the dollar's recent rise.
Overseas dealers said the yen's modest recovery after weeks of declines was a result of a range of events, notably a rebound on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and reported comments from United States Treasury officials that they considered the dollar too strong.
The dollar closed in Tokyo at 157.75 yen, down 2.12 yen from the Wednesday close. Later in London, the dollar traded lower at 156.40 yen. In New York, it fell sharply to 157.25 yen, from 158.125 late Wednesday.
The British pound was quoted at $1.6448, up from $1.6347 late Wednesday. In New York the pound fetched $1.6450, up from $1.6400.
 
Late New York Rates
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6787 West German marks, up from 1.6720; 1.4847 Swiss francs, up from 1.4785; 5.6425 French francs, up from 5.6200; 1,233.50 Italian lire, up from 1,228.25, and 1.16225 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16135.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with those of late Wednesday, were: 1.6755 West German marks, up from 1.6720; 1.4815 Swiss francs, down from 1.4876; 5.6325 French francs, up from 5.6315; 1.8820 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8855; 1,231.25 Italian lire, up from 1,230.50, and 1.1618 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1640.
In the precious metals market, gold rose $1.20 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $377.20, and was later quoted at a bid price of $377 by the Republic National Bank in New York, up 70 cents from late Wednesday.
Gold traded in London at $376.55 an ounce, up from $375. Silver rose two-tenths of a cent on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $5.067 an ounce.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Decline

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped for the fifth straight session in light trading yesterday, but traders said that after the big losses of the last few days bargain-hunters were creeping back.
The bulk of the declines were recorded during trading in Europe, as dealers there reacted to Wednesday's huge selloff by pushing prices lower. But a recovery of sorts began once activity shifted to the United States.
''The market is oversold,'' one trader in government bonds said. ''All the talk is bearish, but we have had a pretty good adjustment over the last few days and we are starting to see a little bottom-fishing.'' 
 
Notes Only Slightly Lower
Since the start of the week yields on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds have risen by more than 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. But traders said the real bargains were to be found among short-term securities like two-year notes, now trading at only slightly lower yields than those offered on 30-year bonds.
''The long end is still overpriced, particularly relative to two-year paper,'' the trader said.
Late yesterday the 8 1/2 percent Treasury bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 96 13/32, down 6/32, to yield 8.84 percent. During trading in London yesterday yields on the benchmark issue rose as high as 8.90 percent. Late Wednesday the bond was offered at a price to yield 8.83 percent.
In comparison, the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered in late trading yesterday at 99 17/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.76 percent.
 
Surprise to Analysts
The recent spurt in interest rates, caused in large part by renewed concerns about inflation, has come as a surprise to analysts, who were looking for a moderating trend in prices and the economy.
But others, who say the increase reflects stronger economic growth and heightened inflation expectations, suggested that even higher rates were likely in the months ahead.
''The market is concerned that either the economy and/or inflationary pressures are beginning to rise,'' said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago. ''I think that notion is premature.''
Nancy J. Kimelman, chief economist at Technical Data, a financial advisory and service firm in Boston, said that ''given the inflation rate we had in the first quarter, we need to see consumer prices rise at 3 percent or less for the remainder of the year to get inflation back to where people were anticipating it would be at the start of the year, at 4.5 to 5 percent.''
 
Near-Term Rally Seen
''I think we will get a near-term rally,'' Ms. Kimelman added, ''but I'm not afraid to say we are going to see bond yields run through 9 percent sometime this year. And you can't rule out even higher rates later on. The rise in rates reflects a readjustment in inflationary expectations.''
Prices were only modestly lower in the secondary market for intermediate-term Treasury notes. And rates on short-term Treasury bills fell.
In the note market, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered late yesterday at 97 23/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.84 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 98 23/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.80 percent.
 
Bill Rates Down
Meanwhile, three-month Treasury bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent, down four basis points. And six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.82 percent.
Traders in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that selling by large institutional accounts pushed down the prices of most actively traded issues by about half a point.
The investment-grade corporate bond market, hard hit by the recent slide in Treasury prices, stabilized somewhat yesterday. Dealers said that most issues in the secondary market were unchanged on the day.
 
Two Money Gauges Rise
In another development, the Federal Reserve Board reported that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose sharply during the week ended April 9. The narrowest measure, M-1, fell by $2.4 billion.
The increase in M-2 and M-3 were well above the forecasts of most analysts. But few expressed alarm at the figures.
''The trend in the money supply of late has been weak and sluggish,'' said Ken Kim, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and analysis on developments in the credit and foreign exchange markets. ''I think these figures are an exception to that trend, and are probably due to tax payment preparation.''
The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: U.S. Report Describes Weak Soviet Economy

 BODY:
The Soviet economy is in such bad shape that a ''single major event,'' like a long strike or new ethnic unrest, could cause economic chaos, Congress was told yesterday. 
Intelligence experts painted an unusually grim picture of rising prices and empty shelves, of policies gone awry and of bureaucratic inertia.
While the Kremlin has said its new policies can revive the economy, one American expert said ''the prospect of even a modest economic recovery appears to be remote at best.''

HEADLINE: Prices of Co-ops Sag in New York About 5 to 10%

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Two years into a real-estate slump that has left the owners of New York City cooperatives and condominiums worrying how far the value of their homes has fallen - and many apartment hunters wondering if now is the time to buy - a review of recent sales suggests that prices have sagged 5 to 10 percent across the city. But there is no evidence of a collapse. In some suburbs in the New York region, home values have plummeted as much as 30 percent, brokers say, and other regions of the nation have suffered even steeper declines. But selling prices appear to have dropped more moderately in most New York City co-op and condominium buildings since the first quarter of 1988.
 
Watching for the Bottom
Powerful economic forces continue to weigh on the city, and no one can be certain that the slow decline has hit bottom. Heavy layoffs on Wall Street have hammered the real-estate market, and the financial problems of sponsors in 200 converted co-op buildings have chilled buyers and lenders alike.
Still, economists and real-estate executives say there is huge backlog of demand in the city that should make itself felt when buyers sense that the market has bottomed out. In a city where finding a better place to live is close to an obsession during real-estate booms, it remains a powerful preoccupation when the market slumps. 
''The first question we are hearing from buyers is whether things will be worse next year,'' said Roberta Faulstick, vice president of the William B. May brokerage in charge of sales in Greenwich Village, Brooklyn Heights and Park Slope. ''We don't have a crystal ball. We tell them our general sense is that the market is stabilizing.''
Some say the best opportunity to find a bargain may already have passed.
''I was hoping to buy at the bottom, and I'm afraid I've waited too long,'' said Simon Barkagan, a Manhattan physician who has spent the last year scouring the fashionable buildings on the Upper East Side, hoping to find a large three-bedroom at a steep discount. He said he missed a chance in January, because an apartment he wanted, offered at $750,000, was snapped up by someone else who bid more than the asking price.
 
A 'Quality of Life' Purchase
Alan Eisenberg, the owner of a Manhattan film-editing company, said he looked at 50 co-ops and condominiums before signing a contract last month to buy a four-bedroom co-op on West End Avenue at 75th Street.
''The question is whether you are buying for a better quality of life or just as in investment,'' he said. ''If what you want is a place to live, this is a good time in New York City.''
Mr. Eisenberg said his reason for buying now is that he is getting married and needs space for a child. Although he declined to say how much he paid for the co-op, he said the price was reduced more than 25 percent from what the owner had asked in newspaper ads in December.
Assessing the New York City market is difficult because the selling prices of cooperative apartments, which far outnumber condominiums, are not publicly reported. As in the case of the apartment purchased by Mr. Eisenberg, asking prices can be misleading because they are often far higher than what owners are willing to accept.
 
Sales Comparisons
But several brokers and management companies agreed to provide price histories of apartments, in most cases on the condition that addresses not be published. The results provide a rough sampling of a market in which the value of most apartments has declined:
* On Riverside Drive in the 70's, a large one-bedroom co-op on the 14th floor with a balcony and Hudson River view sold for $274,000 in February, $6,000 less than the comparable apartment on the 11th floor had sold for three months earlier.
* At a 29-story co-op in the East 60's, sales of comparable two-bedroom apartments have been frequent enough to show a trend. The apartments sold for $610,000 in 1987, $675,000 in 1988 and $615,000 late last year.
* At 1088 Park Avenue, a richly appointed co-op at the corner of 89th Street, a large three-bedroom on the third floor sold for $1.4 million in June 1988. The comparable fifth-floor apartment went for $1.6 million in July 1989, and the one on the 10th floor is now for sale. The owner listed it at $1.6 million in October, but he has now dropped the asking price to $1.3 million. #30,000 Wall St. Jobs Lost One grim uncertainty is employment on Wall Street, where more than 30,000 jobs have been eliminated since the 1987 stock market collapse, bringing some apartment owners under intense pressure to sell their homes.
Perrin Long, a securities industry analyst with Lipper Analytical Services, estimated that 17,000 additional Wall Street jobs would be cut this year as investment firms further consolidate their operations.
Another problem weighing on the market is the financial difficulties of sponsors, reported in January by the New York State Attorney General, that threaten the stability of some co-ops converted under noneviction plans from rentals. The problems mainly are in buildings that retain many long-term tenants paying below-market rents.
In these buildings, the state said, sponsors are in a financial squeeze because the income they receive from rents of apartments they own is not covering their monthly expenses for maintenance and upkeep. Although none of these co-ops have defaulted on their underlying mortgages, the Attorney General's office has compiled a ''watch list'' of 200 buildings where sponsors are behind on maintenance charges and payments on loans they have taken out on occupied units.
 
Mortgage Money Tight
For those trying to buy or sell co-op units, the difficulty has extended beyond the buildings being watched by state officials because lenders have become more cautious in extending mortgage loans.
''Things are getting tighter all over,'' said Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a financial publishing firm that tracks lending policies in the New York City real-estate market. He said many lenders that had been requiring 20 percent downpayments for apartment purchases are now requiring 25 percent down, and most are reluctant to extend financing at converted buildings that retain many rental apartments.
Real-estate sales people say one significant change in the market has been that the largest, most fashionable apartments, which previously had been holding their value because of high demand from buyers, have now declined slightly in price.
''The larger apartments in the best locations have joined the slump,'' said Barbara Corcoran, president the Corcoran Group, a brokerage in Manhattan that specializes in expensive apartments. In a survey of 2,640 apartment sales in 1989, the most complete analysis of co-op sales available, she said prices had fallen an average of 9.2 percent during the year, following average increases of 8.1 percent in 1988.
 
Price Decline Persists
Ms. Corcoran also tracked sales during the first three months of this year, but confined the analysis to a much smaller number of two-bedroom apartments, and found that prices continued to decline. Although there is no consensus on price trends, other real-estate professionals said they do not dispute her findings, saying the average decline in apartment values had been between 5 and 10 percent since the beginning of 1988.
Like the prices that are paid, the number of apartments sold is difficult to measure in New York City. Brokers regard their sales volume as proprietary information and fear giving away information to competitors. Nevertheless, some will speak of percent changes, among them Douglas Elliman, one of the city's largest brokerages, which reported a 15 percent rise in sales in the first three months of this year against the comparable period in 1989. Another big brokerage, Sulzberger Rolfe, said its 1990 sales were running 28 percent above those of last year.
But in a broader analysis, in which Ms. Corcoran compiled the number of sales contracts recorded at brokerage offices across the city, she said she found a 19 percent dropoff in the number of sales in the first three months of the year. She also said the length of time it takes to sell an apartment is growing, from an average 23 weeks in 1989 to 26 weeks this year.
Despite the sluggish conditions, many apartment hunters and real-estate executives say they are convinced that prices will not go lower. One reason is that New York remains a city of renters, many of them paying almost as much each month in rent as it would cost to own an apartment.
Although rental rates have not been rising as fast as they were in the mid-1980's, and have declined on some of the most expensive apartments, the financial distance between renting and owning appears to have narrowed.
''You hit bottom when the net economic cost of owning an apartment is similar to what it would be for a market rate rental, and I am confident we have reached bottom,'' said John Tyrrel, senior vice president of Sulzberger Rolfe.
Although they are greatly outnumbered by cooperative apartments in New York City, the number of condominiums has been growing rapidly since a surge of new construction in the late 1980's. Because their selling prices are recorded with the city and are available to the public, analysts say they provide a narrow but precise gauge of the market.
In the most comprehensive study of the condominium market, Yale Robbins, a real estate analyst, looked at thousands of sales and calculated selling prices per square foot of space in the apartments. He found that prices reached a peak in early 1988 and then fell swiftly by as much as 10 percent by early 1989. Over the last year, the study found, prices were relatively constant.
Mr. Robbins said two-bedroom condominiums sold for an average of $382 a square foot in February, down from $410 two years earlier. One-bedroom condominiums were also down, selling for $358 a square foot in February, compared to $395 two years earlier. Studio apartments held up slightly better, selling for $355 a square foot in February, down from $385 a square foot two years earlier.

HEADLINE: MERCK IS OFFERING TO CUT DRUG COSTS OF MEDICAID USERS

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Breaking with longtime drug industry resistance, Merck & Company said yesterday that it would offer discounted prices to state Medicaid programs for the poor.
Merck, the world's largest pharmaceutical company, acted as members of Congress and Medicaid officials in several states sought to force drug makers to cut prices. The company, which is based in Rahway, N.J., said its proposal could save the Federal-state programs millions of dollars.
Under the plan, states would get rebates based on Merck's lowest prices, to match what it already offers to the Veterans Affairs Department and a few other large purchasers. 
Merck's best-known products include Vasotec, a blood-pressure and heart drug; Mevacor, a cholesterol-lowering agent, and Pepcid, an ulcer treatment.
 
End of Curbs Sought
Merck's move makes good business sense, analysts said. As part of the deal, the states would have to agree to exempt Merck's patented drugs from restrictions that make it difficult or impossible for doctors in some states to prescribe many of the most expensive drugs for Medicaid patients.
Some state Medicaid plans maintain lists of approved drugs, often requiring the use of low-priced generic aternatives unless a doctor specifically requests the higher-priced drug.
Ronald Nordmann, an analyst at Paine Webber Securities, said the Merck program was ''a very clever program'' and ''it would bring increases in purchases of Merck products.''
Merck, which has a 5 percent share of the worldwide pharmaceutical market, presented its plan to Medicaid officials in 20 states and Congressional committee aides on Thursday. A number of state officials welcomed the proposal as an industry effort to help with prices, but some said a careful analysis would be required.
Securities analysts said they doubted that other drug companies, which do not have as many $100 million-a-year products as Merck, would copy the plan unless forced to do so by new legislation.
In California, officials of the Medi-Cal program for the poor said a draft of a bill in the California Assembly that would apply the Merck program to all drug companies was circulating among legislators. ''Drug company representatives have been asking us for our reaction,'' said Vic Walker, a senior consulting pharmacist with Medi-Cal, who was skeptical about the Merck proposal. ''We're taking it with two or three grains of salt.''
 
'Program Will Make Sense'
Sanford Luger, chief consultant pharmacist with New Jersey's Medicaid program, which covers all drugs, said that ''Merck has again shown its leadership; I believe the program will make sense.''
But John Alquest, the commissioner of medical services in Kansas, said that giving up his state's drug restrictions might ''result in increased cost to us; we're going to have to take a closer look.'' A dozen states restrict Medicaid prescriptions for at least one Merck product.
Other drug companies were reluctant to comment on the proposal. Noting that ''Merck is one of the leading companies in our industry,'' Edward A. West, a spokesman for Eli Lilly & Company, said the plan ''appears interesting, but we don't feel we're in a position to discuss it in depth.''
''It would be premature for us to comment until we study it further,'' said Anthony A. Biesada, a spokesman at Pfizer Inc. Peter Wolf, a spokesman for the Warner-Lambert Company, said, ''It wouldn't be appropriate to comment on another firm's pricing practices or policy.''
The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, said its board would discuss the proposal at its next meeting on May 3. 10 Percent of Sales Dr. John L. Zabriskie, president of Merck Sharpe & Dohme, Merck's drug manufacturing unit, said Medicaid purchases amounted to about 10 percent, or $300 million, of the company's $3 billion in annual American pharmaceutical sales.
''Our proposal maintains the physician's prerogative to prescribe what they think best for poorer patients just as they do for the general public,'' he added. ''We don't think governments should be interfering in that decision.''
The nation's Medicaid programs spent $3.3 billion on drugs in 1988. Christopher Jennings, deputy staff director of the Senate Committee on Aging, said that if the Merck plan was widely accepted, it could mean potential savings of $20 million to $30 million, based on the company's current discounts of 7 to 12 percent for bulk buyers.
Senator David Pryor, who is preparing a bill to require drug companies to bid for Medicaid business, said the Merck proposal was ''generally encouraging.'' The Arkansas Democrat added, ''It represents an acknowledgement that it makes no sense for taxpayer-funded poverty programs to keep paying top dollar'' for drugs.
But Mr. Pryor, who is chairman of the Committee on Aging, said that Merck's discounts were much smaller than those of ''most other drug manufacturers,'' which grant price cuts of up to 40 percent to hospitals and health maintenance organizations.
Mr. Nordmann, the analyst, said the plan was ''a viable alternative to the Pryor bill.'' He added that other drug companies, many of which offer deeper discounts, were unlikely to follow Merck's lead unless Senator Pryor's bill attracted strong support.
 
Discounts Much Smaller
California officials said some manufacturers had been charging Medi-Cal patients almost twice as much as the Veterans Affairs Department pays for the same drugs. But Merck's discounts are much smaller, Mr. Walker said. For example, Medi-Cal patients are charged $27.83 for a month's supply of Merck's Pepcid ulcer drug, but the Veterans Affairs Department pays $24.26. Medi-Cal pays $56.97 for a bottle of Vasotec, Merck's blood-pressure drug, which costs the Federal veterans agency $54.03.
Merck said it was addressing ''America's health-care cost problems'' and that it had kept its drug price rises below 5 percent this year and in 1989. Prices charged by the drug industry as a whole have been increasing at about twice the rate of inflation in recent years.
Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, had said in November that the company's policy was to raise prices no more than the inflation rate.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
U.S. SEES THREATS TO SOVIET ECONOMY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
The economy of the Soviet Union is in a ''near crisis'' state, and prospects for improvement are slight, United States intelligence agencies told Congress today.
A ''single major event'' like a prolonged strike or new ethnic unrest could lead to economic chaos, the agencies said.
In their annual report to the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency said Moscow had cut military spending by 4 to 5 percent last year, the first such cuts since President Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader in 1985. Further cuts are likely this year and next year, the agencies said. But they said the reductions so far do not meet Mr. Gorbachev's pledge to reduce military spending by 14 percent and weapons production by 19 percent. 
The report is always read closely by students of the Soviet Union, and the data compiled in preparing it are crucial to American policy makers. This year, the intelligence experts painted an unsually grim picture of rising prices and empty shelves, of policies gone awry and of bureaucratic intertia.
 
Strong Medicine or Compromise
The assessment of the Soviet economy last year was not substantially different from Moscow's own. But while officials there have been somewhat optimistic that new policies can turn the economy around, the American experts took a different view.
''The prospect of even a modest economic recovery appears to be remote at best,'' said John L. Helgerson, Deputy Director for Intelligence at the C.I.A. ''The most likely outcome for 1990 is that the Soviet economy will stagnate or decline slightly, that inflationary pressure will remain strong and that widespread shortages will persist.''
Mr. Helgerson was skeptical that Mr. Gorbachev could achieve the bold economic measures he has promised. ''We wonder if this will finally be the strong medicine the economy needs or another compromise,'' he said.
The analysts buttressed their anecdotal snapshots, familiar to most anyone who has been in the Soviet Union, with statistical data, including these:
* Total energy production fell last year for the first time since 1940. Oil output, for example, dropped 2.5 percent.
* A small per capita increase in consumption was due largely to a sharp rise in sales of alcoholic beverages and imported consumer goods. The production of alcoholic beverages increased 20 percent after the Government eased controls on vodka sales.
* The 1.5 percent increase in the Soviet Union's gross national product was illusory. Much of the Soviet output went into warehouses and never reached customers.
* An improvement in agricultural production after a two-year decline was offset by widespread breakdowns in the transportation and distribution networks. Freight shipments fell by 116 million tons, one of the worst annual performances in years.
 
Cuts in Conventional Forces
Assessing military changes in the Soviet Union, Dennis M. Nagy, Acting Deputy Director for Foreign Intelligence at the Defense Intelligence Agency, told the lawmakers that Moscow was well on the way to accomplishing the unilateral troop reductions and conventional arms cuts promised by President Gorbachev.
''The withdrawal of most if not all Soviet forces from Eastern Europe appears to be only a matter of time,'' Mr. Nagy said. He said that tank production had been halved and that production of field artillery, multiple rocket launchers and bombers had also declined.
The decline in military spending, Mr. Nagy said, consisted of a 6 to 7 percent drop in weapons procurement, a 5 percent cut in operations and maintenance and a 4 percent reduction in spending for personnel.
On the other hand, Mr. Nagy said, the modern equipment being withdrawn from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union's eastern and southern borders is not being destroyed but is being stored in the interior of the country. Furthermore, he said, cutbacks in conventional strength are not matched by nuclear forces.
 
Causes of Economic Distress
''The Soviets have continued vigorous and broad-based modernization of both their strategic offensive and defensive forces,'' Mr. Nagy said. He continued, ''The trend toward modernization of a somewhat smaller military force will continue.''
The intelligence agencies said the causes of the economic distress in the Soviet Union included these:
* Some policy decisions had unforeseen consequences. For instance, the decision to allow an increased budget deficit stimulated strong inflationary pressure.
* Central economic planning was abandoned long before market revisions were in place. As a result, although some enterprises were free to produce what they wanted, the lack of competition and market prices often meant that expensive goods were made that nobody wanted.
* The Soviet Union lags far behind the West in the use of computer technology, making modernization of industry difficult if not impossible.
Also, disasters like the earthquake in Armenia in 1988 and the nuclear power disaster at Chernobyl in 1986 squeezed already limited resources.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Intelligence agencies told Congress the Soviet economy had reached a ''near crisis.'' John L. Helgerson, left, Deputy Director of the C.I.A., and Dennis M. Nagy, Acting Deputy Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, testified before the Joint Economic Committee. (The New York Times/Jose R. Lopez)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); EUROPE (92%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (91%); 

CITY: MOSCOW, RUSSIAN FEDERATION (91%); 

COMPANY: DEFENSE INTELLIGENCE AGENCY (91%); DEFENSE INTELLIGENCE AGENCY (91%); CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY (90%); CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY (90%);

HEADLINE: For North, Missions That Have One Goal

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
Oliver L. North is still a man with a mission.
In fact, since his conviction last May for involvement in the Iran-contra scandal, the retired lieutenant colonel in the Marine Corps has become a man of many missions.
He is traveling the country, preaching freedom - freedom not only for the Nicaraguan rebels and the peoples of Eastern Europe but also freedom from what he calls an ''imperial Congress,'' freedom for young people trapped in the nation's slums, freedom for the American economy and, well, freedom for Oliver North, felon.
He is also pulling in a lot of money, sometimes as much as $25,000 for a single speech, and, in a departure from the usual political practice, is being paid to make political endorsements.
Many conservatives see Mr. North as the man who can rejuvenate the right - the Barry Goldwater and the Ronald Reagan of the 1990's. He gives every indication that he is willing to be out in front, to walk point, as they put it in the Marine Corps. And he shows no sign that being found guilty of obstructing Congress, destroying Government documents and taking an illegal gift has dampened his zeal for the cause. 
 
Assembling a New Organization
''Ignorance and apathy aren't just problems of the left,'' he says, looking as fit and closely cropped as in the days when he was serving as an aide to the National Security Council, devising ways to sell arms to Iran in return for hostages and enough profit to underwrite the rebels in Nicaragua.
Already, as he awaits the outcome of an appeal of his conviction and three-year suspended sentence, he is assembling a new conservative organization, the Freedom Alliance. In his words, it will seek ''to return America to its first principles'' of traditional morality, free enterprise, close-knit families, sound schools and a strong defense.
Howard Phillips, a veteran of the right who heads a major organization, the Conservative Caucus, said, ''Ollie comes closest these days as a rallying point for true conservatives.''
''He has the potential to be someone like the Goldwater of the 50's and 60's or the Reagan of the 70's and 80's,'' Mr. Phillips added. ''There's a real need for a new focal point because so many of the true conservative positions got subsumed or watered down in the later Reagan years. Ollie North is the most marketable political commodity that I know of in the whole United States.''
 
On the Road and Speaking
The marketing is well under way.
Mr. North is spending 15 to 20 days a month on the road delivering his message about God and country, mainly to civic and business groups. The message is now well honed; the timing of the jokes and digs is trouper perfect.
First there is some Congress bashing and some baiting of news organizations. Next comes a plea for a voter revolution. Then comes a clucking litany about the fallen ''Commie Cronies'' in Eastern Europe.
He does not credit glasnost for this development. Rather, he pins the medal on his old supreme commander, Ronald Reagan, the man who would not testify on his behalf at his trial.
 
'We Must Remain Vigilant'
But always he adds a warning. ''We must remain vigilant,'' he says. ''We must keep our eyes open and our powder dry.''
At some point in most speeches, Mr. North speaks of personal mistakes and of the special hurt he felt when his felony convictions cost him his military pension, his right to vote and his right to serve in Government. But he offers no apologies. Sometimes Mr. North shows up for his speeches in a limousine escorted by the police. He often confronts clusters of noisy protesters and eager autograph seekers. Usually he gets a hefty fee, the charge reportedly being $25,000, although those who hire him and those who arrange his speeches refuse to say how much he receives.
Mr. North is also appearing at fund-raising events and rallies for conservative candidates. Most political stumpers do this kind of work at no charge or for expenses, but he usually requests a fee.
 
Aides Say North Isn't Rich
His aides and friends say the fee is readily paid by candidates. And they said it is justifiable because the money goes to Mr. North's lawyers and to the Freedom Alliance, which pays him an annual salary of $44,000. They put little stock in a contention by the judge in his trial that his notoriety had made him rich.
''Ollie still buys the cheapest beer he can find, and he still takes his garbage to the dump so he can save the $30-a-month collection fee,'' said Ben Hart, the executive director of the Freedom Alliance.
Some months back, Mr. North raised money for a Republican Senate candidate in New Hampshire, Thomas Christo, who supports abortion rights, not the usual conservative stance. Next month, he is scheduled to raise funds for a Republican Senate candidate in Michigan, Clark Durant, who opposes abortions, the more typical conservative approach.
This straddling on a major issue has left some conservatives mumbling, though mostly to themselves so far. On the other hand, the straddling, along with the fee Mr. North charges, led The Ann Arbor News in Michigan to write in an editorial: ''There's something contemptible about this kind of political trafficking. Big-money endorsements don't necessarily cut it with the people, whose votes aren't for sale.''
 
Working With Youngsters
Besides working with conservative candidates, Mr. North is also working with ghetto youngsters, trying to persuade them to stay off drugs and to stay in school.
This work began as court-ordered punishment, which also included two years of probation and a $150,000 fine, along with the suspended three-year sentence. Mr. North was sentenced to 1,200 hours of community service, and he is still serving that with the Alliance to Save America's Future, a Washington group that works with inner-city youngsters in the capital. Mr. North says that what he has witnessed and experienced in the slums of the nation's capital has given him a desire to spend much of his future working to ''save'' American youth and, by extension, America.
Mr. North's close friends go beyond saying he is simply ''imbued'' with a desire to work with youth as a result of his Washington experience. ''He's been radicalized into action by what he's seen,'' said L. Brent Bozell 3d, a conservative advocate who is close to Mr. North. ''He never speaks of his work in the ghetto as being punishment.''
Finally, there is Mr. North's new business venture.
He and an old acquaintance from the Central Intelligence Agency in the Iran-contra days, Joseph Fernandez, have formed a company called Guardian Technologies International that makes body armor for police officers and others in need of such protection. Mr. North, who reportedly was once a target of terrorists and who is frequently accompanied by security guards, says in one company brochure: ''I rely every day on the security of a G.T.I. vest.''
By any measure, Oliver North is a busy man in the aftermath of the Iran-contra scandal.
But in a larger sense, Oliver North is mainly waiting. He is waiting for the outcome of his court appeal, waiting to see if the word ''felon'' will be struck from a life record that he sees as one of steadfast duty, honor and courage.
