HEADLINE: Biotechnology Enters Political Race

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis., April 18

 BODY:
A furious four-year struggle that mixes concern about new farm technology with old-fashioned partisan politics has left Gov. Tommy G. Thompson facing one of the most difficult decisions of his administration.
The 48-year-old Republican Governor, who hopes to be elected to a second term this November, has made attracting and supporting biotechnology businesses a cornerstone of his program to stabilize Wisconsin's struggling rural economy. This state is home to several leading agricultural biotechnology companies.
Now the first economically important farm product of the young biotechnology industry is poised to come to market: a genetically engineered drug intended to increase milk production in cows by 10 to 25 percent. 
Standing in the way is the Wisconsin Legislature, led by Mr. Thompson's Democratic challenger for governor, the Assembly Speaker, Tom Loftus. On March 22, the Legislature approved a temporary ban on the drug.
 
Fear of Economic Disaster
Mr. Loftus, 44, and other critics say the drug is a ruinous application of gene-splicing technology that is being forced on the dairy industry by four big corporations. They fear that it will result in a huge milk surplus and that consumer fears about the health effects of residues in milk might lead some people to stop buying dairy products. They say the result would be an economic disaster for farmers.
The manufacturers, the Monsanto Company, Eli Lilly & Company, the American Cyanamid Company, and the Upjohn Company, have been joined by the Food and Drug Administration in declaring that trace amounts of the drug in milk from cows injected with it are harmless.
The drug, bovine somatotropin (suh-mat-uh-TROPE-in), is a nearly identical artificial copy of a natural protein produced in the pituitary glands of cows that helps to control milk production. The development of genetic engineering, in which genes from one species are incorporated into the chromosomes of another, makes it possible to produce unlimited quantities of the hormone for use as a veterinary drug.
Yet after years of review and predictions by the manufacturers that the drug would be approved this year, the drug agency has not cleared it.
The delay is in part a result of a clash that began in Wisconsin in 1986 and spread across the Midwest, New York, Pennsylvania and New England. Led by Jeremy Rifkin, a critic of biotechnology from Washington, and supported by a Wisconsin State Senator, Russell Feingold, hundreds of dairy farmers held protests focusing on the question of who really benefits from the drug: farmers, consumers or the four corporations racing each other to bring to the product to market. Analysts believe the drug could generate worldwide sales of $500 million to $1 billion a year.
After years of trying to avoid the controversy, Governor Thompson was pushed into the struggle on March 22, when the State Legislature approved a bill that would temporarily bar the use or sale of the drug in Wisconsin. Under the legislation, bovine somatotropin would be barred until July 1, 1991, or until six months after approval by the Food and Drug Administration, whichever comes later. If the Governor does not act by April 27, the legislation automatically becomes law.
Mr. Thompson has now become the first prominent political leader in the country to come face to face with the new politics of biotechnology. In many rural areas, the use of modern technology on the farm is under attack by critics who say that is doing more to damage farmers than to help them. In Wisconsin, where the rural vote is a significant portion of the electorate, Mr. Thompson must decide between barring a product of biotechnology never proved to be hazardous and angering his supporters in the business community or vetoing the bill and upsetting thousands of rural voters.
Republican lawmakers here say that in any other year Mr. Thompson's decision would be easy: he would veto the bill. But this election year the decision is much more of a problem.
Mr. Thompson declined to be interviewed about the issue. His executive assistant, Patrick Osborne, said on Wednesday that Mr. Thompson would accept ''a cooling off period'' and allow the drug to be barred in Wisconsin until July 1991, but that he had reservations about the provision for a six-month delay after Federal approval. Mr. Osborne said the Governor also had questions about other provisions of the bill and had not made up his mind.
''The Governor recognizes there is a lot of uncertainty about the use of the drug among Wisconson's farmers,'' Mr. Osborne said. ''There is confusion also about the health effects. Rightly or wrongly people have concerns about the use of this drug.''
Mr. Loftus, meanwhile, has been meeting with his campaign advisers to develop a strategy to take advantage of the issue. In an interview, he said he viewed the debate over the drug as a rare opportunity to use an agricultural issue to bring out the differences between himself and the Governor.
''If ever there was an unneeded invention, this is it,'' Mr. Loftus said. ''It's only here because Monsanto wants it here. It doesn't make milk any better. And to tell you the truth, there is something weird about a farmer putting on his overalls and grabbing his syringe first thing in the morning.''
The manufacturers, led by Monsanto, say the drug is a triumph of technical ingenuity. They argue that bovine somatotropin makes it possible for cows to produce more milk on less feed, thus lowering costs, increasing profits and making the lives of dairy farmers easier. Monsanto has invested $300 million on research and development of the drug, more than any new product in the company's history.
Laurence J. O'Neill, a Monsanto spokesman in St. Louis, where the company is based, said: ''If a temporary ban is approved, it means more of a hardship for Wisconsin's dairy farmers than for the manufacturers. It still leaves the rest of the United States to buy BST. And we will sell BST.''
A group of Wisconsin executives in the biotechnology industry have also joined the battle by warning the Governor that a state ban on the drug would send a message to investors that would not only seriously hurt the development of genetically altered plants, microbes and other products of agricultural biotechnology, but that would also damage Wisconsin's reputation as a leader in biotechnology development.
Legislators of both parties say a close race could be decided by each candidate's position on BST.
 
MINNESOTA APPROVES BAN
ST. PAUL, April 20 (AP) - The Minnesota Senate today gave final approval, 34 to 23, to a one-year ban on bovine somatotropin.
The Minnesota House approved the ban, 68 to 59, on Thursday.
State Representative Chuck Brown, a leader of the move for the ban, said he had received assurances that Gov. Rudy Perpich would sign the measure into law. The ban would apply to non-medical use of the drug.
Mr. Brown and State Senator Steve Morse urged the ban to provide more time to study the potential effects of the drug on animals and human.

HEADLINE: Nunn Urges Cutting Bush Budget For Military by Up to $18 Billion

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
Senator Sam Nunn today recommended cutting President Bush's 1991 military budget proposal by as much as $18 billion, setting the stage for a battle with the Pentagon as well as House Democrats, who are seeking even deeper cuts.
The remarks by Mr. Nunn, a Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, came in the last of a series of speeches on military strategy and the budget in light of the political upheaval in Eastern Europe and the diminished Soviet threat.
In his speech on the Senate floor, Mr. Nunn proposed that the military budget next year range from $289 billion to $291 billion. The Administration has proposed $307 billion. 
House Democrats, who will take their proposal for the overall Federal budget to the House floor next week, have recommended a $283 billion figure for the Pentagon.
Mr. Nunn's recommendations provided only a general picture of how reducing the budget would affect major Pentagon programs and weapons systems. Specific recommendations will be made later this year when his panel and the House Armed Services Committee begin work on legislation to guide spending.
 
Competition of Services Urged
Mr. Nunn urged the Pentagon to begin what he called ''a constructive competition'' among the military services to see whether various roles and missions that are now handled independently could be combined or eliminated for greater efficiency.
His proposal is significant because he exerts considerable leverage on military issues in Congress. His recommendation will almost certainly be regarded as the ceiling in the Congressional debate over what share of the $1.2 trillion Federal budget should go to the Pentagon in the coming fiscal year.
In brief comments to reporters, Mr. Nunn said he would adhere to his number despite the expected efforts by many in his own party to lower it.
But the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, predicted that once Congress begins to translate the recommendations for military reductions into cuts in specific weapons programs, there would be opposition from lawmakers whose districts and states will begin to feel the pinch.
He also said that because the economy has been weaker than the Administration expected, larger budget cuts will be necessary to meet the 1991 deficit target set by law.
 
'Range of Responsibility'
On Thursday morning, Mr. Nunn told reporters that an initial version of the House proposal for the military budget was ''in the range of responsibility.'' But that was before liberal House Democrats persuaded their leadership to slice an additional $3 billion from the Pentagon in the final version of the plan approved by the House Budget Committee on Thursday afternoon.
But today the Senator said that the $283 billion military budget envisioned by House Democrats ''is no longer reasonable, too deep and one that cannot be met.'' Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, said he and other Democratic leaders agreed to the additional cut to place themselves in a better bargaining position with Mr. Nunn and the Senate.
The Senate Budget Committee is scheduled to begin drafting its version of the overall budget next week, but it is deeply divided on a number of issues including military cuts. Its chairman, Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, favors sharper military cuts than those proposed by Mr. Nunn and the House budget panel.
One of the key decisions Congress will have to make this year is whether to proceed with both the Mobile MX missile system and the smaller, Midgetman missile system. ''We cannot afford to continue with the two mobile ICBM programs,'' said Mr. Nunn, who has long been a proponent of the single warhead Midgetman.
 
Proposals on Missiles
He stopped short, however, of calling for a halt in the program to build a mobile basing system for the multi-warhead MX missile, suggesting instead that it be slowed while the United States and the Soviet Union continue negotiations on elimination of multi-warhead missiles.
The Midgetman program should continue, he said, with an eye toward initially basing the missiles in existing silos.
Mr. Nunn, who is at odds with a number of his Democratic colleagues in favoring continuation of the Stealth bomber program, said he would wait until a Pentagon review of the radar-evading plane is complete before suggesting just how many planes should be built. But he said both the total price tag for the program and its yearly costs would have to be brought down.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:
Holocaust and Earth Day It would be hard to miss the arrival of Earth Day on Sunday, a time for reflection on the fragile state of the planet. But it is also a day set aside for a commemoration of another kind. It is Holocaust Memorial Day, known in Hebrew as Yom Hashoah, a time to remember the murder of six million Jews by the Nazis during World War II.
While events marking Earth Day and Yom Hashoah will, for the most part, be separate, a Jewish environmental group outside Philadelphia is suggesting a connection. 
''Jews have a special sensitivity to the preciousness of life,'' said Ellen Bernstein, director of Shomrei Adamah, a project of the Federation of Reconstructionist Congregations and Havurot in Wyncote, Pa. ''Jews have a real understanding on this day in particular to the possibility of disaster when the world sits back and watches and waits.''
Ms. Bernstein will be a speaker at the Earth Fest in Philadelphia's Fairmont Park, where she plans to ask participants to observe a moment of silence for the victims of the Holocaust. She hopes to begin speaking at 2 P.M., just as a Yom Hashoah commemoration will be getting under way at the city's nearby Holocaust memorial.
 
Canterbury Favorite
Just days after the Archbishop of Canterbury announced plans to retire early next year, London bookmakers were picking favorites for a successor. They were offering 2-to-1 odds that Bishop Robin Eames, the Anglican primate of Ireland, would succeed Archbishop Robert Runcie.
With the Canterbury title comes the leadership of the worldwide Anglican communion, which includes the Episcopal Church in the United States. Dr. Runcie, who is 68 years old and has held the post for a decade, is stepping down just short of his 70th birthday, the mandatory retirement age.
As is the custom, the new archbishop will be nominated by the British Prime Minister and appointed by the Queen. If Dr. Eames is chosen, he will be the first non-English bishop to hold the position.
News of the resignation has been the occasion in the British press for speculation not only about a successor but also about the system of appointment and the institution of archbishop itself. The Economist, for example, called the involvement of the government and the monarch ''odd'' and ''crazy,'' concluding, ''The Anglican communion could do perfectly well without a figurehead at all.''
 
New Post for Prelate
Another prelate stepping down after 10 years of service is Archbishop Pio Laghi, who has been Pope John Paul II's representative of to the United States since 1980. Archbishop Laghi, an Italian, will return to Rome in May to head the Vatican Congregation for Catholic Education.
One of Archbishop Laghi's primary tasks has been to make recommendations to Rome about new appointments as vacancies in the church hierarchy in the United States have occurred. During his term, some of the staunchest proponents of Roman Catholic orthodoxy have been named, including John Cardinal O'Connor of New York and Bernard Cardinal Law of Boston.
A successor to Archbishop Laghi will be named by John Paul. The bookmakers haven't a clue.
 
Popeye and the Quakers
Quaker Oats has nothing to do with the Religious Society of Friends, also known as the Quakers. Quaker Oats was formed in 1891 by seven independent millers, some of them Scotch Presbyterians; today it has no religious ties.
But the Religious Quakers have taken umbrage at the company's use of the cantankerous Popeye the Sailor Man in a new campaign to promote instant oatmeal. ''The comics and the commercials featuring this character associate the Quaker name with violence and demeaning images of women,'' Paul Enyart, presiding clerk of the Friends United Meeting wrote to the Chicago headquarters of the corporation. ''Such images are repugnant to foundational Quaker testimonies of peace and equality.''
A corporate spokesman in Chicago said the protest caught Quaker Oats by surprise. ''We had not anticipated that this would create a controversy, and we're certainly sorry if it offended,'' said the spokesman, Ronald Bottrell.
Mr. Bottrell said that one commercial, featuring ''Popeye the Oatmeal Man,'' was immediately withdrawn and that others were permitted to run their course through the ''oatmeal season.'' As for next winter, he said, ''we have not ruled out using Popeye, but we're going to be very sensitive about the concerns raised by the Friends.''
 
Mass Trip to Israel
Some 800 Jews from the New York area will leave for Israel on Wednesday, in what organizers are calling the largest group of New Yorkers ever to visit Israel at one time. The trip, organized by the New York United Jewish Appeal-Federation, is intended to be a show of support at a time when Israel is under attack from both allies and enemies and tourism is lagging.
Organizers had hoped that they could send 2,000 from the New York area, where there are more Jews than in Tel Aviv. They insisted, however, that they were not disappointed with the turnout. ''We see it as more of a commentary on the diversity of the New York Jewish community than on any organizing effort or lack of support for Israel,'' said a spokesman, Steven Matthews.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); UNITED KINGDOM (92%); ITALY (90%); ISRAEL (79%); HOLY SEE (76%);

HEADLINE: Eclipse Ends for a Rising Star

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Nearly 30 years ago, Robert Moskowitz was on the verge of stardom: one of his paintings had been bought by the Museum of Modern Art and his collages were being shown by the dealer Leo Castelli in company with works by Roy Lichtenstein and Frank Stella. Fifteen years ago, Mr. Moskowitz was driving a taxi in New York and seldom sold a painting.
But now, in another change of luck, the 55-year-old painter earns a comfortable income selling his canvases and has become one of those rare living artists to have his work featured in a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.
''It's both difficult and educational to see your life in front of you like this,'' Mr. Moskowitz said of the exhibition of 83 paintings, drawings and collages that traces his career from the late 1950's to the present. His works are characterized by playful, dreamlike images that tread a fine line between abstraction and representation. The show, which can be seen through May 1, was organized by Ned Rifkin of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, and was exhibited there and at La Jolla Museum of Contemporary Art in California last year. 
 
Assessing the Twists and Turns
Mr. Moskowitz lives and works in a 5,000-square-foot loft in TriBeCa with his wife, Hermine Ford, also a painter, and their 23-year-old son, Erik, a painting student at the School of Visual Arts. The other day in his studio, he reflected on the twists and turns in his career.
''Up until your 40's, you're still learning,'' the artist said. ''Most people don't really do mature work until then. I agree with Auden that all you can hope for is good influences up to that point.''
By the time he had turned 40, Mr. Moskowitz's influences included Abstract Expressionist artists like Adolph Gottlieb, his teacher at Brooklyn's Pratt Institute, and his father-in-law, Jack Tworkov, a painter; the Surrealist painter Marcel Duchamp; the photographer Walker Evans, with whom Mr. Moscowitz worked; Alfred Hitchcock, and Samuel Beckett. But the paintings he was doing were not finding a receptive audience, and he was devoting much of his energy to work outside his studio.
Mr. Moskowitz was born in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn and illustrated technical manuals for the Sperry Gyroscope Company during the late 1950's while studying graphic design at night at Pratt. He was derailed from his intended career as a technical illustrator by Mr. Gottlieb, whose painting class at Pratt persuaded him to become an artist.
 
Collages With Window Shades
In the early 1960's, Mr. Moskowitz burst on the New York art scene with a series of collages using window shades that seemed to place him at the heart of the growing Pop Art movement. As the art historian Robert Rosenblum wrote in 1983 of Mr. Moskowitz's early works, ''They seemed to push both the basic language of painting and the fundamentals of image-making to a rock-bottom economy, where suddenly the two worlds were forever fused - a flat painting equaling a flat window shade.''
But this early brush with the limelight was short-lived for Mr. Moskowitz, a man noted for his low-key manner and strong sense of privacy. In 1964 he left the Castelli Gallery because he felt the dealer was no longer interested in his work and he wanted to explore what he called ''a slower kind of painting.''
''It wasn't a good place for me to be because I was learning and experimenting rather than doing resolved paintings,'' he said. ''I was never a Pop Artist. The window shades weren't like the Brillo boxes or Campbell Soup cans. The Pop imagery was jazzier and more specific than mine in drawing from popular culture.''
Mr. Moskowitz spent much of the next decade doing bleak, enigmatic paintings of corners of rooms. ''The corner paintings were considered Minimalism in that there wasn't a lot going on with the canvases,'' he said. ''But I had images, while the Minimalists were abstract. The corners came out of a book on decorating I'd found in a used-book store. I wanted to make them look like rooms you could go into. But I found they became closed and too perfect, so I started to violate the surfaces.'' These violations first took the form of tiny blotches of paint. On later canvases, they became geometric shapes and eventually quirky but more recognizable images, like a smile and a duck's head.
 
'I Needed the Money'
The late 1960's and 1970's, however, were difficult years, Mr. Moskowitz acknowledged. He had only a handful of gallery shows, and they were poorly received. He now feels this was because his paintings were ''different from most work being shown at the time, and they weren't aggressive in grabbing people's attention.'' He made his living driving a taxi three nights a week, while making canvas stretchers for other artists and teaching often uninterested students during the day at the Maryland Institute of Art in Baltimore and the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan.
''I needed the money,'' he said, ''but it was more visually stimulating and I learned more driving the taxi than teaching. You meet these amazing people, and it's very voyeuristic.''
Mr. Moskowitz's fortunes started to improve in the late 1970's, when his work was exhibited at the Clocktower gallery, an alternative space just down the street from his loft, and in a now-famous group show called ''New Image Painting'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Included in the Whitney show was his diptych of the World Trade Center reminiscent of works by Georgia O'Keeffe or Charles Demuth. It was one of his many paintings of the period of skyscrapers like the Flati=ron and Empire State Buildings in New York and the Wrigley Building in Chicago.
Another stylistic shift occurred around 1982, when Mr. Moskowitz began to experiment with flat, silhouetted images of sculptures like Rodin's ''Thinker,'' Brancusi's ''Bird in Space'' and Giacometti's ''Elongated Figure.'' ''I wanted to see what would happen if you took sculpture and tried to paint it,'' he said.
 
Creating a Sense of Great Space
In much of his work, however, Mr. Moskowitz has attempted to capture a feeling of immensity - either with tiny images in the midst of huge canvases, large subjects like skyscrapers and icebergs, or oversize close-ups of a bowler's arm in motion. ''Scale is definitely an issue for me,'' he said. ''The scale brings you closer or pushes you back from the image.'' Mr. Moskowitz will talk about the ideas behind his work in general terms - he says, for instance, that he uses colors and images as metaphors for people and relationships - but he does not like to discuss the meaning of particular works. ''I make a painting first, and later figure out what it means,'' he said.
Although he has regularly shown his work at the Blum Helman Gallery in recent years, he has avoided contractual ties with any gallery. ''I accumulate a certain amount of work over two or three years, and then think about having a show and trying to sell the work,'' he said. Many of his large canvases line the walls of his spacious studio, which is connected by various passageways to his living area, his wife's studio and his son's studio and apartment.
Throughout the ups and downs of his career, Mr. Moskowitz said, the opinions of critics and the vagaries of celebrity have been unimportant. ''I try not to read criticism of my work,'' he said. ''The good criticism gives me an ego boost I don't need. And the bad criticism I usually just don't agree with, and it can be very destructive. When you're younger, maybe there's something magical about celebrity, but I'm not taken in by it.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''It's both difficult and educational to see your life in front of you like this,'' Robert Moskowitz said of his Museum of Modern Art show. (The New York Times/Ruby Washington)

HEADLINE: Why Bankroll Africa's Ceausescu?

 BODY:
Mobutu Sese Seko seized power in Zaire through a military coup in 1965, the same year Nicolae Ceausescu became the Communist boss of Romania. Mr. Mobutu is no Communist. But his methods of rule resemble those of the executed Romanian tyrant. Wholesale repression, corruption and megalomania have deformed Zaire. 
There is a further regrettable resemblance. President Mobutu, like Mr. Ceausescu, has known how to profit from his outspoken opposition to Soviet foreign policy moves. Washington has winked at his disastrous misrule and made his regime the leading African recipient of United States economic assistance.
The end of the cold war removes any possible justification for this taxpayer subsidy to a repellent dictator. Representatives Howard Wolpe of Michigan, Stephen Solarz of New York, David Obey of Wisconsin and Ronald Dellums of California are proposing changes in the aid relationship. Their efforts deserve support.
American aid dollars have not measurably helped Zaire's people. Annual per capita income is about $150; living standards are lower than when Mr. Mobutu took power. His Government has not built a single hospital in its 25 years. Only 3 percent of Zaire's budget goes to health and education while 23 percent goes to the military and 50 percent to ''political institutions.''
Meanwhile Mr. Mobutu's personal fortune has, by some estimates, grown to $6 billion. His holdings include perhaps a dozen French and Belgian chateaus, a Spanish castle and a 32-bedroom Swiss villa. Mr. Mobutu protests that his fortune is a mere $50 million, and that none of it has come out of the pockets of his people. But recent World Bank studies have found hundreds of millions of dollars in mineral revenues unreported in the national budget, and more gold and coffee smuggled out of the country than legally exported.
Mr. Mobutu has supported anti-Communist initiatives of successive U.S. Administrations, especially in Angola. But he has done so for his own reasons, not always in coordination with Washington. For him the U.S. has proved a useful ally. He uses his conspicuous access to American leaders to further discourage dissent.
Mr. Solarz, Mr. Wolpe and Mr. Obey would end military aid to Zaire and channel most economic aid through non-government organizations. Mr. Dellums would go further and press international aid institutions to consider the abuses and corruption in Zaire. Americans have better uses for their tax dollars than reinforcing the Mobutu tyranny.

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush, Lean on the Lithuanians

BYLINE: By John B. Oakes; John B. Oakes is former Editorial Page Editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
It is all very well for President Bush to warn Mikhail Gorbachev against the use of force in Lithuania. But it would be more to the point right now if he warned the Lithuanians not to push President Gorbachev any further into using it.
If the Lithuanians persist in doing so - and are deceived into thinking that a sympathetic America will continue to support them right down the line - the results could be catastrophic for the Lithuanians, destructive for President Gorbachev and highly dangerous for the United States.
Mr. Bush has repeatedly called for a ''dialogue, discussion and peaceful resolution.'' It won't happen and it won't be helped by yielding to the demands of the extreme right in this country to put all the heat on Mr. Gorbachev and none on the Lithuanians. 
Naturally, Americans sympathize with the demand of the Lithuanian people for freedom. Paradoxically, it is Mr. Gorbachev who is offering them and their two Baltic neighbors the best hope for freedom they have had in many centuries of Russian, Polish, German and Swedish rule. Even in the brief and dubious interlude of nominal independence between the two World Wars, the Baltic states were governed largely by rightist dictatorships; but it was Stalin who finally snuffed out what remained of their freedom in 1940.
Now, thanks to the Gorbachev revolution, the Baltic peoples - Lithuanians, Letts, Estonians - are within reach of that freedom once again. The trick today is not to overreach.
This the Lithuanians are in imminent danger of doing, egged on by such irresponsible tactics as those of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York. His most recent publicity-seeking trip, this time to the Lithuanian border (diverting attention from the Senate investigation into his ethics), gave ultimate proof of his unlimited capacity to trivialize even the most serious foreign policy issues.
The physical presence of a United States Senator on that border, acting almost as agent provocateur, could hardly have failed to rouse false hopes (or claims) on the part of the Lithuanian leadership that they had significant American endorsement of an all-or-nothing stance. This is not helpful to President Bush's plea for a ''peaceful resolution.'' Even Senator D'Amato must realize that no head of a great nation could possibly accept instant and unilateral secession of one of its component parts, however illegally acquired.
But he could negotiate its independence, and this is what Mr. Gorbachev, despite much resistance from his own right wing, is trying to do, revising Soviet law in order to do it.
By refusing to accept the slower but surer legal path toward independence that Mr. Gorbachev is clearly offering, the Lithuanian leadership is inviting not only the economic crackdown that has already begun but the possibility of full-scale military repression.
If that happened, everything that has been gained for human rights and civil liberties in the Baltic states thus far - and a great deal has been gained - would surely be lost.
The repercussions would go far beyond the Baltics. Such a convulsion would inevitably derail Mr. Gorbachev's already too long delayed economic reforms. The probable result of that would be the derailment of Mr. Gorbachev himself.
That is something fervid right-wingers in this country and elsewhere would dearly love to see. They are helping it along by pressing President Bush to take an ever tougher line against Soviet-American economic cooperation.
There is a certain irony here. Until recently, the U.S. was waging total economic warfare and supporting a major military force to bring down the elected Government of a neighboring small country called Nicaragua, where we have even less historic claim to sovereignty - legitimate or illegitimate - than the Russians have in Lithuania.
What the U.S. should be doing in the interest of world peace is just the opposite. A blind policy of retaliation could not possibly help the Lithuanians. It could, however, help destroy Mr. Gorbachev and bring Soviet-American detente to an abrupt and fateful end - a tragedy for us no less than for the Soviets, and a disaster for the world.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Mild Gain in Drive on Illegal Aliens

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 19

 BODY:
A report by two influential research organizations has concluded that the Government's efforts to seek penalties against employers who hire illegal aliens has been only a modest deterrent to illegal immigration.
The Rand Corporation and the Urban Institute, in what they called the most comprehensive study yet of the impact of employer sanctions on illegal immigration, said the sanctions had reduced illicit border crossings by less than 20 percent.
''If the intent was to generate a large decline in the flow, employer sanctions appear to have been unsuccessful and Congress may wish to weigh the cost of continuing the program against its current level of effectiveness,'' said the study, which was issued Thursday. 
But the study added that if the policy was intended only ''to curb the rate of increase in the flow, the sanctions have probably been successful and Congress may wish to continue with the current law.''
The study was released as Congress debates whether to repeal or revise provisions of the landmark 1986 immigration law that establish civil and criminal penalties for employers who hire illegal aliens. A study released last month by Congress's General Accounting Office found a ''widespread pattern of discrimination'' in employment against people with a ''foreign appearance or accent.''
 
Impact of Finding of Bias
Under the terms of the immigration law, the finding of bias by the accounting office forces Congress to reconsider the legislation's provisions requiring employers to demand from everyone they hire proof of citizenship or the right to work legally in the United States. The report by the accounting office said the law had ''apparently reduced illegal immigration,'' but it made no systematic attempt to reach a firm conclusion about the law's effectiveness in stemming the flow of illegal aliens across the border.
The conclusions offered by Rand, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., and the Urban Institute, in Washington, were based on a three-year study of statistics on legal immigration, border arrests of illegal aliens and changes in the pay and labor supply for jobs at car washes and restaurants. The study by the two independent, nonprofit research organizations, was conducted under a grant from the Ford Foundation.
The study found what it called ''clearcut'' evidence that the law was having its intended effect on immigration in 1987, with the flow of illegal immigrants falling by more than 15 percent and requests from farmers for temporary workers from abroad rising 28 percent. But in 1988, the study found, the downward trend in illegal immigration was reversed, and in 1989, labor market analysis suggested only a small decline in illegal immigration.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who was one of the authors of the legislation, said the latest report and the accounting office report ''are a commentary on how the bill is working now, but not on the concept behind the bill or on how it might work if it were taken seriously by the Administration.''
Mr. Schumer said that if the legislation was to be successful, the Government must not try to enforce it on a ''shoestring'' budget.
Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said border apprehensions declined from 1.1 million in 1987 to 857,000 last year, although they appeared to be climbing again this year. ''Apprehensions have been down considerably and, in the absence of the law, probably would have increased considerably,'' he said.

The Economy
 Michael R. Milken reportedly agreed to plead guilty to six felony charges and pay $600 million in fines. HEADLINE: Pentagon's Technology Chief Is Out

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Sparking expressions of outrage from Capitol Hill to Silicon Valley, the Defense Department said yesterday that it had removed the director of its agency responsible for developing advanced technologies.
Officials of the agency said the move resulted from a bitter dispute over what the agency's role should be in financing research projects intended to make American high-technology industries more competitive.
Dr. Craig I. Fields, the director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, was told yesterday that he was being removed and transferred to the position of deputy director of defense research and engineering for defense management report implementation. He was informed of his transfer by a representative of Deputy Defense Secretary Donald J. Atwood. The new post would include responsibility for streamlining the general research activities of the Defense Department. 
 
Denial by Pentagon
 The Pentagon said yesterday that Dr. Fields had not been discharged, but several executives of the research agency said he had lost his position because of his advocacy for high-technology initiatives opposed by some high Bush Administration officials. These officials have expressed their opposition to policies that help specific industries.
In a telephone interview last night from his home in Washington, Dr. Fields, 43 years old, said he was weighing his options and had not yet decided what to do. He had no further comment.
White House officials refused to comment on the announcement.
Dr. Fields's transfer follows closely on the heels of a Pentagon decision this month to cut financing for research on high-definition television, a technology for delivering sharper television images that has become a symbol in the debate over how the United States can best compete with Japan.
 
A Lightning Rod
 In recent months, the research agency has served as a lightning rod within the Bush Administration for a policy debate over whether the Government should actively encourage developing advanced commercial technologies like high-definition television and more sophisticated semiconductors and computers.
Dr. Fields has long been the primary champion of such programs within the agency, and he has always justified them as having military as well as commercial applications. But his position has apparently incurred the wrath of Administration officials who oppose the idea that the Government should attempt to pick ''winning'' technologies.
Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, are widely reported to oppose extensive Government backing for high-technology research consortiums.
One White House official said yesterday that Mr. Darman believed that the research programs were not as valuable as many supporters have contended and that the programs could have a limited impact on America's industrial base. He has argued that the technologies are better developed with funds from business and industry.
''They think Dr. Fields has done far too much,'' said a Pentagon official yesterday who asked that he not be identified. ''They want to buy technology from the Japanese that he had hoped we could use as a lever to make the United States more competitive.''
 
The Final Straw?
 People close to the Defense Department said yesterday that what might have finally led to Dr. Fields being transferred was a decision the agency made this month to invest $4 million in Gazelle Microcircuits Inc., a Silicon Valley electronics company that is working on high-speed circuits made of gallium arsenide.
Under an experimental program approved by Congress, the agency made its investment much like a venture capitalist, expecting to receive a payback if the company becomes successful. The deal also allowed Gazelle to deflect an investment from a Japanese company, which might have entailed transferring the technology to Japan.
One Defense Department official said yesterday that the deal provoked ''grouchiness'' among high Pentagon officials, who wondered why the Pentagon was investing when another private company, albeit a Japanese one, was willing to put money in.
Defense Department officials apparently discussed the possibility of a new role with Dr. Fields on Tuesday, the Pentagon official said, but he told them he wished to remain head of the agency. Yesterday, several Department officials said, he was presented with paperwork outlining his transfer with no advance warning.
 
Described as Assertive
 Dr. Fields, who is universally described as having a quick mind and as being very assertive, has been almost an institution at the agency. While most of its officials are university or industrial scientists who stay at the agency for a few years, Dr. Fields has been there for 16 years.
His shift yesterday drew cries of outrage from members of Congress and former Government officials who support Government spending for high-technology.
''It's terribly wrong,'' said Robert B. Costello, a former Under Secretary of Defense during the Reagan Administration. ''Darpa, in order to do its job, has to be involved in certain industrial activities.''
 
Debate May Be Settled
 Several members of Congress suggested that Dr. Fields's transfer indicated the Bush Administration was settling its internal debate over whether the Government should support the development of high-technology industries.
''It represents more than the loss of one person's job,'' said Senator Albert Gore Jr., the Tennessee Democrat who has strongly supported high-technology financing by the Government. ''It's the defeat within the Administration of an argument of importance to the future of our country.''
The removal of Dr. Fields was also met with shock in Silicon Valley, where the research agency, with a budget of only $1 billion a year, is known for financing early work in many computer-related technologies.
''It's a tragedy for American competitiveness,'' said L. John Doerr, a partner at Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers, a leading venture-capital firm in San Francisco.

HEADLINE: RATES JUMP ON NEWS OF BUDGET GAP

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Interest rates climbed yesterday as prices of Treasury securities were battered by the report by the Government that it posted its largest monthly budget deficit on record in March.
The $53.34 billion deficit was some $10 billion above the most pessimistic forecasts. The largest previous monthly deficit was $39.4 billion in May 1986, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
Before the Treasury Department's deficit report was released in the early afternoon, prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed. Dealers said the market's consensus at the time was that the decline in bond prices earlier in the week had led to an oversold situation. 
 
'Excuse to Head Lower'
 ''The consensus was overly optimistic because the Treasury market was looking for an excuse to head lower and the extraordinary March budget deficit provided it,'' said Philip Braverman, chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation.
The Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.5 percent issue maturing in 2020, were being offered late in the session at 95 18/32, down a full point, which is equivalent to a loss of $10 for each $1,000 of face value. This caused the yield on the long bond to soar to 8.93 percent, its highest level since last May, from 8.84 percent the day before and 8.58 percent on April 12. The Treasury debt market was closed on April 13, Good Friday.
Although the March deficit could be an aberration, the $53.34 billion shortfall was a shock when compared with one of $36.4 billion in February and $35.8 billion in March 1989, Mr. Braverman said. ''But the deficit was only the last straw for many traders in a week that saw Japanese holders of Treasury paper continue to be net sellers,'' he added.
 
Estimate on Japanese Sales
 Mr. Braverman estimated that the Japanese sellers, mostly insurance companies, were net sellers of at least $6 billion of Treasury notes and bonds between the start of their fiscal year on April 1 and April 13. ''They probably unloaded more this week,'' he said, ''partly as a currency play and partly to raise funds for bargain-hunting in their sharply depressed stock market.''
As a currency play, the Japanese sellers were counting on a decline in the dollar against the yen. Their sales did contribute to a slight decline in the dollar during the week.
''The Japanese are not turning their backs on our Treasury debt market because of recent signs of a pickup in domestic inflation,'' Mr. Braverman said. ''But they and many other investors in the fixed-income market may be unsettled by the first-quarter gross national product figures due out next Friday.''
''We expect the G.N.P. to be up at least 2.5 percent on an annual basis, compared with the rise of 1.1 percent in the last quarter of 1989,'' he added. ''The first-quarter fixed G.N.P. deflator, a measure of inflation, could be up between 5.5 and 6 percent, compared with a rise of 3.6 percent in the previous quarter.''
 
Vulnerable for Other Reasons
 William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, said the bond market was also vulnerable for other reasons. As he explained: ''The half-point rise in the March Consumer Price Index showed a pickup in inflation, the bane of any investor in fixed-income debt issues. We also face a $30 billion quarterly refunding. While the terms of the refunding are due out May 2, the Street expects the Treasury to auction $10 billion each of 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds the following week. The Street thinks that a yield of 9 percent on the long bond will be necessary to attract bidders. If 9 percent doesn't represent value, then who knows how high interest rates will have to go until it does.''
As for the surprising March deficit figure, Mr. Sullivan said that the $53.34 billion shortfall ''is either an aberration, or it indicates that the Federal budget deficit is out of control. In either case, it tells the bond market that the Treasury will have to keep issuing more debt.''
 
ABOVE 1990 TARGET
 WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -The March gap between spending and revenues pushed the budget deficit for the first six months of the fiscal year past the Gramm-Rudman target for all of the 1990 fiscal year.
The deficit now stands at $150.85 billion for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, 17.5 percent more than the $128.4 billion imbalance during the first half of 1989 and well above the Gramm-Rudman 1990 target of $100 billion.
The Treasury Department's report said March revenues were down 4.9 percent from March 1989, to $64.82 billion, while spending rose 13.6 percent, to $118.16 billion.
Louis Crandall, an economist with R. H. Wrightson of New York, attributed most of the March deficit to payments by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, spending by the Resolution Trust Corporation to bail out failed savings and loan associations, expedited income tax refunds as a result of electronic filing systems and Federal Reserve losses because of the falling value of the Fed's foreign currency reserves.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Profit Lags at Caterpillar

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., April 20

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. announced today that it had put into effect a white-collar hiring freeze after the company's profit fell short of last year's performance for the second consecutive quarter.
Despite record sales, Caterpillar earned $99 million, or 97 cents a share, in the first three months of 1990, a 29.8 percent drop from last year, when the first-quarter profit was $141 million, or $1.39 a share. 
Revenue for the Peoria-based Caterpillar, the world's largest manufacturer of earth-moving equipment, was up 9.1 percent, to $2.87 billion for the quarter, the second-best quarter in Caterpillar's 75-year history. The company's revenue was $2.63 billion in the corresponding quarter last year. The all-time high for revenue was $3.04 billion in the second quarter of 1989.
The hiring freeze applies to all management or salaried employees, said Len Kuchan, Caterpillar's treasurer.
He said a company reorganization, which created profit-driven management centers, had resulted in a reduction of middle-management jobs and some salaried workers.
Mr. Kuchan said no layoffs of blue-collar workers is expected in 1990, although they could occur if the nation's economy sinks into a recession.
Mr. Kuchan attributed the low profit level to increased costs resulting from soaring health-care expenses, plant modernization programs, higher material costs and trouble in key markets.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 15.99; Bigger Drop Averted

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices bounced back sharply in late trading yesterday but ended on a weak note amid concern that rising interest rates would continue to depress stock and bond prices.
After plunging as much as 39 points around 2:30 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average recovered more than half that loss to end the session at 2,695.95, down 15.99, putting its loss for the week at 55.85 points.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange advanced briskly, to 174.3 million shares, from 152.9 million on Thursday. But in a sign of the breadth of the decline, 1,079 issues fell and 96 reached new lows. Only 401 issues advanced. 
 
'It's Been a Tough Week'
 One of the new lows was AAR, an aviation parts company, which fell 2 1/2, to 23, touching a new low of 22 after falling 2 3/8 on Thursday. The company said it expected a modest gain for the fiscal year ending May 31 but had told analysts on Wednesday that it was taking ''a cautionary view'' of its fiscal fourth quarter.
''It's been a tough week,'' said Hugh Johnson, head strategist for the First Albany Corporation. He maintained that much of the stock market's troubles could be attributed to the bond market, where interest rates are now ''an attractive alternative to stocks.''
''Bond prices were collapsing all around us,'' he said, ''almost like a free fall.'' He called it ''very troubling'' that the yield on long-term Treasuries had risen to 8.93 percent - the first time the level has climbed above 8.9 percent in nearly a year.
Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading for Shearson Lehman Hutton, said one big uncertainty - as it always is when the Government raises money - is the level of Japanese buying in the Treasury's $30 billion refinancing next month.
Mr. Johnson of First Albany said there was evidence not only that Japanese investors were big sellers of United States Treasury issues but also that they were not very big players in the last Treasury refinancing. And if the Japanese do not take part in any meaningful way, he argued, interest rates will go up to attract other buyers.
 
Du Pont and Primerica Down
 Among the Dow industrials, declines of a point or more occurred only at Du Pont, off 1 at 36 5/8, and Primerica, down 1 1/4 at 28 1/2. A.T.&T. was unchanged at 40 7/8; General Motors fell 1/8, to 46 3/4; General Electric fell 1/4, to 65 1/2, and I.B.M. rose 1/4, to 109 3/8.
In the Dow transportation stocks, Airborne Freight rose 1, to 48, and UAL 1, to 154. Burlington Northern rose 3/8, to 34 1/4, and Norfolk Southern rose 3/8, to 38. The rest fell less than a point, but enough to clip the Dow transportation index by 5.69 points, to 1,154.87.
Along with the decline in bond prices, insurance companies, many of which are big investors in bonds, also declined. CNA fell 2 3/4, to 73 1/2; General Re fell 2, to 83 1/8, and Chubb fell 1 7/8, to 90.
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the publisher, again headed the Big Board active list, falling 1/4, to 4, in heavy trading. It has declined comment on takeover rumors; some traders said they had not heard the rumors.
Bank stocks weakened because of disappointing earnings. Brent B. Erensel, bank analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that Eastern banks did poorly, except Bankers Trust New York, and that West Coast banks did well. But in the selloff Bankers Trust fell 1/4, to 35 1/2; Wells Fargo fell 1 1/4, to 68 3/4; Security Pacific fell 5/8, to 36 3/8, and BankAmerica stood unchanged at 27 1/2. Citicorp fell 1/2, to 23 3/8, in heavy trading after Moody's Investors Service said on Thursday that it was reviewing its ratings on some Citicorp debt.
Among other indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index fell 2.97, to 335.12; the Nasdaq composite index 3.21, to 425.79, and the Amex market-value index 2.77, to 347.96.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Broadly Amid Tensions on Lithuania

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher on world currency markets yesterday, as investors sought a safe haven amid heightened tensions over Lithuania.
Traders said the market focused on the Soviet Union's toughened economic embargo against Lithuania. Moscow diverted some shipments of food, metal, wood and industrial parts. 
Earlier this week the Kremlin cut off most of the natural gas and all of the oil it supplies to the Baltic republic, which is trying to secede from the Soviet Union.
Further rocking the currency market was a report that dozens of Red Army soldiers stormed a Lithuanian printing plant and beat at least a dozen people.
As tensions in the Soviet Union intensify, the market is concerned over ''the possibility that either the United States or Europe will be drawn into it,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
 
A Dive, Then a Revival
 Volume was heavy. Shortly after midday, the dollar took a dive as traders turned their sights to weakening United States stock and bond markets, but the currency managed to finish higher.
Earlier in Europe, the dollar rose in modest activity.
The dollar closed in Tokyo at 157.60 yen, down 0.15 yen from Thursday's close. In late trading in London, the dollar rose to 157.90 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 157.50 yen, up from 157.25 yen on Thursday.
The British pound declined to $1.6357 in London, from $1.6448 late Thursday. Later in New York, sterling dipped to $1.6388 from Thursday's $1.6450.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6872 West German marks, up from 1.6787; 1.4895 Swiss francs, up from 1.4847; 5.6655 French francs, up from 5.6425; 1,238.20 Italian lire, up from 1,233.50, and 1.1628 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1623.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6895 marks, up from 1.6755; 1.4910 Swiss francs, up from 1.4815; 5.6695 French francs, up from 5.6325; 1.8910 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8820; 1,240.00 Italian lire, up from 1,231.25, and 1.1619 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1618.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion settled at $376.60 a troy ounce, off 60 cents from Thursday.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1877 words

HEADLINE: How Physicist's Weapons Genius Led Him to Greed and Then Death

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES with JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Gerald V. Bull was a gifted designer of military hardware: at age 22, a doctor of aerophysics; at 32, star of a Pentagon ballistics lab. But when he could not earn a living making guns for the United States, he turned to illicit trade, and at 52 he was in a Federal prison for illegally exporting arms to South Africa.
At 62, Mr. Bull was dead. A month ago, on March 22, he was shot twice in the neck with a silencer-equipped 7.65-millimeter pistol outside his apartment in Brussels. The killer left behind $20,000 in American cash in the victim's pocket.
Who killed him, and why, is a mystery that has consumed the European press. But a growing body of evidence suggests that Mr. Bull was a pivotal figure in a violent subculture, promoting the black-market proliferation of advanced weapons to volatile third-world nations like Iran and Iraq. 
 
Steel Pipes in Britain
European press reports have focused on the British Government's April 11 seizure of steel pipes that Mr. Bull sought to ship to Iraq, apparently for use in launching rocket bombs.
The lethal technology marketed by Mr. Bull was based on work financed and sponsored by the Pentagon in the 1960's and 1970's, when he worked for the Canadian and American Governments.
He was then regarded as so vital to American national security that Congress voted in 1972 to make the Canadian-born scientist retroactively eligible for American citizenship, allowing the Pentagon to upgrade his security clearances to include nuclear secrets.
His relatives said this month that he had received warnings of an attempt on his life by Mossad, the Israeli intelligence service, which wages a shadow war against Iraq, but that he had dismissed the report.
Israel has denied any role in his death. Others say Iran also had reason to wish Mr. Bull dead. As a supplier of advanced arms, sometimes to foes on both sides of third-world conflicts, Mr. Bull collected enough potential enemies to fill several police blotters with murder suspects, American intelligence officials and others said.
Mr. Bull's death has raised anew questions about whether the United States knew of his business and ignored or tacitly encouraged it.
Although he was jailed for illegal weapons sales to South Africa in 1980, officials in the United States, Europe and Africa later allowed Mr. Bull to license the same technology from his Belgian corporate base for eventual use in much of the developing world, according to Government documents.
 
Congressional Inquiry
Mr. Bull's dealings with South Africa were assisted by a Central Intelligence Agency operative involved in Angola's civil war, a 1982 Congressional inquiry concluded. The C.I.A. denied any knowing involvement.
A former senior Pentagon official who monitored arms proliferation in the Reagan Administration, Frank Gaffney, said Mr. Bull's activities might have been overlooked. ''The truth is the administration of export controls from this country is a sometime thing,'' he said. ''When you talk about policing exports from third countries, it's a very erratic thing.''
But ''there is always the possibility we or other countries were looking the other way,'' he added.
After breaking with the Pentagon in the 1970's, Mr. Bull set up companies and licensing agreements to sell improved versions of the technology he had developed there, according to legal documents and former associates.
 
Long-Range Howitzer
That weaponry includes a highly accurate long-range howitzer, which is a staple of armed forces in Iran, Iraq, Israel and South Africa, and which also may have been used in Beirut's war between Christian and Muslim factions.
It also includes a gigantic cannon -really a mortar with a barrel over 120-feet long - which Mr. Bull developed under Army direction in the 1960's and which he apparently was seeking to build in Iraq when he died.
''He adjusted his administrative capabilities to whatever brought him money,'' one former business associate who requested anonymity said of Mr. Bull this week. ''He sold to the pariahs of the world.''
How a gifted physicist drifted into the amoral supply of black-market armies is not altogether clear. What is widely reported is that Mr. Bull suffered financial difficulties and that he was deeply embittered by failed research ventures with the Americans and Canadians.
 
Seemed Destined for Stardom
Detailed accounts of Mr. Bull's work and his arms dealings are available from public documents and reports published in The Burlington (Vt.) Free Press.
Mr. Bull seemed destined for scientific stardom. The youngest doctoral graduate of the University of Toronto, the Ontario native first worked at Canada's defense institute. His work in artillery technology caught the Pentagon's eye, and in 1955, at 27, Mr. Bull began a liaison with the Defense Department that lasted two decades.
The Army declined comment on Mr. Bull. But documents from 1972, when Senator Barry Goldwater promoted legislation backdating his legal American residency, indicate he worked in the 1950's and 1960's on 16-inch guns that fired rocket-propelled shells to unheard-of heights.
His High Altitude Research Project, or HARP, produced one cannon on the Caribbean island of Barbados which sent a projectile into space, a record 112 miles high. Other Bull cannons were built in Senator Goldwater's home state of Arizona and in Canada.
 
His Venture Waned
But despite Mr. Bull's claims that it was a cheap, low-technology alternative to guided missiles, the HARP venture waned in the late 1960's as the United States committed to conventional rocketry.
With Army financial support, Mr. Bull turned in the early 1970's to designing a long-range 155-millimeter gun and shell on a remote 8,000-acre plot that straddled the Vermont-Canada border. He set up a private company, Space Research Corporation, to make shells and conduct tests.
Using nuclear secrets, Mr. Bull made a 155-millineter nuclear shell for the Army, a former associate said. Israel later bought 5,000 rounds of Mr. Bull's nonnuclear 155-millimeter shell and still uses improved forms of the shell for long-range artillery, he said. The Israeli embassy here declined comment.
But though it developed a system far more accurate than competing howitzers, Space Research fell into financial straits when the Army, which was researching its own long-range artillery, stopped financing Mr. Bull. The company turned in 1974 to South Africa, secretly selling a license for its howitzer technology - and later, a hidden one-fifth stake - to the state-owned munitions conglomerate, Armscor.
Investigators later concluded that Space Research had shipped howitzer prototypes, radar and at least 30,000 shells to South Africa in violation of Federal laws, with the help of Israel and a military consultant who worked for the C.I.A.
 
Marketing Abroad
Mr. Bull spent 4 1/2 months in Federal prison after admitting violations of the Arms Export Control Act and a United Nations arms embargo against South Africa. A spokesman for the South African Embassy had no comment today on the country's ties to Mr. Bull.
A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee stated in a 1982 report that the State Department's Office of Munitions Control ignored ''substantial, if not conclusive,'' evidence that Mr. Bull's howitzer technology was Pentagon-owned and should not have been marketed abroad without consent. The State Department declined comment.
In any case, despite Federal laws barring the unapproved resale of American military technologies, Mr. Bull and South Africa later prospered by selling modified versions of the 155-millimeter artillery system around the world - to Austria, China, Taiwan and Singapore, among others, according to a former associate. Some of those deals were struck by retired Israeli intelligence agents and arms dealers working for commissions, he said.
The details of these sales and the licensing agreements under which Mr. Bull sold his technology remain unclear, but a new criminal case in Austria has shed some light on the subject.
 
A Company in Vienna
Legal documents there contend that a Vienna company, Voest-Alpine, licensed Mr. Bull's howitzer technology about 1979 and began reselling it to third world armies. Mr. Bull dismantled his Vermont operation and moved to Brussels, working with Poudriere Reunie Belge, a huge Belgian munitions company that had acquired a hidden interest in his company in order to make and sell howitzer shells.
Several press accounts in Vienna state that a Voest-Alpine subsidiary contracted in the last decade to sell the 155-millimeter howitzers worldwide, including 72 to Saudi Arabia, 100 to Nigeria, 200 to Iraq and 140 to Iran. The guns are said to have played a bloody role in the Iran-Iraq conflict, where they devastated troop emplacements on both sides of the battle line.
The sales turned Mr. Bull into a wealthy man and a sought-after figure in the third world. Along the way, he became most closely involved with Iraq, which was using profits from its vast oil sales to acquire first-rate arms, scientists and technology. One former associate said that the Iraqis cemented their ties during a 1987 trip to South Africa in which they inspected Mr. Bull's 155-millimeter howitzer.
A son in Canada, Michel Bull, who is an executive of Space Research Corporation, said in a British interview that the company had ''very close contacts in Iraq'' and held defense contracts with that nation. A former associate told The New York Times that the elder Mr. Bull may have helped Iraq develop its own indigenous artillery, including a 210-millimeter gun.
But Michel Bull has denied that his father was designing a gun for Iraq. Michel Bull has gone into hiding since his father's death and could not be reached for comment.
An American official said evidence indicated that Mr. Bull sought last month to ship steel pipes to Iraq similar to the rocket tubes he designed in the 1960's for the HARP project. The pipes are virtually as long, a second Administration official noted on Friday.
British customs officials seized eight sections of pipe on April 11 that were bound for Iraq, and more pipes were confiscated on Friday in Greece and Turkey. British newspapers have reported that they were destined for an Iraqi test site for long-range bombs.
An obscure book on HARP written by Mr. Bull and a military associate and published in 1988 offers some hints about the pipes. The publication, ''The Paris Guns,'' includes charts and drawings suggesting that steel tubes could be used to guide rocket-driven shells to targets up to 3,300 miles away.
''Modern steel characteristics and fabrication techniques made fixed-elevation launch tubes of very large diameter a relatively low-cost proposition,'' the book states. ''One-meter diameter launch tubes'' - the precise size of those seized in Britain this month - ''could be built for well under ten million dollars.''
Both Iraq and the British firm that manufactured the steel tubes have insisted that they were intended for a petrochemical plant. But a second British firm which sold a hydraulics system to Iraq since has said it was duped, and now believes it actually provided a recoil mechanism for a huge gun.

HEADLINE: On Tokyo Runways, Foreign Labels Still Rule

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 21

 BODY:
While Japan's emergence as an economic power has been driven by exported electronics and industrial products, it has been paralleled by a growing obsession at home with fashionable goods that have foreign cachet: clothing and accessories.
In a sense, Japanese retail executives say, there is no place else for the money to go. With land selling for as much as $1 million a square yard in downtown Tokyo, real estate is not an investment within the reach of most Japanese. Though a fleet of high-powered Porsches clog Tokyo's streets, the infamous traffic here makes them a frustrating luxury.
Instead, affluent young people buy clothes. And as they do, they create a surging market for the fashion capitals of the world, which have seen demand elsewhere slacken as economies slowed. 
At a dinner party last week at a restaurant in the Roppongi district, the women, all in their 20's, wore clothes by Romeo Gigli, Christian Dior and Chanel. The men wore Giorgio Armani. Over California wines and French-American food, they shared knowing conversation about labels, licenses and the joys of dressmakers in Seoul who are now producing the best line-for-line copies of high-fashion clothing in the Far East.
To Europe, Japan is the new America. It is a market for luxury goods that expanded throughout the 1980's and still has vast potential, fashion executives say, as demand shifts from clothing produced under license with foreign design houses to the real article.
''Japan is now the No. 1 market for French luxury goods in the world,'' said Christian Blanckaert, the president of the Comite Colbert in Paris, a trade association of 70 French companies, including Christian Dior, Givenchy, Hermes, Nina Ricci, Louis Vuitton and Chanel.
 
Outfitters to the 'Salary Men'
Japan accounts for about 27 percent of his organization's sales, Mr. Blanckaert said, compared with about 18 percent to the United States. ''And the pattern of increase is higher than anywhere else in the world,'' he said.
While there is no comparable American organization keeping track, American brands are also well established in Japan, despite some trade barriers. ''Salary men'' wear Brooks Brothers, Paul Stuart, Polo and Wilkes Bashford suits, purchased at branches of those stores here; ''office ladies'' turn out in Donna Karan and Anne Klein II outfits. Last week, the windows of the Takashimaya department store in the Nihombashi section were dressed with clothing made under a new licensing agreement with Geoffrey Beene, perhaps America's leading designer.
American techniques of specialty retailing and merchandise display are also being imported, as high-fashion stores like New York's Barneys and Charivari open here.
''There is a certain sector of our customers who are very brand-name oriented,'' said Naoki Ueno, the merchandise manager of designer dresses, suits and coats at Isetan, another department store. ''They are crazy about Chanel, DKNY and Armani.''
Some of Isetan's customers are so wild about Giorgio Armani, Mr. Ueno said, that they may dress themselves almost entirely in his clothes, from shoes to scarves. ''From a commercial point of view, this type of customer is good for sales,'' Mr. Ueno said.
 
Amid Riot of Labels, A Few Buds of Style
 The mere purchase of expensive goods, of course, does not in itself constitute style, an elusive quality achieved by a process that might be described as editing. Indeed, Tokyo itself, one of the most fashion-conscious cities in the world, sometimes seems in desperate need of editing. So many labels, signs, shops, sounds and smells assault the senses. But fashion executives in both Tokyo and foreign capitals say Japanese consumers, though still profoundly name-conscious, are becoming more sensible and sophisticated in their fashion choices.
The day after the dinner, two of the guests, Yasuko and Yoko Amau, daughters of a retired Japanese diplomat, went shopping in the fashionable Aoyama area, where many European and Japanese designers have boutiques.
At the boutique of Issey Miyake, Japan's world-class avant-garde designer, Yasuko Amau held up a fan-shaped pleated circle of fabric resembling an origami paper sculpture.
''Someone tell me what to do with this,'' she demanded. With a salesman's help, she looked through a catalogue to see how it was meant to be worn. ''You see, even Japanese women have trouble trying to figure Miyake out,'' her sister said.
In the catalogue, Yasuko Amau saw a version of a dress as it was shown in Paris; it was sexier than the one in the store. The salesman said it was not in production in Japan because most Japanese women would not wear something so revealing.
This traditional reluctance presents an obstacle to Western designers, who shift the revealing emphasis of their clothes up and down the torso almost as often as the seasons change. At the Calvin Klein boutique in the Isetan department store in the Shinjuku district, the problem was obvious.
 
Career Look Seems To Cover It All
 A Sony monitor at the entrance to the Klein boutique played a well-worn and blurry copy of a videotape of Mr. Klein's spring fashion show in New York. Models floated down the runway in styles that included two-piece strap less dresses baring lots of shoulder and slivers of skin below the bodice and in back.
None of those dresses is carried in the boutique, which is almost exclusively devoted to career clothing.
''Too sexy,'' said Mr. Ueno of Isetan. ''Japanese women are rather reluctant to expose their skin.''
Japanese retailers like Isetan have shaped the fashion destiny of their country in a way that exceeds the role of merchants in the development of French or American fashion. Historically, the Japanese retailers have produced the foreign designer collections themselves, under licensing agreements, which makes them fashion houses as well as fashion stores.
Isetan, which holds licenses to make Calvin Klein and Adrienne Vittadini clothing in Japan, was the first Japanese company to set up an American ready-to-wear system, a move that profoundly changed the way Japanese people dress.
Before World War II, there were few garments a Japanese woman could buy and wear out of a store. Kimonos were custom-made. After the war, women who wanted to wear modern styles had them copied from Western fashion magazines by local dressmakers. The best-dressed women wore clothing mail-ordered from the Sears Roebuck catalogue.
In the 1950's Isetan set up a design laboratory to study the ready-to-wear system, learning the technique of sizing that enabled Seventh Avenue fashion houses to translate Paris styles for the masses. By the 1960's and 70's, Isetan and other stores, like Seibu, had licensing agreements with the leading designer names - Balmain, Cardin, Lanvin, Saint Laurent. Their factories had to alter styles to suit the smaller Japanese figure, sometimes until they were barely recognizable. But Japanese women didn't mind. There was still the name, printed in English, on the label.
 
Some Faded Names Are Sparkling Here
 Even today, designer names that have lost their steam in Europe and America have cachet here. Others that have always done relatively small business in America are given large sections of retail space, like Jean-Louis Scherrer, who sold a majority interest in his company to Seibu Department Stores this month. Some smaller American designer names, like Carmelo Pomodoro and Ronaldus Shamask, generate expanding business in Japan.
Takashimaya has opened a Carmelo Pomodoro store on the outskirts of Tokyo. Mr. Pomodoro has no shops in the United States. The clothes are primarily made in Italy, and unlike most licensed lines, are specifically designed by Mr. Pomodoro for the Japanese consumer.
Takashimaya also recently entered into an agreement with Geoffrey Beene to make and sell his lower-priced line, called Mr. Beene.
''In the fashion world, there's a tremendous American influence,'' said Teruhiro Kagamihara, the associate director of the Takashimaya chain. ''It certainly has the leadership in visual merchandising.''
American stores themselves are being licensed, as even small New York specialty retailers have entered into the Japanese consciousness, by way of local fashion magazines like Popeye and Brutus, and, of course, Manhattan shopping sprees. Charivari, a New York store that pioneered in bringing Japanese designers to America, has opened shops selling its own brand merchandise in Tokyo and Yokahama, through a licensing agreement with Taka-Q, a Japanese retailer. Barneys New York is scheduled to open in Tokyo in November.
''It's not so much the name of the retailer that they want,'' said Mike Allen, a retail analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd, the securities division of England's Barclays Bank, in Tokyo. ''They need the specialty store know-how. Japanese retailing has been geared to volume merchandising, and it reached a plateau. They want to diversify into other retail formats.''
 
The Licensed Label No Longer Satisfies
 The Japanese fashion industry is entering a new phase, retail executives here say. ''In the 1970's and 80's, the big retailers were eager to put foreign designer names on a label,'' said Nobuyuki Ota, chairman of the Tokyo Council of Fashion Designers. ''There is now a boom in imported merchandise.'
Part of this push comes from the domestic fashion designers, whose daring and quality earned the respect of consumers and made licensed products seem bland. There is also the high cost of manufacturing in Japan. But the overriding reason is a more demanding Japanese consumer.
Christian Dior, which sells licensed products in Japan, opened a shop last month in Osaka that sells only imported styles by Gianfranco Ferre, the company's new designer. The move reflects the philosophy of Beatrice Bongibault, the new managing director of Christian Dior. Ms. Bongibault was formerly a top executive of Chanel, which sells its styles in Japan on a direct-import basis.
''They have become very strict,'' said an executive of Kanebo, the Japanese company that makes Dior's licensed product lines. ''They control the image down to the paper shopping bags. They want everything to be exactly like Paris.''
From the standpoint of price, however, direct imports present a problem, said the Kanebo executive, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. Along with the recent precipitous slide of the Tokyo stock market, the value of the Japanese yen has declined about 30 percent with respect to other world currencies, which could force up the price of imported goods.
Others are less concerned. ''The exchange rate will not affect high fashion,'' said Mr. Allen of Barclays. ''One of the reasons for the Tokyo stock crash was a drop in corporate profits due to higher salaries now paid to workers. I don't expect even a small slowdown in consumer spending.''
''If there is a decline in spending, it won't be as great as in America after the stock market crash there,'' said Takuya Mikami, the general manager for merchandise planning at Takashimaya. ''Japanese have risen to a much higher standard of living than ever before. They will not let it go down.''
