HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Mike Milken And Market Perversity

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Ah, the perversity of Wall Street.
Take last week, for example. For years, Michael Milken of ''junk bond'' fame has protested his innocence of securities fraud charges leveled against him by Federal prosecutors. But late Friday, he agreed in principle to settle the case by pleading guilty to six felony charges and paying a fine of $600 million, according to people who had been briefed on the talks. (They cautioned, of course, that a last-minute change of heart on either side could not be ruled out.) Then there was the worldwide tumble in oil prices. For consumers, the decline might conjure up visions of lower gas prices and utility bills. Corporations might benefit from cheaper petrochemical supplies, and lower transport bills. Just the tonic for the sluggish economy that Wall Street has worried about for months, right? The market promptly went into a panic over the possibility of rekindled inflation. 
To be fair, it wasn't a totally mindless reaction. On Tuesday, the government reported that the consumer price index for March rose five tenths of 1 percent, the largest quarterly jump in almost eight years.
Some inflation-watchers shrugged off the news. ''Look, there was an inflation scare at the beginning of last year,'' said Edward Yardeni, director of economics at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''Then things moderated quite a bit the rest of the year. I think the same pattern will play out here.''
Other economists, however, rang the alarm. Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley, was downright militant. ''I view the March C.P.I. number as potentially a watershed figure,'' Mr. Roach said. ''We've had a minority view for some time that the risks to the United States economy were shifting away from recession and toward inflation.''
Mr. Roach's view wasn't in the minority for long. As traders sold off the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond in anticipation of higher interest rates, the bond's price tumbled to levels that produced the highest yields since last May. The stock market, which started the week strongly, succumbed to sympathy pains; the Dow Jones industrial average closed the week at 2695.95, down 56.08 points for the week.
The prospect of more expensive credit is not only bad for bonds, it's also a drag for utility stocks, which typically act like bonds in their responses to interest rate trends. When interest rates seem likely to climb, utility stocks fall. Last week, the Dow Jones utilities index hit its lowest point since last July.
And not too long ago, it was a widely accepted truism that the credit markets would be greatly reassured if the trade gap would just narrow a little. Well, last week brought the news that the February trade gap hit its lowest level in more than six years. But the credit markets utterly ignored the news. Analysts have been certain for months that headlines about Mr. Milken's case would be bad news for the junk bond market. The latest news hit after traders had closed their books for the week. But a cynic, looking at recent experience, might be tempted to look for a rally.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Glut in Europe; a Stir in Japan

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
In the first quarter of this year, country funds traded in the United States raised more than $2 billion to invest in stock markets outside the country - a record and almost four times the amount raised in any previous year.
About $1.78 billion, or 87 percent, of the $2.03 billion is for funds investing in Europe, and of that, $810 billion was for three funds investing in West Germany and one in Austria.
The figures for these closed-end mutual funds, which raised money from both Americans and foreigners, are another sign of the quick shift in capital toward Europe that followed the opening of Eastern Europe. This money flow has helped push the West German, Austrian, French and Norwegian markets to new highs and may now give a boost to Spain and Italy, where analysts are pointing their latest recommendations. 
Americans have joined wholeheartedly in this trend of buying abroad and show signs of finally breaking out of their long-term reluctance to buy anywhere but Wall Street.
In 1989, investors from the United States increased their purchases of foreign stocks to a record $13.7 billion, according to the Securities Industry Association. This was three and a half times greater than the previous record in 1985, and the $13.7 billion was more than half of the $25 billion in total foreign stock purchases by Americans in the last 10 years.
''All signs are pointing to the trend continuing,'' said David Strongin, the director of international finance at the S.I.A.
Michael T. Porter, the country fund analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said that in addition to the $2 billion boom in the first quarter, there is a long line of new country funds getting ready to raise more money for investment abroad. As many as 10 new funds have indicated that they want to raise about $828 million.
But because of the first-quarter glut, he is not as sure these funds will do as well. By the time the third new Germany fund this year - the Emerging Germany Fund - began trading at the end of March, the market was overloaded. It fell to $11.625 on its first day and closed Friday at $10.375, below its initial offering price of $12 per share.
The Japanese stock market found a little life last week. And there are signs that the end of the slump could be near, if not precisely at hand.
Even with a sharp 750.74 decline on Monday, Tokyo finished the week up 662.52 points, or 2.13 percent, at 29,835.44, and some Tokyo brokers spoke of a positive mood.
Analysts, who had advised getting out at the beginning of this year, are now saying it is time to get in again. More important, there is a feeling that the yen, whose decline was a major factor in the stock market's 28 percent plunge, may be stabilizing.
Several pieces of data support this view. For one, the figures for the first 10 days of April show that Japanese inflation may be moderating. The report for all of April will be watched closely because it is the first month that does not include the one-time impact of the 3 percent consumption tax the Japanese Government imposed last year.
The preliminary figures for the first ten days of April show overall inflation at 2.6 percent over the previous 12 months, compared with the 12-month increase of 3.9 percent through March. And price increases excluding imports (which have gone up sharply because of the declining yen) have fallen even more, to seven-tenths of 1 percent, from 2.5 percent in March.
In addition, the March report for the Japanese trade surplus indicates that it may be beginning to grow again, another change that would support the yen. In fiscal year 1989, Japan's surplus with its trading partners fell to $47 billion, from $78 billion in 1988.
A third factor is that the Bank of Japan has allowed interest rates to creep up slightly as the new fiscal year began in April while not moving its official discount rate again.
Last week the yen-to-dollar exchange rate weakened to the key 160 level, but then bounced back to fall under 157. It ended the week at 157.45.
Nicholas Sargen, director of international bond market research at Salomon Brothers, said these factors mean a sharper fall of the yen, to the 170 level, which had seemed possible, is now very unlikely. ''There is a more balanced sentiment in the market now,'' he said.

LENGTH: 2900 words

HEADLINE: Now It's Red Poling's Turn at Ford

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich.

 BODY:
Red Poling, the Ford Motor Company's new chief executive, keeps a model of a 1948 Jaguar XK-120 on his desk, symbolic of Ford's acquisition of the British car maker this year. No doubt the toy is less a plaything than a reminder of the $2.5 billion paid for Jaguar and the hundreds of millions more Ford must invest to refurbish the ailing company.
The willingness of Ford's top management to pay five times Jaguar's book value was controversial because the investment is unlikely to return a dividend for several years, if at all. With competition in Europe and at home as keen as it has ever been, the world's No. 2 auto maker can ill afford a world-class stumble. But neither can Ford afford a defensive strategy that would attempt merely to shelter its gains. The Jaguar acquisition and other ventures suggest that Ford management - with Mr. Poling at the helm - will be aggressive in protecting the company's prestige and profitability. 
Indeed, Ford's sterling performance in the American market over the last decade, during which it went from near failure to become the strongest of the Big Three auto makers, clearly has raised expectations among investors, analysts and business experts. At a time when much of domestic manufacturing seemed bogged down by bureaucracy, Ford proved that an American company could reinvent itself. Lately, however, its share of the domestic automotive market has slipped, to 23.7 percent for the latest quarter, compared with a 10-year peak of 24.5 percent last year; profit in 1989 was down 27.6 percent from a year earlier. Ford recently put its aerospace and farm equipment units up for sale to help pay for the new engines, transmissions and body styles under development.
 
Matching the Japanese
 Ford's profit and market share problems could be temporary, but they may signal an awakening at the General Motors Corporation, whose Geo franchise has begun to steal Ford's small-car sales, as well as the seemingly unstoppable march of the Japanese auto makers in this country. An issue much larger and more critical than short-term profit, however, is whether Mr. Poling has what it takes to hone and sharpen Ford into the kind of organization that finally can match Japanese quality and productivity.
''I'm convinced we'll get there,'' said Mr. Poling, using as evidence a string of new cars and trucks, like the Ford Explorer four-door utility vehicle. The Explorer is particularly significant since it also will be sold as the Mazda Navajo. It is the first vehicle produced by one of the Big Three that a Japanese auto maker has judged good enough to sell under its name. ''We have plans in place that will enable us to reach the Japanese competition. We're as good as some of the Japanese auto makers already, but not as good as the best,'' which American auto executives universally acknowledge is Toyota.
The only way American auto makers can catch the Japanese, say many experts, is simply to continue to replace and improve vehicle models until they match Japanese quality and productivity. But with capital scarce and the cost of developing a new vehicle from scratch often surpassing a billion dollars, Ford and its rivals will have to find ways to stretch their money.
To do this, Ford has allocated engineering responsibility for new vehicles to different regions of its worldwide organization. Previously, Ford would develop one vehicle for Europe and a separate but similar-sized model for the United States. This policy was necessitated by a host of engineering issues that Ford says have been resolved. Now, Ford's European engineers are designing the replacement for the Tempo/Topaz compacts, a version of which will be sold in Europe as the Sierra; its U.S. engineers are designing a Taurus/Sable replacement, to be sold as the Scorpio in Europe. Japanese engineers working for Mazda, which is 25 percent owned by Ford, did most of the work on the new Escort, which began production in Wayne, Mich., in February and is now in showrooms.
Mr. Poling's biggest challenge, say analysts and other experts, will be coordinating responsibility among the engineers so costs are cut and the new vehicles appear on time. But it is unclear whether successful coordination will address another problem Ford concedes it has: the top Japanese auto makers bring out new models every 3 to 5 years while Ford takes about 10 years.
Another way to reduce capital costs has been the formation of joint ventures. Ford is building Probe sports coupes in partnership with Mazda and will bring out a luxury minivan model with Nissan at a Ford plant in Avon Lake, Ohio, in 1992. As joint ventures proliferate, they may begin to test the limits of antitrust law. G.M. and Chrysler recently announced that they have Justice Department permission to jointly produce four-wheel-drive transmissions. Mr. Poling sees the trend toward joint ventures as a healthy one and declined to rule out a production venture with a Big Three rival.
''The domestic industry has shown it can join together for a joint clean-air study with the petroleum companies,'' said Mr. Poling. Japanese industry has proved that competitors can cooperate to everyone's advantage, he said. ''Why shouldn't we?''
To remain successful, James Womack, research director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's international vehicle project, said, ''Ford must continue to introduce striking products'' like the Taurus. Unveiled in late 1984, the Taurus received much attention because of its unusual styling.
 
High-End Competition
 The decision to buy the established name of Jaguar, however, was an alternative to creating a new high-luxury model Ford needs to compete with Japanese and European models. While Ford's Lincoln luxury cars have been successful, they appeal to older, less affluent buyers than the target audience for Jaguar.
Some auto experts have criticized the Jaguar acquisition, saying that by taking the safer course of buying an established line, Ford loses the chance to stress its strengths as it did with Taurus. Ford risks diluting Jaguar's strong image by interfering and by its promise to boost production, but executives vow they will only aid Jaguar financially, provide some managers and help with suppliers.
With the unexpected promotion of Harold Arthur Poling, 64 years old, to a three-year term as chief executive in November, some conventional wisdom was challenged. At a moment when Ford was facing the need for aggressive spending, it was choosing a man who had earned his reputation as a cost-cutter. Mr. Poling, who was paid $2.1 million in 1989 as vice chairman and chief operating officer, got the top spot when his predecessor, Donald E. Petersen, 63, decided to take early retirement, citing weariness of the job. Some Ford executives believed Mr. Poling, an accountant by training, balanced Mr. Petersen's background as a product engineer. Mr. Petersen tended to give engineers and designers more freedom to spend on new vehicles; Mr. Poling used his experience as a financial controller to set limits.
American auto executives often are categorized as ''product guys,'' engineers like Mr. Petersen and G.M's chairman-elect, Robert Stempel; ''marketing guys,'' like Lee Iacocca, or ''finance guys,'' like G.M.'s outgoing chairman, Roger B. Smith, and Mr. Poling. In the 1950's, corporate power shifted from engineers and entrepreneurs like Henry Ford and Alfred Sloan of G.M. to a coterie of financial executives, epitomized by G.M. chairman Frederic Donner and his acolyte, Mr. Smith.
Numerous Ford officials have tried to head off speculation that Mr. Poling will be little more than a number cruncher by insisting that he understands auto-making from top to bottom. Moreover, they point out, he belongs to a management team that has boosted Ford's capital expenditures to an all-time high.
A growing number of industry experts now wonder whether a chief executive's credentials from early in his career are determinative of future behavior. Moreover, the picture of narrowly focused accountants, engineers and sales executives balancing one another at the top of American auto companies may be outdated. ''Fifteen years ago this might have been an apt way to look at Ford, but top management really has got religion in terms of getting a broader perspective,'' said David Cole, who heads the University of Michigan's center for transportation studies. ''I can assure you Red shares that breadth of view with Don Petersen.''
 
Not a 'Bean Counter'
 David E. Davis, publisher of Automobile magazine, said, ''Red's very soft-spoken affability camouflages a really tough guy. He is constantly described as a bean counter, but a more accurate description would be a tough administrator who really believes in goals, budgets and timetables that must be met.''
Mr. Poling also downplays the importance of his pedigree: ''I've been out of the financial end for more than 15 years. How long do you have to be away from it before you can be considered a general manager?''
A qualification whose importance is beyond dispute is Mr. Poling's cordial rapport with members of the Ford family, said one family member who requested anonymity. The heirs of the late Henry Ford still control ownership of the auto maker through a separate class of stock and were not happy last year when Mr. Petersen resisted promoting William C. Ford Jr. and Edsel Ford to important committees of the board of directors. (Mr. Petersen subsequently relented.) Mr. Poling graduated from Monmouth (Ill.) College and Indiana University, where he earned a master's degree in accounting. He took a job in Ford's steel division as a trainee in 1951. After a number of financial management jobs, he caught the eye of J. Edward Lundy, Ford's legendary chief financial officer. Mr. Lundy recommended him as vice president of finance for Ford's European subsidiary. ''Henry Ford II believed all top managers needed to get tuned in Europe,'' said Mr. Davis, noting that a tough but quiet demeanor was what pleased Mr. Ford.
Based in Great Britain, Mr. Poling rose to president and then, in 1977, chairman of Ford of Europe. Already an excellent golfer, Mr. Poling took advantage of a court on the roof of Ford headquarters to learn squash. ''He's very competitive by instinct,'' said Paul Tippett, the former chairman of the American Motors Corporation who worked with Mr. Poling at Ford's European subsidiary and once required five stitches to close a gash on his face caused by Mr. Poling's errant squash racquet.
 
A Stubborn Streak
 Unlike some corporate chieftains, Mr. Poling maintains a calm exterior. But that covers a stubborn and tenacious streak, say his colleagues. ''If you say you're going to reach a certain level of sales or hit a certain target, Red expects you to do it,'' said a senior Ford official.
As Mr. Poling put it: ''If you set objectives, they should be met.''
On weekends, Mr. Poling brings his 8-stroke handicap to Bloomfield Hills Country Club, a bastion of Big Three auto executives, where he plays with friends and his wife, Marian, whom he met at Ford's steel division. His red hair, now close-cropped and flecked with gray, gave him his childhood nickname. Only his siblings still call him Harold, he said.
In 1979 Ford brought Mr. Poling back to America to become executive vice president and he was elected a director. In 1980 he took over as head of North American automotive operations and was faced with too much plant capacity and too few sales.
''Our products were not being well received,'' recalled Philip Caldwell, a senior managing director of Shearson Lehman Hutton and former Ford chairman. ''The decision was not being made to cut capacity, and the consequences of this inaction were becoming critical, so I sent Red.'' Although the decision would severely hurt profits, Mr. Poling recommended that production capacity be closed.
''Those days are indelibly seared in my mind,'' said Mr. Poling, referring to layoffs and cutbacks. ''I run scared because I don't ever want that to happen again.''
With Mr. Petersen, Mr. Caldwell and other top executives, Mr. Poling was in the vanguard of Ford's push to change its corporate culture in the early 80's. Ford had a typical business autocracy: more often than not, one listened to the boss to discover what to think. The recession of 1980, competition and regulatory costs had driven Ford into perilous financial condition. As head of North American automotive operations, Mr. Poling was influential in supporting an openminded approach to new ideas. The consensus technique had been used successfully by Japanese rivals.
''Early in my career I felt the company was too militaristic and authoritarian,'' Mr. Poling said. ''All my life I believed it was important to get people involved.''
At the same time, slavishly copying Japanese workplace customs is not appropriate either, he said. ''Mazda managers couldn't understand why American workers insisted on taking their vacations'' when Mazda was scurrying to complete its assembly plant in Flat Rock, Mich. ''I can understand it. You have to learn the most efficient way to tackle a problem, and I think the Japanese are learning from us in some areas.''
 
THE CRITICAL EUROPEAN CONNECTION
With seven years at the Ford of Europe headquarters near London, Red Poling comes to the top position with more firsthand international experience than any prior Ford chief executive, a reflection of the immense - and growing - importance of Ford's overseas markets, particularly in Europe.
Profit from European operations accounted for 34 percent of Ford's $3.8 billion net income in 1989; Ford sold about a third of its 6.4 million vehicles in Europe. With the planned reduction of European trade barriers in 1992 and the expected growth in Eastern Europe, Ford executives are predicting that Europe soon could surpass North America as the biggest automotive market.
The Jaguar acquisition holds potential for both markets, Ford executives say, even though Jaguar cars will not be sold in the same large volumes as other Ford models.
At $40,000 and up, Jaguar is an expensive, virtually hand-built luxury car. Its well-known brand name has long had a reputation for traditional elegance, but the car has been known for mediocre quality. Profit had slipped in recent years, limiting capital for development of new models.
William Hayden, a veteran Ford of Europe manufacturing executive who replaced Sir John Egan as Jaguar's chief executive, has said he wants to boost the company's production capacity to 200,000 cars annually within 15 years, up from the current 50,000. This could mean a new assembly plant. Ford will introduce its manufacturing methods and try to use its clout with suppliers to increase quality, productivity and reliability. Ford already has discovered that Jaguar was paying 38 pounds sterling for a set of door handles that it can buy for 4 pounds.
 
FINANCIAL SERVICES, TOO
Though the name Ford instantly denotes the business of cars and trucks, the company also is a rapidly growing player in financial services with $115 billion in assets. In this country, only Citicorp, American Express and Salomon Brothers are larger financial services companies.
Last year Ford bought the Associates, the nation's third-largest finance company, for $3.4 billion, to add to its Ford Motor Credit car financing unit, First Nationwide Financial Corporation savings and loan unit and U.S. Leasing International unit. Ford has disclosed that it is negotiating to buy Marine Midland Bank's automotive lending business.
Profit from financial services was down 4 percent in 1989, providing 17 percent of Ford's total earnings for the year as the group felt the effects of lower net interest margins, increased loan losses and unfavorable exchange rates. Ford executives hope financial services eventually will provide a third of the corporation's profit.
Ford Motor Land and Development owns a number of real estate properties and is developing one that is of special interest to Mr. Poling: a golf club adjacent to Ford headquarters in Dearborn that will host a PGA Seniors golf tournament next year.
The company last year fullfilled a longstanding desire to dispose of Rouge Steel for an undisclosed price; but Ford suffered a $424.3 million net loss on the transaction. Ford will will own 20 percent of the surviving company, which was bought by the Marico Acquisition Corporation.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Earth Day Isn't Getting Any Easier

 BODY:
The 20th anniversary of Earth Day is being marked around the world. Here are four views on its significance.
 
Peter D. Moore
Mr. Moore is managing partner in Inferential Focus, a market research and forecasting firm in New York.
On the surface, Earth Day is about clean air, clean water and a safer environment. But underneath, the motivation for this effort comes from a fundamental shift in society's values from short-term, leveraged exploitation to long-term control and protection. This shift is driven by people who have been disillusioned by the ineffectiveness of big government and big business in dealing with the problems confronting society. Their new mood is evidenced by a desire for participation, not delegation, effective action, not talk, and a willingness to accept responsibility for what is happening to our environment now. 
This new mood recently energized Harlem residents, led by local clergy, to paint over billboards with messages they felt exploited the youth in their community. Again it was seen in Tacoma, Wash., where a judge refused to accept a settlement between the city and the Pennwalt Corporation over a 75,000-gallon chemical leak into Puget Sound until the chief executive himself appeared in court. The judge said: ''I think the public is entitled to know who is responsible.''
Environmentalists have been active ever since Earth Day 1970, but only recently has their message gained popular momentum. They have not changed; the listeners have changed, and the listeners' new perspective gives shape to the new ''environment'' in which business and political leaders must act.
 
Edward L. Hennessy
Mr. Hennessy is chairman of Allied-Signal.
America's environment has improved markedly in the 20 years since the first Earth Day. Spurred by the growth in environmental concerns during the 1970's, government and industry made major strides in improving air and water quality, controlling hazardous wastes and addressing the most visible ecological abuses.
Still, many environmental problems remain unsolved. And we face new, more pervasive concerns. The connection between ozone depletion and chlorofluorocarbons, for example, was not discovered until 1974, and the thinning of the ozone layer over the Antarctic was not observed until 1985. Allied-Signal Inc. and other CFC manufacturers have responded by phasing out CFC's and by spending hundreds of millions on research and development of safe substitutes. In the next 20 years, however, we must do more than just respond to clear and present dangers. We must create a generation of environmentally knowledgeable leaders who understand that all of our actions have environmental consequences.
How can we do this? Tufts University has taken an innovative first step. Financed by Allied-Signal, the Tufts Environmental Literacy Institute will help faculties across the country integrate environmental issues into courses ranging from the liberal arts to engineering science.
Equipped with a broader understanding of environmental problems, our future leaders will be better prepared to strike a balance between preserving the earth's resources and extending the benefits of new technology to the world.
 
Julian Simon
Mr. Simon is professor of business administration at the University of Maryland and author of ''The Economic Consequences of Immigration.''
Earth Day is a costly fraud and not a trivial one at that. All these doomsayers are wasting a terrible amount of our resources and it is very bad for everyone's morale. Young people are being told that they cannot flex their muscles, that they cannot do great things because it might hurt someone else.
But the scientific data compiled by the government show that the quality of the environment has been steadily improving. The air is more breathable, the water more drinkable, and we don't have the scarcities doomsayers predicted.
There are many biologists who say that social scientists like myself just do not understand science. But the fact is these scientists ignore all of the evidence of history that says that things are getting better. They ignore the fact that there is more abundance, less starvation and that people are living longer. But when these scientists are confronted with these facts, they say this time the future will be different and things will get worse.
Some environmentalists say affluence causes the deterioration of the environment. And, while it is true that very poor people do not produce much trash, affluence is what cleans up the environment. This is true in part because the affluent can afford better services, but also because waste and pollution present opportunities. Economists like myself think that the economic system is responsive: every shortage is an opportunity for someone to fill a need.
 
Lester R. Brown
Mr. Brown is president of Worldwatch Institute, an environmental policy and research group.
Each year in our ''State of the World'' report we - in effect - give the earth an annual physical. The results are not reassuring. Each year the earth's forests shrink, the deserts expand, cropland loses precious topsoil and the protective ozone layer thins. The concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere continues to rise and the number of plant and animal species diminishes.
The challenge facing humanity in the 90's is to reverse the environmental degradation of the planet before it leads to economic decline of the sort seen in parts of Africa. Meeting this challenge requires more than fine-tuning; it will take a fundamental restructuring of the global economy.
Stabilizing climate means phasing out fossil fuels, replacing them with renewable sources of energy like hydropower, geothermal generating plants, solar-thermal power plants, wind-electric turbines and photovoltaic cells. It means designing a transport system that will be powered largely by solar-generated electricity, and perhaps hydrogen fuel, rather than gasoline. It means replacing garbage collection with recycling industries. Most of all, it requires greatly increased efficiency.
Enterprising corporations will look at the blueprint of an environmentally sustainable global economy and design a corporate plan that helps make it a reality. Some farsighted corporations will move rapidly and capitalize on the new needs. Others will resist change and lose out. Corporate environmentalism is more than good public relations. It is a matter of economic survival.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
WHY MEXICO NEEDS A FREE TRADE PACT

BYLINE: By SIDNEY WEINTRAUB; Sidney Weintraub, distinguished visiting scholar at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, is author of ''A Marriage of Convenience: Relations Between Mexico and the United States.''

 BODY:
During the 1980's, Mexico embarked upon what can properly be called its second revolution. This revolution, which relies upon exports for economic growth, recognizes that the majority of Mexico's trade is with the United States and that this trade is in what are called intermediate goods - the engine and not necessarily the automobile, semi-conductors and not always computers. This trade takes place largely within the same industry, even within the same company, between a parent and an affiliate. Partly because of this trade, Mexico has relaxed restrictions on foreign direct investment.. The two countries are thus suppliers to each other's production facilities, with around 90 percent of Mexico's exports of manufactured goods going to the United States. 
The question arises of whether this mutual industrial reliance is healthy, particularly for Mexico. It makes Mexico vulnerable to an American economic downturn or to American protectionism. With respect to the latter, Mexico has one assurance against widespread American import restrictions: the close alliances that now exist between large companies operating in both countries. Mexican concerns over excessive reliance on the United States market can be dissipated only as Mexican industry increases its competitiveness.
The logical next question is whether this integration is best secured by a more formal agreement between the two countries. Mexican leaders have decided that it is and they have suggested starting the process for free-trade negotiations. Canada also made the decision to enter into a free-trade agreement with the United States to more thoroughly secure access to the American market. By allocating production for a vastly larger combined market, Canada is able to increase its industrial productivity and, thereby, its global competitive position.
The decision to enter into a free-trade agreement with the United States was controversial in Canada out of concern for its national political and cultural identity. It will be sensitive in Mexico as well, out of fear of the loss of national sovereignty. However, if Mexico is to become a developed country, it will have to compete on first-world terms. Mexico cannot do that based on the size of its domestic market alone. That is the logic behind Mexico's suggestion that negotiations for a free- trade agreement begin.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania's Message to Investors

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is indeed ironic that just as so many socialist and Communist nations are taking bold steps toward a capitalist economy, the Pennsylvania Legislature has seen fit to pass a law that can only be seen as socialist in its primary thrust (''A Paradoxical Anti-takeover Law,'' April 8). While this law does not actually remove private capital from the hands of investors, it makes the status of that ownership nominal at best, removing the last vestiges of any influence or control shareholders have had over the people actually running the firms they own. Moreover, it clearly allows boards of directors to favor the interests of ''stakeholders'' - like employees or communities - over those of stockholders.
Much of this was done in the name of encouraging stability. Yet free-enterprise capitalism has never been and never will be ''stable.'' Indeed, it is Joseph Schumpeter's ''creative destruction'' that typifies the very heart of capitalism and which has provided, over all, its generous bounty. We might all ponder what those seeking ''stability'' might have wrought had they thwarted the advent of the automobile 90 years ago, in the name of protecting the horse, buggy and harness industries from economic disruption and job losses.
Pennsylvania has sent a very clear message to investors, whose only logical response is to avoid the securities of Pennsylvania-based corporations, perhaps their products and services too.
 
RODNEY E. BATE
Hohokus, N.J., April 9

HEADLINE: TOUGH CALL;
Why the U.S. Has a Case of The Mumbles On Lithuania

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE situation in Lithuania has become a test of whether the cold war is really over. The way President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev handle the explosive questions raised by Lithuania's drive for independence will demonstrate whether they are truly willing to treat one another more as allies than adversaries.
Consider a few of the delicate issues posed by the evolving situation in Lithuania, where the Kremlin has expanded its economic embargo even as officials in Moscow and Vilnius are making conciliatory noises.
* Mr. Gorbachev has already proven to the United States that he is not Stalin. But for Washington to go on expanding relations with him, must he now prove that he is Woodrow Wilson and immediately set Lithuania free? 
* Mr. Gorbachev lives in a tough neighborhood - a teeming multi-ethnic empire bursting with conservatives and rabid nationalists. But does that mean the United States should tolerate his doing nasty things in the short run, so he will do kinder things in the long run?
* If the United States never actively insisted that Brezhnev or Khrushchev set Lithuania free, should it now punish Mr. Gorbachev for not doing so on the terms Lithuanians want - particularly when it was precisely his reforms that made the Lithuanian independence movement possible?
 
Caution and Anger
The Bush Administration initially confronted these questions by urging both sides to enter into a peaceful dialogue. But as events in Lithuania have deteriorated, the Administration, while doing its best to postpone taking any action, has grown privately angry with both parties. While they would not say so publicly, officials believe that the Lithuanians have behaved foolishly by simply declaring their independence in defiance of Moscow without any tactical plan as to how to achieve it. It is not enough for small, weak states to be right; they also have to be smart.
At heart, there is much more sympathy in the Administration for Mr. Gorbachev and his dilemma than there is for the Lithuanians' demand for immediate independence. The democratic reforms Mr. Gorbachev has initiated, and the arms control agreements he is prepared to enter into, could better the lives of millions of Americans and Russians. If, to preserve that process, three million Lithuanians might have to delay independence a few years, then, American officials say privately, so be it.
 
Making an Example
At the same time, Administration officials are beginning to fear that Mr. Gorbachev may have decided to make such an example of Lithuania - so no other Soviet republic would even think about secession - that he will exceed what the White House considers tolerable levels of pressure. If Mr. Gorbachev goes too far - and ''we will know it when we see it,'' said one Administration official - the United States will punish him by reducing some trade or commercial ties that benefit him much more than Washington. But the White House, under the guise of consulting with the allies, is trying to postpone even that moment of reckoning as long as it can. Barring a massacre, the United States does not intend to allow Lithuania to upset arms control negotiations or other mutually advantageous aspects of the relationship.
While this is the policy, one would hardly know it from Administration public statements. On the subject of Lithuania, President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d have engaged in the diplomatic equivalent of mumbling. After Mr. Baker last week delivered, in testimony to Congress, the most explicit statement yet by the Administration on its Lithuania policy, Representative J. J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas, remarked to him: ''I join with my colleagues in commending you for a good statement. At the same time, Mr. Secretary, I've tried to read through it hurriedly, and I've listened to you, and I keep asking myself 'Now what did he say?' ''
To some extent this mumbling is deliberate. By keeping its red lines vague, the White House hopes to maintain maximum flexibility and maximum deterrence by constantly forcing Mr. Gorbachev to wonder whether the next move will be the one that goes too far. At the same time, the Bush team is also speaking in muted voices because it is afraid of criticism from the Republican right. Or, as Richard N. Perle, a former senior Pentagon official in the Reagan Administration, put it: ''Were it not for the Republican right, what we would be seeing in Lithuania today is an unvarnished American sellout rather than a glossed-over one.'' But to a great extent the Administration's mumbling on Lithuania is part of an oft-repeated pattern - an inability to articulate its foreign policy so that the average American can understand and identify with it.
The situation in Lithuania is a wake-up call saying that change in the Soviet Union is going to be a long, bumpy, nasty, occasionally violent process that will not be supervised by Mother Teresa. At every bump in the road the Administration is going to find its policies toward the Soviet Union challenged by voices from the right, left and center. Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker seem to believe that by saying little they will maximize their room to maneuver. But perhaps only by stating frankly the competing considerations in Lithuania will the Administration build the confidence with the public and Congress that allows real maneuverability.
Michael J. Sandel, a Harvard University political theorist, said: ''I don't see why they can't say in simple language: 'Frankly, we are confronted here with a dilemma between our committment to the principle of national self-determination on one hand and our fervent desire that Gorbachev succeed in bringing political and economic reform to the Soviet Union as a whole on the other. Therefore our interests in his political survival and success have to temper, but not extinquish, our support for Lithuanian independence.' ''
By not clearly articulating the competing principles at stake and acknowledging the tension between them, said Mr. Sandel, the Administration fails to do justice to either and runs the risk that both principles will eventually become blurred or distorted in the public's mind.
Such are the challenges posed by Lithuania. Mr. Bush's and Mr. Gorbachev's ability to meet them in creative ways, argued Michael Mandelbaum, an expert on East-West relations at the Council on Foreign Relations, will determine whether Lithuania ''is the latest cold war crisis or the first post-cold war crisis.'' He added, ''If it is just another cold war crisis, then what Gorbachev has done would demand harsh condemnation and a halt to real progress in the relationship.''
If it is a post-cold war crisis, he said, ''then it is just a bump in a road in which the United States gives Gorbachev some leeway and Gorbachev eventually strikes a deal with Lithuania that allows him to save face, but gives the Lithuanians the promise of fulfilling all or most of their aspirations in the long run.''

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
States Are Finding Pension Funds Can Be a Bonanza Hard to Resist

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
LEGISLATORS here and in other state capitals use words like ''adjustment'' or ''revision'' when they change the formula that determines how much money will be set aside for state workers' retirement. But in virtually all cases in recent years, these changes have gone in one direction, decreasing the amount the states paid to the funds. Now, the people whose pensions are at stake are starting to use other words, like ''robbery'' and ''raiding,'' to describe the changes.
In New York, the latest skirmish over pension funds is being fought between State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the trustee of the state pension system, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature, who are still struggling - three weeks after the legal deadline - to reach agreement on a new state budget. 
The Governor and legislative leaders, contending that the state pension system has more than enough assets to meet projected obligations, are proposing what would be the second major reduction in two years in the state's contribution to the funds.
 
Saving $200 Million
The Comptroller is resisting, maintaining that another round of cuts on top of the $325 million reduction he reluctantly agreed to last year could eventually threaten the state's ability to honor its obligations to all its pensioners. The changes sought this year would save the state at least $200 million more.
With so many states under such severe pressure to balance their budgets, there is no mystery in why politicians find the pension funds, which are worth more than $700 billion nationally, such attractive targets. Reducing the amount a state gives to the funds is likely to generate less protest from the voters than raising taxes.
Moreover, the basic question that surrounds such reductions - do they threaten the long-term stability of the pension funds? - is literally as difficult to answer as it is to predict the course of the stock market. Even those most alarmed by the cuts concede that any problems may not become obvious for a decade or more. Then, they say, lawmakers will be forced to impose new taxes to restore the pension funds to a sound footing, or simply find ways to reduce the pensioners' benefits.
 
'This Is Robbery'
''This is robbery, pure and simple,'' said Joe McDermott, president of New York State's Civil Service Employees Association, which represents about 260,000 current and former public employees. ''They're using the pension funds as a piggy bank that they can turn over and shake when they get into a jam.''
Nearly two-thirds of the states have taken steps in the last five years to ease their short-term budget problems by reducing the amount of money they set aside for pensions, state fiscal experts say.
The most common method is to simply change what is known as the ''interest rate assumption,'' or the rate of return that a state supposes a retirement fund will earn on its investments, said Cathie G. Eitelberg, chief pension lobbyist for the Government Finance Officers Association, a Washington-based group of state and local finance officials. The higher a projected rate of return, the less a state will have to pay to insure that the fund can meet the fixed costs of its pensioners, she said.
Last year Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, and Mr. Regan, a Republican, negotiated a change in the assumed rate of return for the state pension system, which controls $45 billion in pension funds for 850,000 current and retired public employees, from 8 percent annually to 8.75 percent. That, combined with a downward revision of the expected inflation rate, enabled the state to reduce its pension payments by $325 million.
But the problem with such projections, some experts say, is that no one knows how accurate they will prove to be. The difficulty in forecasting is illustrated by the wild swings in the rate of return that the New York system, known as the Common Retirement Fund, has actually received in recent years. For 1988 it was 13.9 percent, but for 1987, the year the stock market collapsed, it was just 1.6 percent. Back in 1982, the fund reaped a 21.4 percent return; the year before, it was 3.4 percent, according to the Comptroller's office. Much of the fund is invested in stocks so the return is measured by the market value of the stocks at a given moment.
Over the last 10 years, the total return by the New York fund has averaged about 12 percent annually, a figure that would indicate that even the changes made last year were well within the bound of prudence. But the national average for such funds over the last 30 years is only about 5 percent, said Ms. Eitelberg of the finance officers association.
This year Mr. Cuomo is advocating another change in accounting methods under which the annual state contribution to meet the ultimate projected cost of a worker's pension, rather than remaining constant as it is now, would gradually increase as the worker grows older and his salary increases. The immediate effect would be to lower the state's required payments by at least $200 million by most estimates. Critics say the state would be forced to raise contributions in later years.
Any change would have to be approved by the Legislature. The Governor contends that the pensions are so overfunded that the shift would be harmless. The state has, in the words of Gary G. Fryer, the Governor's spokesman, ''a Rolls-Royce pension system and a Chevy budget.'' But groups representing public employees describe the proposed revision as a dangerous step that will haunt somebody - either the employees or all taxpayers - later on. This change ''simply puts off today's payment until tomorrow,'' said Mr. McDermott. ''When tomorrow comes, it will create a crisis for state and local governments.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 557 words

HEADLINE: A Monumental Day

 BODY:
On Earth Day 1970, Americans rose up against what they had done to foul the environment. That wave of dismay drove Congress to decree a substantial cleanup of air and water. Twenty years later, on Earth Day 1990, public concern about the environment is again at a peak. And this time the wave washes far beyond American shores. Whether the issue is global warming or ozone depletion, what happens in Eastern Europe or China matters as much as what happens here. 
If, for example, global warming is confirmed, global burning of coal, oil and wood must be sharply reduced. That will be hard for America, traumatic for developing countries. Yet the lesson of the last 20 years is that even the most painful readjustments can be made.
Cars rolling off Detroit's assembly lines emit 96 percent less carbon dioxide and 75 percent less nitrogen oxides than those of 1970. The Great Lakes have been restored to life and the Hudson now teems with fish. Congress has raised $6 billion to help clean abandoned toxic waste dumps, and $60 billion for building sewage treatment plants. And it's about to rewrite the Clean Air Act, finally tackling the divisive issue of acid rain.
Some countries cannot afford such expensive solutions. But global threats like ozone-layer depletion and climate change knit all predicaments together. At some point, each country's waste becomes the world's business, whether it be America's profligate use of energy, Brazil's wanton destruction of forests or the miserable pall of Stalinist filth that blights Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
The ruination of nature now apparent in East Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia shows what environmental indifference can do. Communist central planners faced no public pressure to heed the consequences of pollution. Unchecked, heavy industry spewed poisons into air and water.
The results were disastrous. Half of Poland's rivers are now too toxic even for industrial use. Acidic industrial fallout has eaten away the faces of Cracow's medieval statues. In Katowice, poisonous gases and toxic dust are so severe that people sleep in salt mines just to breathe clean air.
And even though East bloc governments have long suppressed health statistics, their savage disregard of the environment seems certain to have taken a heavy toll.
 
The contrast between West and
East makes clear the value of relentless pressure from environmentalists in the U.S., including the organizers of Earth Days past and present.
At times, their acknowledgment of past accomplishments seems grudging, their warning of future perils excessive, their exhortations to change life styles intrusive. Commute by bus, they cry; don't use disposable diapers, and be sure to separate recyclable materials in the garbage.
Those are not trivial ways to raise consciousness. But what will count most are economic incentives to save energy and curb pollution, research into new energy-saving technologies, and a reasoned effort to set priorities among threats of widely different risk.
An America humming on solar cells and wind turbines . . . A Brazil that has at last achieved sanctuary for its irreplaceable rain forests . . . An Eastern Europe on the way to restoring its environment along with its freedoms: these are fitting goals for today's outpouring of concern and tomorrow's work.

HEADLINE: They Need Our Know-How, Not Our Bucks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It's in America's interest - and that of our Western allies - to help the ravaged economies of Eastern Europe shift from socialism to capitalism. But pouring in billions of dollars in financial aid won't solve East Europe's economic crises (''Rethinking Foreign Aid,'' editorial, April 9). New loans and credits will only add to their staggering debt burdens. 
History suggests that incentive-based policies, not foreign aid, are the source of economic growth and rising living standards. The low-tax, free-market economies of South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong have enjoyed economic success without development aid. In contrast, massive loans to Mexico, Brazil and Argentina have subsidized economic failure.
The proposed Eastern European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is no way to help East Europe.
I don't think we should be part of an effort to subsidize Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Let him pay for perestroika himself by cutting the one-fifth of Soviet gross national product that goes to his military. Also, this bank will be dominated by Western Europeans who favor quasi-socialist economic policy emphasizing central planning - the opposite of the economic system East Europe needs.
The United States should recall the proud heritage of the Marshall Plan. We provided the pro-capitalist leadership that rebuilt Europe after the nightmare of Nazi Germany; let us show the same leadership in rescuing East Europe from the nightmare of socialist economics. Here are measures we can take to lead East Europe down the road to prosperity:
* Encourage private investment. We should reform and simplify foreign tax laws that burden United States business investments abroad. We could issue bonds to private Americans of East European descent to finance small business start-ups in East Europe.
* Expand opportunities for United States exporters. We have to reform our export control restrictions for East Europe and overhaul our outdated licensing process. The United States should also grant most favored nation status to Eastern European countries to expand overseas trade.
* Support institutions and organizations essential to a free market economy. United States financial aid should go to private-sector enterprises in which residuals are owned by individuals, not government. Public-sector loans must be conditioned on progress in market-oriented reforms, like securing private property rights and deregulating the economy.
Individual Americans have a big role to play. John Malcheski and Daman Szymanski, Wisconsin farmers who are part of an overseas volunteer assistance group, recently told me that Polish farmers are in desperate need of technical and managerial assistance in running a dairy farm -how to dig a modern well, how to meet a payroll, how to introduce incentives into their farm economy.
During Vaclav Havel's recent visit to the West, the Czechoslovak President said, ''we value your advice and moral support far more than your money.'' This is the kind of help the Eastern Europeans need - old-fashioned Yankee know-how, not an endlessly flowing fountain of foreign aid.
 
(Senator) ROBERT W. KASTEN JR.
Ranking Republican Member, Foreign Operations Subcommittee
 Washington, April 10, 1990

HEADLINE: They Need Our Know-How, Not Our Bucks;
The New Horsemen

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Rethinking Foreign Aid'' (editorial, April 9) is on target in calling for revitalization of United States development assistance policies in the face of radically changed international circumstances. But the alternative you suggest is only half a program.
The principal rationale you put forth for new development assistance initiatives is promoting America's own economic well-being and political security. That's undeniably important, but it is an incomplete justification that would lead to a seriously deficient program. 
The Four Horsemen of the modern age have been the ascendancy of militarism and the vast armadas it has spawned; the authoritarian suppression of human rights; the widespread poverty and hunger afflicting one-fifth of humanity, and the unrelenting assault on the environment and the natural systems. Here, on the cusp of the 1990's, as the cold war seems winding down and democracy rising, America should commit itself to encouraging these geopolitical developments and to starting a new era of action against world poverty and environmental deterioration, with particular focus on helping those who need it most.
In the developing world, the foremost challenges are mass poverty and environmental decay, with excessive population growth contributing to each. The United States should make these the primary focus for cooperation and assistance in the third world. Our goal should be to promote sustainable, nondestructive livelihoods for the rural and urban poor. And to promote environmental protection that conserves the resource base for long-term production; protects public health, and establishes a sound basis for international environmental cooperation. None of the great environmental challenges of the 1990's - global warming, ozone depletion, biodiversity loss, soil and water deterioration - can be met without increasing North-South cooperation.
Americans have shown they want this country to stand for more than short-term political and economic self-interest. The time is ripe for a new United States mission internationally, one based on the concept of cooperative action to sustain the earth and its people.
 
GUS SPETH
President, World Resources Institute
 Washington, April 10, 1990

To the Editor:
We at the Overseas Private Investment Corporation couldn't agree more with ''Rethinking Foreign Aid'' (editorial, April 9). But we would like to point out that the Bush Administration has been putting some of your recommendations into action. 
I refer specifically to your point ''to attract private capital into risky new marketplaces, investment insurance, loan guarantees and preferential credit programs need to be enlarged.'' The Overseas Private Investment Corporation is a self-sustaining Government agency designed to accomplish exactly what you advocate.
President Bush announced last year that the United States would extend OPIC programs to Poland and Hungary, and this year the Administration proposed legislation to authorize our programs in the rest of Eastern Europe. The services are producing investment in more than 100 countries, including Eastern Europe and Central America, but unfortunately, our agency remains obscure.
Thanks to growing recognition of a global investment strategy as the best way for the United States to meet economic challenges in a changing world, OPIC won't be obscure much longer. In this fiscal year, some 100 United States corporations have registered for our investment insurance or loan guarantees for Eastern Europe. These ventures represent potential investments of almost $2 billion.
 
FRED M. ZEDER
