LENGTH: 4675 words

HEADLINE: FUTURE TRADING: DOES CHICAGO RUN WALL STREET?

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle; Louis Uchitelle covers economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:
AS IF FRANTICALLY TRYING TO PLACE A BET ON THE outcome of a cockfight, Thomas M. Hunter Jr. signals wildly with his hands and arms from the top tier of a small amphitheater at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. He is 40 years old, a husky, bearded 6-footer. His nickname, Turk, abbreviated for identification purposes to TRK, is emblazoned on a button on his lapel, and the gold bracelets he wears career on his wrist as he waves.
Turk is betting big at the moment, but not on battling roosters or some thrilling miniature chariot race taking place in the central pit of this strange arena. The action that so excites Turk and the other gamblers jammed onto the arena's octagonal tiers is far away, at the New York Stock Exchange, where the shares of American corporations are bought and sold. Turk and his colleagues, participants in the ritual known as futures trading, are, in essence, wagering on whether the prices of these shares will rise or fall. 
On this particular morning, Feb. 12, Lincoln's Birthday, Turk is betting that stock prices will fall. More precisely, he is acting as agent for a big Wall Street firm, Shearson Lehman Hutton, which is gambling on a sell-off. Rumors are circulating that a major brokerage house, the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., is about to declare bankruptcy (it will, the next day), and Shearson figures the rumors will drive down stock prices for a while.
Acting on this hunch, Shearson has enlisted Turk to place its bets, which he does in the grand style of the Chicago futures trader. Signaling his wager, and screaming it out at the same time, Turk bangs three fingers against his forehead. Each finger represents 10 betting tickets. Quickly, he pumps his arms forward, palms out. And others on the tiers scream back, waggle a finger or two and pull their outstretched arms toward them, palms inward. Each is taking a part of Turk's bet.
Over the next 15 minutes, Turk repeats the signals and slowly builds up the bets for Shearson to nearly $69 million worth of stock. Technically, he is selling ''futures contracts,'' but each contract is in fact a wager that the stocks named in the contract will fall in price. If they do, then Shearson is entitled to collect the amount of the fall.
As the betting mounts in Chicago, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the great gauge of American stock prices, plunges 10 points in just minutes in New York and keeps falling. Within an hour the Dow is down 26 points; then it levels off and begins to rise as Turk and other gamblers perched on the arena's tiers begin to cash in their bets and end their wager. Before lunch, Shearson is ahead more than $200,000.
Clearly, the gambling on stock prices in Chicago, a practice that began only eight years ago, has become intertwined with the trading of real stocks in New York, a relationship that many link with a new, dangerous age on Wall Street. After the crash on Oct. 19, 1987, few people believed that so shattering an event, with the Dow Jones average falling 508 points, could recur more than once in a lifetime. Only now, in the aftermath of last Oct. 13, when the Dow fell 190 points in just 90 minutes, is there finally open acknowledgement that a nightmarish trait has crept into the American system for trading stocks: the periodic, unheralded, panicky one-day crash. Many efforts are being made to identify the reasons for these crashes. The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing a soon-to-be-released account of exactly what happened on Oct. 13. The New York Stock Exchange has appointed a blue-ribbon panel, headed by Roger B. Smith, chairman of General Motors, to pinpoint causes and recommend remedies. The Bush Administration has a high-level panel reviewing all the data and reporting to Congress.
But in all the discussions, one theme stands out. Nearly every expert places some blame on futures trading in stocks. And nearly everyone agrees that when the Dow Jones average is declining for other reasons - for example, a Government report that unemployment has risen - then the gambling in Chicago can, without warning, accelerate a bad day on Wall Street into a disaster. Richard Ketchum, the director of market regulation at the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a succinct description of the role of futures trading. ''Why hold stocks,'' he says, ''if the futures market tells you that prices are going down?''
WHATEVER THE CAUSES OF THE NEW ONE-DAY CRASHES, the transformation from an earlier time is striking. Since the late 1930's, few events have triggered the sort of decline that occurred last Oct. 13, when the Dow average lost 6.9 percent of its value. The German advance across Europe and the fall of France and Holland produced two such days in May 1940, with the Dow falling by 6.8 percent each time. President Dwight D. Eisenhower's heart attack on Sept. 26, 1955, made the Dow go down 6.5 percent. But on no other day - not the Monday after Pearl Harbor nor the day President John F. Kennedy was shot - did the Dow average's loss even crack 6 percent. When sharp sell-offs did come, as in the early 1960's and mid-70's, they were drawn out over days or weeks.
Then the one-day sell-offs began to appear, each one reducing the Dow average by roughly 7 percent - not so shattering as the Great Crashes of Oct. 29, 1929 (a 12.8 percent drop) and Oct. 19, 1987 (22.6 percent), but very severe by post-Depression standards. Each became an unnerving event for an American public accustomed to a more predictable stock market. The first episode, on Oct. 26, 1987, was written off as an aftershock from the devastating crash that had occurred just seven days before. The next one, on Jan. 8, 1988, was harder to explain, coming as it did out of nowhere on a snowy, uneventful Friday, at the end of a week in which stock prices had been rising briskly. Much of the 6.9 percent decline in the Dow average that day was in the final hour or so of trading, and it was out of all proportion to the events of the day. The only major news, in fact, was bullish. The Federal Government said the unemployment rate had declined in the previous month, the sort of report that often makes stock prices rise. Similarly, in the view of the S.E.C.'s Ketchum, the news that preceded the late-afternoon minicrash last Oct. 13 would not, in another age, have triggered such a plunge. A group trying to buy United Airlines announced that it could not get bank loans for the deal. Speculators in United's stock and in the stocks of other takeover targets got worried and began to sell. But these ''small, aggressive'' traders who rushed to sell were only a handful of people, Ketchum says. Their selling, by itself, should not have precipitated the panic that ensued. And that is where suspicion of futures trading comes in.
TO UNDERSTAND THE ROLE OF THE FUTURES market in a minicrash, one needs first to know a little about the evolution on Wall Street in the 1980's. The New York Stock Exchange remains the premier marketplace for the trading of shares in American corporations. These shares now have a value of $3.5 trillion, and three-quarters of this value is in stocks listed on the exchange at 11 Wall Street. What happens in its trading rooms sets the price levels of American stocks wherever they are traded, and influences stock markets throughout the world. But in the last decade, several new forces have transformed the exchange into an easily triggered, hard-to-control selling machine.
One obvious change is the concentration of trading in the hands of the mutual funds, insurance companies and pension funds that accumulate huge amounts of cash and invest big chunks of it in stocks. Measured in dollar value, these institutions, as they are called, own or control 45 percent of all shares in American companies, about double what it was in 1970. And they do approximately 50 percent of the trading in the 1,741 stocks listed on the New York exchange, also double the 1970 level, according to the Securities Industry Association.
When a sell-off gets rolling, institutions often pull away from the market, neither buying nor selling until the trouble passes. Two of the biggest, Prudential Insurance Company and the Dreyfus Corporation, did exactly that last Oct. 13. And when such big players stop buying, it does not take many of Ketchum's small, aggressive sellers to produce a ruinous day on Wall Street. Compounding the problem is the burgeoning trading technique known as basket trading. Rather than trade only in individual companies - say 200,000 shares of J.C. Penney or one million shares of General Electric - the biggest players buy and sell ''baskets'' of stock in a single trade; that is, thousands of shares in dozens of companies. Basket trading now represents roughly 10 percent of all the buying and selling on the New York Stock Exchange.
Basket trading (also known as (Continued on Page 82) program trading because computers are programmed to execute the complex orders) reflects a huge change in attitude toward the stock market, one that makes a virtue of restlessly trading stocks rather than holding them as long-term investments.
Many money managers now design their holdings to reflect a cross-section of the nation's publicly traded companies. They own, in effect, the shares of selected companies in nearly every industry represented on the stock exchange. Each basket, in turn, is a miniature of this cross-section, a way for the institutions to trade without changing the mix in their holdings. The minimum goal is to be able to tell corporate clients that the pension money, say, they have entrusted to the institution to invest in stocks is performing at least as well as the overall market, rising and falling in value with the Dow Jones average of 30 major corporations or with Standard & Poor's 500 representative stocks, another popular yardstick. To keep their clients happy, however, they need to do better than that, which they try to accomplish through relentless trading, a lot of it in baskets. The side effects of all this have proved not so benign. On a down day, the selling of so many stocks simultaneously will naturally accelerate a decline, as it did during the minicrash last Oct. 13. Basket trading that afternoon accounted for nearly 30 percent of all transactions, according to the S.E.C.
NO ONE WAS ANTICIPATING such severe sell-offs in 1982, however, when the Chicago Mercantile Exchange instituted what is now the most popular forum for futures trading in stocks. The practice was intended, in fact, to protect institutional traders against the occasional daily losses that result from restless trading.
The contracts wagered in Chicago are, essentially, imaginary baskets, each representing the 500 stocks in the Standard & Poor's cross-section. Because this cross-section is also the most popular mix among the big institutions, money managers turn to the Chicago futures pit when they are reluctant to sell the stocks in their portfolios but fear prices might soon decline.
In other words, the money manager ends up eating his cake and having it, too. He has ''hedged,'' as Wall Street calls it, losing money on his portfolio of real stocks in New York, but making back the loss by gambling on those same stocks in Chicago. Specifically, the big money manager calls his broker, perhaps Shearson or Salomon Brothers, or he gets word directly to a Turk Hunter, standing on the top tier of the trading pit, and asks him to sell a specified number of futures contracts. The stocks in each contract are valued today at roughly $170,000, but in Chicago, Hunter isn't dealing in real stocks.
What he does, when he bangs one finger against his forehead and pushes his arms forward, palms out, is to create 10 baskets of imaginary shares and offer them for sale at the prevailing price. If stock prices decline in New York, then the value of the real stocks in the money manager's portfolio declines. That's bad news. But so does the value of the imaginary stocks, which Hunter might have sold for $170,000 per contract. One hour later, each of these baskets might be worth only $169,000, and that's good news. Hunter and his client have, in effect, had the foresight to get rid of 10 baskets of stocks before they lost $10,000 of their value. No matter that the stocks don't exist; Hunter has bet correctly on the direction of the market. By the rules of the Mercantile Exchange, his client can demand from the purchaser the $10,000 spread and the purchaser must pay this amount.
Plainly, the futures market does play a useful role for the big money managers whose trading so dominates the stock market today. For those critics who argue for its dissolution, the reply often comes back that high-volume institutional trading required it; without the futures market, institutions could never achieve the hefty returns that constant trading made possible in the 80's. ''You and I know, and the world knows, that when there is a strong enough need, the necessary instruments are created to meet that need,'' says Leo Melamed, chairman of the executive committee of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. ''Futures trading gives people the ability to enter and exit the market easily.''
Melamed has a point, but as the practice has evolved sometimes the entry and exit has been haphazard and panicky, having little to do with the hedging requirements of the institutions. That was the case last Oct. 13, when the late-afternoon announcement about United Airlines' lack of financing triggered a minicrash that vividly demonstrated the Chicago-New York interplay. Some 62,500 futures contracts were traded that day, way up from last year's daily average of 42,000, and the price plummeted from $179,000 a contract to $164,525. Arthur D. Cashin Jr., director of floor operations for Paine Webber Inc., describes what happened:
''United was one of the more spectacular takeover stocks, and the speculators who owned it began to sell and, oops, suddenly there are so many sell orders that trading in the stock is halted in New York. The same happens to American Airlines, also then a takeover target. ''So the guy trying to sell airlines can't, and he begins to sell whatever he owns to raise cash, to protect himself against losses in airlines. And other people holding takeover stocks get scared and sell, too. Maybe someone owns 35 different stocks, but he can't remember how many shares he has of each, and prices are falling. To save time, he turns to Chicago and starts to sell futures contracts. The price of the S.& P. 500 contract sinks, and everyone sees this on their computer screens and they get scared and they sell -in New York and Chicago.'' That is why futures trading plays a major role in triggering sell-offs, says Robert R. Glauber, an under secretary of the Treasury who directed the Brady Commission report on the 1987 crash. ''The futures market acts as a billboard,'' he says. ''Falling prices in Chicago get wired back into the stock market in New York.''
TO A VISITOR, THE impact of a decade of change on the stately New York Stock Exchange isn't immediately apparent. The crowds of brokers and clerks still move restlessly about, just as they seem to be doing in the dark photos of early days on the exchange. As if shopping, the brokers still stop at the booths of the specialists, each one a sort of auctioneer assigned by the exchange to orchestrate the trading of shares in three or four companies.
But then the old imagery breaks down. The exchange has installed a superfast computer system that instantly routes buy and sell orders from any brokerage office in the country to the trading floor in New York. The goal of the new system was to keep up with the rising trading volume, which has grown to an average of 165.5 million shares a day, from only 11.6 million in 1970. But one result was to make basket trading easy to carry out: institutions and brokerage houses that deal in baskets no longer have to telephone simultaneous sell orders for the 500 different S.& P. (Continued on Page 94) stocks, as they did in the early 1980's, the pioneer days of basket trading. And the floor brokers no longer have to walk these orders to the specialists' stalls and negotiate a trade.
Today, a computer network brings to the floor 80 percent of all buy and sell orders, of whatever nature. They pop up - bang bang bang -in yellow numbers on the black screens of the small computers on the counters at each specialist's booth. During a down day in the stock market, the yellow sell orders stack up alarmingly in a long column down the right side of the screens. Many represent basket sales. They appear far more quickly and in far greater volume than the buy orders forming another column on the left side. When this happens, prices fall rapidly in the hope that buyers will be attracted and more yellow numbers will pop up in the buy column. The speed of it all, and the cold technology, resonate with the people who man the booths.
''It affects you differently than trading face to face with a broker,'' says Jay A. Mahoney, a specialist whose firm manages the stocks of the Marriott Corporation and Con Edison of New York, among others. ''You wonder what is going on out there, and you get scared.''
WHAT IS GOING ON OUT there is futures trading, the principal forum being the huge main room at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. More than 450 traders, most of them men in their 30's and 40's, crowd the four tiers of this miniature Roman amphitheater and spill over onto the stage. Futures traders have their hierarchy. At the pinnacle stand Turk Hunter and about 100 others who represent the big money managers and the Wall Street brokerage houses and earn most of their income from commissions. Fittingly, they occupy the top tier, encircled by clerks in yellow smocks who pass them the orders to buy or sell futures contracts that flow in by phone from New York and elsewhere. Increasingly, these 100 brokers wager among themselves. Some 60 percent of the trading in futures contracts today never gets below the top tier, the reason being that only a Shearson or a Dreyfus, acting through a top-step broker, have the wherewithal to pay off a gambling loss that might come to $100,000 or more.
But that doesn't dampen the enthusiasm of the ''locals,'' the traders who occupy the lower tiers and wager their own money. When Hunter sells futures contracts, the locals take some of the bet. They are people like Ronald S. Sheldon, a 47-year-old former labor lawyer who gave up his practice in 1982 and purchased a place in the futures pit for $60,000.
With a week or two of training at the Mercantile Exchange - lessons include how to shout from the diaphragm - Sheldon donned a blue smock, took his place two tiers down from Hunter and began gambling for a living - trading futures.
So far, Sheldon's profits have been greater than his losses. He rarely gambles more than several hundred dollars at a time. Indeed, most of the locals are cautious traders, taking their cues from the brokers on the top tier, as they did on the morning of Lincoln's Birthday, when Turk Hunter began to sell 400 contracts for Shearson.
Turk's clients rarely tell him the reasons for their trades. Shearson might have been acting as a broker for an institution, or simply trading for its own account, seeking a quick profit for itself. ''Stock prices were down in London and the rumors of the Drexel bankruptcy were circulating,'' Turk explains. ''Shearson, or anyone else, might have felt that if it put selling pressure on the futures market at the opening, there would be a break in prices from which it could profit.''
The break came. Others in the pit, watching Hunter and knowing whom he represented, sold too. As they did, the S.& P. 500 futures contract fell slowly, from $167,050 near the opening to $166,475 an hour later, and the Dow declined more than 25 points in the same period. The profit for Shearson, at that point, was $230,000, and maybe Shearson did quickly collect its bets from the purchasers of its contracts. The mechanism for doing this is to buy the same number of contracts that had been sold.
Or maybe Shearson bought back some contracts and kept other bets open. Turk did not say. Most positions are closed out in minutes or hours, but the most commonly traded contracts can, under the exchange's trading rules, remain open for three months.
Whatever Shearson's goals, the traders in the pit taking Hunter's lead march to a different tune. On Feb. 12, for example, Sheldon followed Hunter's lead and also sold, creating two S.& P. futures contracts with his hand signals, and unloading them for about $167,000. But minutes later, with the price still declining, he ended his gamble by purchasing two contracts at $166,950. His profit on the trade: $100.
While Hunter and Sheldon were selling, others in the pit were buying, gambling that the S.& P. futures price would soon rise, which it did shortly before lunch. (Futures trading is also capable of driving stock prices up, of course. But such episodes are relatively undramatic. In the 1980's, the Dow never rose by as much as 190 points in a single day.) Whether selling or buying, few locals deal in more than five contracts at a time, or hold a trading position for more than a minute or two, closing it out if a loss gets to $400. ''Five minutes would be a lifetime,'' Sheldon says. ''A minute or 30 seconds is more the norm.'' The final hour of trading on Lincoln's Birthday produced another sell-off in Chicago. Brokers in the top tier started offering several hundred contracts for sale and the locals joined the selling frenzy. The futures contract fell in an hour from $166,750 to $165,750, and the Dow Jones average followed suit, plunging 12 points in the final hour and closing down 29 points for the day.
BACK IN NEW YORK on Lincoln's Birthday, Robert W. Seijas watched the S.& P. 500 futures price fall. Seijas, a partner at Lasker, Stone & Stern, a specialist firm, runs the stall where Cooper Industries, a machinery manufacturer, and the Sysco Corporation, a food distributor, are traded. That day, as always, he kept watch on the boxy computer screen dangling from a robotic arm that juts out from his booth. Every specialist stall at the exchange has these computer screens, and the clusters of stalls look like giant bugs with stubby, cut off legs.
Seijas programs his terminal to give him various bits of helpful data: selected stocks, bond prices, news headlines. But on his screen, and every other across the floor, two numbers are tracked religiously. One is the ever-changing price of the S.& P. futures contract in Chicago and the other is the parallel, very slightly lower value of the real 500 S.& P. stocks in New York. When the Chicago price falls faster than the one in New York, as it often does, and the two lines begin to converge, the crowds on the exchange floor brace for selling.
The same numbers are tracked, with the same tense reaction, in the trading rooms of Salomon Brothers, Merrill Lynch and other major brokerage firms. These are the rooms where the institutions arrange to trade huge blocs of stock, usually to one another or to the brokerage house itself, if a Dreyfus can't get a Prudential to trade right away.
But when the S.& P. futures price falls and the spread narrows, a trader about to purchase, say, 700,000 shares of Unisys, pulls back, figuring that if he waits a few minutes the price might go lower. And in another trading room, the sale of 100,000 shares of J.C. Penney, for example, is hastened before the stock's price is caught in the impending slide. Both trades - the postponed purchase and the rushed sale - accelerate a price decline.
On Lincoln's Birthday, as the spread narrowed between the futures price of the 500 S.& P. stocks and their current, minute-by-minute value, the sell orders mounted on the computer at Seijas's booth. There were 18 in all for Cooper and Sysco, many of them bunched in the late afternoon - nearly all placed by Morgan Stanley, either for itself or as broker for a big client.
Seijas wasn't sure, but most likely they were part of a much larger basket trade. Cooper and Sysco are both among the S.& P. 500 companies and each of Morgan's sell orders - invariably 400 shares of Cooper and 300 of Sysco - is roughly a multiple of the shares assigned to these companies in the S.& P. index.
Sometimes the price of the futures contracts falls so low that owning the imaginary shares in the S.& P. 500 companies suddenly becomes less costly than owning their real counterparts in New York. That was the case late in the day on Lincoln's Birthday. And when it happens institutions and brokerage houses sometimes sell the real shares, purchase the imaginary ones and pocket the difference. Morgan's trades undoubtedly included some of this index arbitrage. The upshot of this selling is often a downward twist in stock prices. Index arbitrage accounted for about 12 percent of the late-afternoon sell-off last Oct. 13.
NOT SURPRISINGLY , a movement is gaining steam to treat Chicago's futures trading as if it were part and parcel of a single national stock market, whose flagship is the New York Stock Exchange.
This would be achieved by expanding the domain of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates stock trading. Under a proposal before Congress, the S.E.C. would also be given authority over stock futures trading in Chicago, now the responsibility of a separate agency. Such a proposal emerged from the 1987 crash, but then was forgotten - until the minicrash last October.
Until late March, a White House task force, called the Working Group on Financial Markets, had been evenly split on the regulation issue. The Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, and the S.E.C. chairman, Richard C. Breeden, had favored giving overall authority to the S.E.C. The two other members, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Wendy L. Gramm, chairman of the Chicago Futures Trading Commission, which now regulates the futures markets, balked at making such a change. But then Greenspan seemed to switch sides, telling a Senate committee that he was ''very slightly'' in favor of switching some jurisdiction to the S.E.C. - a signal that the Administration was prepared to revamp stock-market regulation.
A more powerful S.E.C. would probably enact rules that halt trading in stocks and futures contracts, in some coordinated fashion, whenever prices plunge too rapidly. ''We should not do away with the futures market, but put through rules that make the stock and futures markets work with each other, instead of against each other,'' says Treasury under secretary Glauber.
Already, the S.E.C. is considering new proposals to slow down stock trading whenever the Dow Jones industrial average falls too far. It has been asked by the New York Stock Exchange, for example, to authorize additional limits on trading when the Dow declines 50 points within a day. Among other things, some huge sell orders would be prohibited. If the Dow kept falling, more restrictions would kick in at around 100 points, and at 250 points trading would stop altogether. Currently, the 250-point rule is in effect, adopted after the 1987 crash.
Whatever the reforms, it is very possible that the Federal Government will have made no changes at all before the stock market's next frightening sell-off. The Bush Administration might be ready to act, but Congress is not of one mind on the issue of expanding the S.E.C's authority.
When the next sell-off comes, Richard Breeden will be among those scrambling to restore confidence and get stock prices to bounce back quickly, as they have so far since the 1987 crash.
''If necessary, I'll go on television to correct inaccurate perceptions about the market,'' Breeden says. ''I don't want people, for the wrong perceptions, to lose confidence in the stock market as a safe place to save. That would be a terrible mistake.''

HEADLINE: WHEN LEGAL TITANS CLASH

BYLINE: By Ken Emerson: Ken Emerson is a former editor of this magazine.

 BODY:
YOU PEOPLE ARE NOT A RANDOM, TYPICAL sample of the U.S. population,'' deadpans the new dean of Harvard Law School to appreciative laughter. After all, the hundred-odd students gathered to hear Robert C. Clark's talk on ''Laws, Markets and Morals'' are investing nearly $75,000 in their Juris Doctor degrees. Although you'd never guess from their backpacks and corduroys, many of them will earn more than their money back the very first year they graduate to briefcases and gray flannel.
But appearances can be deceiving at America's most prestigious law school. Although almost everyone agrees that Harvard has left behind the factional acrimony that soured its reputation in the 1980's, the school has not quite returned to business as usual. Beneath a surface ''civility'' - an oft-heard word in Cambridge these days - roil currents of dispute that are potentially broader and deeper than the left-right infighting of the last decade.
The argument is over the nature of the law. It's a text, all agree, but how freely can it be interpreted? Is it elastic enough to impel social reform - or at least to twang spitballs at the establishment? Or is the law sufficiently fixed in its meaning to aspire to the condition of science? 
Even more important, the argument is over the role of the law school in the legal profession. Is it Harvard's function to feed the mammoth law firms and keep the wheels of commerce turning, or to resist market forces and provide alternative careers for attorneys? Is the American lawyer a man with a mission, a crusader on the ramparts of the public interest? Or is she (42 percent of Harvard Law students are now women) a highly paid janitor in the basement of society, as more than one Harvard professor has suggested?
Doubtless the same issues are being debated at many of the other 175 law schools in the United States. But the arguments at Harvard Law School assume undue importance because Harvard Law assumes an unduely important role in America. At the moment, for example, 10 of its graduates are serving in the Senate, three in the Cabinet, and four on the Supreme Court, and it has usually been thus. So it's only a slight exaggeration when Prof. Alan Dershowitz insists, with all the indignation he is mustering for the defense of Leona Helmsley, that the struggle at his law school is nothing less than a battle ''for the future of the profession and potentially for the future of the country.''
BACK IN THE LECTURE HALL, CLARK IS EXPOUNDING on the themes of a book he says was ''rudely interrupted'' by his appointment last spring as dean of Harvard's bitterly divided law school. It's an ambitious talk, ranging from Kant to cognitive psychology, from economics to animal behavior, laced with dry asides. Why can't corporate law, muses Clark, the author of a highly regarded textbook on the subject, be derived from a Summa Theologica or the Talmud? A candidate for the Catholic priesthood who lost his faith after reading too much philosophy, he answers his own question: because you can't get the Occupational Safety and Health Act out of a sacred text.
The lecture is sponsored by the law school's chapter of the Federalist Society, a national association of conservative lawyers and law students. You can pick the Feds out of the crowd because they're the only ones wearing suits other than Clark, their erstwhile faculty adviser.
Bob Clark's appointment by Harvard President Derek Bok, himself the dean of the law school from 1968 to 1971, provoked yawps of outrage from the left. ''The worst possible choice,'' one law professor told the press; ''a bad and divisive appointment,'' charged another; ''I was shocked,'' said a third. All three naysayers were aligned with a radical movement among legal scholars, known as Critical Legal Studies, that is stubbornly rooted at Harvard. One of the Crits' founders, Duncan Kennedy, once described them as a ''ragtag band of leftover 60's people and young people with nostalgia for the events of 15 years ago.''
Kennedy made his remark back in 1985, during a heated session sponsored by the Federalist Society at the Harvard Club in New York. Much of the heat was provided by a young Bob Clark (even now he's only 46), who likened the Crits to Huns rather than hippies and denounced the movement's ''generalized antipathy toward many major institutions and practices of the modern 'western' world.''
The year before, at another symposium sponsored by the Feds, Clark had delivered a paper entitled ''The Return of Langdell,'' in homage to Christopher Columbus Langdell. Dean of Harvard Law School after the Civil War, Langdell devised the doctrinal or case-study method of legal instruction that put the law on a quasi-scientific footing. Clark's talk, which deplored contemporary students' ignorance ''of how one goes about proving something,'' was as literary as it was scientific. It began with Yeats's ''The Second Coming'' (''The best lack all conviction, while the worst/Are full of passionate intensity'') and concluded with a free adaptation of the poem's conclusion: ''What new Langdell, his or her hour come round at last, /Slouches toward Cambridge or Chicago to be born?''
Bob Clark looks more like a teddy bear than the ''rough beast'' Yeats imagined. Wary of being misquoted, he places his own tape recorder alongside mine in his office the morning after his lecture. There's reason for caution: Harvard may no longer be ''the Beirut of legal education,'' as one Crit denied tenure charged, but it's still full of land mines. During our conversation, he repeatedly tugs on his beard, as if reining himself in. ''I don't want to say what I'm thinking,'' he says at one point, ''it'll come out too strong.''
We have been talking about his address last September to incoming students. ''Do not let anyone convince you that you are 'selling out' in whatever career you choose,'' he reassured them. Among those careers he emphatically included corporate law, which he defined grandiloquently as ''helping the wheels of commerce turn and helping business produce the goods and services needed by society.''
So he doesn't agree with Alan Dershowitz's line - ''It's as if all the medical doctors in America were performing elective cosmetic surgery while the emergency wards of our hospitals had no doctors'' - about corporate law?
''That's a bad analogy,'' says Clark, who began his deanship by eliminating the position of adviser to students considering careers in public-interest law. ''It might be a sign of ill health in the country if people needed lawyers more. An ordinary person, I guess, uses a lawyer for a will, a divorce, buying a house and so on, and even those things ought to be more routinized.''
Having minimized the need of ordinary people for lawyers, Clark then compares lawyers to, well, ordinary people: carpenters, electricans and plumbers. ''They aren't usually thought of as doing public-interest work,'' he says, ''but if in fact you look back at the total amount of good they do, and at the total benefit to human welfare, it's enormous.'' To draw ''an ideological dichotomy between altruistic, doing-good work'' and more mundane human labor, he insists, is ''a fundamental mistake.''
Corporate law, Clark continues, ''is intensely moral, you know.'' The challenge is ''to devise optimal controls on managerial discretion, the behavior of people who are responsible for large organizations. You have to give them adequate discretion to make all sorts of decisions - otherwise the system won't work - at the same time you have to have constraints on abuse of power. So it's a kind of generic problem which is, to my mind, a real-world, most significant ethical problem.''
Given his omnivorous interests in (Continued on Page 53) religion, philosophy, sociology, and economics, it's not surprising that one of Clark's intellectual model's is the German sociologist Max Weber, or that he already envisions an end to his deanship. How else could he finish his book? ''Ten years is what was contemplated by Bok,'' he says of his appointment. ''If I get fed up with it, I might stop after five. So far, I like it a lot.''
He must be doing something right. Alumni contributions are way up after a ''sharp dip'' at the height of the Crit controversy, and Clark is launching a new fund-raising campaign with the astonishing goal of $150 million.
''I wonder,'' he says facetiously as I prepare to leave, ''what we're going to do when Leona Helmsley, in gratitude, offers us something.''
'' MISS ----, WHY ARE YOU in the back row?'' ''I brought a friend to class.'' ''As long as it isn't the other explanation,'' booms Phillip E. Areeda, referring to the unthinkable: that a student would come to his first-year course on contracts unprepared.
If Bob Clark is awaiting the return of Langdell, Areeda teaches as if he had never left, using the wham-bam Socratic method still popularly associated with Harvard Law School. Yet as he roams the classroom's raked semicircle, Areeda seems as up-to-date as that other Phil: Donahue. Recognizing raised hands and singling out victims with a ballpoint he waves like a baton, he reels off one ''hypothetical'' after another. He sells his house, knowing full well that termites are gnawing away at its foundations. Is there a duty to disclose? He's a composer, contracted to write an opera, ''The Rose of Abalone,'' for the opening of the new Bastille opera house. He expires with his masterpiece uncompleted. Is his estate liable?
Every ''hypo'' spawns a swarm of variations; each question begets another. ''I'm not sure whether I'm basing this on the canons of human decency,'' a student confesses. Pressed, he folds: ''Sounds dumb, doesn't it?''
''I'm a relic,'' laughs Areeda, a blunt, bullet-shaped man of 60, as we enter his office, where everything (Continued on Page 63) but the fax machine is burnished with a brown patina of cigar smoke and time. His life's work is bound in leather and gilt: eight volumes, plus annual supplements, of a treatise on antitrust law. ''I hope to be done by volume 12,'' he says.
Areeda's sentences are as elaborate and self-assured as his hypos. He expresses optimism about the future of the law school, and relief that the faculty now realizes ''uncivil discourse doesn't further any cause.'' Yet when asked what common convictions unite the law school, what if anything it stands for, he grinds to an uncustomary halt and, after a long pause, lurches. ''That's a hard question to answer. . . . Twenty years ago I would have said that . . . we all thought we had a common mission. And the common mission was to - and now to use a terrible cliche, but it also has meaning . . . would have had meaning 20 years ago . . . our common mission was to teach law in the grand manner.''
It's not just those subversive Crits who have chipped away at the grand manner, the Harvard tradition of Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., Louis Brandeis and Felix Frankfurter. Nor is it simply the competitive pressure to make big bucks. What tongue-ties Areeda may be in part Dean Clark's rationalizations, and his own.
''My image of the ideal lawyer,'' Areeda says, ''is the exalted image of the lawyer as ethicist, as the person of high moral values, the lawyer as someone with a kind of religious insight into the character of society. I find that image both appealing and entirely consistent with greasing the wheels of commerce. Because, of course, the very point of the exalted image is that the wheels of commerce ought to be greased in the right way, in the way that keeps dealings consistent with the highest principles of fidelity, and with law and duty. So when one uses the image of greasing the wheels of commerce, there are better and worse greases. . . .''
When the grand manner is reduced to a finer grade of grease, Harvard Law School is in trouble.
IF PHIL AREEDA SAID 'DO that,' you'd do it,'' jokes Derrick Bell as he brings to order his class on constitutional law. ''There are some losses in entering the new age.''
Harvard Law School's first black tenured professor (now there are two more) does not yearn for the ways things used to be - not that he's particularly enamored of the way they are now. Derrick A. Bell Jr., 59, spent much of the 60's as an ''outside agitator,'' desegregating Southern schools as a staff attorney for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. At Harvard, where he's taught since 1969, taking time out to serve as dean of the University of Oregon Law School, he's been an inside agitator. ''Derek Bok hired me,'' he says, ''and we have disappointed each other ever since. I have not been grateful, which is about the most serious thing a black person can do to a white person.''
Bell has lobbied indefatigably for more minority students and faculty, not only at the law school but university-wide. In 1988, for example, he issued a report in the form of an ''allegory'' suggesting that Harvard's record on affirmative action might improve if a bomb blast killed all of its 198 black professors and administrators and Derek Bok! The year before, during commencement, he staged a four-day sit-in in his office to protest the denial of tenure to two professors (both white) in the Crits' camp. Bob Clark, not yet dean, was reported to have said (he disputes the exact wording), ''This is a university, not a lunch counter in the Deep South.'' Today, Bell says that Clark, ''given his druthers, would like to go back to the law school of 1960.''
Professor Bell tries to instill the same defiance in his students. Earlier this month, he actively encouraged students who occupied Dean Clark's office, demanding, among other things, that a black woman be granted a tenured professorship by September. ''You are now lawyers,'' he says to graduates, ''and you don't have to be kissing people's behinds.'' Today Bell is concerned that his constitutional law class hasn't been defiant enough. He's divided it into teams to try a hypothetical case in which the Lettuce Growers Association of State A is suing State C for banning the importation and transportation across its borders of lettuce harvested with the notoriously backbreaking short-handled hoe. To his dismay, the students playing the role of Federal District Court judges have sided, 6 to 1, with the lettuce growers, insisting that whatever the suffering of migrant farmworkers, no state can be allowed to interfere with interstate commerce.
Bell seems to regard the law with a mixture of impatience and resignation. His most recent book, ''And We Are Not Saved: The Elusive Quest for Racial Justice,'' asks whether civil-rights litigation is ''a freedom train that has run out of steam.'' As if to underline his disillusionment with the law, he does not frame his arguments in academic legalese but instead employs fables, often with a sci-fi tinge, that he calls ''chronicles.''
Bell is quick to cite violence and ''direct action'' as more effective means than the law of provoking social change. One such direct action, his sit-in on the Crits' behalf, was a solo performance. ''What they didn't realize was that reform requires confrontation, he says. ''It can't be intellectualized. At some point somebody's (Continued on Page 66) got to stand up in the fire and say, 'Goddamnit, no!' . . . . The lack of hard experience manifests itself in their writing and their theories. It's all theory. . . . But give Crits good credit for opening up legal scholarship.''
I CAN ONLY GIVE YOU AN hour, so don't leave your missiles in your silos.'' It is time to visit the Crits' corner, where Duncan Kennedy admits to feeling ''gun-shy and paranoid.'' He is also pressed for time, because he is bound for Poland, along with 10 other members of the Critical Legal Studies movement, to discuss rights at the University of Warsaw. Why the Crits? asks a colleague. ''I guess they probably took an objective look at the most valid work that's been done in the area and decided that, without regard to friendship, political ideology or anything else, they ought to allocate the boondoggle to the people with the most merit.''
That's the way Duncan Kennedy talks: volubly, sarcastically, mischievously peppering his speech with ironic quotation marks.
This is how Duncan Kennedy dresses: dirty bucks, black jeans, tieless shirt, an old corduroy jacket. Overlook the lines in his face and the gray in his beard, and Duncan Kennedy, 48, is the spitting image of a grad student circa 1968.
Critical Legal Studies reared its head in the late 1970's when Kennedy and two other Harvard Law professors, Morton Horwitz and Roberto Unger, plus a few kindred spirits elsewhere, notably at the University of Wisconsin Law School, rebelled against what Kennedy would later decry as ''the substantive inanity of what we teach.'' The law, they argued, far from being written in stone, is characterized by a high degree of elasticity; it is not an autonomous field of objective expertise. ''There is never a 'correct legal solution' that is other than the correct ethical and political solution to that legal problem,'' wrote Kennedy. And the politically, ethically, legally correct solution was radical social transformation.
In 1983, Kennedy published a pamphlet, bound in red, called ''Legal Education and the Reproduction of Hierarchy: A Polemic Against the System.'' Its preface urged readers to ''Resist!'' (Practicing what he preaches, Kennedy refused to pose for a photograph to accompany this article ''as a gesture of resistance.'') Warning that ''wherever you are situated, the system of hierarchy maims you,'' Kennedy wrote, ''it is not only possible but also meaningful to resist anywhere and at any time - at upper-middle-class dinner parties and at the bank, as well as in law-school classrooms, faculty meetings, on the assembly line and in welfare offices.''
In order to transform the law school into a ''counterhegemonic enclave,'' Kennedy recommended such measures as admitting by lottery students who had passed a basic skills test, and either giving tenure to every professor or abolishing it altogether. After all, ''the ideology of the legal hierarchy is no more than a specialized application of the general meritocratic ideology of American society.'' Harvard, of course, takes considerable pride in its ''meritocratic ideology,'' and Harvard took offense.
Students waving copies of Kennedy's little red book didn't provoke a Cultural Revolution, but Critical Legal Studies did raise important questions about the political nature of the law. It gradually generated enough sympathy and antipathy among the faculty to polarize the school and make tenure decisions increasingly rancorous. James Vorenberg, the liberal dean of the law school from 1981 to 1989, was caught in the middle. Eventually Derek Bok intervened, first by reversing the law school's decisions to grant tenure to two professors in the Critical Legal Studies camp, and then by appointing the outspokenly conservative Clark when Vorenburg stepped down as dean and returned to teaching.
There's a hall-of-mirrors aspect to the argument between the Crits and the conservatives, with both sides enlisting similar imagery for opposite purposes. Is it fine and dandy to help the wheels of commerce turn, as Dean Clark holds, or to grease them as Professor Areeda maintains? ''Most of what corporate lawyers do is just 'greasing the wheels of the system,' '' Kennedy has written.
The lawyer as janitor metaphor seems to intrigue both left and right. Kennedy has written that he does not believe ''we'd lose anything at all in terms of social product if lawyers, law professors, secretaries, paralegals and law-firm janitors were all paid exactly the same amount.'' Subsequently, his colleague and ideological opponent, Charles Fried, who served as Solicitor General under President Reagan (and is now faculty adviser to the Federalist Society), proposed that we regard lawyers ''not as the architects of society but as its janitors.'' The legal profession made a big mistake, he wrote, when it ''tried to get out of the basement.''
''Do you think our rhetoric has influenced them?'' Kennedy asks. ''There's a kind of complicated reversal. . . . This is the megalomaniac, grandiose fantasy, that it will be snuck into their, infiltrating their, very rhetoric.''
Kennedy's own rhetoric remains unapologetically countercultural. ''The slogan should not be '68, the failed revolutionary moment,' '' he wrote in the journal Rethinking Marxism a couple of years ago, ''but 'the 60's,' a diffuse cultural rebellion with a thousand specific implications for daily life in the '90s.' ''
TODAY'S LAW STUDENTS ARE different, Charles Fried is saying. They know that they're going to have to make a living in a world that ''is sick and tired of the 60's.'' So is the former Solicitor General.
The Carter Professor of General Jurisprudence is a tall, gangly man with permanently arched eyebrows. His English accent sometimes arches, too, into a near falsetto. On his desk is a flag bearing the ''Smile'' insignia of Czechoslovakia's Civic Forum movement. Fried, 55, who fled Prague with his family in 1939, says he was moved to tears by Vaclav Havel's Congressional address. I wonder if he has read the papers that morning. Havel, who visited Columbia University in 1968, said that the spirit of the 60's had helped inspire his ''velvet'' revolution.
Fried's revolution was Ronald Reagan's. Co-chairman of Law Professors for Reagan-Bush in 1984, he declared that since lawyers were ''the handmaidens of regulation,'' he looked forward to ''a reform that will simply reduce the number of lawyers and the number of law students.'' Reducing the number of law professors by one, Fried eventually became Solicitor General, in which capacity he argued vigorously against affirmative action and a constitutional right to abortion.
He also gave a high literary gloss to the Administration's emphasis on a strict interpretation of the Constitution. In ''Sonnet LXV and the 'Black Ink' of the Framers' Intention,'' an essay originally delivered at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington in 1986, Fried argued eloquently that words, be they Shakespeare's or the Constitution's, can communicate over time and thus achieve a kind of permanence. ''At the very core of the rule of law is the conviction - perhaps it is only a hope - that legal texts have meaning.''
Professor Fried's positions as Solicitor General were consistent with those he staked out in his 1978 book ''Right and Wrong.'' Preoccupied with the ''limits to our responsibility for the world's good and ill,'' the book is intended as a corrective to bleeding-heart liberalism. But it often sounds like a smug defense of do-nothing indifference: ''Indeed, a good lawyer is a good man, and the fact that he chooses his clients among those who can pay the most or whose cases involve travel and excitement does not vitiate that conclusion.''
The Solicitor General's stance bothered Laurence Tribe. Fried's colleague and frequent adversary at the law school used Fried's arguments, and rulings by the Supreme Court, to illustrate the differences between what he calls Newtonian and post-Newtonian legal thought in a recent, dizzying essay, ''The Curvature of Constitutional Space: What Lawyers Can Learn From Modern Physics.'' Tribe criticized the Court's ''stilted premodern paradigm,'' in which ''there is no hint that the hand of the observing state may itself have played a major role in shaping the world it observes.'' How much more dynamic, Tribe contended, to consider the state and the law as Einstein's general theory of relativity views space - as curved and warped by the mass and energy within it, so that space is not a neutral stage but an actor in the play of the universe.
Tribe's approach, Fried says, ''makes me a little nervous. I think it's a little too malleable.'' He cites last year's debate in Congress, after the Supreme Court struck down a Texas flag-burning statute, about legislation to prohibit desecration of Old Glory. Democrats eager to demonstrate their patriotism after Michael Dukakis's Pledge of Allegiance debacle were calling for such a bill, and Tribe obliged by testifying that a constitutionally acceptable one could be drafted. Fried, on the other hand, defended the Court's unpopular decision and the exercise of free speech, winning ''three cheers'' from Tom Wicker, the liberal columnist for The New York Times -''the first time Tom Wicker ever said a good thing about me,'' Fried laughs.
If Tribe is Fried's opposite, is Duncan Kennedy his doppelganger? Each stakes out extreme positions and defends them with a rhetorical relish that is deliberately provocative. I raise the question tentatively and Fried chortles, displaying a framed photograph taken when both of them had longer hair and taught a course together.
''I'm with Duncan, if you like,'' he says. ''I think janitors are terribly important.''
OF LAWE THERE CAN BE NO lesse acknowledged than that her seate is the bosome of God,'' declares the only inscription ringing the rafters of the main reading room of Langdell Library that is not in Latin. But many of the professors at Harvard Law School no longer seem to share that conviction. Where is the grand manner of Holmes, Brandeis, Frankfurter, that faith of yesteryear in the lofty mission of the law?
An unlikely place to seek it would seem to be beyond a door festooned with a singed Israeli flag and xeroxed hate mail bearing sign-offs like ''Die, Jew - Adolf Hitler.'' In his office, Alan M. Dershowitz is holding forth.
''Did he say that? That's shocking!'' he exclaims when I relate Dean Clark's skeptical comments about the ordinary person's need for lawyers. ''Anyone who thinks that the crack users don't need a lawyer to get themselves into programs. . . . My God! I get calls like this every day. I got a call just before you came in from a woman in a law firm who was a paralegal who was fired, she said, because she was told to destroy documents in a pending lawsuit. How can I not help a woman like that out?''
While, as Dean Clark proudly notes, there are more media stars at Harvard than at any other law school, no one seems to revel more unabashedly in his celebrity than Alan Dershowitz. Clients like Claus von Bulow and Leona Helmsley, that monthly column in Penthouse - it's undignified, embarrassing, and some professors politely but pointedly distance themselves from Dershowitz. Tribe, for example, says, ''There are a lot of cases he has taken that I have refused.''
The problem is that Dershowitz's choice of cases sometimes seems dictated more by passion than by principle, by personal identification rather than by legal significance. His first scholarly book, which he co-authored in 1967, was ''Psychoanalysis, Psychiatry, and the Law.'' It doesn't take a shrink to figure out why he defended, for example, a Jewish Defense League terrorist from his boyhood neighborhood of Borough Park, Brooklyn. But Leona Helmsley?
''I definitely have an identification with her,'' he says. ''This is a gutsy, somewhat crass woman from Brooklyn who made it to the top, clawing at every point and a lot of people clawing at her, too. . . . I would not conduct my life that way, because money's not important to me, but. . . .''
It should not be forgotten, however, that Dershowitz devotes much of the 20 percent of his time that Harvard Law professors are allowed to spend on outside work to pro bono cases. And Dershowitz, the outsider from Borough Park who will never seem at home on Brattle Street, at least has a vision of the law that is more exalted than wheel greasing.
There are at least 15 law schools at Harvard, Dershowitz says, and in many respects he runs his own. ''The tragedy is that the students come here wanting to go to my law school,'' he says. ''They come because they want to do public-interest work. They come because they want to work on the environment. They come because they want to help poor people. And they left here, before Bob Clark's speech, guilt-ridden, knowing that they were going to have to go to work for the big law firms. After Clark's speech, they leave here without any guilt. I want them at least to have some guilt, so maybe they can change those big law firms and help increase the ammount of public-interest law that's being done.''
WHEREAS DERSHOWITZ'S DIATRIBES are ME, ME, ME!, Laurence H. Tribe speaks with detached intensity, considering even himself as an object to be rotated in space. It's as if he had never abandoned for the law his undergraduate specialization in algebraic topology.
''I occasionally will read some newspaper account saying, 'Tribe craves publicity,' '' Tribe says. ''And I will ask myself, in my quiet moments, 'Is that true of Tribe? Does Tribe crave publicity, or does he just not mind it?' And the honest answer is, I probably used to crave it. But I've become a bit more mature now, and I just don't care as much one way or the other.''
''For me, it's instinctive,'' Tribe says when I remark that by the time his class in constitutional law had ended, the blackboard was covered with axes and helixes. ''I see things geometrically, in terms of patterns and structural relationships. When I taught evidence, I taught about triangulating hearsay. I get much more insight per cubic inch if I don't insist on moving in a linear direction.''
Tribe's cases have made as many headlines as Dershowitz's, though perhaps not in the tabloids. The Rev. Sung Myung Moon was a client. He defended Pennzoil against Texaco in the battle for Getty Oil. He's consulting on constitutional issues in the defense of the junk-bond maestro Michael Milken and believes the R.I.C.O. statute under which Milken was indicted is unconstitutional - ''a blank check for the prosecution.''
Last month, the Supreme Court decided in his favor a case in which he represented, like students in Derrick Bell's class, migrant farm workers. So far, he's won 11 of the 16 cases he's argued before the Court.
Like Dershowitz, Tribe is a centrist where Harvard Law School is concerned. That's one of the reasons he headed the faculty's advisory search committee for the new dean. The faculty elected two members on the right, two on the left and, in the middle, David Shapiro and Tribe. At the outset, Tribe and Shapiro declared themselves out of the running for the deanship. Some of the others, including Bob Clark, a representative of the right, did not. ''It was awkward,'' acknowledges Tribe, who said, when President Bok's final decision was announced, that ''there were other candidates of whom I had a more favorable impression.''
Today, Tribe is a diplomatic supporter of Clark. As a longtime defender of affirmative action, however, he regrets that ''there's likely to be a more conscious effort to pay less attention to the cultural, racial and ethnic diversity of the people we add to the faculty.'' He also foresees potential polarization in ''choices of emphasis on public or private law,'' conceding that ''there was at least initially some prospect of that when Dean Clark decided to eliminate the public-interest office.''
As a matter of fact, almost two-thirds of the students signed a petition of protest. Although Clark subsequently added more money to the fund forgiving the student loans of graduates who take public-interest jobs, and announced a $1 million gift by Judge Irving R. Kaufman to endow public interest fellowships, many faculty as well as students remain suspicious.
Tribe had concluded his class with a series of questions. If the area of activity or expression protected by a legal right is a penumbra, what casts the light? What difference does it make to think in terms of the ''foundation'' or the ''roots'' or the ''well-springs'' of a right?
What effect, I asked, does the imagery of wheel-greasing and broom-pushing have on the law?
''This is where some people in the middle . . .disagree dramatically with both the right and the left,'' says Tribe. ''I do have a much higher aspiration for the legal profession.
''The graduates this school has thought most highly of - Brandeis, Frankfurter - were not just wheel-greasers. . . . They were willing to engage in substantive discussion about the good society. I don't believe it's defensible for the place to become simply a technocratic training ground for the janitors of the legal order.''
AFTER A LONG DAY READING law-journal articles in the stacks of Langdell Library, I emerged blurry-eyed one evening into a dank mist. Holmes Field, named after the Justice, was alive with bounding shapes that were hard to make out in the filmy dark. It took a moment before I realized they were dogs - German shepherds, collies, beagles, mutts - running about without leashes or discernible masters.
It was Dean Clark who quoted Yeats: ''Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world.'' And it is his task to reimpose order on an unruly law school. But if the Critical Legal Studies movement deconstructed the law, the conservatives who now hold sway are not articulating an especially inspiring vision of how to restore it.
Some arguments are healthy. If everyone agreed on how strictly or freely the law should be interpreted, there would be no need for law schools or even courts. We could adjudicate by computer. But the differences over the role of the law school and its relation to the world are more virulent.
One wonders if Dean Clark's reaction - his corporate boosterism, his emphasis on ivory-tower excellence, his less than impassioned commitment to the public interest, broadly defined - may not create divisions within the law school that are deeper than the Critical Legal Studies rift. The danger is that the fault line at Harvard Law School may shift rightward, isolating its administration and leaving those professors in the middle on the same side of the chasm as the Crits.
It was de Tocqueville who wrote that, in America, ''the spirit of the law, which is produced in the schools and courts of justice, gradually penetrates beyond their walls to the bosom of society.'' Be it the bosom of God or of society, the law has traditionally enjoyed an exalted position. It remains to be seen how Harvard will retrieve it from the basement.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 24, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Times Magazine on Sunday about Harvard Law School referred incorrectly to a $1 million gift received for public-service fellowships at the school. It was given by Walter H. Annenberg in honor of Judge Irving R. Kaufman; the judge was not the donor.
