LENGTH: 1236 words

BYLINE: By R. STEPHEN WARNER; R. Stephen Warner, a professor of sociology at the University of Illinois, Chicago, is the author of ''New Wine in Old Wineskins: Evangelicals and Liberals in a Small-Town Church.''

 BODY:

THE CATHOLIC MYTH
The Behavior and Beliefs of American Catholics.
By Andrew M. Greeley.
322 pp. New York:
Charles Scribner's Sons. $21.95.
Armed with social survey data and state-of-the-art software, Andrew M. Greeley, sociologist, priest, novelist and self-styled maverick, battles two myths about Roman Catholics, cherished by two different constituencies. One - a secular stereotype he has met in Democratic Presidential campaigns - holds that American Catholics are blue-collar reactionaries whom it is hopeless to court for liberal political coalitions. The other, perversely comforting to the episcopate, says that those Catholics who are educated and middle-class have wised up and left the church. 
In fact, claims Father Greeley, American Catholics are better educated and more affluent than Protestants and more liberal on virtually every political issue. They still vote for Democratic members of Congress, and they cling to their Catholic birthright. But the moralism of the George McGoverns and the Walter Mondales sets their teeth on edge, and the church's neglect of their spiritual needs makes them angry. So the Democrats lose elections, and the church, according to his calculations, loses $7 billion per year in offerings.
The findings on Catholic educational and occupational achievement are well known to sociologists (attributable largely to Father Greeley's earlier efforts), as are those on political attitudes: Catholics tend to be liberal on economic policy and more conservative on family matters, and have become practically indistinguishable from white Protestants on attitudes toward abortion. Although Father Greeley does not make enough of the diversity among Protestants and the decline of their old elite as factors in this story, Catholics caught up long ago.
Father Greeley's theory of Catholic loyalty is indebted to Will Herberg, the journalist and theologian of the 1950's. In spite of the policies of their bishops (the utterly ineffectual ban on birth control and the neglect of parish life in favor of pronouncements on foreign policy), 85 percent of those raised Catholic remain Catholic, because in a society where religion serves to mark social identity, it makes good sense for them to do so. They are proud to be called Catholic.
Newer is the theory of the Catholic imagination, the myth of the Catholic people themselves. Inspired by the theologian David Tracy (to whom the book is dedicated), Father Greeley distinguishes the ''sacramental'' imagination, which sees the world filled with God, from the ''dialectical'' imagination, for which the world, including society, is Godforsaken. Using his intuitive grasp of these concepts as well as questionnaire items on images of God, Father Greeley successfully predicts an astonishing range of Catholic (sacramental) versus Protestant (dialectical) behavior and belief. Some results accord with stereotype: Protestants are more likely to read the Bible than Catholics are; Catholics are more likely to visit their relatives than Protestants are. But others are confounding: Catholics are more feminist than Protestants and more accepting of science. Father Greeley challenges skeptics to reanalyze the data (which are available in the National Opinion Research Center's general social surveys) or gather their own.
The sacramental imagination explains the independence of lay Catholics from the follies of their leaders. Narrative and poetry form the infrastructure of religious life, persevering through ''a millennium and a half of confrontation'' with dogma and structure. Father Greeley's view is that even if the Pope does not understand the importance of sexual love in marriage, lay people embrace God in the beloved. Father Greeley intricately reasons from survey items on respondents' upbringing, images of God, experience with clergy and marital satisfaction to argue that married Catholic women are happier when they can talk with celibate priest confidants.
Lest the structure of this argument seem too abstract, Father Greeley fleshes it out with a seven-page scene from one of his novels -always more didactic than ribald - wherein an attractive parishioner learns from her own effect on a masculine Irish priest how her husband must both fear and love her. Women should have the right of ordination, Father Greeley insists, so that male parishioners might enjoy the same privilege in the rectory. Their wives would benefit, for men who think of God as female make better partners.
By the time readers get this far, they will know why the author told them at the outset that his story was ''fascinating, wonderful, and slightly daffy,'' and it must be said that he expects the sacramental-imagination construct to do more work than the sociologist, wanting to inspect the tables, or the general reader, looking for imagery from other Catholic novelists, can easily accept. ''Sacramental imagination'' becomes a deus ex machina.
There are also loose ends and lacunas. Father Greeley shows that a quarter of Hispanic Americans are Protestants, but he can only guess why. He tells us nothing about charismatics or gay Catholics, and offers only a footnote about the disastrous decline in the number of women who are entering religious orders. But what is in ''The Catholic Myth'' is worthwhile.
And it would be a mistake to relegate Father Greeley to the margins he seems almost too eager to occupy. Other theologians, Protestant as well as Catholic, are turning from doctrine to narrative. Other sociologists, working with survey data, are reaching broadly congruent conclusions about Catholics and Protestants, and evidence is accumulating that Americans' images of the deity are becoming more androgynous and nurturing. Ethnographers and historians are showing that Americans routinely run their churches in ways that defy denominational structures. American religion is not a relic of the past but a response to the present. Andrew Greeley is a well-trained, abundantly energetic and imaginatively gifted sociologist of religion, but he is not alone.
 
 
 
WHO'S MORE HOSTILE TO SCIENCE?
 One's ''picture'' of God is in fact a metaphorical narrative of God's relationship with the world and the self as part of the world. . . .
 [The theologian David] Tracy argues that two approaches to human society of the respective traditions are shaped by these imaginative pictures. The Catholic tends to see society as a ''sacrament'' of God, a set of ordered relationships, governed by both justice and love, that reveal, however imperfectly, the presence of God. . . . The Protestant . . . tends to see human society as ''God-forsaken'' and therefore unnatural and oppressive. The individual stands over against society and not integrated into it. . . . Catholics are more likely than Protestants to see God as an intimate other - lover, friend, spouse, and mother - and the world and human nature as basically good. . . . Catholics are more likely to emphasize the presence of God. Protestants are more likely to emphasize reading the Bible and being born again. Catholics are less likely to be morally rigid and are also less likely than Protestants to rely on the Bible and on authority for moral decisions. Protestants are less likely to have doubts or to be angry at God. . . . Catholics are less hostile to science than Protestants.
 
From ''The Catholic Myth.''

HEADLINE: A JOURNEY AROUND THE RIM

BYLINE: By BARBARA SLAVIN; Barbara Slavin is a former Beijing correspondent for The Economist.

 BODY:

PACIFIC DESTINY
Inside Asia Today.
By Robert Elegant.
533 pp. New York:
Crown Publishers.
$24.95.
Fans of Robert Elegant's Asia potboilers will find his latest book slow going. A regional survey patterned after the old John Gunther series (''Inside Europe,'' ''Inside Africa'' and others), ''Pacific Destiny'' contains nary a swelling breast nor a steamy seduction. Neither is it loaded with facts and figures despite Mr. Elegant's declared audience - ''the men and women who must strive to restore the competitiveness of the West.'' 
Mr. Elegant, a former foreign correspondent and the author of a dozen Asia books evenly divided between pseudohistorical best sellers such as ''Dynasty'' and less commercial nonfiction, writes that his intention is to help Western businessmen and planners by explaining the human qualities behind the extraordinary development of most Asian nations since World War II. The longest sections of his book are devoted to Japan and China. Taiwan, South Korea, the Philippines and Indochina (Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia, with little Laos omitted) get briefer treatment, while Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Australia and Hong Kong are allotted one chapter each.
Such surveys are bound to be superficial, and ''Pacific Destiny'' is no exception. It may be useful as an introduction for first-time travelers to Asia. But original insights are few and most of the book reads like an assignment, not a labor of love.
It is best where Mr. Elegant dips into his notebooks of 40 years ago, when he was first posted to Asia as a young correspondent, and reminds us how far most Asian nations have had to come to reach the gleaming reality of today. Of Taiwan in 1951, he writes:
''Taipei, the capital, was dusty, grimy, and stench-ridden, and its atmosphere medieval. Military police prodded deserters, wearing manacles and leg-irons, across the broken cobblestones. . . . The ponderous red-brick edifices built by the Japanese . . . loomed over ramshackle hovels. . . . The open-fronted shops offered few goods beyond bamboo pails, iron dishpans, and coarse blue coolie clothing. . . . The first skyscraper . . . occupied by the American economic aid mission . . . was five stories high.''
Today, Mr. Elegant notes, Taipei boasts the biggest trade center in Asia if not the world. Taiwan's per capita gross national product has increased more than one hundredfold since the war and its foreign exchange reserves are an incredible $75 billion, second only to Japan.
There are other interesting contrasts, such as a description of Nikita Khrushchev's visit to Indonesia in 1960 and the clash of dictatorial styles between the Russian leader, sweaty and clumsy in the unaccustomed tropical and political climate, and Indonesia's sinuous Sukarno.
There are some good lines: ''When they are not overachieving, many Singaporeans are bored stiff.'' ''The overwhelming pride that has made for China's survival as a nation is today the single greatest obstacle to China's modernization.'' The Japanese are a tense people who are ''not much liked by outsiders because they do not much like themselves.''
But Mr. Elegant's analysis of Japanese economic single-mindedness - based partly, he explains, on fear of a return to postwar poverty - is familiar. So is his discussion of the pluses and minuses of Asia's Confucian traditions: a willingness to submit to authority, work hard and sacrifice for future generations, marred by bureaucracy, nepotism and corruption.
While he asks the right questions, he comes up with few new answers. To resolve United States trade frictions with Japan, for example, he suggests: ''We must both do what comes unnaturally: for us, contraction in our living standard; for them, expansion of their domestic economy and really joining the outside world.'' He repeats the standard advice that American industry, academia, government and finance must work better together and that executives must look beyond short-term gain. And he seems to make an argument for greater protectionism, noting favorably that ''West European nations do not bow down to free trade as to a holy icon.''
Through no fault of the author, the book suffers from being somewhat outdated, given the momentous events that have occurred in Europe and elsewhere over the past few months. Mr. Elegant has inserted a discussion of last June's Tiananmen massacre into his China section, but it was not possible for him to analyze how snowballing democracy movements and ethnic nationalism in East Europe might affect Asia. For example, who could have predicted last year that the two Germanies would be on the verge of reuniting - and speculated about what implications that development might have for ending World War II's other division, of the Korean peninsula?
''Pacific Destiny'' concludes tamely that ''only change is inevitable, not its direction.'' It is hard to imagine that this will come as news to a single one of Mr. Elegant's readers.

HEADLINE: Baseball Fans Must Fight Back

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor: rrThe major league owners and the players' union have earned, indeed invited, both Federal regulation and a public boycott for their contemptuous behavior during the 32-day lockout (''Baseball Negotiators Cleaning Up Loose Ends,'' The Times, March 20). Congress should mandate Federal regulation (overriding the Supreme Court's longstanding antitrust exemption) of professional baseball in view of the abuse of monopoly power and the callous disregard for basic Economics 101 principles of supply and demand in depriving the public of a historic and valued national product and depriving the local economies of spring training sites of essential revenues. 
Public disapproval is easily registered and, in theory, should be easier to achieve than Congressional action. Fans can select one or more of the following options to register their outrage:
* Reduction in games attended.
* Reduction of games viewed or listened to on the broadcast media.
* Reduction in the purchase of baseball-sponsored equipment and other paraphernalia.
* Boycott of companies advertising products during games.
 The likelihood that a partial or complete boycott would attract sufficient fan participation to have a material effect on the future conduct of the owners or the players union seems to be marginal, at best.
Until the owners and the players realize, however, that the demand for their product is truly elastic, or that their game will be regulated, it seems even more unlikely that we will experience an end to outrageous ticket prices, skyrocketing salaries, huge profits and unnecessary and tragic lockouts, walkouts and the like. In the interim, America's youth - including my otherwise avid baseball-playing sons -will continue to become more and more disenchanted with the ''business of baseball,'' thereby jeopardizing the future of the professional game.
 
TIM PLATT
Concord, N.H.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2204 words

HEADLINE: Builders Feel Pinch of New S & L Act

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
FOR more than 20 years, the Cardinal Federal Savings and Loan bank in Owensboro, Ky., financed the land acquisition and construction costs of Tommy Thompson's house-building business, and Mr. Thompson hardly expected that relationship to change when he recently took an option on another piece of developable land.
But despite Mr. Thompson's two decades of credit worthiness, Cardinal turned him down, citing new Federal rules governing the country's problem-plagued thrift industry. The rules, enacted last August as the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act - ''Firrea,'' as it has come to be known - are intended to avoid another savings and loan crisis by curtailing the share of its assets that a savings association may lend to a single borrower.
Under the regulations, real estate development loans, the source of most of the problems that troubled thrifts have gotten into around the country, have been assigned the highest risk factor, compared to other loans like home mortgages and Treasury notes. That means these lenders must now have more capital in reserve for such real estate acquisition, development and construction loans - ADC loans, for short - than the safer forms of debt. 
Many developers believe that, as a result, many of the thrifts will simply refuse to make the loans for them to acquire land and build housing.
''It seems to me that unless you have a long-term relationship with a bank, they're really not interested in any new business,'' said Josh Weiner, the head of Weiner Homes Corporation of Neptune, N.J., a medium-sized developer. ''The banks have become more and more conservative and more and more frightened about what the regulators are going to do.''
Barbara Alexander, managing director of the Construction and Building Products Group for Salomon Brothers, the investment bankers, said that the country could lose 100,000 new housing starts a year for the next five years because of the credit crunch the new regulations are creating for residential builders.
She echoed the view of housing industry officials that Federal limits on the amounts that may be lent to a single builder will drive housing prices up, either by raising the builders' costs or reducing the supply of new housing.
The value of all ADC loans from the major housing construction lenders ''likely will slide by 10 to 15 percent in 1990, and then fall considerably more in 1991,'' Ms. Alexander said in a speech at the National Association of Home Builders convention in January. ''In addition, with few incentives - and a plethora of disincentives - for such lending, the likelihood of a quick revival by such lenders is remote.''
The thrift institutions also lament the crimp the new Federal rules put on their ability to lend to developers. But secretly, some analysts say, they may be pleased to have a valid reason for turning down their old customers in a sluggish and - in many regions - an overbuilt market.
Home buyers feel the pinch, too, when builders whose credit has been stopped by a lender are unable to complete all the planned phases and amenities in a housing development. In some New Jersey projects where early buyers have invested their money and moved in, roads have been left unpaved, sewage hookups have not been made and half-built houses have been left abandoned.
Mr. Thompson, the Kentucky builder, has not just thrown in the towel. He has begun talking with a commercial bank, which will lend him less and charge him more than he used to pay at Cardinal Federal. A result, the builder said, will be a smaller project with fewer houses.
''Not only was it frustrating to have to find another source of acquisition and development loans,'' Mr. Thompson said, ''but we couldn't hire the people we were planning to employ, and in the meantime, another developer came in and started a project that will compete with ours.''
THE new regulations - the response of the Administration and Congress to fraud, loose lending practices and huge losses by the savings-and-loan industry - require these institutions to adopt the same underwriting standards as commercial banks. From the builders' perspective, the most important new requirements are that thrifts have more capital on hand as a proportion of real estate loans and that they not lend more than the equivalent of 15 percent of their stockholder's equity or core capital to any one borrower.
Cardinal Federal's core capital amounts to about $22 million, said its president, Bill Spurrier, and Mr. Thompson's company's current debt with the bank, at about $3 million, is close to the 15 percent limit.
Before the act was adopted, thrifts could lend up to 100 percent of their core capital to one borrower.
''Some lent 100 percent, and some got in trouble for it,'' said Jim Grohl, vice president of the U.S. League for Savings Institutions, a thrift industry trade group.
The league and the National Association of Home Builders want Congress to phase in the changes enacted last year over several years to give developers time to forge new relationships with other lenders and the thrifts time to develop the loan-sharing network that commercial banks use when they parcel out major loans. In that common practice, each commercial bank takes a share of the debt and the fees.
But in seeking the phase-in period, the bankers and builders have run up against the wall of political fear surrounding the S & L crisis. It is a wall that members of Congress have built around themselves as protection against the political scandals that have touched some of their less fortunate or less careful colleagues.
The cost to taxpayers of covering federally insured savings and loans losses may reach $500 billion, according to a recent General Accounting Office report. Several builders and bank assocation members agreed that this, plus the charges against five Senators of protecting a foundering savings and loan institution in return for big campaign contributions from its owner, Charles Keating, have made Congress wary of any changes that seem to reduce the regulatory burden on a savings and loan.
''There's just tremendous sensitivity about this,'' said Martin Perlman, a Houston residential developer who is president of the National Association of Home Builders. ''On the House side it's an election year and the representatives are very concerned about getting tagged with the cost of the thrift bail-out to the taxpayer. On the Senate side you have the Keating five and how all that will play with the voters. So nobody really wants to stick his neck out on this.''
According to Mr. Grohl of the U.S. League, the impact of the so-called ''loans to one borrower'' rule strikes hardest at builders and bankers outside the major urban areas, where banks and savings institutions are smaller and often tend to carve up the local market by specializing in different segments of the market - one thrift association focusing on mortgages, another on acquisition and development loans to builders and commercial banks focusing on loans to retailers and manufacturers.
In those markets, developers and bankers are going to have to develop new relationships and understandings of each other's business, Mr. Perlman said, and that will take time.
MR. THOMPSON, meanwhile, has found himself explaining the housing industry to commercial bankers, who are more used to lending money for inventory or expansion of existing retailers and manufacturers than to developers who often have few assets beyond their reputations as reliable businessmen.
''Ever since we were turned down by our regular bank, we've been involved in an education process with commercial banks,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''So when we started to talk to them about a land acquisition and development loan of maybe two or three years, they didn't have much of an appetite for it, and they said, 'What do you mean, release schedule and marginal releases and percentage of buildout value?' They just weren't familiar with those terms and that kind of loan.''
Marginal release, Mr. Thompson explained, is the common practice of a bank's releasing its lien on a completed house, allowing it to be sold, while retaining the loan lien on the unfinished and unsold properties.
Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association, said that in the present regulatory climate even commercial banks that are well on the right side of the rules may shy away from making ADC loans.
''There's a phenomenon I call Firrea-fallout that is definitely affecting the business decisions that banks are making,'' he said. ''Commercial bank managers seem right now to fear the possibility of a regulator taking action against them more than they do the stockholders. They figure they won't be fired for being unprofitable but they could be fired if a regulator comes in and second-guesses some loan they made.''
Last January, Mr. O'Keefe's group did a quick survey of just over 100 of its members in which 85 percent said they were having more trouble getting ADC loans than a year earlier, 56 percent said they had encountered problems getting an extension of current loans and 70 percent of those experiencing difficulty getting loans cited Firrea or ''bank examiners'' as the source of their problems with the banks. Mr. O'Keefe said his members are loath to go public with their problems, for fear of further undermining their relations with lenders and suppliers. But the stories, he said, keep coming in.
''I have heard any number of instances where an individual has a performing loan, they are meeting the schedule for home sales and repayments and they have simply been told by the thrift or the bank that their line of credit will be terminated, and a lot of people don't understand that terminating a line of credit is the same as terminating a construction job, even if you're still in the middle of it.''
THE problem has been compounded by an ''overreaction'' to the current slowdown in real estate development in the Northeast, Mr. O'Keefe went on.
''We have a national policy that fails to take into account the cyclical nature of our business,'' he said, ''and so it is taking what is a normal market correction in the Northeast and transforming it into a severe real estate recession that could take the rest of the economy with it.''
Mr. O'Keefe predicted that the the one-two punch of tightened lending regulations and a softening market will soon be felt in the rest of the country, too.
''Right now Firrea is a hot topic in the Northeast, and soon it will hit Washington, because that market is softening, and then it will be felt in Southern California,'' he predicted. ''And at that point these very strict regulations will begin to strangle our sector of the economy.''
Edward L. Yingling, director of government relations for the American Bankers Association, the commercial banking group, downplayed the fears of some developers that his member banks would not be available for development loans.
''They'll be interested in those loans and they are already making them,'' he said. ''To the extent that the S & L's will pull back from them, I think the banks will move in and pick up the slack. Banks are already taking up the slack on mortgages when the S & L's pulled back on them.''
As for reopening Firrea to create a phase-in period for the new loans-to-one-borrower rule, Mr. Yingling was as warm as a hard-nosed bank examiner going over an overdue loan.
''Our basic feeling is that the new rule is the correct rule and that the old system where the S & L could effectively lend up to 100 percent of their capital was a bad rule,'' he said. ''But if there is going to be some very limited transition to the new rule, we won't get in the way. As long as it's very limited.''
Ms. Alexander of Salomon Brothers doubts the usefulness of stretching out the phase-in of the loans-to-one-borrower rule, however. If a bank has to have its loan portfolio in a certain shape by a certain date, she said, chances are it will get its loans in compliance as soon as possible and not put the changes off until the last moment. But, she added, what else can the builder do but ask for more time?
''THE National Association of Home Builders is a politically sensitive organization and they know Firrea is not going to be repealed in the short term - there are too many people out there screaming for blood,'' she said. ''So if it isn't going to change, and there's nothing you can do about it, what's the best you can hope for? That it won't take effect as fast.''
The savings-and-loan associations are supervised by the Office of Thrift Supervision, a bureau of the Treasury Department, where lawyers are currently studying the Firrea legislation to see whether Congress gave the office the power to delay the effect of the lender rules without new legislation, said Paul H. Lockwood, a spokesman for the office.
Mr. O'Keefe of the New Jersey Builders Association worries that the legal review could take too long.
''They say they need to review the empirical data,'' he said, adding:
''My concern is that by the time the empirical data comes in, my members will all be out of business.''

PUB-DATE: April 22, 1990

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 274 words

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Called by Cuomo;
Parley's Agenda: Low-Cost Housing

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Innovative strategies to produce more low-cost housing will be discussed by 350 New York State leaders, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, at a daylong conference Thursday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.
Under Secretary Alfred A. DelliBovi of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development; Karney Hodge, director of the California Housing Finance Agency, and John Sidor, executive director of the Council of State Community Affairs Agencies, a nonprofit housing advocacy group in Washington, are among the experts from other sections of the country who will attend. 
Called by Mr. Cuomo, who also is to be the luncheon speaker, the conference will revolve around six three-hour panels, three in the morning and three in the afternoon. The meeting was assembled at Mr. Cuomo's direction by the State Housing Finance Agency, the State Mortgage Authority and the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
''Affordable housing,'' Mr. Cuomo said, ''is the backbone of every community. It is more than just bricks and concrete - it means a place to call home. The conference will mobilize private developers and not-for-profit groups to work together to increase the availability and affordability of housing through the 1990's.''
Among the larger issues to be discussed are housing for the homeless, new construction methods to reduce building costs, creative financing to increase investment funds and innovative roles that government agencies might be able to play.
Registration is at 8:30 A.M. The $110 fee includes lunch, dinner and a reception. For more information, telephone 686-9700, extension 206.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Modular Housing;
Widening the Role of Factory-Built Units

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
A CRANE swings and a section of house is fitted into place at a development called Aqueduct Homes. It happened last week in the University Heights section of the West Bronx. It is also happening in the Hunts Point section, at a development called Villa Maria.
Modular housing - with fully outfitted components built in a factory and trucked to the site - is a growing factor in home construction in New York City. In particular it has become a growing part of affordable-housing efforts in the city, which are bringing home ownership to farflung neighborhoods.
Modular housing now accounts for 30 percent of the housing produced through the New York City Partnership, a nonprofit organization that has a housing affiliate to help builders produce for-sale units, mainly two-family houses, that are affordable to moderate- to middle-income buyers. 
Now a new factor has been introduced: A second major producer has entered the New York City market. The developer of Aqueduct Homes is one of New Jersey's largest home builders, the Kaplan Organization of Edison, which has built 20,000 houses in New Jersey, mainly by conventional methods, since the early 50's. Heretofore only DeLuxe Homes of Pa., based in Berwick, has been a significant factor in modular development in the city.
The acceptance of modular housing by construction unions and home buyers suggests that in many inner-city places where home builders might hesitate to venture, new houses for a moderate-income market may be built. It also gives a lift to the 10-year, $5.1 billion housing plan begun by former Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1986. And it suggests a need for closer attention to site planning in large-scale affordable-housing developments.
In some developments the excessive use of pad parking - whether in modular or conventionally built development - seems to be inviting unsightly street environments in the long run.
Modular construction lowers risk and cost for the builder by drastically shortening the time of on-site work and the time between contract-signing by the buyer and closing. Even more important than the dollar saving may be the fact that potential loss from theft and vandalism during construction are sharply reduced.
This means that builders ready to use it can venture more easily into lower-income areas that have concentrations of rental housing and a long-term drop in middle-income populations. Used in places like Hunts Point, it can help to promote economic integration by bringing in working families with incomes of $25,000 to $53,000, or keeping in the communities those with such incomes who might otherwise move out when they are ready to find better housing.
The Aqueduct Homes project is a case in point. It is going on a site that was devastated by housing abandonment.
''IN four days from the time of delivery we can have 12 buildings standing,'' said Morris Kaplan, president of the Kaplan Organization and head of its modular operations, which are in Pine Grove and Tower City, both in Pennsylvania. ''In 30 to 45 days people can move in. Conventionally, it would take us five months to build on the site.'' Cost savings in interest on construction loans amount to about $4,000 a house.
Aqueduct Homes consists of 110 two-family houses on a group of vacant lots near Jerome Avenue and West 181st Street. Occupancy is to begin in May. The three-level houses have an unadorned brickface facade. Despite their front stoops, they are architecturally undistinctive, mainly because of their flat facades and roofs. But inside there is a generous-sized three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath duplex unit of 1,600 square feet for the owner, and a two-bedroom rental of 780 square feet for the renter. There is a parking pad for two cars in front. The house is 20 feet wide and 40 feet deep.
The price to the buyer is about $150,000. Public assistance makes up the additional cost of $40,000 for each two-family house.
Kaplan has also has been awarded a site in the southeast Bronx - off Intervale Avenue, Kelly Street and West 163d Street - for 125 two-family houses. Construction there will begin in the fall.
LIKE DeLuxe Homes, the Kaplan Organization will seek to sell its products to other home builders. These builders would buy the land, provide the foundations and handle the sales. When the Partnership is involved and the land is acquired from the city, a subsidy of as much as $20,000 a unit may be available, depending on the strength of the market where the houses are sold. A community sponsor normally assists the Partnership in the sales.
At the Villa Maria site, at Prospect Avenue and Beck Streets in Hunts Point, DeLuxe has a house with greater design features. The facades are of both aluminum siding and brickface, and there are pitched roofs with dormer windows. Stone stoops lead to a covered front porch. Most of the houses have pad parking in front, but there will also be some clustering of cars. The developer is DeLuxe's development arm, DeLuxe Development of New York, in collaboration with a community sponsor, Hunts Point Multi-Service Center.
DeLuxe has already shipped 1,500 house units to New York City, said Donald E. Meske, president. The current products come in five basic types: two-story one-families; two-story two-families; three-story two-families; three-story three-families (usually sold as three condominiums per building); and three- and four-story two-families, as at Shorehaven.
Also active in the city as a factory builder is Forest City Enterprises of Cleveland, which does multifamily housing and plans to use its product in Arverne, Queens.
New for-sale construction constitutes a major part of the 10-year plan, which Mayor David N. Dinkins is continuing. It comes to 37,000 units, or 44 percent of the 84,000 newly created units envisioned in the plan. The rest are apartments in vacant tax-foreclosed buildings that are being renovated.
Mr. Koch used the figure 252,000 units when he began the plan. But 168,000 of these are in occupied rental buildings that get rehabilitation financing wholly or partially from city or state funds. The ownership may be private, nonprofit or public. The for-sale new-construction phase of the plan includes 23,000 units to be developed through the New York City Partnership; 5,000 through the Nehemiah Plan, the low-cost moderate-income one-family approach begun by churches in East Brooklyn, and 9,000 under miscellaneous programs.
Seven years ago the Partnership invited modular builders from all over the country to come to New York City and was turned down by all except DeLuxe. They uniformally feared the city's bureaucracy and were uncertain about the marketability of the houses, said Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership.
There also has been uncertainty about the acceptability of modular construction to the construction unions. Agreements with the national unions of carpenters, plumbers and electricians oblige both DeLuxe and Kaplan to use 100 percent unionized contractors. Local unions typically honor these agreements.
''The quality of the modulars has improved dramatically since the first project in 1983,'' Ms. Wyle said. ''Initially, the techniques were not up to New York City standards either for marketability or durability.''
In Brooklyn, the Hudson Companies, a development company based in Carroll Gardens, is planning to use DeLuxe modules for 21 two-family houses called Antioch Place, on Lexington Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, with the Antioch Baptist Church as community sponsor.
The Hudson Companies is one building organization that is trying to steer clear of pad parking. Alan R. Bell, a principal, said that the company would provide the parking at the rear, off a looped drive, to avoid the unsightly appearance of pad parking spaces, which he said the company deplores. ''It costs more - for the asphalt, the lighting and car bumpers - and the buyers sometimes complain about it,'' he said. ''We also lose one house. We could have had 21.''
It is perhaps unlikely that the ambitious numerical goals of the 10-year plan will be fully achieved. Many of the gut-rehabilitation units are on sites so scattered and in buildings so small and decrepit that the required public subsidy per unit is far out of line with the housing benefit obtainable. And an effort to use major contractors to rehabilitate old buildings in large bidding ''packages'' of hundreds of apartments has already backfired in huge cost overruns in Harlem.
But the for-sale elements in the program may have a long-term vitality. People like to own a home. Given a fairly moderate subsidy per unit, and a low-cost method of delivering the home, sale programs have a good future.

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
A Shopping Mall Opens East of Hartford

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE malling of Connecticut in the last 20 years has produced 19 enclosed regional shopping centers. Danbury Fair Mall, with 1.2 million square feet, is the largest, and some are as small as 160,000 square feet. Half a dozen new ones are proposed but their developers have been unable to find anchor stores or get zoning approval.
Nevertheless, the Pavilions at Buckland Hills, a 900,000-square-foot mall, opened last month in Manchester, eight miles east of Hartford off the Buckland Street exit of I-84, and while malls often generate hostility, this one seems to serve a need. Many shoppers who were starved for retail outlets east of Hartford love the Pavilions. 
''It's delightful,'' said Evelyn Lyons of South Windsor. ''It used to take me over half an hour to get to Westfarms Mall through Hartford traffic. This is five minutes from my house.''
Sales at the Pavilions, which serves a population of 275,000 east of the Connecticut River and centered on Manchester, are exceeding expectations, said Stephen Qualkinbush, director of the project for the Homart Development Company of Chicago. Homart is a member of the Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group and managing partner in the joint venture with Melvin Simon & Associates of Indianapolis and Bronson & Hutensky of Hartford.
Some attendant decline in business is expected at Westfarms Mall in West Hartford, the Crystal Mall in Waterford and the Enfield Mall near Massachusetts, and the already diminished retail presence in downtown Hartford is expected to decline further.
''The issue of downtowns is one of obsolescence,'' Mr. Qualkinbush said. ''If the populations were there and their needs were met, regional malls would not be so successful.''
The $150 million project on 115 acres has 150 small shops, all but 10 percent of them occupied. Anchor department stores are Sage-Allen and G. Fox of Hartford and D & L of New Britain, Steiger's of Springfield, Mass., and Sears, Roebuck & Company. J. C. Penney, whose two-million-square-foot distribution center is across Buckland Street, is a likely candidate for one of two additional anchor spaces.
Among the clothing shops are Anderson-Little, Ann Taylor, Eddie Bauer, the Gap, Lane Bryant, the Limited and Victoria's Secret. Bostonian, Florsheim and 9 West are among theshoes shops; Haagen-Dazs, McDonald's, Taco Bell, Sbarro and Ruby Tuesday's among the food stores and restaurants; Sam Goody, Waldenbooks, Brentano's and Radio Shack for books, records and electronics; Brookstone, CVS Drugstore, CPI Photo, a Disney Store, and stores with pet products, children's apparel, toys, housewares and jewelry. Rents average $30 a square foot.
''Homart did not want to compete with Westfarms' upscale character, which is correctly keyed to the affluent suburbs west of Hartford,'' said Mary Ellen Brigham, who will teach a new course called Shopping Center and Mall Management and Marketing at the University of Connecticut next fall. ''East of Hartford is more of a moderate income area. Homart went for that. Older people with expensive tastes will still go to Laura Ashley and Polo at Westfarms; teen-agers and young families will like Buckland Hills.''
Judy Coady, a professor of sociology at the university who did a nationwide study of malls in 1986, said: ''The future of malls may depend on just that kind of specialization. California and Texas have malls for college students, kids, older people and singles. It minimizes the threat of competition for developers.''
James O. Rogers, president of the Connecticut Retail Merchants Association, said the Pavilions ''hits the saturation point.'' He added: ''I think with the economy the way it is that shopping center development is going to stand still for awhile. Store owners will only go into a certain number of malls.''
The area around the Pavilion site is a swirling beehive of current and potential development, including a 932-unit rental apartment complex by Trammell Crow, the developer based in Dallas. It opened on Jan. 15 opposite the mall.
One hundred fifty units are occupied, 150 more are leased and 500 will be completed by July, with rents from $690 for one-bedroom to $970 for a three-bedrooms with two baths.
''WE haven't yet figured out where all these people are coming from,'' said Charles Berman, head of the Trammell Crow regional office in New Canaan.
Projected for a 270-acre site between the mall and Buckland Street is a town-approved 250,000-square-foot shopping center. There are preliminary plans for a 150-room hotel-convention center and 395,000 square feet of office space. ''John Finguerra of New York City assembled the land,'' said Mark Pellegrini, Manchester's planning director, ''but there is not much of a market now, so he has not sought final approvals.''
The Cambridge Seven of Cambridge, Mass., designed the Pavilions with an informal, contemporary air, accented with blue and red exposed support pipes against white walls. Its 1,100-foot length is interrupted by five skylighted atriums that provide floor space for special events and define the entrances to department stores. Three of the courts have escalators to the second level and two have elevators partly enclosed by matching abstract steel sculptures created by George Sugarman and painted in sprightly colors repeated in free-form benches.
Roofs covering the second-level shopping corridors between the atriums are made of Sheerfill, a Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric manufactured by O. C. Birdair in Buffalo. The translucent white fabric is stretched tent-style over steel rods and casts a soft natural light.
All the anchor stores except D & L bought their land at low cost from Homart and built their own stores. Philip Davidson, chairman of the 89-year-old D & L chain of 114 stores in 14 states, said, ''We decided that we want maximum flexibility and a landlord's participation.''
D & L has stores at Manchester's Parkade shopping center, in Hartford, in Vernon's Tri-City Plaza six miles from the Pavilions and in 28 other places in Connecticut.
''There is new retailing afoot,'' Mr. Davidson said. ''We are not smart enough to know in advance what the transference will be. We will wait and see.''

LENGTH: 1029 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
AT the edge of the city, near its beginning and end, John O'Rourke sits, asking the time. It's just after noon of a blustery midweek that does not feel anything like spring.
A retired meat cutter with tours of duty in a dozen supermarkets, Mr. O'Rourke, 72 years old, knows Newark. He remembers when important people from Hahne's and Bamberger's used to take rooms at the Executive House on Saybrook Place, the crooked street that runs from Military Park downtown to Newark's border at the Passaic River. He remembers when the Newark Athletic Club used to run the Military Park Hotel, around the corner on Park Place. He remembers. 
''It used to be a beautiful neighborhood,'' he said, sitting in his light jacket and frayed baseball cap in a little unnamed park that celebrates Newark's beginning, marking the spot where Puritans climbed out of their boats 324 years ago to find heaven on earth. ''It used to be nice. But now? Now it's run down. Now there's nothing here anymore.''
Perhaps, but someday, if this old city's will prevails, Mr. O'Rourke's observation post above the river may end up being somewhere near center stage of a 3,000-seat world-class multi-use theater and performance hall, one part of an opulent dream known as the New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts.
Mr. O'Rourke, who lives nearby, has heard about the plan, and he approves. ''It'll build things up around here, bring in a lot of people,'' he said. ''Yeah, it'll be good.''
To look around from the vantage point of Mr. O'Rourke's tired knoll, it is hard to imagine anything good. Trucks blast down McCarter Highway, and everything for blocks and blocks looks tired, worn and old. But the proof of what could happen was there in front of Mr. O'Rourke, in the persons of M. John Richard and Tom Lussenhop.
Mr. Richard is vice president of development and Mr. Lussenhop, executive assistant, of the New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts. They came that day to tour the 12 grimy acres of urban refuse that could someday be New Jersey's Lincoln Center. Of late they have been helping to hammer out details of the plans to purchase the land, move the streets and then start building a place from which will be staged the masterpieces of world music, dance and theater. In Newark!
They walked slowly, careful to step over the broken glass without getting impaled on the barbed-wire fences. There, on the corner of Saybrook and Park Place, where the hollowed-out remains of the Military Park Hotel disintegrate, will be an 2,500-seat concert hall. There, next to the Quality Inn, where the parking lot and Boy Scout headquarters are, another hall, of 1,800 seats.
''What's this? Parsley,'' Mr. Lussenhop said, stepping on a lush bed of weeds sprouting from what had once been a sidewalk on Saybrook Place, alongside the parking lot that could one day be the site of a monumental multi-use theater palace or maybe a hotel. Then, dodging traffic to cross Central Avenue to the well-fed lawns around the buildings now owned by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, he pointed to where a theater for dance and drama, seating 600, might be built.
''It's a heck of a challenge,'' said Mr. Lussenhop, who came from Minneapolis by way of Princeton and who believes that Newark can be bright and strong in a way it was before despair took over. ''What we're hoping to do in the design of the center,'' he said, ''is make a statement: this is an important place.''
Important for a lot of reasons and to a lot of people. Recently, the consulting firm of Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler, which estimated the economic impacts of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York and the roaming MX missile somewhere out west, determined that building the performing arts center would stir up $1 billion of new economic activity for New Jersey.
According to the study, the theaters and concert halls would generate 10,400 construction jobs and draw an annual audience of 650,000 people to downtown Newark by the year 2003. The impact of the large investment - more than $220 million for just the first two phases - could be multiplied further by timing. ''Given the slowdown coming over the next six or seven years, this could be absolutely critical to the future of the city,'' said James Alschuler, the consultant.
But for many, the economic impact, great as it is expected to be, is incidental to how the center could raise the psyche of the city and put an end to the myth that cities serve only to take society's waste, a reservation of sewage plants, incinerators, prisons and dumps. They believe that a center of uncompromised quality will give back to this city and to others the dignity that extends beyond usefulness and into the intangible called community.
Lawrence P. Goldman, the man who directed the development of Lincoln Center and now is maestro of the Newark project, said it would be far easier to build an arts center in the Meadowlands than in Newark, but it wouldn't produce the same benefits for so many people. ''What will come from this is how Newarkers and New Jerseyans come to think of themselves and the place in which they live,'' Mr. Goldman said. ''This will provide a strong physical representation of excellence.''
Gov. Jim Florio was in Newark not long ago to restate his support for the center in spite of the harrowing budget problems he inherited. The state is kicking in $20 million in low-interest bonds to be used to buy land, negotiations already nearing completion.
Mr. Florio spoke forthrightly. ''I regard what we're doing here as an investment in the future,'' he said. ''This is a celebration of the spirit upon which Newark was founded.''
The very spot on which Newark was founded, the bare-boned knoll on Saybrook Place where Mr. O'Rourke usually sits watching traffic, appears to be a fitting site for the new performing arts center. ''On this slope,'' reads the inscription on a sandstone monolith there, a fountain on one side now filled with green stagnant water, ''from the river came the founders on a day late in May 1666 to plant their settlement on the plain above.''
On a similar day not long from now, they may return.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A State Budget Plan That Breaks the Rules

BYLINE: By Norman J. Glickman; Norman J. Glickman, an economist, is the director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University.

 BODY:
POLITICIANS who think about the long-term interests of their constituents have a choice, according to today's cynics. They can commit political suicide by proposing complicated solutions to hard problems. Or they can go for short-term, superficial fixes that don't really do the job.
In Washington, most politicians have taken the second route. This has resulted in governmental paralysis over nearly all issues of importance, from reducing the national debt to controlling health care costs. 
Here in New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio has proposed a complex tax and budget plan that may not play well on the evening news. He has taken a politically risky road toward reducing the $1.4 billion budget deficit he inherited. He's trying to cut spending, freeze hiring and raise taxes. He's got many people mad at him, including state workers, college students and suburban mayors.
We should all remember that the Governor's choice was not about whether to raise taxes and cut spending, but how. Since the state constitution requires a balanced budget, he had to do something. The real question is: Did he ask for the right mix of cuts and taxes? The debate in New Jersey is over that question.
Mr. Florio has broken several political rules. He's broken Bush's Rule of Political Expediency by saying, in effect, ''Read my lips: higher taxes.'' He's broken Koch's Re-election Rule by failing to resort to accounting gimmicks to balance the budget. Significantly, he has also broken Reagan's Rule of Trickle Up Economics. Instead of raising the taxes of lower-income people, as President Reagan did, he's raising taxes for those who can afford it most. This is particularly true of the income tax, where people making over $100,000 will pay much more. Average working people will pay a smaller share of state taxes. This is a populist approach. The increased income taxes will be used to cut the property taxes of those with incomes below $65,000 (most of us) and to reduce what localities will have to pay for welfare and social services. This will help reduce the terrible pressure that local governments face in financing much-needed services, particularly in our blighted cities. This is a step toward meaningful property tax relief that homeowners have been demanding. Under the plan, moderate-income households will most likely get higher property tax rebates than under the existing law. Although next year will be hard on localities because of the 1990 cuts, the long-run situation might improve.
The Governor's plan also begins to redress the imbalances in state aid to school districts. Down the road, we may see the gap in state aid per pupil between rich and poor school districts reduced. In the meantime, the Governor has taken a principled stand in favor of minorities and the cities in anticipating the State Supreme Court school finance decision.
Mr. Florio's changes ought to bring a more equitable system than the one in place. They also help make the system of financing public services more efficient. And they should reduce overreliance on local property taxes to finance lots of services, including education.
The Governor's plan could help us because it puts the state in a more stable fiscal footing - especially given the recent threat of a downgrading of New Jersey's bond ratings by a financial house because of the budget imbalance. The program should provide businesses with better roads, a more educated labor force and other public services they need.
There are potential problems with the package that should be watched. For instance, the sales tax increase could be regressive since the poor tend to pay a higher proportion of their incomes to sales taxes than do the nonpoor. But if the sales tax isn't charged on basic necessities like food, clothing and medicine, the tax will most likely be proportional - all of us pay the same percentage of our incomes. Fortunately, the Florio plan leaves these necessities tax-exempt. Although the Governor says this plan will not hurt economic growth, experts have raised troubling questions. Will higher income taxes mean that fewer new companies will locate in New Jersey? Will the wealthy move out of the state? Will the higher 7 percent sales taxes drive our consumers to Pennsylvania, where it is 6 percent? It will take some time to answer those questions. They must be answered satisfactorily.
Not everyone will agree with the details of Mr. Florio's program. For example, even some fellow Democrats want to make sure that the current homestead rebate continues until Mr. Florio's clicks in.
Clearly, the administration and the Legislature must still enact a detailed program. But it is hard to deny that Mr. Florio has made a strong political statement about his priorities for taxes and spending. He has come out in a populist and progressive way. He has shown leadership when few politicians are willing to be out front on anything controversial.
This plan will not be well received in affluent suburbs like Bedminster or Saddle River. It may not even be appreciated immediately in some of our poorer cities. But how it plays in middle-class towns like Edison or Cedar Grove will determine how the plan, with the Governor's populist message, plays in New Jersey.

PUB-DATE: April 22, 1990

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 24, Column 6; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 421 words

HEADLINE: Auto Insurance 'Reform' Really Isn't

 BODY:
The present New Jersey auto insurance reform act demonstrates the inherent weakness of political solutions to economic issues. Such solutions are based on lack of experience in the field and on emotion.
Jim Florio's attempt at rate leveling shifts the burden of high risk to those presenting little or no risk at all. Good drivers pay for bad drivers. Suburban and rural drivers pay for urban drivers. 
The abrupt termination of the J.U.A. will lead to chaos as J.U.A. brokers go out of business and there's no immediate substitute coverage for the 1.6 million drivers in the program. Attempt to pay off the $3.1 billion J.U.A. debt in a short time could lead to bankruptcy or abandonment of New Jersey by some insurers. It will further force up medical and legal costs and other costs as commercial drivers, along with other drivers, have to pay more for registration.
The limitation on P.I.P. coverage is asinine. That means higher costs in additional premiums. Resort to medical insurance will, of course, force up the cost of medical insurance to the point where not even Fortune 500 employers would afford the coverage. So where's the savings?
A fairer approach would involve rate determination by the following factors: (1) accident-violations-criminal record; (2) driving experience; (3) total assets, investments and returns of carrier (to curb excessive ''management fees'' charged against state branch offices); (4) make and model of car; (5) home address.
A long-term approach involves the following: (1) close cooperation between the insurer, the state and the insured in monitoring medical and legal expenses; (2) a crackdown on excessive litigation, and responsible deliberation as jurors in claim cases, (3) continual review and upgrading of the D.M.V. and stricter compliance with traffic laws.
The last and most important element involves getting at the root problem of insurance costs; road congestion. This means getting economic development under control. On a state and local level, let's tighten up on elected officials who owe their election to campaign contributions from developers or who approve builders' applications indiscriminately. In the end, we may pay higher local taxes but reap some nice savings in insurance costs.
 
STEVE RAYNOR
 Wayne
The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and daytime telephone number and be addressed to The Editor, New Jersey Weekly, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

PUB-DATE: April 22, 1990

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2303 words

HEADLINE: Sorting the Garbage: How Well Is It Working?

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
IN the two decades since the first Earth Day, county residents have learned a thing or two. They are still planting trees and cleaning up local parks, but they are also sorting through their garbage.
''There's a growing perception that what is required is changes in life style, that our affluence and conspicuous consumption must be contained,'' said Paul L. Steineck, professor of earth science at the State University of New York at Purchase. And nowhere are such changes more easily measured than in the disposal of solid waste.
No longer satisfied that the Federal and state laws enacted since the first Earth Day will protect the environment, volunteers are helping to monitor the water quality in the Hudson, measure oxygen depletion in Long Island Sound or create land trusts and clustered housing to preserve green spaces. But garbage provides a common denominator, a front line that includes everyone. 
Not every resident has a boat whose sewage needs to be monitored or even a lawn on which to reduce the use of pesticides. But apartment dwellers and homeowners all produce garbage, much of which can be recycled.
''We have been so wasteful that minor adjustments, as in recycling, can have tremendous impact,'' Professor Steineck said. ''People are realizing we all have a part to play.''
 
The Landfills Close
During the 20 years since Earth Day 1970, the Croton Point landfill has closed down; its estimated one billion pounds of toxic waste remain a concern to environmentalists because of the potential for leaching into the Hudson River. The county's four municipal incinerators have been closed as well, along with the two landfills that once took construction debris.
Taking their place is the six-year-old, $237 million Charles Point Resource Recovery Plant in Peekskill, now the county's only disposal site. But it is already too small by a third to handle the nearly one million tons of garbage that Westchester will throw away this year. The space allocated to the 36 participating communities leaves little capacity for the private carters, who haul waste from the county's commercial sector and from its seven northern towns to increasingly distant landfills.
In response, recycling has emerged as the option of choice. Both economic and environmental considerations argue against building a second plant, say county officials, who believe the waste stream could be reduced sufficiently if the public cooperated in recycling. State laws now require municipalities to have recycling programs in place by September l992 and to recycle 40 percent of the state's solid waste by l997.
''Twenty years ago, all people wanted from their garbage was for it to go away,'' said Prof. Richard Knabel, who teaches environmental science at Westchester Community College in Valhalla and is vice president of the Federated Conservationists of Westchester. ''Now there is a tremendous willingness to be involved in the process.''
But he added a caution: ''Seventy-five percent of the students in my class consider themselves environmentalists, but only one-third think they are part of the problem.''
 
The County Role
 
Carrots Now, The Stick Later
 Recycling has gained a measurable foothold in Westchester. In the two years since County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke announced an 11-point comprehensive recycling plan, there has been a fivefold increase in programs, with 205 diverse ones now in place or planned to start shortly and involving all of the county's 43 municipalities.
But the 8.6 percent reduction in residential waste that Westchester municipalities achieved last year is far below the 40 percent reduction the state will require by 1997. County officials say that meeting that goal is also required to avoid building a second waste-to-energy incinerator or expanding the existing one.
The recycling program has worked well enough that six months ago the county withdrew its request to the state Department of Environmental Conservation to increase its capacity to burn at the Charles Point plant, which produces power for Consolidated Edison. ''We pulled back so as not to discourage people from recycling,'' said Charles Miles, assistant commissioner for environmental projects in the Department of Public Works. ''Besides, this mental attitude is catching on.''
Despite population increases, the volume of residential solid waste incinerated at the plant declined 1 percent last year for the second consecutive year; it had steadily increased during the plant's first three years of operation. Participating communities diverted 48,000 tons of solid waste from Charles Point last year, twice the 1988 total.
An incentive is the county's direct payment of $17 for each ton a municipality does not send to the plant, compared to the amount it delivered the previous year.
The Charles Point plant processes 571,000 tons of residential waste yearly and the balance of its permitted capacity of 657,000 tons is sold to private carters.
 
$10,000 Grants Are Offered
The most popular incentive offered by the county, said James J. Hogan, director of resource management in the Solid Waste Division of the county Department of Public Works, is the $10,000 available to each community for composting sites, curbside collection containers, depots to store recyclables until they can be marketed and collection trucks.
Within the next 18 months, a $10 million plant in Yonkers is expected to open, providing a single disposal site where municipalities can deliver mixed recyclable garbage (except newsprint). Known as a ''Murf'' (derived from materials recovery facility), the plant is where recyclable material will be sorted and packaged into marketable products.
Finding reliable markets remains the greatest obstacle to the program's success, Mr. Hogan said, and newspapers present the greatest difficulty. Pulp processors have not been able to count on a consistent, reliable supply, but he suggested that requiring newspapers to be recycled should stabilize the market.
 
Composting, but Where?
Yard waste is another problem. Although 15 municipalities now have composting space, finding sites is difficult, especially in southern Westchester, where open land is scarce. Because of laws prohibiting the use of parkland for non-park purposes, the county has been unable to provide a regional site of its own.
Pending legislation that would provide an exception to the law is opposed by local environmental groups, which favor case-by-case consideration. Additional pressure to resolve the issue is expected from the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, which has proposed legislation to ban the incineration of compost.
The county is considering mandating recycling even before state regulations take effect in l992, Mr. Hogan said. A proposal is under review by the law department, he said, and could be enacted to coincide with the opening of the materials-recovery plant.
It would include the business community, which contributes nearly one-third of the county's waste stream, an estimated 371,000 tons each year.
There are no real figures on how much recycling is carried out by business. ''I suspect it has a long way to go,'' Mr. Hogan said. Two-thirds of commercial waste is believed to consist of corrugated cardboard and office paper, material that is recyclable and marketable.
With a $650,000 state grant, the county is conducting a comprehensive solid-waste-management study to measure the impact of local recycling efforts and alternatives. A decision about a second site for a resource-recovery plant, Mr. Miles said, ''will depend on whether we are optimistic or pessimistic about recycling.''
 
Municipal Efforts
 
What Works? Finding the Market
If coordinators in each of the county's municipalities could recycle all the newpaper and compost all the yard waste their residents produce, the county's waste volume would be cut in half. But there are too few markets for the one, and too little land for the other.
With few mandatory programs in place, some communities are struggling to persuade residents to ''source separate,'' causing homes and apartments to overflow with plastic bags, bottles and cans. Other areas allow the commingling of materials, which then overflow municipal depots while harried public-works employees try to sort and package the recyclables for other markets.
Scarsdale recycled 36 percent of its solid waste last year, the highest percentage of any municipality in the county and an amount equal to 750 pounds per resident. The village succeeded without curbside pickups, and the lines of residents waiting to deposit at the community recycling depot get longer each day.
The 20-year-old program, one of the oldest in the county, appears to have captured the attention of a majority of residents.
The village has ''positive'' (paying) markets for almost all its recyclable material, even its newpapers, said James E. Rice, its recycling consultant. Scarsdale has been selling newsprint for 20 years, Mr. Rice said, and guarantees dealers that each bundle will be ''clean,'' or free of colored stock.
Other communities can do the same, he insisted: ''When you go to someone and they want a blue suit, don't go home and start making them a brown suit.''
Mr. Rice and Lowell J. Tooley, the Scarsdale Village Manager, said that there was little more the village could do to encourage recycling but that the county could do much more. Additional financial incentives for already vigorous programs like the one in Scarsdale should be provided, they said, including higher bonuses to keep recyclable waste out of the Charles Point plant.
''We believe the county should pay municipalities what it is really saving,'' Mr. Rice said.
 
Imagination in Yorktown
Although Yorktown recycles only 13 percent of its waste, under the direction of Patrick J. Lofaro Jr., superintendent of the Department of Environmental Conservation, it has developed one of the county's most energetic and creative recycling programs - from public education developed in cooperation with Teatown Reservation to recycling one ton of automotive batteries last year.
Yorktown sells biodegradable leaf bags at cost; when filled, the town picks them up, mixes them with sludge from its sewage treatment plant, composts it and then gives the finished product away to residents, the town's beautification committee and the local highway department for soil conditioning. Last year, Yorktown disposed of 3,000 tons of organic yard waste and sludge in this fashion.
At Lakeland High School there, students under the direction of Ellen Purcigliotti started the county's only plastics-recycling program, in cooperation with Jenpac, an upstate recycling company owned by a consortium of oil companies.
Students deposit their lunch trays and containers into special stacking stations; they are sent to the company for resale as plastic pellets to be used in combs, insulation and other products. The program costs the school nothing. It has already been adopted at neighboring Yorktown High School.
Between state grants, tipping-fee savings and the sale of materials, Yorktown gained $74,224 last year for its recycling efforts. ''Whoever thought,'' Mr. Lofaro said, ''that we would make money on garbage.''
 
The Grass Roots
 
Convenience Wins Converts
There are the grumpy residents, still in the majority, who will voluntarily recycle their cans, plastics and bottles only if it is convenient, and that means frequent curbside pickup from municipally supplied containers.
When Yorktown residents were asked how a recycling program could be made more convenient, nearly half asked for a container and almost as many asked for same-day collection. The same response came in a recent survey of New Castle residents.
In order to work, municipal coordinators agree, new recycling programs must be made easy for residents, volumes must be large enough to attract markets, and the collection process must be manageable for local public works departments.
The village of Elmsford currently has no recycling programs, but now it has a new Trustee, Robert Williams, manager of the scrap-metal department at the Brookfield Metal Company of Elmsford, as its recycling coordinator. His vote plurality was the highest in recent Elmsford electoral history.
''Homelessness is not the major issue in Elmsford,'' Mr. Williams said. ''When I rang doorbells, all they wanted to know was what I would do to help them recycle. People got mad after they bundled newsprint and watched public works guys just dump it into the trucks with the other garbage.''
 
A 'Limitless' Market
The company buys bulk metals from every Westchester community and from locations as far away as Canada, reselling the material to steel mills. His business, Mr. Williams said, has doubled in the last two years.
Brookfield has a ''limitless'' market for metals, said Mr. Williams, who believes that markets for other recyclables are there, as well. He has negotiated an agreement to sell Elmsford's newspapers for $10 a ton.
''People are ecology minded because they realize the earth is getting full,'' he said, and Elmsford residents are ready ''to recycle 100 percent so long as I don't make it difficult for them.''
Other recycling officials, though less sanguine than Mr. Williams, agree that recycling is here to stay and say that if adults haven't all got the message yet, their children have.
His own 8-year-old son, Christopher, has kept him in line, Mr. Lofaro said, in Yorktown. ''The plumber was in my house recently and threw away a can of soda. Christopher came to me immediately and said, 'Daddy, what is a can of Pepsi doing in our garbage?' I was immediately defensive. And I don't even drink Pepsi.''
