The New York Times

 April 22, 1990, Sunday, National Edition

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1307 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Gas Station Design Contest Pulls Nearly 400 Entries

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: PORTLAND, ME.

 BODY:
When Theo Holtwijk, a landscape architect and planner, approached the officers of C. N. Brown Company last September with the idea of sponsoring a national design competition to elicit fresh ideas for the company's newest gas station, he thought they would promptly turn him away. After all, he reasoned, more often than not, when a gas station is built these days, the design reflects a prototype chosen by whatever major oil company supplies the fuel.
But C. N. Brown, which owns or services some 200 gas stations throughout New England, welcomed the idea, and architects and others from as far away as Hawaii have responded enthusiastically. Nearly 400 companies and individuals have paid the $25 application fee to receive the packet of guidelines. The actual designs are due tomorrow and the winner - chosen by a panel of independent judges - will be announced May 9.
Even before the entries were officially received it became clear that Brown would have some unusual plans to consider. 
The contest is believed to be the first gas station design competition in 40 years. The interest shown reflects an ongoing debate between architects and corporate marketing agents about whether they need to build virtually the same building in every place coast-to-coast.
''The day of just plopping any old box down is gone,'' said John Kane, whose company, Architekton, in Tempe, Ariz., specializes in gas station design and is preparing an entry for the Portland competition. ''The cities just won't allow it any longer.'' That was the case here in Portland.
C. N. Brown had hoped to tear down a 40-year-old station it owns at one of the primary routes to downtown Portland. The company wanted to build a version of Mobil Oil Corporation's standard Pegasus 21 design, featuring a large white, brightly lighted canopy and blue fascia above the pumps.
But Portland city planners rejected the plan, primarily because the Brown company wanted to retain the same number of curb cuts as the old station had.
''It was a stalemate,'' said Mr. Holtwijk. ''C. N. Brown threw up its hands and said, 'O.K., we won't do anything.' ''
Portland revitalization groups, among them Uptown & Company, which Mr. Holtwijk serves as president, saw the situation as a chance to generate interest in improving that section of the city. The area has many historic properties, including the city's main post office and its largest park, both of which are on the National Register of Historic Places. Also, historically significant buildings, some in disrepair, surround the site, Mr. Holtwijk said.
''This gives a back-door impression to what should be the front door,'' said Mr. Holtwijk. ''It's a dilapidated station that probably hasn't had a coat of paint since the 1950's and the Portland peninsula is interesting because it has very few gas stations. We would like to encourage the owner to do some broader thinking.''
Thomas Collins, a spokesman for Mobil, said his company has been pleased to participate in the contest, but noted that the company's marketing needs must be considered in any station design.
''Our brand of service station, logo, look of the location is an integral part of our business,'' said Mr. Collins. ''Competition among service stations is incredibly intense'' in the country generally ''and we want our service stations to look a certain way and be a certain way.'' Mobil has spent millions of dollars rebuilding its 3,800 stations in the Pegasus 21 image. To get the 10,000 independent dealers who sell Mobil products to do likewise it offers them financial inducements - although it will not disclose what those inducements are.
Mr. Collins said that it costs about $2 million to rebuild a service station and that the standard designs can be modified so they are right for every site and, often, quite striking in appearance. He cited as an example a new station Mobil built recently in Fairfax County, Va., about five miles from the company's United States' headquarters.
''It's a magnificent setting with trees, a car wash, electronic payment at the pump,'' he said.
Gas station architecture has gone through phases since the first pumps were installed outside the nation's general stores in the early 1900's, according to Daniel Vieyra, an architect and director of the historic preservation graduate program at Kent State University. In ''Fill 'er Up,'' a book on the architectural history of gas stations (MacMillan Publishing Company, 1979, $7.95), Mr. Vieyra identifies the various types of stations that had been built, from ''the fantastic,'' which included buildings fashioned after airplanes, lighthouses, shells and castles, to ''the respectable,'' which included buildings that looked more like colonial homes or classical pavilions than a place to fuel a car. A Van Nuys, Calif., station built in 1935, was a reproduction of the elegant Los Angeles City Hall tower.
Also, some world-famous architects have designed gas stations. Among them were Frank Lloyd Wright, who believed the gas station would one day serve as a community gathering place, and Mies van der Rohe. Eliot Noyes, a New Canaan, Conn., architect who specialized in industrial design, created a prototype gas station for Mobil in 1964 featuring round canopies and round gas pumps that was used until the Pegasus 21 design came about in 1985.
Standardization of gas station design has been around as long as stations themselves have been, but it really caught on in the 1950's when large scale construction of interstate highways began, Mr. Vieyra said.
''Oil companies have to convince motorists who are in their own little worlds to stop,'' he said. ''When traveling was an adventure, the romantic, interesting shaped buildings werethe way to do it. But then it got easy to get from one end of the country to another and motorists traveled many more miles at much faster speeds. The last thing they want is a surprise, and you communicate that with a simpler building that says it's the same as it is back home.'' The look-alike buildings erected by restaurants and hotels as well as oil companies have been detrimental to the look and feel of America's landscape, some architects and planners said.
Said Mr. Kane: ''You get a series of independent buildings with no sense of context, continuum. That's what's lacking in our towns today. In successful cities, those things are not allowed.''
But Mr. Kane added that the major oil companies choose to build the same basic building everywhere because it has worked for years. His company, which has been in business about a year, hopes to convince them that a little variety in design can benefit both the community and the company.
Joan Fowler Smith, a vice president of the Portland School of Art and a member of Uptown & Company, said other national companies have met success when they have veered away from their standard designs. She noted that McDonald's Corporation, at the bidding of the Freeport, Me., Town Council, renovated a historic house instead of razing it. Tourists to the town - which is home to L.L. Bean and scores of factory outlet stores - are so taken with the building that frequently they are seen snapping pictures of it.
Said Mr. Vieyra: ''I think standardization is a passing thing. It's certainly peaked. Perhaps the competition will encourage more diversity.''
That is certainly Mr. Holtwijk's desire. But it will be up to the C. N. Brown Company to make the idea reality. Under the contest rules, the company has no obligation to build the winning design or any other design submitted.
Jinger Duryea, the advertising manager for C. N. Brown Company, said the company would like to see the station blend in with the surrounding buildings. ''As long as it's not the Taj Mahal,'' he said, ''we would be able to spend the extra money needed to do that.''

PERSON: RIDDLE, LYN JOHN KANE (54%);

PUB-DATE: April 22, 1990

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1306 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS: Gas Station Design;
Nearly 400 Enter Contest in Portland

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: PORTLAND, ME.

 BODY:

Brown Company last September with the idea of sponsoring a national design competition to elicit fresh ideas for the company's newest gas station, he thought they would promptly turn him away. Portland revitalization groups, among them Uptown & Company, which Mr. Holtwijk serves as president, saw the situation as a chance to generate interest in improving that section of the city. The area has many historic properties, including the city's main post office and its largest park, both of which are on the National Register of Historic Places. Also, historically significant buildings, some in disrepair, surround the site, Mr. Holtwijk said.
''This gives a back-door impression to what should be the front door,'' said Mr. Holtwijk. ''It's a dilapidated station that probably hasn't had a coat of paint since the 1950's and the Portland peninsula is interesting because it has very few gas stations. We would like to encourage the owner to do some broader thinking.''
Thomas Collins, a spokesman for Mobil, said his company has been pleased to participate in the contest, but noted that the company's marketing needs must be considered in any station design.
''Our brand of service station, logo, look of the location is an integral part of our business,'' said Mr. Collins. ''Competition among service stations is incredibly intense'' in the country generally ''and we want our service stations to look a certain way and be a certain way.''
Mobil has spent millions of dollars rebuilding its 3,800 stations in the Pegasus 21 image. To get the 10,000 independent dealers who sell Mobil products to do likewise it offers them financial inducements - although it will not disclose what those inducements are.
MR. COLLINS said that it costs about $2 million to rebuild a service station and that the standard designs can be modified so they are right for every site and, often, quite striking in appearance. He cited as an example a new station Mobil built recently in Fairfax County, Va., about five miles from the company's United States' headquarters.
''It's a magnificent setting with trees, a car wash, electronic payment at the pump,'' he said.
Gas station architecture has gone through phases since the first pumps were installed outside the nation's general stores in the early 1900's, according to Daniel Vieyra, an architect and director of the historic preservation graduate program at Kent State University.
In ''Fill 'er Up,'' a book on the architectural history of gas stations (MacMillan Publishing Company, 1979, $7.95), Mr. Vieyra identifies the various types of stations that had been built, from ''the fantastic,'' which included buildings fashioned after airplanes, lighthouses, shells and castles, to ''the respectable,'' which included buildings that looked more like colonial homes or classical pavilions than a place to fuel a car. A Van Nuys, Calif., station built in 1935, was a reproduction of the elegant Los Angeles City Hall tower.
Also, some world-famous architects have designed gas stations. Among them were Frank Lloyd Wright, who believed the gas station would one day serve as a community gathering place, and Mies van der Rohe. Eliot Noyes, a New Canaan, Conn., architect who specialized in industrial design, created a prototype gas station for Mobil in 1964 featuring round canopies and round gas pumps that was used until the Pegasus 21 design came about in 1985.
Standardization of gas station design has been around as long as stations themselves have been, but it really caught on in the 1950's when large scale construction of interstate highways began, Mr. Vieyra said.
''Oil companies have to convince motorists who are in their own little worlds to stop,'' he said. ''When traveling was an adventure, the romantic, interesting shaped buildings were the way to do it. But then it got easy to get from one end of the country to another and motorists traveled many more miles at much faster speeds. The last thing they want is a surprise, and you communicate that with a simpler building that says it's the same as it is back home.''
The look-alike buildings erected by restaurants and hotels as well as oil companies have been detrimental to the look and feel of America's landscape, some architects and planners said. Said Mr. Kane: ''You get a series of independent buildings with no sense of context, continuum. That's what's lacking in our towns today. In successful cities, those things are not allowed.''
But Mr. Kane added that the major oil companies choose to build the same basic building everywhere because it has worked for years. His company, which has been in business about a year, hopes to convince them that variety in design can benefit both the community and the company.
Joan Fowler Smith, a vice president of the Portland School of Art and a member of Uptown & Company, said other national companies have met success when they have veered away from their standard designs. She noted that McDonald's Corporation, at the bidding of the Freeport, Me., Town Council, renovated a historic house instead of razing it. Tourists to the town - which is home to L.L. Bean and scores of factory outlet stores - are so taken with the building that frequently they are seen snapping pictures of it.
Said Mr. Vieyra: ''I think standardization is a passing thing. It's certainly peaked. Perhaps the competition will encourage more diversity.''
That is certainly Mr. Holtwijk's desire. But it will be up to the C. N. Brown Company to make the idea reality. Under the contest rules, the company has no obligation to build the winning design or any other design submitted.
Jinger Duryea, the advertising manager for C. N. Brown Company, said the company would like to see the station blend in with the surrounding buildings. ''As long as it's not the Taj Mahal,'' he said, ''we would be able to spend the extra money needed to do that.''

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1549 words

HEADLINE: Evicted By an Act of Congress

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
IN the five-room ranch house in Fairfield dotted with braided rugs and quilted pillows, Janet O'Donnell stands over the stove, turning pork chops, while her 3-year-old son, Patrick, curls up on the couch with his puppy. The plaque above the pantry door says, ''Home Sweet Home.'' Mrs. O'Donnell and her family moved into the house just three months ago, and now they are being evicted. Their landlord is the Pentagon.
The house is one of 28 in a cluster of military housing off Reef Road, and Mrs. O'Donnell, her husband, Thomas, a first boatsman for the Coast Guard, and their two children, along with the 27 other families that live there, must leave.
''It's enough of a struggle as it is,'' said Mrs. O'Donnell, who spoke with the soft drawl of her native North Carolina. ''What are we supposed to do? We certainly can't live in this area on what we make. But I guess they didn't think of that.'' On Wassell Lane in Westport, where 15 other military families are being forced out, a group of residents sat around Cheryl and Charles Cherico's kitchen table sipping coffee and wondering about their futures. After a long pause, Heather Israel, a 16-year-old junior at Staples High School, combed her fingers through her hair and let out a sigh. 
''My dad has given 19 1/2 years of his life to this country,'' said Heather, who, as the daughter of a military officer, has attended 14 different schools in the United States and Europe and hoped to graduate next year from Staples in Westport. ''And now the Government turns around and kicks us in the face.''
 
'Absolutely Floored'
Last month, the Army announced its plan to close and sell military-housing developments in several states, including 12 in Connecticut, this year. Residents of the two Fairfield County complexes say they remain shocked that they are being forced into one of the most expensive rental markets in the country on annual base salaries that average from $15,000 to $20,000.
''We were absolutely floored when we saw how much rents were in this area,'' said Joann Israel, Heather's mother. Mrs. Israel's husband, Steven, an Army sergeant major, earns around $1,600 a month as an R.O.T.C. instructor at the University of Bridgeport.
The family moved to Connecticut last year from El Paso, Tex., where they rented a house for $525 a month, Mrs. Israel said. In Westport, two-bedroom condominiums rent for $1,200 a month and up, said Patricia Abbott, the head of the town's Housing Authority.
In addition to the Fairfield County housing, the Army said it will sell the other houses it owns in the state. The action affects 239 families in Connecticut and another 165 in other parts of New England.
In addition to those in Fairfield and Westport, the affected families in Connecticut include 16 in Ansonia, 16 in Milford, 16 in Shelton, 16 in New Britain, 16 in East Windsor, 32 in Plainville, 16 in Middletown, 15 in Portland, 20 in Orange and 32 in Manchester.
Since the early 70's, families of low-paid military recruiters and other support-staff members have been allowed to live in the military housing complexes built in the East in the 1950's for the crews of Nike anti-aircraft missiles. The missiles had been intended to shoot down high-altitude Soviet bombers.
The announcement of plans to install Nike missiles on Bayberry Lane and North Avenue in Westport had upset residents who feared the military's presence would lower land prices and corrupt the town's young women. The ruckus inspired Max Shulman's 1957 novel, ''Rally Round the Flag Boys,'' which was made into a film starring Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward.
But by the early 1960's, the missile sites were abandoned after the Army announced that the Nikes would be replaced by anti-ballistic missiles. The Town of Westport later took ownership of the former missile site and uses the buildings for municipal offices.
The recent decision to shut down the military housing is the result of a law passed by Congress in 1988 ordering the closing of obsolete bases and the sale of some military property.
A Congressional report issued before the base-closing law was passed said that the cost of operating the Connecticut properties was double the Army's average for housing sites. Helen Mulligan, community affairs director for Fort Devens in Massachusetts, the parent base for the housing installations, said that operating costs for fiscal 1989 for the 12 Connecticut sites came to $891,182.
The law said the houses must first be offered to other branches of the military and to other Federal agencies. If no purchasers are found, then the properties will be offered to state and local agencies for use as low-income housing or shelters for the homeless.
The Coast Guard is negotiating with the Army to buy the Milford and Ansonia housing, said Roger Blake, a real estate specialist with the Army Corps of Engineers office in New York City, which is overseeing the properties in Connecticut. Those complexes each contain 16 units. Other agencies that had expressed an interest in the Army properties ''have pretty much dropped out,'' Mr. Blake said.
Most of the military personnel who live at the Fairfield and Westport sites work in recruiting stations in Stamford, Norwalk, Bridgeport and New Haven. Their average stay is around three years before they are transferred to other assignments, the residents said. Depending upon the region where they are stationed, those who live in civilian housing receive a monthly housing allowance of between $500 and $700.
 
Priorities Questioned
Members of the military families who gathered in the Chericos' home recently said they supported the Government's attempts to cut military spending. But they said they believed that Congress, in passing the base-closing law, should have considered the repercussions of displacing the residents.
''They think they're going to save money by doing this, but it's going to end up costing them more to raise allowances in order for people to live in this area,'' said Sergeant Cherico, who works at the Army recruiting station in Stamford.
''Their priorities are all wrong,'' said Barbara Stubbs, the wife of an Army sergeant. She recalled news reports of the Pentagon's unveiling of the Stealth fighter bomber, which cost $6 billion to develop and build.
''When I saw that black, ugly thing on TV, it made me so angry,'' Mrs. Stubbs said. ''Why in the devil couldn't they have taken that money and put it into housing?''
The Stubbses, who moved to Wassell Lane in early March, said they waited a year to get their home. Before that, the couple and their 6-year-old son lived in a two-bedroom condominium in Naugatuck for $750 a month plus utilities. Sergeant Stubbs, who works as a recruiter in Norwalk, has been in the Army for 14 years. He receives an annual base salary of $20,000.
''Naugatuck was an economic nightmare,'' said Mrs. Stubbs, who added that living in civilian housing made her feel isolated from of her friends among the military families. ''I couldn't wait to get down here,'' she said. ''We're all like one big family.''
 
Some Are Transferring
The evictions will fall hardest on the young families with children, said Myron Verville, an assistant operations officer for the Coast Guard, who lives with his wife, Nancy, in the Fairfield complex.
Some, like the Chericos, who will transfer to California in May, will not be affected by the eviction order. But for those who still have a year or more to serve in Connecticut, the future is uncertain.
''We put in for a transfer,'' said Mrs. Stubbs. ''How much good that will do we don't know. You pretty much live where they tell you to.''
Julie Rosson, a spokeswoman in Washington for United States Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Stamford, said the base-closing bill, for which the Congressman voted, was intended to ''reduce the Federal deficit and raise money for the Government.'' She said Mr. Shays had assumed that the closings involved major military bases. ''He was surprised they counted housing, too,'' Ms. Rosson said.
She added that Representative Shays has written to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney on behalf of the military families living in the Fairfield County sites, asking him to be sensitive to their needs.
Connecticut's Housing Commissioner, John Papandrea, said his department would like to help municipalities or nonprofit organizations buy the properties, if state and Federal officials can negotiate an acceptable price. ''We would like to turn it into affordable housing,'' he said. ''And I know the local governments would certainly be interested.''
Ms. Abbott, the director of the Westport Housing Authority, said that if the town could afford to buy the housing units for low-income families, military personnel would be qualified to live in the homes a moderate rents.
Standing in the front doorway of her Fairfield ranch house, Mrs. O'Donnell she said she will probably move with her two children back to North Carolina while her husband finishes his final two years of duty in Connecticut. Dozens of other military families, she added, are facing similiar futures.
''And they want to throw us out of here to put in the homeless,'' she said shaking her head. ''Well what the heck do they consider us?''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 22, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 7, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1562 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
The Joy of Five Characters All Talking at Once

BYLINE: By SUZANNE RUTA; Suzanne Ruta is the author of ''Stalin in the Bronx and Other Stories'' (Grove).

 BODY:
For years people told the novelist Jose Yglesias that he ought to write a play because his dialogue was so good. He even thought like a dramatist: ideas would come to him in the voices and accents of well-defined characters. This writer of Spanish and Cuban descent would find himself thinking, for example, in the voice of a snobbish New England matron.
But even in his 60's he hesitated. ''I felt and I still think it's true,'' he said recently in a Lower East Side coffee shop, ''that I dare not write plays because I have not been a theater worker, like Shakespeare or, up to the present day, Odets. But I've always kept up with it. The gossip of my life would be theater and movies'' - and the gossip of that morning, when he threw in anecdotes about Henry James, the W.P.A., Jules Feiffer, Howard da Silva, Lorenzo da Ponte, John Garfield and Brecht's actress-daughter, among others.
''And then,'' he continued his thought, ''I just reached a stage where I finished a novel eight years ago, where I said, 'Hey, I'd better have the chutzpah to do it.' I sat down and did a play. I did three plays.'' 
This trilogy drew on the life of his family and their hometown of Ybor City, a section of Tampa, where from the turn of the century poor Cuban, Spanish and Sicilian cigar factory workers made a rich world of their own. For Mr. Yglesias it has been an inexhaustible subject. ''None of us thought of ourselves as immigrants in Ybor City. This was our place. It was those barbarians, the Americans with hair on their teeth. They had no culture. You know, Caruso came to sing in Tampa; he was booked by the Latin colony. If you lived on the other side of town life was a desert. If you lived in Ybor City, it was full of life, political ideas, all sorts of things. You had all the benefits the New Deal tried to bring on in later years. Mutual aid societies. The two best hospitals in town. Daily newspapers.''
There were also the social clubs, Cuban and Spanish, with their ''great ballrooms'' and theaters, Mr. Yglesias remembers, where touring troupes from Spain and Mexico performed, and the local workers staged zarzuelas.
Ybor City was also a political education for him. Jose Marti, the hero of Cuban independence, gave his most important speech in Ybor City. Mr. Yglesias' grandfather shook his hand. ''My background was very class-conscious radical. You know how people say'' - he mimics - '' 'I vote Republican because my parents did'? I'm socialist because my parents were socialist.'' (In one reference work Mr. Yglesias lists his politics: ''I should like to overthrow capitalism.'') So there was never any question as to what he would write about in his plays. And , as he says, the mechanics of playwriting gave him little trouble.
The hard part for him, a much-published member of a family of writers - his wife, Helen, and his son Rafael are both prolific novelists - has been waiting to see a work produced. The Ybor City trilogy has had public readings at the Coconut Grove Playhouse in Florida and in-house readings by actors at the Public Theater and Circle Rep in New York. But Joseph Papp's plan to put on all three plays at the Public one day, ''with a long break like Maurice Evans's 'Hamlet,' '' fell through, Mr. Yglesias said, for lack of funds. He is philosophical. ''There's a profound lack of interest in Latins. We're not bankable. The audiences pay to see what interests them and the theatergoing public is not very Latin.''
Then he wrote a fourth play, ''New York 1937,'' an autobiographical comedy set in Manhattan's Washington Heights during the Depression. In the 30's, as the demand for cigars, a luxury item, dwindled and the factories in Ybor City shut down, the cigar makers came to New York looking for work. Mr. Yglesias himself arrived in 1937, fresh out of high school. ''It was like with the Puerto Ricans in the 50's,'' he said. ''You walked into any cafeteria and you went into the kitchen and you called, 'Anybody here from Ybor City?' and there was always somebody.'' At first he lived on 163d Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, near the family cigar store. ''We were the only Latins on the block.'' Most of the neighbors in those days, of course, were German-Jewish refugees from Hitler.
When Mr. Yglesias showed the director Charles Maryan, a fan of his since the Circle Rep readings, his new play about Tampa Latins in New York and their German-Jewish neighbors, Mr. Maryan took it to the Jewish Repertory Theater, where he had already directed several plays. ''New York 1937'' opens at the Jewish Rep on East 14th Street on Thursday, the first of Mr. Yglesias' plays to be staged anywhere. The theater's Israeli-born artistic director, Ran Avni, explained the connection: ''We do plays that have some aspect in them related to the Jewish experience. This play is about people escaping from other cities, other countries. Jews are still escaping from Europe.''
''New York 1937'' turns on a love affair, a pregnancy (involving a different couple), a labor strike and a bankruptcy, all in the space of three days. Something he couldn't do in his novels, Mr. Yglesias often has four or five characters talking at once. ''It's a play of non sequiturs,'' he said proudly. The pathos behind the comedy lies in the close parallel between the plight of political refugees from Hitler and the economic refugees from the Depression in Tampa. The two groups are reduced to shifty expedients to stay afloat. In both there are tensions between timid elders and their radical children. The Latins and the upper-middle-class Germans have been brought up to practice an exquisite courtesy, a definite handicap, as Mr. Yglesias remarked, in the rough and ready United States.
On the second day of rehearsals the sound engineer asked Mr. Yglesias if he had ever seen ''You Can't Take It With You.'' ''My secret was out,'' he said, enjoying the joke on himself. ''This play is my tribute to George S. Kaufman.'' In fact, ''You Can't Take It With You'' was the first play Mr. Yglesias saw in New York on arriving in 1937. He was working, he recalled, as a dishwasher at Hector's Cafeteria at 50th Street and Broadway. ''On my first day off, I went, and with my Southern accent'' - he mimicked himself at 18 with a Florida drawl - ''I asked, 'Do you have a seat for a dollar ten?' '' He saw all the plays on Broadway that summer at 55 cents a throw. The other big events in his life then were union organizing and demonstrations for the Spanish Republic. When he talks about the 30's, nostalgia creeps in. He looks back 50 years to the long-gone days of ''political trade unionism.'' ''You felt there was a future, that you could fight for it,'' he said. At one point in the play, a character sings two lines from ''The Peat Bog Soldiers,'' the German song about concentration camp inmates. When the sound engineer came up with a tape of the song recorded in Madrid in the late 30's by German Communists of the Thaelmann Brigade, Mr. Yglesias said he took it home and listened and cried. But there's nothing nostalgic about the play, he insists. ''It's entirely ironic. Everybody in the play is very prejudiced and the irony of it is that the one person who isn't, the least prejudiced person in the play, is German.''
Mr. Yglesias had written novels and memoirs about his family before he put them in his plays. Did the plays reveal anything new? ''I felt I had to know people in a quite different way,'' he said. ''I had to know their outwardness.'' Casting the play - when words became flesh - was the final revelation.
''In the young people we saw an enormous number of Latin actors who are terrific. One of the guys is wonderful. We cast him as soon as he said the first line. But you know what's hard to find? Latin actors past their mid-40's. To find Sofia'' - the aunt who holds the family together - ''was very difficult.'' Then they found Antonia Rey, a Cuban actress already established when she left her country in 1961. ''I don't have to explain the slighest nuance of her character to her. She's totally authentic.'' Other members of the extended Cuban family are played by a Chicano from California, a bilingual actress who works in English and French and an Italian from Washington Heights ''who has lived with a Latin.''
Will there be more plays to give work to some of that young Latin talent? ''I have a play I'm working on so dark and terrible I don't know why I should write it. I have one I call my WASP play, which takes place in Maine, with no Latins in it. It's the only thing I've written that has no Latins in it. Then I have a couple of others that deal with Tampa Latins. But nobody wants them. You get the feeling, why write another play?''
For solace he draws on his stock of theater gossip. ''It was 10 years before Shaw got a creditable production. And then, poor Chekhov, his first production had three days of rehearsal, the first of which was spent by the actors screaming at one another about who was upstaging whom.''
That morning, a Saturday, the 14th Street YMHA that houses the Jewish Rep's 100-seat theater, with a larger theater under construction, was empty and quiet. Other days, Mr. Yglesias said, it is full of people from the Lower East Side, including Latin immigrants, taking classes, using the gym - an appropriate setting, he feels, for his stage debut.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The author at a rehearsal of ''New York 1937,'' opening Thursday at the Jewish Rep, with Charles Maryan, the director, at rear. (The New York Times/Don Hogan Charles)

PERSON: RUTA, SUZANNE; YGLESIAS, JOSE JULES RALPH FEIFFER (56%); 



561 of 763 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 23, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1916 words

HEADLINE: Millions Join Battle for a Beloved Planet

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Two decades after the birth of the modern environmental movement, millions of people around the nation and the world renewed the call to arms for an endangered planet yesterday with an exuberant and bittersweet celebration of Earth Day 1990.
It was not quite The Day the Earth Stood Still, as an avalanche of publicity in recent weeks had prophesied, but by day's end organizers of the sequel to Earth Day 1970 said 200 million people in 140 nations had taken part in the largest grass-roots demonstration in history.
And a vast patchwork quilt of marches, rallies, concerts, festivals, street fairs and other events in 3,600 communities in the United States, Europe, Asia, Africa and North and South America seemed to bear them out.
''It's like earth's birthday,'' said Gordon Vestnys, a 25-year-old roofer, strolling at a fair overlooking San Francisco Bay and the Golden Gate Bridge. ''It's a gathering of people becoming more aware - and hopefully continuing after today with more consciousness and less Styrofoam.'' 
 
From Italy to Nepal
Diverse, contradictory, extravagant: the bewildering global panoply of happenings included a trash-picking trek up Mount Everest in Nepal, a 500-mile human chain across France, a gathering of space travelers at the United Nations, an ''eco-fair'' on a landfill island in Japan and a roadway ''lie-down'' by 5,000 people to protest car fumes in Italy.
In New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, San Francisco, Atlanta and cities and towns across this country there were tree-plantings, litter sweeps, recycling exhibits, workshops on wildlife and endangered species, fairs and a sunrise-to-sunset clamor for environmental morality that often mimicked the hoopla of a political campaign.
President Bush went fishing in the Florida Keys and used a telephone hookup to address thousands at an Earth Day rally on the Columbia River near George, Wash. Members of Congress, governors, mayors and hosts of other officials got on the bandwagon.
But it was not a day for politicans or corporations, though many of them embraced the common good with solemn pronouncements upon polluted air and oceans, fouled rivers and beaches, the perils of acid rain and tropical deforestation, toxic wastes and mountains of garbage.
Rather, it was a day for ordinary people and the meanings they chose to give it, a day to turn away from the memories of cold war and a hard focus on economic growth, to gather in vast throngs or quiet settings and express something about themselves and their world.
 
'Start Saving the Earth'
''It's really necessary to start saving the earth,'' said Kathy Bernstein, 60, at a festival in Chicago's Lincoln Park. ''I've got grandchildren, and it's necessary to imbue in them that you have to save things, not just be users.''
At a fair in the Playa Del Rey district of Los Angeles, Leslea Meyerhoff, 22, explained: ''I'm here because I think an individual can make a difference if they are aware of recycling and conservation. One way to let people know of the environmental crisis is through activties like this that promote public awareness.''
For some, like Philip C. Martinez, a drum-maker from the Taos Pueblo Indian Reservation in New Mexico, the urgency was greater. ''We're here to save our land,'' he said at a rally in Washington, D.C. ''They're trying to put both an airport and a nuclear waste dump near our reservation. Ten years ago, if we had said anything about it, nobody would have listened. Today, people care.''
 
The Weather Seemed to Approve
And in London, Andrew Lees of the British branch of Friends of the Earth said, ''If Earth Day does nothing else, it will give the clear message to politicians that millions of people are aware of the problems facing the earth and what needs to be done about it.''
It was a balmy spring day in most of the United States. The sun arched over the continent in a sky that was pristine blue in the east and resembled a summer sea flecked with whitecaps in much of the rest of the country. Not everyone, however, turned out because of the day's gentle beauty or a commitment to the environment.
''I'm here to see Bob Weir - I'll admit it,'' said Matt Herren, 18, at a blustery, rainy San Francisco Earth Day concert featuring the Grateful Dead star. And across the nation in Times Square, scene of an observance early yesterday, Jeffrey Aym, 21, of Morristown, N.J., acknowledged: ''We're here because we missed Woodstock,'' the peace movement's 1969 rock-and-drugs festival.
But most people said they had come out because they believed their presence would make a difference, and the turnouts in many communities appeared to underscore a new political commitment to the environment by Americans, one coinciding with the fading era of confrontation with Communism.
 
Evocations of the 1960's
Some said the environmental movement had more support than any since the antiwar and civil rights protests of the 1960's.
And, indeed, scenes reminiscent of the 1960's were abundant across the country. In New York, a huge throng -the police said 750,000, but it was like counting jelly beans in a jar - heard a concert in Central Park. In Washington, 125,000 people crowded onto the sun-drenched Capitol Mall: students in tie-dyed T-shirts and young professionals, older people who remembered the marches of a generation ago. Music and Frisbees floated up, and kites rode the breeze.
Many across the land felt no need to attend spectacular events. They stayed home or met in small groups to plant flowers or saplings, clean up roadsides and vacant lots or just talk about their neighorhoods or why the loss of the ozone layer or the destruction of the Brazilian rain forests were important.
It was possible for some, away from the crowds and the noise, to observe scenes of decorous beauty and be aware of the hidden pollution: sunlight shimmering like gold coins on a Connecticut lake choked with algae; vegetables banked at a stand in New York, an artist's palette of oranges, grapes and bright red tomatoes coated with pesticides; and the Hudson River, tainted with PCB's, flowing in stately procession like a doomed blue regiment moving South.
Such awareness was the essential point of the day, its organizers said. ''It is incumbent upon each of us to make environmentally sound choices throughout our daily lives,'' said Denis Hayes, the 45-year-old chairman of Earth Day 1990 and an organizer of the first celebration 20 years ago.
 
The Creation of a Coalition
''If we consider the environmental consequences of our purchases, our options in transportation, our investments, and our votes, we can send a powerful message to our public policymakers and our business leaders to do the same.''
Two years in the planning, Earth Day 1990 was orchestrated by a coalition of organizations - Greenpeace, the National Resources Defense Council, the Rainbow Coalition, the National Education Association, the Sierra Club, Planned Parenthood and many others - to evoke the idealism of Earth Day 1970, which launched the modern environmental movement.
Nevertheless, there was a widespread sense that this Earth Day had been sold to the American people with the same techniques employed by peddlers of soap and patriotism, but many also said that that was not a bad thing, given the urgency of the environmental cause.
''It feels mass-marketed,'' said Armando Martis, a Brooklyn dancer who was headed for Earth Day events in midtown Manhattan. ''But that's good because it gets the message out to a lot of people.''
Nearby, Rita Robbins said:''I don't think this is too commercial, although about 12 people have tried to sell me buttons - none of them biodegradable.''
''It's a lot of hype, but for a good thing,'' said Donald Braler, a 30-year-old New York film technician.
 
'Really Fast Start' Is Seen
There were other grumblings about companies with poor-to-disastrous pollution records that for weeks had run Earth Day advertisements expressing concern for the ecology, all without the blessing of Earth Day organizers, who said corporate America had wrapped itself in a green flag.
About 2,000 people were at the Washington Monument for Earthfest '90, an event sponsored by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. John Denver sang a song he had written for the event, ''The Flower That Shattered the Stone,'' and the E.P.A. Administrator, William K. Reilly, gave a speech about the meaning of Earth Day.
Afterward, he told reporters: ''It seems to me that the President has made a really fast start on the environment. I can't think of any 15-month period that produced as much by way of environemental initiatives, decisions and participation by a President.'' Later, he sat alone backstage, sipping a soda as the reporters streamed past him in pursuit of the actor Tom Cruise.
 
The Tribute in New York
In Central Park, a celebrity-studded concert entertained the crowd in the afternoon, and speakers included Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins, the union activist Caesar Chavez and others who talked of ecological responsibility.
But there were other settings in the park, less noticed, that gave meaning to the day: contrasts of young and old, of death and renewal - last year's faded grass beside a blaze of yellow daffodils; old people on benches, faces upturned to a warming sun, dreaming of long ago, and out on the lake, far from the exhausts of automobiles, a young boatman upright on the prow, floating like an ancient Chinese dragon.
On the Avenue of the Americas, huge throngs of people, at times all but immobilized by their own numbers, sampled a potpourri of arts and crafts, t-shirts and food, blaring rock music and exortations of environmental responsibility.
Much of it had the flavor of a 1960's antiwar festival: amid books on yoga and meditation were booths draped with hand-made jewelry, yogis orange-robed and cross-legged, people strolling hand-in-hand and vendors of vegetarian cuisine like mango nectar and ''Southern fried cauliflower.''
 
Recycling by the Homeless
The avenue was in shade most of the day between walls of soaring skyscrapers that symbolized corporate America - Exxon, the New York Hilton, CBS, Rockefeller Center, Paine Webber, Manufacturers Hanover Trust. The buildings were closed and the avenue, normally choked with vehicles, teemed with life. A stand sold biodegradable bags, recycled denim rugs and bumper stickers and signs that proclaimed: ''Acid Rain Is a Bad Trip,'' ''No Cholesterol'' and ''High Fiber.''
There were oases of beauty: baskets of pink petunias, red fuchsias, orange and purple impatiens, white peace lilies and banks of begonias, geraniums and renunculus. Nearby, a booth sold lovely bonsai: miniature windblown Japanese elms and junipers.
But it was big trees that preoccupied a man on a bandstand. ''Every ton of recycled paper will save 17 trees that give off precious oxygen for our planet,'' he said. He spoke, too, of recycling, but only a few people were actually doing it, as they do every day - the homeless, picking their way through the crowd, collecting cans and bottles.
Despite the vast numbers of people and events, there was something strangely serene about Earth Day. It hearkened back to the measured values of another age, when Americans raised a barn in an afternoon and took walks of an evening or gathered around a radio in a crisis to listen, not just to what they wanted to hear, but to a familiar voice talking sense.

HEADLINE: Bush Denies Any Deal With Iran for Release

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Administration officials said today that the release of the American hostage Robert Polhill was the result of months of messages to the Iranians that if they wanted better relations with Washington, they would have to unconditionally release all hostages.
''I'm not making gestures. I don't trade for hostages,'' President Bush said in Florida when asked whether the release would lead to some concrete expression of good will.
''This is a mission uncompleted,'' said the President, who spoke with Mr. Polhill and his wife, Feryal, by telephone. ''I do not have forgiveness in my heart as long as one American is held against his will.'' 
Apparently mindful of the Iran-contra affair, in which the Reagan Administration sought to trade arms for hostages, the Bush Administration emphasized that there would be no material trade-off for Mr. Polhill's freedom other than helping to pave the way for better relations between Iran and the United States. Officials said that messages to that effect had been conveyed to Iran through Japan and Switzerland.
 
What Iran Wants
It was difficult at this early stage to confirm this independently, since a specific reward theoretically might be reaped only after the Iranians arranged the release of the seven other Americans whose destiny they control.
Since the benefits that Iran is believed to want most from the United States - an end to the trade embargo, the unfreezing of Iranian assets and an end to Iran's isolation - are all things that successive Administrations have said they would address once all the hostages are freed, an explicit quid pro quo might not really be necessary.
Nevertheless, Administration officials believe that at least some Iranian leaders are hoping to bargain for some of these gains immediately, or to give the impression of a tradeoff for their own domestic political needs, using some of the seven Americans still being held by pro-Iranian kidnappers in Beirut as bait.
The initial demand by the Islamic Holy War For the Liberation of Palestine that Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs John Kelly come to Damascus to receive the freed hostage was seen by the Administration as a probe by the Iranians or their Lebanese surrogates to see whether the Americans could again be enticed into the hostage bazaar.
The release of Mr. Polhill, the officials said, was probably a probe to see how the United States would react -whether the hostage issue would once again dominate the headlines, whether the President would be pressured anew to negotiate and whether the Administration would make some compensatory gesture.
That was why Mr. Bush reacted in a low-key, stern and ungrateful manner - to signal the Iranians that until all of the American hostages are released, it will be as though none of them have been freed, the officials said. His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, issued a statement thanking Iran and Syria for their help in the release, but it could not have been more terse.
 
A Debate in Teheran
Administration officials also say they are trying to influence what they believe is a debate in Teheran. Some factions believe Iran can and should try to bargain for the other seven hostages, the officials said. Other factions, apparently led by President Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, feel that after the controversy stirred by the Iran-contra scandal, no deal is likely, and holding the remaining hostages only hurts Iran, the Administration officials said.
The officials said that Syria's role in the release was largely confined to logistics, although the United States Ambassador in Damascus, Edward Djerejian, openly praised Damascus. That the Syrians handled the release does not mean that they were responsible for it. Administration officials said the decision was made entirely in Iran.
But one American official said that as a payoff to Syria for its assistance to Iran in Lebanon, Teheran allowed Damascus to convey the good news to the Bush Administration. This was something the Syrians wanted to do because of their own interest in improving ties with Washington.
Administration officials said that the story of Mr. Polhill's release began with Mr. Rafsanjani's inauguration as President last August. Mr. Rafsanjani has long been associated with a faction of Iran's revolutionary elite that feels Iran's future lies in ending its isolation, restoring economic relations with the West and securing an end to the American trade embargo.
Since Mr. Rafsanjani took office, Administration officials say, his Government has been working through two channels, one public, the other private. It has privately made use of the Japanese Embassy and of the Swiss Embassy, which represents United States interests in Teheran, to send messages to the Bush Administration indicating that Iran wanted to improve ties and probing to see what it might expect to receive in return for the release of any hostages.
After he consolidated his rule, Mr. Rafsanjani began to condition the Iranian public to the notion of releasing some or all the hostages.
A series of editorials in the Teheran Times, viewed as Mr. Rafsanjani's mouthpiece, began arguing the case for releasing the hostages. On Feb. 22, the Teheran Times declared that ''Muslim forces should work to get the hostages free with no precondition.''

HEADLINE: Iran Reportedly Gave Weapons To Obtain U.S. Hostage Release

BYLINE: By IHSAN A. HIJAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 22

 BODY:
The Iranian Government gave Muslim fundamentalists in Lebanon weapons and financial assistance to persuade them to release American hostages, according to security officials here.
Some of the weapons, which included tanks, armored personnel carriers and multibarreled launchers, were on display here on Friday at parades staged by the Iranian-backed Party of God, said the officials, who spoke on condition they not be identified.
The deal was worked out during two trips to Lebanon in the last four weeks by Mahmoud Hashemi, the brother of President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, the officials said. Mahmoud Hashemi, head of the Middle East section in the Iranian Foreign Ministry, also held talks in Damascus with the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa. 
 
Circumstantial Evidence Cited
Arab diplomats here said they could not confirm the security officials' assertions, but they referred to what they called circumstantial evidence lending the reports credibility.
They recalled that in mid-March Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine - the faction that today freed Robert Polhill, one of its three American hostages - had issued a strongly worded statement rejecting appeals by Teheran and a senior Lebanese Shiite cleric for the unconditional release of the captives. The clandestine group had said it would kill the hostages if previously made demands were not met.
Then last week, the group said it would free an American captive in response to pleas from Iranian leaders. The hostage designated for release was Mr. Polhill; the two Americans still held by the group are Jesse Turner and Alann Steen.
In February, Teheran began to indicate that it favored freeing all 18 Westerners believed to be held by Lebanese Shiite organizations upholding the principles of the Iranian revolution of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The move to free the hostages appeared to have been sponsored by President Rafsanjani and the Foreign Ministry and was promoted by The Teheran Times, the English-language daily known for its closeness to the Iranian Foreign Ministry.
 
A Move of Conciliation
The gesture, coinciding with the 11th anniversary of Iran's revolution, came as President Rafsanjani was signaling the country's desire for better ties with the West and for Western help to shore up the Iranian economy, depressed after eight years of war with Iraq.
Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the Lebanese Shiite scholar called the spiritual mentor of the Party of God, demanded in an address in West Beirut that all foreign hostages be freed ''because their case is being exploited to tarnish the image of Islam and the Muslims.'' The cleric had just returned from Teheran, where he attended celebrations marking the revolution's anniversary.
At the beginning, discreet negotiations produced no results because the kidnappers insisted on something in return for freeing the hostages, security officials said.
Washington had rejected repeated calls by Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine to pressure Israel for the release of hundreds of Lebanese and Palestinian guerrillas in its jails. Israel said it would be prepared to discuss a swap to free three Israeli soldiers captured during action in southern Lebanon in the past four years.
 
Fundamentalists Look to Future
The Iranians helped create the Party of God in Lebanon eight years ago. But since the rise to power of President Rafsanjani, described as a pragmatist, and the decline of militants inside the Iranian Government, Lebanese fundamentalists have become increasingly worried about their future.
Ali Akbar Mohtashemi lost his position as Iran's Interior Minister in August 1989, when President Rafsanjani formed his Cabinet. Mr. Mohtashemi, now a member of the Iranian Parliament, was instrumental in channeling Iranian assistance to the Party of God in Lebanon for several years. In a recent speech, he urged the Lebanese kidnappers to hold on to the hostages.
Mass rallies and military parades staged by the Party of God on Friday showed that the fundamentalists have gained in strength and will probably try to gain the upper hand with Lebanon's one million Shiites.
Street gunfights last week in West Beirut with rival Shiite militia of the Amal movement indicated that the Party of God has infiltrated many residential quarters in the predominantly Muslim part of town.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
NEW YORK RALLY BACKS LITHUANIA

 BODY:
More than 1,000 demonstrators waving Lithuanian flags rallied outside the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday to protest economic measures taken against Lithuania by the Soviet Government and to call on the United States to recognize the Baltic republic's independence.
After hearing several speakers denounce President Bush for his cautious approach to the increasingly tense situation in Lithuania, the protesters marched down Fifth Avenue to St. Patrick's Cathedral for a special mass attended by Bishop Thomas Vose Daily, the newly installed Bishop of Brooklyn. 
The crowd was orderly but vocal, chanting, ''Don't sell us out!'' On Fifth Avenue many strollers joined in, and many others signed letters to Mr. Bush, asking him to recognize the Lithuanian government and take economic and political measures against Moscow.
Several women wore traditional hand-woven skirts and aprons, adding a festive air to the procession.
 
D'Amato Cites Summit Talks
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who recently was turned back from the Lithuanian border by Soviet guards who would not recognize the visa issued by Lithuania, suggested using the coming summit meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush to apply pressure on Moscow to end the embargo.
Angela K. Nelsas, president of the California-based Baltic American Freedom League, said that in a meeting on Wednesday, the President reiterated his concern that any strong show of support for Lithuania by the United States might hamper President Gorbachev's efforts to change the Soviet political and economic system.
''Mr. Bush right now is not being a spokesman for the ideals this country was built on - freedom, democracy and self-determination,'' she said.

HEADLINE: When Plant Shuts Down, Retraining Laid-Off Workers Is Toughest Job Yet

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CICERO, Ill.

 BODY:
Spread over miles of fissured asphalt and chain-link fences, blocks beyond the western edge of Chicago, lie the carcasses of once mighty factories.
On March 2, yet another factory expired, one where the General Electric Company made refrigerators. It is making them instead in Decatur, Ala., where it pays nonunion workers $9.50 an hour, $4 less than it paid here, helping it to keep up with its competitors.
One of the 1,200 people to lose a job here is Freddie Anderson, 42 years old, divorced and the father of two. He worked at the plant since he finished high school and a stint in the Navy. One day this week Mr. Anderson joined a resume-writing class in a cheery, white-walled room that has been carved into G.E.'s dingy brick administration building. 
 
Ingredients of a Resume
''A resume is like baking a cake,'' one of the five counselors, Melvin Williams, told the class. ''The same ingredients almost always go into a resume - like name, address, phone number, job objective, job at G.E.''
At the outplacement center here, the American factory worker confronts the new world of work in the starkest terms possible. Better production technology and tougher competition, much of it against foreign industries that pay workers far less than the men and women here were paid, have driven down the earning power of people who for years made a good living. Good pay now comes with versatility and good education, and few of these people have either.
''That work force is as dysfunctional as you can get,'' Roberts T. Jones, Assistant Secretary of Labor for Employment and Training, said of the G.E. plant. ''You have the anomaly of people coming out of a long successful job history and not able to meet entry-level requirements of other jobs. It's a worst-case model. If you can succeed there, you have a shot at succeeding at most other plants.''
General Electric voluntarily set up the Cicero center, with a staff of 14, by using $1.3 million of its own and $2.7 million from the Department of Labor.
Policy makers and labor experts call retraining the antidote to the human dislocations that accompany the demise of old industries. But so far the results have been mixed.
 
His Prospects Are Cloudy
Mr. Anderson had one of the better jobs at the plant, one involving skill, variety and the opportunity to make judgments. But even his prospects are not especially bright.
''My last job was repairman,'' he said. ''I inspected the cases for dents, scratches, paint defects before final assembly. I repaired them. It was a very good job. I loved it.''
He said he had found only two other jobs so far - one driving a school bus four hours a day for $8 an hour, the other as a $5-an-hour, three-month temporary worker at the United States Postal Service, after which he can apply for an $11-an-hour job if one is available. Even then, he would have to submit to a long written test, a task he has never faced.
Most of the workers are relatively old and unskilled. They have little formal education, and 56 percent are black and 24 percent are Hispanic -groups that have had a tougher time finding good jobs than whites.
 
Many Problems, Few Successes
''We have Hispanics who have never had to communicate in English,'' said Claudia D. Brennan, co-director of the program. She said many, including some of the 50 percent who are high school graduates, function at a fifth- or sixth-grade level.
Drawing firm conclusions about the Cicero program is not possible yet. The program was established two years ago but was slow getting off the ground and has one more year to run. Problems have cropped up - some because of the attitudes of the workers, some because of company practices, some because of union hostility.
By G.E.'s own measure of success -placing 85 percent of the workers in jobs that pay at least 75 percent of their G.E. wage - the company has a long way to go. Ms. Brennan, whom the company hired to work with the union's co-director, Salvador Diaz, said 187 people had found other jobs through March. But 148 of them were not really retrained; they transferred to Decatur and other G.E. plants at hourly wages of $9 to $12, with all their old benefits.
But such opportunities with the company have been largely exhausted now. The 39 others who have found new jobs are mostly in manufacturing, jobs that pay an average of $8.50 an hour, or 63 percent of their old wage. About 225 of the plant's 1,200 workers, those over 55 with at least 25 years with the company, have retired with pensions and other benefits. #750 Still Need Jobs And about 250 have been shifted to the one G.E. plant here, making heating coils for electric stoves and heating elements for dishwashers. But those workers simply bumped out others who had less seniority, forcing layoffs down the line.
About 750 people still need jobs, many more at this point than the company first expected.
Because fewer workers than expected have participated in the full retraining program, G.E. advised the Labor Department some months ago to reduce the $4.7 million three-year subsidy it initially offered to the current $2.7 million.
Still, the dislocated workers here have an edge on most others. Many companies provide no retraining at all, leaving their former employees to fend for themselves or seek help through community programs.
 
'One of the Best' in Retraining
General Electric, along with the nation's auto makers, is among the most experienced corporate retrainers in the United States. The company has set up programs to help the more than 100,000 workers it has laid off over the last decade.
''We don't like closings,'' said William H. Bywater, president of the International Union of Electronic Workers, G.E.'s biggest union. But in retraining, he said, G.E. is ''one of the best.''
In Cicero's case, G.E. went a step further than usual. It gave its workers two and a half years' notice of the closing, far longer than it or other companies had allowed at other plants.
General Electric also provides a week's pay for each year of work; many who have worked at G.E. for 20 years or more have received checks exceeding $10,000.
The company contributes $750 to $1,500 to help workers move to jobs at other G.E. plants. It also lets them keep most of their benefits for a year after they are laid off, and they can apply for up to $7,500 for tuition reimbursement at any time over five years. Moreover, G.E.'s outplacement center is unusually well equipped to lead workers through the often intimidating paces of finding new jobs.
Clifton Collins, 53, who was a punch press operator and forklift driver, is an 18-year veteran who seems to be one of the luckier candidates. He is considering a job that would pay $17.50 an hour. But he is fearful for his health because the job is in asbestos removal.
''They will send me to school to learn safety precautions and get a license,'' he said. ''But it's dangerous work.'' He said he had no other options yet. Adult Education and Job Training The outplacement center provides adult education courses in math, in English as a second language and in preparing for a high school diploma. It provides job-hunting assistance, with help in conducting interviews, filling out applications, writing resumes and negotiating on the telephone.
It also steers workers into on-the-job training with other employers - a dimension of the center's work for which the staff had high hopes. Employers who find a worker qualified in most respects but lacking a skill agree to take him on and teach him the skill. In return, the center gives the employer half the worker's wages until the worker is fully trained, up to 26 weeks.
''It's the best way to get employees hired,'' Ms. Brennan said. But few workers sought such jobs in the first two years of the program. About 200 took the adult education and job placement courses, but few were willing to take the final step and commit themselves to another job.
One reason workers procrastinated was psychological. ''Most of the people said two years is too far away,'' said Mr. Diaz, 60, who worked at the plant for 33 years before he was appointed co-director of the center. ''We tried our best to motivate people, but we didn't start getting numbers of them coming in until six months ago.''
 
Benefits Delayed Job Searches
Inadvertently in some ways, the company encouraged workers to postpone their search. Under a collective bargaining agreement with the union, Local 571 of the Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, G.E. paid a $900 bonus to everyone who was still working as of last June.
The company's benefit plans are an obstacle, too. By working through the end of last year, for example, workers could collect more vacation pay than they could by leaving early. And G.E.'s separation pay, on top of 26 weeks of Government unemployment benefits, came to $9.30 an hour for the average worker - more than the $8.50 that workers on average are getting in jobs outside General Electric.
For all its experience in retraining, General Electric has learned a few things from its experience in Cicero.
''We've been slowed down by our own benefits,'' said Thomas J. Olander, director of employee and community relations at the plant. ''It behooves people to wait until the very end.''

(The New York Times/Jonathan Kirn)

HEADLINE: Property Taxes Should Be Passed Along to Regulated Rents Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Why Tax Apartment Dwellers More?'' (editorial, April 5) gives the misconception that all New York City residential landlords can pass along part of their real-estate tax increases to tenants. Landlords of rent-stabilized and rent-controlled buildings cannot pass even a penny of real-estate tax increases to residential tenants. 
This is especially scary for small-property owners subject to rent regulations who, in view of Mayor David N. Dinkins's threat to raise property taxes to reduce the city's budget deficit, are forced to subsidize their tenants' ever-growing share of our city's economic burden.
A residential real-estate-tax escalation that reflects a percentage of the actual increase in a building's real-estate taxes, should be added to all regulated residential rents, as for commercial leases.
If such a tax escalation is adopted at the next rent-stabilization-guidelines hearing, and tens of thousands of residential tenants are affected by real-estate-tax increases, the Mayor will be under even greater pressure from both landlord and tenant groups to trim the massive waste and mismanagement in city government, rather than raise real estate taxes again.
 
LAURENCE GUTTMAN
 New York, April 5, 1990
The writer is a real estate developer.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
World to Vilnius: Suffer

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When an individual becomes a dissident, he or she is seen by the outside world as a hero: a Sakharov or Mandela stirs the conscience of the world. But when a captive nation becomes a dissident, its resistance to oppression becomes an inconvenience to mankind; it is accused of being an impediment to the Big Picture, a threat to worshipers of the idol of Stability.
That is why European industrialists who insisted that the Kremlin would never use its natural-gas pipeline as a weapon are now so silent at the cutoff to Lithuania. (No mask can be worn to protect civilians against the cutoff of natural gas.) That is why polls say American public opinion treats the reach for independence by the dissident nation to be an annoyance, preferring 2 to 1 that our President continue his policy of paying lip service to the Lithuanian assertion of longstanding independence - while supporting Gorbachev and protecting the summit meeting. 
We have been sold a bill of goods. We are told that we have a great stake in the personal success of Mr. Gorbachev; that his success depends on his absolute control of the Kremlin; and that he would lose control to some neo-Stalinist faction if his freeing of Central European nations extended to the three Baltic republics which were grabbed a few years earlier.
The opposite is true. Our interest in Mr. Gorbachev is limited to his ability to withdraw troops from illegally seized nations and to speed the transition to political and economic freedom; his motive to make these reforms is rooted in the fear of the failed system's impending collapse; and by not putting a price on his reversion to command control, we remove a central impetus for the growth of democracy.
Does pressing Mr. Gorbachev to acknowledge the independence of the Baltic states really jeopardize, as White House backgrounders argue, our greater objective of troop withdrawal and missile reduction?
A minority think not. We believe that the West's toleration of his decision to make economic war on a conquered nation that now dares to assert its freedom is not merely morally wrong, but geopolitically unsound. It breaks the democratic momentum. Our failure to denounce the threat of ''presidential rule'' - the euphemism for dictatorship - bolsters the imperious inclinations of the Soviet strongman and undermines sensibly radical reformers.
But Mr. Bush, following isolationist public opinion in the U.S., and under the cloak of ''consultation'' with European leaders eager to abandon the idea of collective security, is temporizing. The great symbolic dish of the Bush White House kitchen has become the waffle.
In light of this tepid support, what should besieged Lithuanians do?
Negotiating in a vacuum is a non-starter. Offering concessions when the other side answers only with a blockade is taken as weakness rather than reasonableness. The cap of independence has been tossed over the wall; the declaration cannot be undeclared without abject surrender.
Counting on the West for help at the start is another mistake. Our nervous doves (worried about nuclear shakiness of a disintegrating Soviet Union) combine with our ultra-pragmatists (worried about a future charge of ''Who lost Gorbachev?'') to say: America has other fish to fry.
Armed revolt is not an option: as one Balt told me, ''there are no hills here -we cannot do an Afghanistan.''
What's left? Suffering and lamentation; sustained resistance and dramatically expressed resentment; refusal to be starved into submission.
Public suffering can be a powerful force, as individual dissidents have demonstrated. Freedom never comes easily, and rarely does it come from outside.
To prick the conscience of the world, Lithuanians will have to do more than line up cars at gas stations. They will have to parade their jobless, show the ravages of Gorbachev's blockade on their children, passively torment their oppressors and become the grim example of the failure of glasnost.
Moscow's no-gas attack is effective, as is occupiers' brutality, the takeover of printing plants and the imposition of a quisling prosecutor.
But relentless resistance in the cause of long-denied independence begets the shame of bystanders; growing shame changes public opinion; and rising outrage could force politicians to offer recognition, a sealift, serious countervailing economic pressure.
Mr. Gorbachev will set the Baltic nations free only if he must. The Balts, by their courage and willingness to suffer, can shame the world into making sure he must.

HEADLINE: A Warning to Would-Be Federal Judges

BYLINE: By Howard M. Metzenbaum; Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, is a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Imagine you are a lawyer looking to join a private club in your community, one known to be a good place to expand your business and professional opportunities. You meet all the necessary qualifications for membership except one: You are a woman and the club bars women.
Now imagine that a male member of this club is nominated to be a Federal judge. The nominee - who, as a judge, will hear sex discrimination cases - has never been particularly troubled by the club's exclusion of women and has never tried to change its discriminatory by-laws. Should this lawyer be confirmed as a judge by the Senate Judiciary Committee? 
A nominee's membership in a club that discriminates on the basis of race, sex, religion or ethnicity is a matter of serious concern for the Senate Judiciary Committee. In the words of former President Reagan's Solicitor General, Charles Fried: ''The committee has the right to insist that a nominee . . . display some personal devotion to the principles of fairness and equal dignity which lie behind the law.''
Membership in a discriminatory club raises serious questions about a nominee's personal commitment to identifying and eliminating discrimination. Such membership also raises doubts about the nominee's understanding of the economic harm suffered by those who are excluded. Let's face it: Contacts are made and business is conducted at these clubs. If you're locked out because you're female, black or Jewish, you're denied opportunities to get ahead.
A nominee's membership in a discriminatory club also undermines the public's confidence in the judiciary. A party or attorney in a discrimination case has every right to doubt the impartiality of a decision rendered by a judge who finds nothing wrong with belonging to a discriminatory club.
There is a growing consensus among members of the Judiciary Committee that it is highly improper for a judge or a senior Justice Department official to belong to a discriminatory club. This view is echoed by the American Bar Association, whose code of judicial conduct says: ''It is inappropriate for a judge to hold membership in any organization that practices invidious discrimination on the basis of race, sex, religion or national origin.''
Unfortunately, there is not agreement regarding how to assess a nominee who resigns from such a club shortly after - or on the eve of -being nominated by the President. For many, resignation from a discriminatory club suffices to eliminate the concerns raised by the membership.
That is not enough. A nominee who blithely supports a private club's exclusionary policies, but then resigns in order to become a judge, does not display the kind of ''personal devotion'' to fairness and equal dignity referred to by Mr. Fried.
If a nominee fails to grasp the harm caused by the discriminatory policies of a private club that enhances its members' business and professional opportunities, then I have to wonder about his understanding of, and commitment to, equal justice and the principles underlying our civil rights laws.
I do not believe that a nominee should be permitted to swap his membership in a discriminatory club, one that has denied women or other minorities business and professional opportunities that he has enjoyed, for a seat on the Federal bench. Our judicial system should demand more than that.
On the other hand, a nominee who is a member of a discriminatory club but takes a leadership role in trying to change its policies does show sensitivity to fairness and equal justice concerns. I have voted in favor of nominees who, before being nominated, took visible and active steps to change a discriminatory club's policies.
The Senate Judiciary Committee, the President and the American Bar Association must send a clear message to all lawyers who aspire to be Federal judges: Starting now, you've either got to resign from any discriminatory club or start changing the club's policies. Fairness and equal justice demand nothing less.
