HEADLINE: Tone Is Mild at U.N. Session for Third World Aid

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 23

 BODY:
Representatives of two principal third world organizations pledged today to follow development policies that place greater emphasis on individual initiative, and also called for more aid from the industrial world.
Speaking for the Group of 77, as the developing world is called at the United Nations, Bolivia's Planning Minister, Enrique Garcia, urged a transition from ''societies that overemphasize centralism and state paternalism'' to those where ''individual initiative becomes the driving force of modernization and change.''
In another speech at the opening of a special General Assembly session on third world development, Foreign Minister Budimir Loncar of Yugoslavia disparaged past calls for a new international economic order that would redistribute wealth in its favor. Mr. Loncar, speaking for the group of nations espousing nonalignment, called the idea ''unrealistic'' and said that ''human freedom'' is the ''the supreme value of this decade.'' 
But both third world leaders said that for a more capitalistic approach to development to succeed, the industrial world should do more to ease their debt burden, reduce interest rates, increase financial assistance and try to stabilize falling prices of raw materials.
The two keynote speeches came at the opening of the General Assembly session to discuss revitalizing third world development. The speeches were conciliatory in tone and reflected an approach to development similar to that of the Western world, as well as the turn away from socialist doctrines, a turn implicit in the political changes under way in Eastern Europe.
The goal of the weeklong Assembly meeting, which is being attended by about 90 Cabinet ministers, is to set development goals and priorities for the third world in the coming decade and spell out the industrial world's contribution to their attainment.
The Bush Administration came close to boycotting the session, arguing that the United Nations has no role in promoting economic development, which it says is the task of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
At a news conference last week, the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, said the decision to take part was made ''with a lot of skepticism and a lot of reluctance'' because such debates were ''a locus for conflict rather than harmony.''
Today's opening speeches were a far cry from the appeals for a radical redistribution of the world's wealth that its representatives made at the 1975 meeting and on many occasions since at the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Iran's Goals With U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Iran has various economic, political and military interests that could benefit from improved relations with the United States if Teheran uses its influence to help gain the release of American hostages in Lebanon, experts on the region said today.
Iran would like to recover assets that were frozen in the United States a decade ago and are now the subject of complex proceedings before a special tribunal at The Hague. These assets totaled nearly $10 billion in 1981, but most of the money has been paid out to Americans or returned to Iran, so perhaps $1 billion remains in various accounts. 
In addition, Iran claims 3,800 items of military equipment in the United States. Iran says that it has paid for the hardware and that it is worth $12 billion, but the United States says the value is much lower.
Iran also wants the United States and other Western countries to put pressure on Iraq to negotiate an end to their border dispute and an exchange of prisoners of war.
Iran agreed to a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war in July 1988, but the United Nations has been unable to mediate follow-up agreements.
Shaul Bakhash, a professor of history at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., said, ''Iran needs to show enough stability so European countries are willing to invest on a long-term basis.''
The United States could help Teheran obtain foreign credits and investment by ending its effort to isolate Iran economically.
Meanwhile, the Bush Administration continued to press for the release of the remaining hostages while ruling out any negotiations on the subject.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, ''The United States Government continues to probe all sources of information concerning the hostages.''
''We are not going to trade for our hostages, however, or make deals,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
LITHUANIA ACTION BY BUSH EXPECTED

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
After meeting with members of Congress on Tuesday, President Bush is expected to announce some limited American actions in response to the Soviet Union's economic crackdown in Lithuania, Administration officials said tonight.
The officials declined to say specifically what Mr. Bush would do, but the options he has been considering include the suspension of one or more of the five sets of trade and commercial negotiations now under way with the Soviet Union.
''We will be taking action, mostly in the economic domain, that will express U.S. displeasure and U.S. concern about Soviet behavior in Lithuania,'' an official said.
Administration officials said the actions contemplated by the United States were not intended to interfere with arms control negotiations or with the schedule for the next Soviet-American summit meeting, which is scheduled to begin late in May. 
 
Allies Are Consulted
The Administration had been delaying any retaliation for the Soviet Union's economic moves against the Lithuanians for as long as possible, hoping the Baltic crisis would resolve itself.
But as the Kremlin's sanctions tightened late last week, the United States began a round of consultations with its allies to make certain it had backing for whatever steps it might take.
The Administration also wanted to make sure it had the support of Congressional leaders before acting, the official said.
Officials said there has been some reluctance in the Adminstration to take action against the Soviet Union over Lithuania out of concern that it might interfere with the progress made over the last year or so in Soviet-American relations and disrupt efforts to forge a new political order in Eastern Europe.
But pressure has steadily built on Mr. Bush to respond in some way as Soviet actions in the Baltic republic have grown increasingly harsh. Mr. Bush discussed his options with President Francois Mitterrand of France last week at a meeting in Florida and with other Western leaders in telephone conversations and other diplomatic contacts over the weekend.
 
Signs of 'Flexibility'
Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said today that Mr. Bush would meet with Congressional leaders on Tuesday morning in the White House to discuss the Lithuanian situation. ''I would not expect any announcement on the courses of action from us before that point,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
Mr. Fitzwater declined to say what, if anything, the White House would do in response. ''The final decisions by the President have not been made,'' he said. Mr. Fitzwater said the United States saw encouraging signs of ''flexibility'' in the most recent Soviet statements on Lithuania.
Two of the negotiations that could be affected by sanctions against the Soviet Union - on civil aviation and on trade - are scheduled to resume on Tuesday. Officials said American negotiators had been instructed to proceed with both sets of talks.
Using the trade talks as leverage against the Soviet Union could be particularly effective since they are a precursor to the granting of favorable tariff arrangements to the Soviet Union and an important milestone in Moscow's efforts to improve ties with the West.
 
Other Talks Under Way
The United States and the Soviet Union are also engaged in talks on an investment treaty, on the extension of import-export credits to Moscow, on tax agreements and on other commerical arrangements that Mr. Bush proposed last December in Malta during his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
The two countries also recently completed negotiations on a new five-year grain agreement that was expected to be signed at the next meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, which is scheduled to be held in Washington from May 30 to June 3.
Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter, asked about possible sanctions during a luncheon with agriculture writers, ruled out using the grain pact with Moscow as leverage in the Lithuanian crisis.
''I don't believe there's any chance whatsoever of a grain embargo being used in that situation or in any other situation,'' Mr. Yeutter said.
At his daily news briefing today, Mr. Fitzwater was asked about reports from Moscow that quoted a Kremlin spokesman, Arkady Maslennikov, as saying the Soviet Government would not insist on an outright repeal of Lithuanian's declaration of independence. Mr. Maslennikov suggested that the Lithuanians could ''freeze'' their proclamation of independence, perhaps for a period of two years.
Mr. Fitzwater said: ''The statements this morning do appear to show some flexibility. We are hopeful that that's the case.''
He said the statements were ''being factored in'' as Mr. Bush contemplates his response to Moscow's latest moves in Lithuania.

Kazimiera prunskiene, the Lithuanian Prime Minister, who received flowers yesterday from supporters at a rally in Stockholm, announced plans to begin offshore oil exploration. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Soviet Experts Say Their Economy Is Worse Than U.S. Has Estimated

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Several senior Soviet economists said here today that the United States had consistently overestimated the size of the Soviet economy and understated Soviet military spending.
The actual condition of the Soviet economy is worse than indicated by data from either the Kremlin or the Central Intelligence Agency, the economists said.
They offered their views after a three-day conference here with scholars from American universities and analysts from the Central Intelligence Agency.
The agency said Friday that the Soviet gross national product was about half that of the United States. The G.N.P., which measures the total output of goods and services, was $5,200 billion for the United States last year. 
Viktor Belkin, a prominent economist from the Soviet Academy of Sciences, said Soviet output was no more than 28 percent of the American G.N.P. and might be substantially less. #20 Percent Military Share Likewise, Oleg T. Bogomolov, an economist who serves in the Congress of People's Deputies, said Soviet military spending might account for 20 percent to 25 percent of Soviet G.N.P., as against a C.I.A. estimate of 15 percent to 17 percent.
In the spirit of glasnost, the increased openness under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, another Soviet economist and legislator, Vladimir Tikhonov, attacked the official Soviet data on agriculture. The amounts of Soviet fruit and vegetables lost through waste and inefficiency far exceed the official Soviet estimates, he said.
Soviet agricultural output is actually about 55 percent of the American output, rather than the 85 percent reported by the State Statistical Committee of the Soviet Union, he said, adding, ''One cannot trust the figures given by the state committee.''
Of the 90 million tons of potatoes harvested by Soviet farmers, only 24 million get to consumers because of transportation and storage problems, Mr. Tikhonov said.
At the conference, sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute, the C.I.A. found itself increasingly isolated as Soviet economists joined a chorus of American skeptics who have for years been saying that the agency underestimated Soviet military outlays. Many, but not all, of the skeptics are considered politically conservative.
American officials said the data offered by the Soviet economists helped explain why the burden of military spending was becoming unbearable for the Soviets and why Moscow had been willing to make concessions in recent arms control talks.
 
'Can't Find Them Ourselves'
Mr. Bogomolov said the Soviets had difficulty figuring out precisely how much they spent on their armed forces. ''For decades,'' he said, ''we assiduously concealed these expenditures. Now we can't find them ourselves.'' In an interview, Mr. Bogomolov said, ''The C.I.A. figures are not correct.'' But the information available from the Soviet Government is ''insufficient to determine the magnitude of the underestimate,'' he said.
President Gorbachev announced in May that Soviet military spending totaled 77.3 billion rubles in 1989. The C.I.A. estimated that the actual amount in 1988 was 135 billion to 165 billion rubles; it has not disclosed its estimate for 1989.
Igor Birman, a Soviet emigre and economist who is president of the Foundation for Soviet Studies, in Silver Spring, Md., said Soviet military spending was probably close to 200 billion rubles this year. Mr. Bogomolov endorsed that suggestion, and a committee of the Soviet Parliament, investigating the question, came up with a similar estimate.
Mr. Bogomolov said ''the economic situation in our country does not allow any alternative'' to reducing military expenditures.
Reasons for the numerical disparities include disagreements over the purchasing power of the ruble and uncertainties about the prices and quantities of goods and services produced in the Soviet Union.
 
Agency Defends Procedures
James Noren, an economist who has worked at the C.I.A. for more than 30 years, generally defended the procedures used by the agency to estimate military spending and G.N.P. for the Soviet Union. The agency computes total military spending by estimating costs for a series of components, or ''building blocks,'' including weapon systems, military pay and allowances, repairs, research and development and construction.
C.I.A. officials at the conference were conciliatory, offering to work with their critics in America and the Soviet Union to produce better measures of Soviet military spending and G.N.P.
Nicholas N. Eberstadt, the chairman of the conference, said: ''Two years ago a meeting of this kind would have been absolutely unthinkable. After this meeting, it was very clear to the U.S. Government people that there is room for improvement in their estimates of the Soviet economy.''
As an indication that their figures were approximately correct, C.I.A. officials noted that some people in the United States criticized their estimates of Soviet military spending as too high. The critics include Franklyn D. Holzman, a professor of economics at Tufts University, who contends that the agency has ''systematically tended to overstate Soviet military expenditures.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vladimir Tikhonov, left, and Viktor Belkin, Soviet economists, said yesterday that the condition of the Soviet economy is worse than indicated by data from the Kremlin or the Central Intelligence Agency. (The New York Times/Paul Hosefros)

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 680 words

HEADLINE: DECISION IS URGED ON SOCIAL SECURITY

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Four months after Senator Daniel P. Moynihan of New York lobbed a political grenade into the Congressional budget process by suggesting a cut in Social Security taxes, his Democratic colleagues are being prodded to take a stand.
Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat, plans to compel the Senate Budget Committee to vote on the measure. The committee will begin drafting its version of the 1991 budget on Tuesday.
''My purpose is to get to truth in budgeting,'' Mr. Hollings said today. ''I'm trying to force a political crisis in Washington to avoid having a real crisis in the economy.'' 
That was Mr. Moynihan's purpose back in December, when he proposed the tax cut as a way to force Congress to tackle what he viewed as a serious problem in the management of the Social Security trust funds. He said the enormous surpluses in the funds were being used to offset current spending and were masking the true size of the Federal budget deficit, when their purpose was to finance Social Security benefits for workers who will retire in the early 21st century.
 
Moynihan's Solution
Mr. Moynihan said the solution was to stop treating Social Security funds as though they were general tax revenues. To insure that they were not spent for other programs, he said the payroll tax increases that took effect in January should be rolled back and those scheduled for future years should be canceled.
Democratic Congressional leaders said they would study Mr. Moynihan's suggestion. The policy problems were enormous, they said. It was one thing to cut Social Security taxes, but where would they find the billions of dollars to offset the resulting explosion in the Federal deficit?
But Democrats outside of Congress saw a political bonanza, a way to wrest the high ground on the tax issue from President Bush and underscore the differences between Democrats and Republicans. Let the President argue for his capital gains tax cut that would benefit primarily the wealthiest taxpayers, the Democratic strategists reasoned; Democrats could now favor a tax cut that would benefit mainly working people.
The Democratic National Committee and the more conservative Democratic Leadership Council last month endorsed Mr. Moynihan's proposal.
 
Moynihan Is Delighted
''This was supposed to have disappeared a long time ago,'' Mr. Moynihan said today.
He also cited a statement over the weekend by the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who said in a television interview that if the proposal was accepted in the Senate, it would also get a vote on the House floor.
In the meantime, Mr. Hollings wants to press the case in the Senate Budget Committee. The measure the panel will be drafting this week is a fiscal blueprint that sets overall spending, revenue and deficit levels for the fiscal year that starts on Oct. 1.
Mr. Hollings wants the revenue figure to reflect what would amount to a $36 billion tax cut by rolling back the increase in Social Security payroll taxes that is scheduled to take effect Jan. 1. But to do that, he will also be asking his colleagues on the budget committee to remove the trust funds from the calculation of the budget deficit and to vote for a 1991 budget that leaves the deficit at a whopping $300 billion.
In an effort to reduce the huge budget deficit, Mr. Hollings plans to put before the panel a variety of other proposals to raise taxes. These include a 5 percent value-added tax on goods and services, a 10 percent oil import fee and an increase in the top income tax rate to 33 percent for the wealthiest taxpayers. A value-added tax is a sales tax paid on products and services at each stage of production or distribution and based on the value added in each stage.
Mr. Hollings acknowledged that he faced an uphill battle and that he might be outmaneuvered in committee with parliamentary tactics to preclude a straight up-or-down vote on the Social Security tax cut.
''They may try to block me,'' he said. ''But we will find a bill by God to cut Social Security taxes. There will be a vote.''

PUB-DATE: April 24, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 519 words

HEADLINE: Blame Japan? No. Save Ourselves

 BODY:
Japan saves six times more per person than the U.S. does and, as the accompanying graph shows, invests at a rate more than twice as high. Sound scary? Many Americans seem to think so.
There is reason to worry, but not about Japan. The two countries are not in a foot race; Japan's gain is not America's loss. In fact, when Japan grows, most Americans benefit. 
American living standards depend primarily on how much Americans, not Japanese, save and invest. On that score, there is cause for concern. Blaming another country for American economic ills only encourages regrettable public policy. The issue is not the leap in Japan's graph line; it's the sag in ours.
Japanese technological prowess provides American consumers with an array of high-quality, low-cost imports. And the steady influx of Japanese savings into American capital markets keeps borrowing costs low. That helps corporate investors and the Federal Treasury.
Particular industries suffer. Detroit auto workers know that. But their specific loss has been more than offset by the general gains from the creation of other American jobs. In fact, U.S. unemployment rates remain low despite the huge trade deficits with Japan.
What's lost in the preoccupation with rival savings and investment rates is a clear view of the U.S. economy. American living standards, correctly measured, dwarf those of any other major country, including Japan. And productivity remains high. Even if Japan were to maintain its current rapid rate of growth, which is implausible, it would still take from 30 to 200 years to catch up to U.S. levels of per capita output. And catching up would not cost Americans one dime.
Meanwhile, America faces formidable social problems - poverty, homelessness, crumbling infrastructure, crime and drugs. The foremost long-term economic problem is the savings rate, low and falling. So far, domestic investment, a primary determinant of future living standards, has declined only gradually because foreign savers have picked up the slack. But there is no guarantee that this good fortune will continue.
All of these problems are home-grown and fully within the nation's power to control.
Japan's success did not cause them and Japan's economic retreat would not solve them.
There is one Japanese practice that might threaten U.S. prosperity. Technological achievement may increasingly depend on which country invests first in high-tech industries. Many observers believe that the Japanese system is superior at targeting such investment.
Even if they are right, the threat has little to do with overall rates of investment in either country. The U.S. may have to find new ways to target assistance to venture capitalists and high-tech industries. There are substantial arguments to be heard about such targeting, and about the risk of further entangling politics and economics. These issues warrant serious Congressional debate.
Meanwhile, to begrudge the Japanese their success reflects either confusion or envy. For America to prosper, what's needed is not for the Japanese to do less but for Americans to do more.

HEADLINE: Finally, End Home Pork

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins will speak for more than New York City today when he appears before a Congressional committee to oppose the completion of a new naval base on Staten Island. The nation's defense needs have changed radically since the Navy proposed an elaborate system of home ports years ago. That system no longer makes strategic or economic sense, in New York or anywhere else. 
In the early 1980's, Navy Secretary John Lehman invented home porting - a costly plan for dispersing the fleet to every Congressional district with a port. Even then, that idea, which critics called ''port barreling,'' was questionable on military grounds. In New York, however, the main criticism arose from ill-founded fears about accidents involving nuclear warheads. Mayor Dinkins still grounds his opposition on that dubious premise. There are better reasons. As long as the Government concluded that the bases were needed for national security, every local community had a responsibility to share the burden. If a community would benefit economically, so much the better. Since then, the dramatic thaw in East-West relations promises cuts, not increases, in defense spending. Cutting has already begun.
If the Navy is likely to shrink, it's hard indeed to argue that 13 new home ports are needed to reduce crowding at existing facilities. The argument that dispersing the ships would reduce vulnerability to military attack seems equally weak given the growing implausibility of a surprise Soviet attack.
The Navy and Congress are now reviewing the whole program and some of the home ports, at least, are likely to go. Logic suggests that the Staten Island base should be among the first. The cost of living is higher in New York than in most other home port sites. Further, most members of New York's Congressional delegation, including Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, have joined Mr. Dinkins in opposition.
Meanwhile, it's also clear that the economic benefits of the home port won't be nearly as large as once thought. The Navy has decided to mothball the Iowa, with 1,500 crew members, the battleship originally scheduled for Staten Island, along with six other ships. The replacements would be the Normandy, a cruiser with a crew of 360, and perhaps five other ships. Guy Molinari, the Borough President, still argues that losing the port would cost Staten Island millions but that's far from certain.
So far, the Navy has spent $174 million of a projected $198 million for construction of the Staten Island port. But that's no reason to finish, or to spend millions upon millions in annual operating costs on a facility that defends nothing - and offends so many.

HEADLINE: Middletown Has Changed Since the 50's, Mostly for the Better

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We, as Mayor of Middletown, Conn., and president of Wesleyan University, join to express our consternation over the egregious misimpression created in your April 2 article about both the town and the university.
The article, however well crafted, was neither factual nor reliable. And, although it may seem naive to say, it was not fair. But ''not fair'' needs to be stated in this case, where the quality of life and of education have been so critically impugned by the country's leading newspaper. 
Wesleyan is a small university (2,700 students) known for research and teaching in the liberal arts and sciences. It has also earned its reputation for tolerating the responsible expression of individuals and for the diversity of its student body. There is no stereotypical Wesleyan student; there is a crewcut for every ponytail, whatever inference one might choose to draw from that. But tolerance of protest is not synonymous with license, liberal not synonymous with libertine. Neither implies approval of illegal activities. Our record, rather than our bad press, proves that to be the case. The notion that Wesleyan has an outlaw image is an affront we vigorously protest.
Like other such cities in the United States, Middletown has changed greatly since the 1950's, mostly for the better. True, we share the problems of all small cities in the country, but we have also demonstrated our solutions. We have a better racial balance in our schools and better relations in our neighborhoods; smaller classes and better-paid teachers; a new courthouse complex in the works, and a lively economy, with more jobs and more industries, literally topped not long ago by Middletown's first (if modest by New York City standards) skyscraper. Our Main Street is busy with shoppers and so far has survived the malling of America.
The city and the Wesleyan community have combined efforts to staff, equip and run a soup kitchen and shelter. We are working to improve the delivery of its service.
Hundreds of students volunteer community service through various agencies. Many more support fund raisers for multiple sclerosis, the March of Dimes and the Red Cross. They are caring and committed, concerned with social problems and willing to make a difference.
Your reporter apparently popped into town with his story written. He popped back out with a few quotations, leaving some hard feelings in an otherwise very welcoming community.
 
PAUL GIONFRIDDO
WILLIAM M. CHACE
Middletown, Conn., April 6, 1990

HEADLINE: Filming Puts Bronx Vanities Out of Joint

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
The Bronx knew there was something funny about the upcoming film ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' when rain soaked the county courthouse yesterday from a crystalline sky.
''How is it going to be raining on a sunny day when there's no clouds?'' asked Abraham Rivero, a 15-year-old Bronx native, shrugging off the huge sprinklers affixed to two 150-foot cranes on either side of the white-granite cube known as the Mario Merola Building.
Behind Mr. Rivero's skepticism about the special effects, it seemed, lurked the unease of an entire borough over how it might be portrayed.
Few in the crowds that gathered to watch Tom Hanks, Bruce Willis and the other actors run around the courthouse location for the director, Brian DePalma, said they had read Tom Wolfe's book. 
 
Criminals and Victims
But many seemed to suspect that the story of a Wall Street bond trader's downfall and redemption cast the State Supreme Court of Bronx County as a lonely island of justice in a teeming sea of criminals and their victims.
And the Bronx shouted its objections.
''If they don't really know what's happening here in the Bronx, they shouldn't come here and talk about it,'' said Felipe Mercado, 36, who suggested that a movie might better be made about his reformed street gang.
Mr. Mercado, who wore a blue ''Bud Lite'' bandana over his long black hair and a black ''Wild Thing'' T-shirt over the many tattoos he said he had gathered in prison, listened silently to another onlooker's brief summary of the ''Bonfire'' plot. Then, he concluded, ''They look at us like we're low lifes.'' With their more ''serious'' gang days over, Mr. Mercado said he and his once rough-and-tumble friends now work to keep their children in school and out of trouble. One year, he said, they even put together a Little League baseball team.
Nearby, a 31-year-old lawyer, who asked to be identified only as a black woman, said Mr. Wolfe's book contributed to a misperception of the Bronx as a ''cesspool'' filled with criminals who live in housing projects.
''It's certainly written from a non-resident-of-the-Bronx-white-man's perspective.''
As well as Mr. Wolfe's novel became known at the end of the decade it chronicled, Warner Brothers, which is producing the movie, did its best to keep the filming under wraps.
 
'Unobtrusive' Is the Goal
Press queries went unanswered. Actors seeking work as extras had to promise not to disclose information about the film. And the Lou Gehrig Plaza parking lot was flushed of its normal complement of lawyers' cars, to better keep gawkers across the street.
''We just want to keep it as quiet and unobtrusive as possible,'' said Robert Harris, who nonetheless had the title of production publicist.
Despite the intense security measures, Mr. Harris admitted, ''in practical terms, we are hiding an elephant in Times Square.''
Mr. DePalma's cameras had no sooner begun to roll when the traffic began to gag at the intersection of East 161st Street and Walton Avenue. Amid the hubbub, the police reported a runaway van whose driver was thought to have fired shots. No one was injured.
 
'Losing All My Business'
And while officials supportive of the filming trumpeted its economic benefits, not everyone in the neighborhood was so flush.
''I'm losing all my business,'' lamented Derrick Phipps, 35, who said he normally earns more than $100 a day feeding quarters into meters for busy lawyers. ''If you lose them for a day, they may find a garage and they may stay there forever.''
The State Supreme Court's administrative judge in the Bronx, Burton B. Roberts, dismissed such grumbling out of hand. ''The parking is taken care of,'' he said. ''It's not interfering with the court. We're not losing anything.''
In an interview, Justice Roberts made no mention of a memorandum from Mayor David N. Dinkins asking city officials to assist movie and television producers wanting to film in the city, whether or not the officials cared for the scripts. But on a wall of photographs in the judge's chamber hung a framed shot of him next to a gaunt man in a white suit and high-necked collar, his ''good friend,'' Mr. Wolfe.
The novel ''Bonfire'' was dedicated to Justice Roberts. He also inspired one of its main characters, Judge Myron Kovitsky, a feisty, somewhat bizarre tryant of the bench who at one point spits on a van full of prisoners to silence their heckling.
''It's a good book and I hope it'll be a good movie,'' he said.
 
Casting at Issue
Others questioned Mr. DePalma's casting, including the choice of Morgan Freeman, the black actor, to play the balding Jewish judge of the novel, and of Tom Hanks to play Sherman McCoy, the bond trader who plunges to the Bronx from glorious perches atop Wall Street and Park Avenue.
''Tom Hanks is not a Master of the Universe,'' sniffed John V. Barbieri, a 29-year-old lawyer, referring to the way McCoy thinks of himself.
About Mr. Willis, who will play the boozy journalist who helps bring McCoy down, a different sort of fan concern seemed to prevail. ''Yo, Bruce,'' one man shouted several times. ''What's up?''
But most of the questions around the courthouse concentrated on whether the building and its environs were really anything like those of Mr. Wolfe's - and perhaps the movie's -creation.
 
'Never Been Mugged'
''It's O.K.,'' said Kern Baptiste, 34, who said he had recently been released from jail after serving 18 months. ''I've been arrested eight times, for marijuana, coke, and this was the first time I've had to do time.''
Judy Gonzalez, 36, who works in the courthouse's microfilm department, boasted, ''I've worked here 10 years and I've never been mugged.''
Willie Watson, 41, a maintenance man at the home for the elderly that occupies the old Concourse Plaza Hotel across the street, said he was disappointed with the scenes being filmed, but not exactly because of what they said about the Bronx.
''I expected more action,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Testing Professor: A Big Developer Sues a Consultant

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
Robert W. Lake, a professor at Rutgers, is nationally known for conducting research surveys. ''If money were my goal, I could do focus groups for J. Walter Thompson,'' he said. ''I could do survey groups about cat food or toilet tissue and get paid tons. I could do social-impact statements for big developers.''
Instead, he uses his training to study social issues he cares about, like patterns of racial segregation or inequities in the siting of toxic dumps. Occasionally he has been hired as an expert for groups like Westpride, which opposes Donald J. Trump's huge project planned for the West Side of Manhattan. Professor Lake said, ''If I did the impact study for Trump instead of Westpride, I would have got $150,000 instead of $1,500.'' 
As a result, Professor Lake drives a 1984 Honda with 125,000 miles and a dented fender. His 1981 book, ''The New Suburbanites: Race and Housing in the Suburbs,'' received good reviews. It sold 2,500 copies, netting him $1,000.
It is his choice. He was raised by Quaker parents and was touched by the 1960's. His peers understand his worth. John Kain, chairman of the economics department at Harvard, said, ''No question he's an able researcher on questions of racial segregation.'' A fair-housing expert for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Dr. John Goering, said, ''It would indeed be frivolous to question Lake's qualifications.''
But that is what has been going on in court for 15 months, and the end is not near.
The Housing Coalition of Middlesex County, a group that fights housing bias, felt it had a strong case against the Woodbridge Terrace apartments. A black man had been unsuccessful in his effort to rent at Woodbridge Terrace.
The coalition sent in teams of white and black testers. Whites reported having been told that there were vacancies. Blacks visiting the same day reported no vacancies. In March 1987 a Federal suit was filed against the landlord.
 
The coalition hired
Professor Lake to supervise a telephone survey of the complex to see if there was other evidence of racial steering. It was about three weeks' work; he was paid $500. The results are very technical, but seemed to indicate steering.
In December 1988, Judge Harold A. Ackerman of Federal District Court in Newark felt that the violation of the Fair Housing Act was so clear that he issued a summary judgment against the landlords, Sam and Arie Halpern; Joseph and Harry Wilf, in two tester cases. Other allegations will be resolved at trial. In January 1989 the landlords sued Professor Lake for defaming them. They cited the lead-in Professor Lake wrote for the survey: ''Hi! I'm (first and last name) from the Housing Coalition of Middlesex County. The Housing Coalition is looking into a matter of housing discrimination, and we're doing a survey of households in a few selected developments in Middlesex County.'' The suit said that ''was designed to hold Woodbridge Terrace in contmept, hatred, ridicule, aversion or disgrace.''
Professor Lake felt the suit was frivolous and meant to bully him, but he needed help. Rutgers refused, saying the $500 fee he received made it his personal business. The faculty union put him in touch with a lawyer who said the case was such an easy victory that it would cost $10,000. Just the American Civil Liberties Union agreed to provide a lawyer, Corinne Mullen, pro bono. What surprised Ms. Mullen was how quiet Professor Lake seemed for someone accused of defaming a big apartment complex. ''He's this typical reserved academician,'' she said.
In September, Judge Ackerman dismissed the suit. The landlords have appealed.
Such suits against advocates and their experts have become so common that George Pring, a law professor at the University of Denver, specializes in them. He said 90 percent were dismissed. Of the ultimate outcome of Professor Lake's case, Professor Pring said: ''It's over. He's won.'' He said that in studying hundreds of cases he had never seen one that was dismissed but later won on appeal. ''But this doesn't mean it's through,'' Professor Pring added. ''It may still have 12 to 18 months to run on appeal. Victory lies in abusing the court process to gain time. It pressures activists to fritter away resources, chills their activism, dries up support.''
Professor Lake said: ''This is an enormous distraction. It goes on and on.'' He says it had robbed him of crucial writing time. If he is to be promoted from associate to full professor, he needs to publish more. He is 45 years old and would like the prestige of full professorship, plus the extra $10,000 a year.
A lawyer for the landlords, Allyn Lite, said, ''There is nothing frivolous about the suit.'' Karin Haber, who is handling their appeal, said: ''Harassment? No way. Experts need to be held accountable for the damage they do.''

HEADLINE: Winfield Revitalized On Yankee Road Trip

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ

 BODY:
It was still morning in Texas, still quietly empty in the visitors' clubhouse at Arlington Stadium. There were hours to go before the game would be played that day, but Dave Winfield was already dressed, and he was in a contemplative mood.
It may have been the music that played through his headphones. Barely a half day after belting two home runs against the Texas Rangers, he was back in front of his locker, listening to jazz. 
Winfield has played the game for 16 seasons and appeared in more than 2,000 games, but he still finds pleasure in every moment, from the pregame rituals to the game itself. He has yet to tire of it.
There had been questions about his comeback with the Yankees, but the 38-year-old outfielder may have put them to rest on the recent six-game trip.
 
Five Consecutive Losses
The swing was tortuous for the Yanks, who are burdened by a five-game losing streak as the Seattle Mariners arrive at the Stadium tonight, but Winfield thrived, hitting two home runs off Charlie Hough, adding two more hits Sunday and sending his batting average to .333, second only to Don Mattingly among the regulars on the team.
More than that, perhaps, he has come to realize again how much he still enjoys performing.
''It's how you approach the game,'' he said. ''You might see a guy come to the ball park and hear him complain about the travel and the schedule, and that seems to be the first thing to go. I still enjoy the camaraderie, the challenges, which you don't get in everyday life. When you start losing that, everything else goes with it.''
 
Return to Form
But in the short span of time he has been back, Winfield has appeared enthusiastic again. He runs hard on routine grounders, is slowly reacquainting himself with playing left field and has apparently located the swing that left him 1 for 29 in spring training and had raised doubts.
He explains away his unsightly training camp by saying: ''Mentally, I don't put everything into it. I'm not going to exhaust myself down there. I know how to focus my spring.''
But clearly, after missing a year following back surgery, it caused questions - although none of them came from Winfield.
''I'd planned on having a month of spring training, and I had to rush everything,'' he said. ''I tried to push hard, but it's not my style to do well down there. When the season comes, I lock in.''
He does it this way: ''Every at bat, I take very seriously. After a lot of years, I'm like a gunslinger, and these young kids think, 'If I can get him, I can build a reputation.' Maybe I'm just putting it in that category, but it helps me to think of it that way.''
If there was concern it did not come from Bucky Dent, the Yankees' manager, who allowed Winfield to work at his own deliberate pace in the spring.
 
'Quality Athlete'
''He's a quality athlete,'' Dent said. ''He plays with great intensity, he plays the game hard. Spring training is different from the season. When the lights come on, it's like you're playing for real.''
With his start, Winfield has allowed himself the small pleasure of thinking ahead. He can play five more years, he said, maybe more. He will eventually try his hand at first base to prolong his career. But he isn't sure exactly how long he will go.
''It's like an economist. Who the heck knows?'' he said. ''That's why they quit using those guys. I think I'd like to go that long.''
And he says that he has gotten better with age. The last season he played, 1988, he had one of his best overall seasons: a .322 average, 180 hits, 25 home runs and 107 runs batted in. His two homers Saturday gave him 205 as a Yankee, moving him past Roger Maris and into seventh place on the team's career list.
 
Consistent Player
''They made me different than they made other people,'' Winfield said. ''I've had my best years in my 30's. You hear people say, 'I wish I knew then what I know now.' Well, I've learned things every year that have helped make me consistent. Every year, every game, you never take things for granted.''
He knows that there are those in the organization, specifically the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, who would revel in his failure this season, his 10th and probably last with the Yankees. He simply says, ''I won't do that.''
But neither will he shout emphatically that he is back all the way. It is only the beginning of the season.
''If I'm not back now, I'm close,'' he said. ''If I'm hitting .310 or .320 at the break, I'll tell you.''

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Johnson Collection of Sacred Art in Warsaw

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
In Poland, where economic strains have forced cultural organizations like the National Museum in Warsaw to reduce telephone service for staff members, the exhibition entitled ''Opus Sacrum'' is singularly opulent. It is also an inspired event.
The show, which has just opened here, puts on view for the first time anywhere a large assortment of paintings, drawings and decorative objects belonging to Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the art-history student who left Poland with $200 in 1969 and who now possesses a fortune estimated at roughly $300 million, inherited from her husband, J. Seward Johnson Sr., the son of the founder of the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical company, who died in 1983. Mrs. Johnson has spent millions of dollars over the last 18 years amassing at her home in Princeton, N.J., one of the most talked-about Old Master paintings collections in the world.
At a time when important private collectors of Old Masters are thought to have virtually died out with the Fricks and Morgans, Mrs. Johnson has accumulated drawings by Raphael and Sandro Botticelli, and paintings by artists like Peter Paul Rubens, Andrea Mantegna and Giovanni Bellini. This exhibition consists of roughly 80 religious works from her extensive holdings. Travel plans for the show have not yet been set. ''Opus Profanum,'' an exhibition of her secular art, is to be presented in Warsaw in about two years. 
Both exhibitions are gifts to her former countrymen from Mrs. Johnson, who will not only pay for the events but will also donate money from the sales of the catalogues to a fund for, among other things, the preservation of monuments in Cracow. (The paintings and other works in the exhibitions will not be donated to Poland; they are destined for a private museum in Princeton that Mrs. Johnson is planning to build, she said.) Mrs. Johnson began to organize ''Opus Sacrum'' about two years ago, long before her proposals last spring to buy the Lenin Shipyard at Gdansk. But clearly, after losing face with many people in Poland in January, when her shipyard plan fell through, Mrs. Johnson is hoping ''Opus Sacrum'' will help to restore her tarnished image. She has apparently spared no expense in making it a lavish occasion. The show is presented, through July 31, in the Princes Apartments at the Royal Castle, which have been theatrically reconceived by the exhibition's designer, Franco Zeffirelli. Where it might have been better to let the paintings and drawings speak for themselves, he has installed spotlights, thick curtains, brocade velvet wall coverings, carpets and, in the most obvious gesture of all, constructed vestibules that are like tiny chapels in which a few works are displayed as altars.
Yet the exhibition cannot be dismissed simply as a public relations gesture or as a flourish of capitalist ostentation in this poor country, which has begun its difficult conversion to a free market system. ''Opus Sacrum'' is also an event of genuine artistic and symbolic significance.
By focusing on religious works, Mrs. Johnson has paid homage to the central role that the Roman Catholic Church played during the late 1970's and 80's in dismantling Poland's Communist regime. She has made a similar if more subtle point with her choice of the Royal Castle, the home during the 18th century of the last Polish kings. This was the one building in Warsaw's so-called old town that the Communists refused to rebuild after World War II; only to ease mounting public opposition to the Government did they reluctantly agree, in 1970, to its reconstruction. Since then, the castle has stood as one of Poland's leading emblems of anti-Communism.
And while the show's overblown title and decor may confuse excess with elegance, this is not to detract from the quality of the collection on view. For the dozens of prominent art historians, dealers, curators and collectors who converged on Warsaw from across Europe and the United States to attend the lavish opening, ''Opus Sacrum'' is an opportunity finally to scrutinize what has come to be regarded as one of the two or three premier Old Master paintings collections put together in the last quarter-century, and more specifically, to see important and recently discovered works attributed to artists like Caravaggio and Gentile da Fabriano, which have not previously been on public view.
The display is even more opportune for Poles, who have had few chances during the last half-century to see Renaissance and Baroque paintings of any quality, aside from works in Polish collections, and who may not have many similar chances in the near future. Traveling exhibitions from the West have been painfully rare. With the current Polish Government's economic ''shock therapy'' program, there is no money to cover the insurance and other costs of bringing such events here.
Under almost any circumstances, however, a show that included works like Mantegna's ''Descent Into Limbo'' would be notable. The same could be said of an exhibition that included Orazio Gentileschi's sweet and intimate ''Madonna and Child,'' or Raphael's study for the head and hand of an apostle, both of which are here.
It hardly matters whether ''The Dead Christ Held by an Angel'' is truly from the hands of Giorgione and Titian, as is contended in the catalogue for ''Opus Sacrum.'' This is a work of surpassing beauty and concentration of expression, whoever painted it. Nor does questioning the attribution to Leonardo da Vinci of two drapery studies cast into doubt the suavity of these drawings. By the same token, experts in Italian art may debate the participation of Caravaggio in the painting of ''St. Francis in Ecstasy,'' but the fact remains that this is a deeply moving image.
Even, in other words, with works over which scholars may debate attribution, Mrs. Johnson and her advisers (for years, Harry Bailey and Adrian Ward-Jackson, and most recently Jozef Grabski, a Viennese publisher, who also helped prepare the catalogue) have bought well. Which is not to say Mrs. Johnson has bought flawlessly. Fra Angelico's ''Madonna and Child (Madonna With the Grapes),'' or Filippino Lippi's ''Madonna and Child with Two Angels,'' for example, are among Mrs. Johnson's less persuasive acquisitions. Yet for almost every disappointing work there is a memorable painting like Gentile da Fabriano's ''Annunciation'' or Carlo Saraceni's ''Martyrdom of St. Cecilia,'' or a sculpture like Alessandro Algardi's gilt bronze ''Flagellation'' group.
Moreover, Mrs. Johnson has bought objects that are now typically considered interesting only to museums. Few other private collectors would choose to live with works on the scale and of the religious intensity of paintings like the ''Martyrdom of St. Bartholomew,'' attributed to Jusepe Ribera but possibly by Luca Giordano, or Francisco de Zurbaran's ''Immaculate Conception.'' Mrs. Johnson has sought out such images. She favors big and bold objects. And she has not limited herself to one period or school. ''Opus Sacrum'' starts chronologically with a panel by Corso di Buono from the late 13th century and ends with a canvas by Paul Gauguin from the turn of the 20th that is a Tahitian variation on the theme of the Madonna and Child.
''We live in an aggressively secular world, and the taste of the few people who buy Old Masters seriously reflects this fact,'' the art historian John Pope-Hennessy states in his introduction to the show's catalogue. ''Paintings of religious subjects are, by and large, viewed with some embarrassment,'' he writes. ''What gives this collection so individual a quality is not just tolerance of great religious images but reponsiveness to the message they convey.''
''Opus Sacrum'' honors the constancy of religious life in Poland. It is also a wonderful gift to a country that is in the process of wrenching and heroic change.

HEADLINE: Goldsmith Ends Bid For B.A.T.

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 23

 BODY:
Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, ended his nine-month battle to acquire B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. today - and failed to earn a place in the history books for pulling off one of the biggest takeovers ever.
The decision made it seem less likely that giant American-style takeovers financed largely with debt would spread to Europe, as many had predicted when the group led by Sir James announced its first bid of $21 billion in securities last July.
Hoylake Investments' decision to give up on B.A.T. came two weeks after the California Department of Insurance dealt Hoylake, the investor group led by Sir James, a heavy blow. It turned down Hoylake's proposed $4.5 billion sale of Farmers, B.A.T.'s American insurance subsidiary, to Axa-Midi Assurances, the French insurer. Eight other states had not yet ruled on the proposal. 
 
B.A.T.'s Progress a Factor
That setback and B.A.T.'s progress in pacifying shareholders caused Hoylake to call it quits, an official in the Hoylake camp said in an interview tonight. B.A.T. has bought back stock, increased its dividend, is selling its American retailing empire and is spinning off other companies.
The reason for giving up was ''the time, cost and uncertainty of going through the U.S. regulatory hoops, combined with the fact that the board of B.A.T. was doing three-quarters of what we said they should do,'' the official said, adding, ''The bird would have been nearly carved.''
Hoylake also advocated splitting up B.A.T.'s financial services and tobacco businesses, which B.A.T. plans to keep.
In a statement, Hoylake said it ''will not renew its offer for B.A.T.'' and added that ''the directors of Hoylake wish B.A.T. and its unbundled offspring great success within their new structures.''
 
Axa-Midi Quest Ends
Axa-Midi also said it would end its quest for Farmers, but Claude Bebear, Axa's chairman, said his company had not given up its ambitions to expand in the United States. ''While we understand the Hoylake board's decision to cease its bid for B.A.T., we are naturally disappointed,'' he said in a statement.
Mr. Bebear again repeated his optimism that Axa could have addressed regulators' concern that its original plan to borrow the entire purchase price would have endangered Farmers. He said Axa had been prepared to submit a new bid that included up to $2 billion in cash.
Patrick Sheehy, B.A.T.'s chairman, said in a statement that he was ''pleased that Hoylake and Axa-Midi have finally abandoned their bid,'' so ''we can now devote our full attention to running the continuing group.'' He also vowed to continue with the plans to enhance shareholder value that were approved in October.
 
Marshall Field Deal
B.A.T. announced last Thursday an agreement to sell its Marshall Field department stores to the Dayton Hudson Corporation for $1.04 billion. It previously sold the John Breuner Company, a furniture retail and rental chain based in California, for $107.5 million. Argos, its European catalogue showroom retailer, began trading as a separate company earlier this month. And the stock of Wiggins Teape Appleton, its specialty paper business, is scheduled to begin trading as a separate company in early June.
That leaves it with two American retail chains: Saks Fifth Avenue, which analysts believe will sell for as much as $1.3 billion, and J. B. Ivey, a specialty retail chain in the Southeast. B.A.T. said it hoped to complete those sales by the end of June.
B.A.T. has also repurchased 67 million of its shares for a total of 540 million ($883 million). It said last year that it planned to repurchase as much as 10 percent, or about 150 million, of its shares.
 
B.A.T. Receipts Dip
The end of the B.A.T. takeover fight came after the London Stock Exchange had closed. In trading on the American Stock Exchange, the price of B.A.T.'s American depository receipts closed at $11.6875, down 43.75 cents.
Analysts estimated that the takeover battle cost both sides a total of at least $150 million.
Both Hoylake and Axa-Midi insisted tonight that they had incurred only small losses in the takeover bid. A spokesman said Hoylake's loss would be less than 10 million ($16 million), and a spokesman for Axa said its losses would be ''less than Hoylake's.'' Costs were 30 million to 40 million ($49.1 million to $65.4 million), the Hoylake official said, but both Hoylake and Axa said their costs had been largely offset by the dividends and the profits they expect to reap from the B.A.T. stock they own. Hoylake said it owns 19.4 million shares, and paid 6 to 6.50 each for them. The Axa spokesman did not know how many B.A.T. shares the insurer has.
B.A.T. has said that it spent 56 million (about $90 million) through the end of last year defending itself.
 
Sir James's Next Target
Analysts speculated tonight that Sir James might now go after Ranks Hovis McDougall P.L.C. Almost 30 percent of the big British food concern is owned by Sunningdale Holdings, a company controlled by Sir James and his allies, who include Jacob Rothschild, the British financier, and Kerry Packer, the Australian business executive.
The Anglo Group P.L.C., a company controlled by Sir James and Mr. Rothschild, has said it intends to invest in undervalued British companies. An Anglo director who asked not to be named repeated that intention tonight. ''Anglo remains in position and will continue to do what we said it would do,'' he said.
With the end of the fight for B.A.T., it seemed tonight that giant leveraged buyouts were not ready to take root in Europe.
 
Buyouts on the Wane in Britain
That likelihood was already fading, given problems in Britain, where leveraged buyouts have achieved the greatest acceptance in Europe. Most of the buyouts completed to date have been relatively small. And two of the larger buyouts that American investment banks helped to orchestrate in Britain - that of Magnet, a furniture retailer and building supplier, and Gateway, the supermarket chain -have run into some difficulty.
In addition, Britain's economic growth has slowed to a near-standstill and interest rates have soared, posing big obstacles to leveraged deals.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-Treasury Official To New England Bank

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
The Bank of New England Corporation, the troubled banking company operating under Government supervision while it tries to regain profitability, yesterday announced the appointment of R. T. McNamar, a former Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, as vice chairman.
While at the Treasury Department from 1982 to 1984, Mr. McNamar, known as Tim, was involved in some of the decade's most spectacular financial crises. He was the Treasury's principal negotiator during the collapse of the Continential Illinois Bank and Trust Company and in talks to provide an emergency $1.1 billion in loans to Mexico to prevent its banks from closing. 
At the Bank of New England, which had a loss of $1.1 billion last year, Mr. McNamar, 51 years old, said he expected to spend most of his time working with regulators and strengthening the bank's capital position.
Although he has not lived in New England since he earned an M.B.A. degree from Dartmouth College in 1965, Mr. McNamar is familiar with the economic and financial turmoil in New England. Last year, he was part of an investor group that tried to buy the First Constitution Financial Corporation in New Haven, a holding company for a savings and loan association. The deal was abandoned, he said, as falling prices for real estate prevented the company and buyers from agreeing on terms.
''I got a pretty good look last year of what is going on up here,'' Mr. McNamar said. ''I don't think this real estate overhang and economic slump will last forever.
''If we at the Bank of New England do the right things in the next months, and if we have enough time from regulators and can show we are making progress, this is a tremendous opportunity to turn around a company.''
The Bank of New England, which Mr. McNamar described as ''one of the best regional banking franchises in the country,'' has a network of more than 400 branch offices in four states, concentrated in Massachusetts and Connecticut.
But as it acquired other banks to create the regional network, the company was slow to cut costs by eliminating duplicated resources and did not develop strict lending policies that might have protected it against the many real estate loans it made in the late 1980's, which have since turned sour.
The agreements that Bank of New England and its subsidiary banks have signed with regulators require the company to raise more capital, shrink its size and develop better lending policies.
Before moving to Boston, Mr. McNamar was a managing director at Conover & McNamar, a merchant banking firm in Los Angeles. Before his stint at the Treasury, he was an executive director of the Federal Trade Commission and a management consultant at McKinsey & Company.
He and his wife, Karen, will move to Boston, but are still looking for a house. For relaxation and exercise, Mr. McNamar said he is a regular jogger. The move to Boston from Los Angles will be the catalyst, he said, ''to become a proficient cross-country skier.''

HEADLINE: Making German Twain Meet Is Difficult

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Whenever people in one country do business with people in another, they have to exchange their currencies. When Americans shop in Italy, for example, there must be a rate of exchange that tells them how many lire they will get for each of their dollars.
Normally, this figure, known as the exchange rate, is set by free trading in foreign exchange markets around the world. 
But this commonplace process takes on fantastic proportions when the need arises to devise an exchange rate for the merging of two very different economies, as in the case of West Germany and East Germany. It is even more difficult when the value of one currency, the East German Ostmark, or ''east'' mark, is not generally known because by law it has not been allowed to freely trade in the foreign exchange markets.
 
Other Factors Influence the Evaluations
In the foreign exchange markets, the value of one currency to another is based, in part, on how many goods and services a dollar or franc or mark can command in another country. But other factors also enter into the evaluations of traders of what currencies are worth, including the economic outlook for one country versus another, taking into account their rates of growth, inflation rates, interest rates and political developments.
Exchange rates are changing all the time, as economic and political developments shift. For example, the West German decision on the exchange rate announced yesterday knocked down the value of the West German mark against the dollar.
In the case of West Germany and East Germany, the Governments have to make an artificial decision on an exchange rate to convert Ostmarks into West Germany's Deutsche marks because there is no free-market level to provide a figure.
Although there are some official exchange rates in East Germany, these do not reflect the value in the open market because the Ostmark has not been exchangeable outside the old Eastern bloc. The Ostmark is worth very little outside East Germany because it is not officially convertible into other currencies and because there is little confidence in the economy and economic policy behind it.
The official exchange rate for visitors from West Germany is currently three Ostmarks to one West German mark. This exchange is now made at a branch of the state-owned bank in East Germany. But on the flourishing black market, West Germans have been able to get 4.5 to 5 Ostmarks for one West German mark. An East German leaving the country could exchange Ostmarks in the state bank at home at official rates for the country being visited, or try to exchange the Ostmarks on a black market.
 
Political Reasons Outweighed Economic Ones
The one-to-one exchange rate for many transactions announced in Germany yesterday implies that the currencies are at parity, that is, of equal value. But this decision was made more for political than economic reasons. The one-for-one exchange rate is the most attractive for workers of the alternatives considered and is designed to help stop the flow of East Germans into West Germany.
Still the difference in the economic performance of the two countries is shown in the average salary in East Germany, even after the one-to-one exchange. In East Germany, it will be 1,200 marks a month compared with 3,000 in West Germany.

PERSON: FUERBRINGER, JONATHAN
